headline: Ariba, Bank of America Form Alliance
abstract: April 04, 2000

headline: Israeli High Court Orders Release of 8 Lebanese Prisoners
abstract: Israel's Supreme Court reverses itself, ruling that Israel is not justified in holding Lebanese detainees as bargaining chips for missing Israeli soldiers; court orders that 8 of 15 Lebanese detainees who have been imprisoned without charges for more than decade be released immediately; after court rules, Israeli prison authorities say they will release 13 of 15 detainees; two others, Mustafa al-Dirani and Sheik Abdel Karim Obeid, are high-ranking guerrilla leaders who are being held in secret location by army; Justice Min Yossi Beilin says government would try to retain them as security risks; Prime Min Ehud Barak expresses his opposition to prisoner release but says he would abide by court's ruling; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: I.M.F. to Consider Changes In Conditions Put on Loans  The International Monetary Fund, which has ordered developing nations to enact wrenching reforms as the price for emergency aid in recent years, is likely to curtail the demands it makes of clients who borrow money in the future, a senior fund official said.    Streamlining the conditions the I.M.F. imposes on borrowers is one of the changes Horst Kohler, the new managing director, is weighing as a panel he set up to study the agency's role finishes a draft report. [Page C2.]

headline: When Only a Code Warrior or XML Guru Will Do
abstract: History of exotic job titles in cyberspace industry discussed in light of current use of such titles to attract employees (M)

headline: Two-Way Radio Days
abstract: Andrew Greene letter on Apr 6 article cites benefits of using two-way radios

headline: Russia and Poland Seek to Heal Rift
abstract: Pres Vladimir Putin signals desire to improve Russia's relations with Poland, which were marked by public feuds earlier in year; influential Polish officials welcome overtures, but see more difficult times ahead; some Polish analysts say a new government is likely to take a softer line toward Moscow in any case (M)

headline: Printing Photos at Home
abstract: Letter by Craig Delsack responds to June 15 article on home-printed snapshops; says article did unfair comparison of printers

headline: Rambus Climbs Again as More Licensing Deals Are Seen
New South Korea Airport a Safety Challenge
abstract: SEOUL—  Congestion in the Air

headline: Parties Squabble Over Digital Signatures Bill
A Third Travel P.D.A.
abstract: Lynne Klinger letter on May 4 article cites her problems with Bell Atlantic's DSL service

headline: Fuller´s Dymaxion House to Be Rebuilt by Museum
abstract: NEWS WATCH: Fuller's Dymaxion House to Be Rebuilt by Museum

headline: Liquica Journal; East Timor's New Issue: Can It Forgive and Forget?
abstract: Former members of violent anti-independence militias are returning to Liquica and other towns in East Timor from their refuge in Indonesian West Timor to beg forgiveness from survivors; map; photo (M)

headline: The Paperless Newspaper
abstract: Letter by Michael Knatz responds to May 25 artricle on cyberspace news; says he has been reading most of his news for past few years online

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Yen rises on expectations Japan's economic growth is picking up, raising speculation Bank of Japan will lift interest rates; in New York, dollar settles at 105.69 yen, down from 107.69; graphs (S)

headline: VIBRANT JOB GROWTH IN FRANCE
abstract: French companies lifted number of jobs in economy by 1 percent, or 142,300 jobs, in first quarter with computers and telecommunications leading the way; growth is attributed to rapidly expanding economy, likely to show growth above 4 percent this year; in March, unemployment fell to 10 percent, its lowest in eight years (S)

headline: The Appeal: Internet Browser Is Seen as the Key
abstract: The Appeal: Internet Browser Is Seen as the Key

headline: Media Talk; Restoration Work on 'Antiques Roadshow'
abstract: WGBH-TV is pulling appraisals performed by George Juno and Russ Pritchard 3d from its Antiques Roadshow television programs in wake of disclosure that they got a friend to bring in antique that did not belong to him during show's first season in 1996; have pulled another segment, in which expert appraised costly helmet, in response to tip that helmet did not belong to woman who brought it in; Pritchard says he and Juno staged only one scene and did not mean to hurt show; photo (M)

headline: In Crippled Afghanistan, a Torturing Drought
abstract: Effects of unusually harsh drought are particularly hard on Afghanistan, which lacks functioning government to coordinate relief efforts; ruling Taliban, milita preoccupied with completing its conquest and enforcing its puritanical intepretation of Islam, has appealed to United Nations aid agencies, but is unpopular with international donors; map; photos (M)

headline: Raul Rettig, Head of Panel On Chile Killings, Dies at 90
abstract: Raul Rettig, who headed an official inquiry into political atrocities in Chile during the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, died on Sunday at his house in Santiago, Chile. He was 90.    Mr. Rettig, a lawyer, had been a senator, an ambassador and something of a swashbuckler before he became president of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, or simply the Rettig commission.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Microsoft in the Court of the Investor
abstract: Market Place column focuses on outlook for Microsoft following decision by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ordering breakup of company for violating antitrust laws; investors who believe in company with almost religious conviction face question of how well it can perform in future; are concerned that even though it could retain effective monopoly, it would be hamstrung by government oversight to extent that profit margins would eventually erode and that it would be less fromidable competitor; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Quarterly Earnings at Dillard's Decline 31%
abstract: Dillard's Inc reports net income fell to $46.2 million in fiscal first quarter ended Apr 29, down 31 percent from $66.9 million a year ago; says it will buy back up to $200 million of stock (M)

headline: A Tory's Populism Turns Tables on Blair
abstract: Interview with William Hague, Britain's increasingly popular Tory leader, who has led resurgence of once-depleted Tory Party has prime ministership within reach; he has thrown Labor government of Prime Min Tony Blair, blamed for country's social service shortfalls, on defensive; Blair's attempts to portray him as opportunist are proving unconvincing with public; photo (M)

headline: S.U.V. Suits Still Face Long Odds
abstract: Analysis: While Ford Motor Co recently acknowledged that sport utility vehicles can be hazardous to other motorists, law professors and plaintiff lawyers say it remains difficult to win lawsuits based on damages that sport utilities inflict in crashes; trial lawyers and automakers say that they are aware of only one lawsuit so far in which a car occupant has sued manufacturer of sport utility that hit her; that case, against Land Rover, was summarily dismissed in January by Superior Court judge in Los Angeles who concluded that automaker had no legal duty to consider what would happen to other vehicles and motorists struck by its products (M)

headline: In Quebec, French-First Policy Riles Small Sites
RANGER OIL GETS OFFER
abstract: Shareholders of Ranger Oil Ltd of Calgary have been offered 1.6 billion Canadian dollars (about $1.1 billion) in cash or stock by Petrobank Energy and Resources Ltd, Calgary; Ranger calls proposal inadequate and says it will seek better offers (S)

headline: Solitary Republican Senator Blocks Peacekeeping Funds
abstract: New Hampshire Republican Sen Judd Gregg has singlehandedly blocked US from paying $368 million owed to UN for four difficult peacekeeping missions; dispute that infuriates Clinton administration is latest skirmish in battle with Congress on using US power and money abroad in operations short of war; Gregg as chairman of Appropriations Subcommittee has stopped State Department from transferring money already approved by Congress for missions in Congo, East Timor, Kosovo and Sierra Leone; administration warns that delay hinders missions that are already frayed; Gregg, interviewed, objects most to Sierra Leone, saying he will not finance unethical 'barbaric' policy there; reference is to amnesty for rebels who have terrorized and mutilated civilians and held peacekeepers hostages; Gregg photo (M)

headline: Times Co. Names a President for Its Broadcast Group
abstract: Cynthia H Augustine, senior vice president for human resources at The New York Times Co, will succeed C Frank Roberts as president of the broadcast group; until he retires at end of the year, Roberts will become chairman of the broadcast group; Augustine will also retain her current title and responsibilities in human resources; photo (S)

headline: DEAL FOR RUSSIAN CIGARETTE MAKER
abstract: British concern Gallaher Group will buy Russian cigarette maker Liggett-Ducat for $390.5 million; deal gives Gallaher biggest share of market where estimated 260 billion cigarettes were smoked last year (S)

headline: Layoffs at J. D. Edwards
abstract: J D Edwards & Co to lay off 800 employees, 13 percent of work force (S)

headline: Fear of Failure? Back Up
abstract: Letter from Kenneth R Burns on his unsuccessful use of DOS Copy command to back up his files to CD

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN FUND IN AMERICAN DEAL
abstract: South Africa's Old Mutual PLC reaches agreement to acquire United Asset Management Corp, Boston-based fund manager, in deal valued at nearly $1.5 billion (S)

headline: CLINTON AND PUTIN UNABLE TO AGREE ON MISSILE BARRIER
abstract: Pres Clinton and Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin conclude two days of talks in Kremlin with mutual praise, but without narrowing differences over national missile defense system US wants to build; issue joint statement pledging to continue talks on further cuts in strategic nuclear weapons, calling ABM treaty cornerstone of global strategic security and urging experts from both sides to prepare joint report on how to tackle new threats to strategic stability; Putin insists he is willing to continue working on issue with next American president, if necessary; both countries agree to each destroy 34 metric tons of weapons-grade plutonium, enough to make tens of thousands of nuclear weapons; call for joint center in Moscow to share early warnings about missile launching that would be first permanent American-Russian military operation; atmosphere at summit described as correct and businesslike, though not necessarily warm; photo (M)

headline: Despite Yen, Half-Year Income Is Up 25% at Toyota
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp reports surprisingly strong financial results for the second half of its fiscal year, with earnings rising 25 percent to 205.1 billion yen ($1.9 billion), compared with earnings of 163.5 billion yen in same period year before; cost-cutting programs are factor in earnings gain; photo to Toyota president Fujio Cho (M)

headline: HOSTILE OFFER EXTENDED
abstract: Petrobank Energy and Resources Ltd, Canada, extends its hostile bid for Ranger Oil Ltd by two weeks, to June 19, and says it is exploring ways to improve the terms of its $664 million offer (S)

headline: American Histories: Chasing Dreams And Nightmares; WESLEY JESSEN, TAKEOVER TARGET, IN TALKS
abstract: Wesley Jessen VisionCare Inc, which has received hostile takeover offer from rival Bausch & Lomb Inc, says it is talking with undisclosed third party; Wesley Jessen says its agreement last month to buy Ocular Sciences Inc for about $386.2 million remains in effect (S)

headline: W.T.O. RULES AGAINST BRAZIL
abstract: In a blow to Brazil's booming aerospace industry, the World Trade Organization ruled that the government had failed to comply with an earlier decision by the trade body that called for ending subsidized interest rates for buyers of Embraer's 50- and 37-seat planes. The aircraft manufacturer stands to lose $3.7 billion in export financing. Brazil has 90 days to bring the interest rates up to market levels.   Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

headline: Dispute Could Warm U.S.-Cuba Relations
abstract: Experts say that in immediate sense, hostility in Cuban-American official relations is unlikely to be touched by Elian Gonzalez case; say that in longer term, dispute could encourage trends in American public opinion that favor more relaxed ties (M)

headline: Breaking The Mold At Tiffany
abstract: Linda Hanson, senior vice president for merchandising at Tiffany & Co, directed team of gemologists, designers and marketers in creation of a new Tiffany engagement ring, the Lucida, starting at $2,000; Lucida marks bold departure from trademark engagement ring Tiffany has been producing for 114 years; Hanson joined Tiffany in 1990; photo (M)

headline: What's That Noise on the Internet? The Sound of Alliances Being Forged
abstract: E-commerce partnerships and alliances involving Internet companies and companies doing business on Web are booming for cultural, practical and technical reasons; opportunity for publicity also plays role; consumer sites are among most aggressive in partnership efforts, under pressure to broaden products they offer; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Is Linking Illegal?
Two sturdy companies -- Juniper and Sycamore -- are setting their sights on Cisco.
abstract: Profiles of Juniper Networks and Sycamore Networks, which are among young companies seeking to succeed Cisco Systems as powerhouse of Internet communications equipment; Juniper leads in field of ultrahigh-capacity Internet switches; Sycamore leads in next generation of optical networking; drawing (M)

headline: EARTHSHELL TO SELL SHARES TO ACQUA WELLINGTON
abstract: EarthShell Corp, maker of new biodegradable sandwich container for McDonald's Corp, says Acqua Wellington North America Equities Fund Ltd has agreed to purchase $60 million in EarthShell's shares (S)

headline: 20 Kidnapped From Malaysian Resort Island
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  Six men armed with assault rifles and a rocket launcher stormed a tiny resort island off the eastern coast of Borneo and took 20 hostages, including a Malaysian police officer and 10 tourists from Europe and the Middle East, the police said Monday.

headline: EUROPEAN GROWTH
abstract: European Union reports expansion by 7/10 percent during first quarter 2000; exports surge 3.2 percent (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Percent           Yesterday   Day Ago   Year Ago       Prime rate   9.50   9.00   7.75        Discount rate   6.00   5.50   4.50        Federal funds   6.38   6.34   4.64        3-month T-bills   6.02   6.06   4.51        6-month T-bills   6.21   6.25   4.63        10-yr. T-infl.   4.19   4.19   3.84        10-yr. T-note   6.42   6.44   5.65        30-yr. headline: T-ONLINE PRICES ITS SHARES
abstract: German Internet portal T-Online International AG will price its shares at less-than-expected 26 euros to 32 euros in public offering; that would value service, unprofitable division of Deutsche Telekom AG, at as much as 38.4 billion euros ($36.3 billion); Deutsche Telekom shares fall as price means less money for T-Online to expand outside German-language market; graph (S)

headline: DUTCH RETAILER BUYS 51% OF ONLINE GROCER PEAPOD
abstract: Royal Ahold says it agreed to buy 51 percent of Peapod for $73 million (S)

headline: Attorneys General of Illinois and Ohio Dissent
abstract: Text of statement filed by Illinois and Ohio attorneys general explaining their differences with some of remedies proposed by other plaintiffs in Microsoft antitrust case (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar is little changed against the euro and the yen; in New York, euro settles at 95.30 cents, down from 95.31 cents on June 9; dollar trades at 106.75 yen, down from 106.83; graph; chart (S)

headline: Phnom Penh Journal; Pushed From the Land, and the Trees
abstract: Land disputes and land grabbing spreads across Cambodia as country emerges fitfully from three decades of mass killings and civil war; tens of thousands of landless farmers are in competition with business interests and military officers for former battlegrounds and minefields; result is new generation of dispossessed people in country where land ownership has been in dispute since overthrow in 1979 of brutal Khmer Rouge government, which had taken all the land for itself; photo; map (Phnom Penh Journal) (M)

headline: Texcoco Journal; The 'Slippery Slope' of Patenting Farmers' Crops
abstract: International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center, Texcoco, Mex, which has freely supplied plant breeders from around world with genetic material from its vast seed store for years, has surprised some supporters with plan to patent work traditionally made available to everyone; says move is defensive, to keep others from patenting its discoveries and thus keeping poor farmers from using them; map; photo (M)

headline: Calm Scene Isn't Really, Police Say
abstract: Canadian and American police locate 15-year-old who goes by computer name Mafiaboy, for moment North America's most notorious computer crime suspect, in Ile Bizard, Quebec; Canadian police have carted away computers that they say ninth-grader used to sabotage CNN.com on Feb 8; Yan Romanowski, lawyer hired to defend boy against charges of criminal mischief, comments; boy's father, John Calce, says he does not know anything about the computers; photo (M)

headline: L'OREAL AGREES TO ACQUIRE MATRIX FROM BRISTOL-MYERS
abstract: L'Oreal SA agrees to buy Matrix Essentials from Bristol-Myers Squibb Co for undisclosed price; L'Oreal will acquire Matrix through its New York-based Cosmair unit (S)

headline: Dispute Over Jewish Graves Draws Protesters to Prague
abstract: International Orthodox Jewish organizations renew their protests against planned construction of administrative building over remnants of 13th century Jewish cemetery in downtown Prague; fear is that construction would disturb medieval graves; Czech police have arrested at least dozen Orthodox Jewish rabbis from United States, England and Belgium who illegally entered construction site; rabbis insist they found destroyed graves and bone fragments on ground, charge denied by representatives of insurance company that owns site; dispute has opened rift between leaders of Prague's small Jewish community and foreign rabbis (M)

headline: GRANADA AND COMPASS TO MERGE
abstract: In an all-stock deal worth $8 billion, Granada Group and Compass Group agree to merge, allowing Granada to start spinning off its media unit this summer (S)

headline: Rights Gains Are Preserved At U.N. Forum On Women
abstract: Weeklong forum at United Nations meeting turns back efforts to reverse achievement of watershed conference held in Beijing in 1995, which articulated and affirmed what more than 180 nations could agree were universal rights of women (M)

headline: Germans Seek Foreign Labor For New Era Of Computers
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder recently said that Germany urgently needs new talent in its high-technology sector and should be prepared to give residency documents to brilliant Indians; remark reflects serious issue: underfunded, state-run German universities have been very slow to adapt their traditional curricula to reflect explosive growth of Internet-related industries; in all of Germany, there is just one newly created chair in e-commerce; as result, threr are estiamted 75,000 to 100,000 jobs vacant in booming Internet sector, with few Germans qualified to fill them; Vinod Kymar, political counselor at Indian Embassy in Berlin, says India's best software engineers are already in United States (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    ITALY: PREMIER LOOKING TO QUIT -- With Prime Minister Massimo d'Alema appearing intent on announcing his resignation to Parliament today after losing regional elections on Sunday, his shaken coalition was ponderering whom to propose to try to form a new center-left majority. If Parliament does not approve a candidate, President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi will either appoint a caretaker government or call elections, now likely to favor the big winner in the regional vote, former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, above, leader of the center-right.   Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: CAMPBELL SOUP CO., Camden, N.J., named Marty Thrasher, currently its president for North American soups and sauces, to the position of president for the North America unit.

headline: Rodniki Journal; Bloodsuckers of Old Are Poised for a Comeback
abstract: Some Russians still turn to blood-sucking leeches to cure their ailments; about 1.5 million leeches are bred annually at International Center for Medicinal Leeches in Rodniki, to be sent to pharmacies and doctors all over country to be used in treatment of everything from migraines to phlebitis; photos (L)

headline: Offshore Scanners
abstract: US-based companies are using workers from third-world countries to 'double key' book texts for computerization (S)l

headline: Mexican Election Spotlights Ailing School System
abstract: Presidential race in Mexico arouses genuine debate over education, with opposition candidates criticizing top-heavy bureaucracy and inequities of public schools; government contends that on average, Mexicans attend classes for eight years; Inter-American Development Bank figures show poorest 30 percent of students attend for just three years; Pres Ernesto Zedillo says 27 percent of budget already goes to education, but educators contend that little of that money reaches their schools; many schools are badly in need of repair, and ill equipped to educate children; experts on country's education system say extraordinary sums are frittered away by education bureaucrats; Mexican schools are controlled by federal Education Dept; photos; map (M)

headline: Kodak to Buy Stake in Online Photofinisher
abstract: Eastman-Kodak will buy stake in Snapfish.com, which provides free film developing and printing, storing and sharing of pictures on line; reaches accords with nine online photofinishers, including Snapfish, to use Kodak's laboratories and technicians to print photos; photofinishers will have links to Kodak's Web site to put thumbnail photos on Internet for customers to use when ordering prints (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANG, ANNA
abstract: LANG-Anna. Beloved mother of Justice Irving Lang. Beloved grandmother of Tamar and David Lang, and sister of Malke Badaines. Funeral will be held 11 AM, on Friday, April 14, at Shomrei Haddas, 3803 14th Ave., Boro Park, Brooklyn, 718-436-8700.

headline: A Socially Responsible Fund: Whose Conscience Is It, Anyway?
abstract: Patrick McGeenhan humorous comment on investing in 'socially responsible' mutual funds, pointing out that social responsibility is in the eye of beholder; notes his idea of socially responsible fund, the Enough Already fund, would be one that rules out shares of any company having anything to do with Donald Trump, Martha Stewart or Dick Clark, for example (M)

headline: For the hungry, gadget-loving motorist, a microwave oven in the glove compartment.
abstract: Daniel Perlman and Jane Katims patent microwave oven built into the area now used for glove compartments in most cars; Jay Walker, founder of Priceline.com, and two co-inventors patent system of offering fast-food diners a choice of fresh food or food that is a few minutes old, the point being to reduce waste; Arthur A Krause and Walter K Lim patent a breakfast cereal coated with powdered milk to which water can be added on camping trips or wherever there is no refrigeration for milk (M)

headline: TheStreet.com Threatens to Cancel Program in a Dispute With Fox
abstract: Decision by The Street.com to cancel its cable television program sets off dispute with Fox News Channel, cable channel, which contends TheStreet.com has no right to cancel it; controversy started when James J Cramer, co-founder of TheStreet.com went on cable program and plugged TheStreet.com's own stock; result was battle over ethics of stock promotion that may result in cancellation of program; TheStreet.com has agreed to keep producing the program for an undetermined period; Cramer, who is hedge fund manager as well as commentator for TheStreet.com, mentioned number of stocks on program in addition to TheStreet.com; Dave Kansas, the editor-in-chief of TheStreet.com, publishes column criticizing Cramer for making the comment; Cramer is not available for comment (M)

headline: Look, Doc, No Pad! An Rx for Prescriptions
abstract: Allscripts, Libertyville, Ill, packages its TouchScript software in Hewlewtt-Packard Series 600 handheld computers as means of enabling doctors, often known for having poor quality of handwriting, to write presecriptions and send them electronically to patients' pharmacies; cost of service to doctors is about $200 a month; photo (S)

headline: PrivateSector; A Broker's Painfully Personal Tale
abstract: James Ronald Whitney, star broker at Tucker Anthony, discusses the documentary film he made, Just, Melvin, which tells how his maternal grandfather sexually abused Whitney's mother, uncle, aunts and step-aunts, some from the age of 2; photo (M)

headline: EURO RISING
abstract: Euro strengthens to its highest level in a month against dollar, fueled by speculation that European Central Bank might intervene on its behalf and by signs of stronger growth in Europe; euro hit its all-time low of 88.5 cents on May 19 and has since rebounded to exchange rate of more than 94 cents; graph (S)

headline: Kars Journal; As War Wanes, Tourists Return to Turkey's East
abstract: Tourists begin returning to mostly Kurdish eastern region of Turkey, less than year after peace returned to area and their arrival suggests tourism industry could become source of income and stability in economically depressed area; are flocking to Kars and spectacular ruined city of Ani, which was thriving Armenian capital 10 centuries ago; maps; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Sees Some Bumps In Its Earnings
abstract: Microsoft Corp reports that third-quarter earnings were couple of cents above Wall Street's expectations, but revenue trailed most analysts' estimates; for quarter ended March 31, earnings were $2.39 billion, up 24 percent from $1.92 billion a year ago; revenue rose 23 percent, to $5.66 billion, from $4.60 billion in 1999 third quarter (M)

headline: Microsoft, Responding, Offers Stark View of the Future
abstract: Analysis of Microsoft Corp's alternative to Justice Department's plan to split up company; says Microsoft's legal protest is essay of grim futurism; holds apocalytic passages seem intended to warn Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson that splitting up Microsoft would be dangerous gamble to take with company that is pillar of nation's high-technology economy; chart; photo (M)

headline: Wylie Dufresne
MARRIOTT INTERNATIONAL SETS SALE OF 10 HOTELS
abstract: Marriott International Inc sells 10 hotels t

headline: TRAVEL COMPANY AGREES TO TALKS
abstract: Thomson Travel PLC, Britain's largest travel tour operator, rejects sweetened offer of 1.45 billion pounds ($2.3 billion) in cash from its German suitor C&N Touristic AG; but it agrees to talk with C&N (S)

headline: Rome Journal; Youth Had Its Day: Revenge of the Gerontocracy
abstract: Former Prime Min Giulio Andreotti, 81, featured in advertisements for Web site, symbolizes revenge of Italy's gerontocracy; older leaders are making comeback despite emergence of new generation of business and political leaders in wake of political corruption probe that toppled old political order; Prime Min Giuliano Amato, for example, held cabinet posts in many previous governments; photo (M)

headline: Berlin Journal; A Dog's Best Friend, It Seems, May Be a German
abstract: Dogs are social icebreakers in Berlin, Germany, where residents do not usually display spontaneous friendliness; Cora, mid-sized mongrel owned by Chicago expatriate Stacy Wiedenmann, is huge social magnet in city, unleashing passions and 'unbuttoning the standoffish;' city is home to estimated 200,000 dogs; photo (M)

headline: Amato Is Approved as Italy's Prime Minister by a Slim Margin
abstract: Italian parliament approves Giuliano Amato as prpim minister by 21-margin that reflects new government's fragility (S)

headline: MORE BRAZILIANS BORROWING
abstract: Brazilian bank borrowing rose in April for 10th consecutive month as economic recovery increased consumers' appetite for credit; banks lent $33 billion in April, 4.1 percent increase from month before; lending rates fell to lowest rate since 1994, at 58.1 percent; government says April unemployment fell to 7.8 percent, down from 8.1 percent in March (S)

headline: Royal Philips Makes Offer
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics NV to make tender offer for about 60 percent of MedQuist Inc at $51 a share (S)

headline: For Dreamcast Players, A Network of Their Own
abstract: Sega Enterprises new Sega.com unit plans to offer private online network devoted to high-speed console gaming; network will also function as Internet service provider and cater to other interests of its target market of young males; is offering heady incentives to those who sign up for service, including cash and Dreamcast consoles (M)

headline: BANK OF AMERICA PURCHASES THE REST OF MARSICO CAPITAL
abstract: Bank of America Corp buys half of Marsico Capital Management it does not already own; pays $1.1 billion for all of Marsico, money manager based in Denver; purchase price includes $150 million that Bank of America and its predecessor, NationsBank Corp, paid for options in 1997 and 1998 to buy half of Marsico (S)

headline: Of Two Minds on Microsoft: Wall Street After the Ruling; The Bears: Rivals Are Pulling Ahead
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer gives stock market bears' argument for cutting back on Microsoft Corp stock, in wake of antitrust ruling against company (M)

headline: EBay Cancels Art Sale and Suspends Seller
abstract: EBay, online auction house, cancels sale of abstract painting, contending that seller, Kenneth A Walton, violated its rules in way that artificially inflated sale price; company also suspends three accounts Walton used to trade art, accusing him of 'shill bidding,' entering bids on his own sales; Walton, a lawyer, says he did not realize he was violating eBay's rules; bidding on abstract painting in question began at quarter and was propelled by hints that painter was modern master Richard Diebenkorn; it sold to Rob Keereweer, Dutch software executive, for $135,805 before eBay stepped in to cancel sale; episode sheds light on exponential growth of chicanery and fraud in Internet auctions; open nature of auction sites like eBay has spawned wide range of scams; many art dealers say cases of fake art in online auctions are multiplying, but that most of sellers have avoided prosecution (M)

headline: Fate Unclear For F.T.C.'s Privacy Push
abstract: Federal Trade Commission will encounter skepticism from key Republicans and from industry groups when it goes to Congress to seek tough new privacy rules for Internet businesses (News Analysis); high-technology industry groups insist that any new rules are unwarranted and premature, but companies themselves have differing views on whether and what types of new laws might be warranted; only common theme expressed by Internet businesses is that if Congress proceeds with legislation to regulate consumer privacy protections online, it should do so cautiously (M)

headline: Hong Kong Phone Company Approves a Takeover Bid
abstract: Richard Li moved a step closer to sealing his audacious bid for Hong Kong's main telephone company today, as the board of Cable and Wireless HKT approved the filing of a takeover document to be voted on by shareholders next month.    But even as Mr. Li's company, Pacific Century Cyberworks, cleared another hurdle to its giant purchase, it got a rude reminder of what it is taking on: Cable and Wireless HKT reported a 28 percent decline in its 1999 earnings, as rivals went after its long-distance and cellular franchises.

headline: U.S. Cracks Down on Day-Trade Advisers
abstract: Federal Trade Commission, Securities and Exchange Commission and Commodity Futures Trading Commission say they forced 14 online day-trader advisory firms to stop declaring they can show cllients how to make money with little risk; firms sign consent decrees to settle charges by regulators that they had made unsubstantiated claims and misled potential clients (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Genuine Parts Co  Thornburg Mtg Asset Corp    TUESDAY  Cavalier Homes Inc  CCB Finl Corp  First Tenn Natl Corp  Health Care REIT Inc  HSB Group Inc  IMS Health Inc  Omega Healthcare Invs Inc  Public Svc Enterprise Group  Republic Group Inc  Smucker J.M. Co  Timken Co  Washington Mut Inc  Whirlpool Corp  Willamette Inds Inc

headline: After Campaign Marked by Intimidation, Zimbabwe Voting Opens With Relative Calm
abstract: First day of long-awaited national elections in Zimbabwe is reported largely peaceful; brazen intimidation and violence that marked campaign had threatened to mar vote seen as biggest challenge to grip of Pres Robert Mugabe in 20 years since white minority rule ended; country's more than five million voters are electing new Parliament; party that has controlled government since 1980 faces its first real challenge; photo; map (M)

headline: House Clears Bill to Curb Plans for FM
abstract: US House, 274-110, approves legislation that would curtail ambitious plans to open FM airwaves to hundreds of new low-power stations for churches, community groups and schools; legislation was marked by bitter debate in which its Republican supporters accused officials of Federal Communications Commission of violating criminal law that forbids government agencies from lobbying Congress; FCC officials deny they violated any laws; they say legislation marked first time in agency's 65-year-history that chamber of Congress stripped Commission of its authority to oversee portion of radio spectrum; bill, which is opposed by Clinton administration, moves to Senate (M)

headline: Report Proposes Update of Copyright Act
abstract: Progressive Policy Institute, Democratic research center, sees need to update law meant to protect intellectual property on Internet; proposes outlawing technologies like Napster software, which enables Internet users to trade music files with little regard to copyrights; report is issued ahead of House Small Business Committee hearing scheduled for May 24 to examine Internet music technologies (M)

headline: Motorola Enters Wireless Internet Venture
Official Defends Call for Breakup of Microsoft
abstract: Joel I Klein, assistant attorney general in charge of Justice Department's antitrust division, in response to Microsoft Corp's public criticisms of plan to break it in two, says actual result would be 'exciting new products, with more choices and lower prices for consumers,' speech at forum of new economy at University of California at Berkely (M)

headline: Web Site Lists Iran Coup Names
abstract: Web site about international security publishes list of names from CIA document, outlining agency's role in 1953 coup in Iran, that New York Times deleted when it originally posted report on its own Web site; Times feared publishing them would endanger lives of people involved in coup, almost al of whom were Iranians (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Cristian Dobles was named to the new post of executive creative director at HispanAmerica, New York, a division of the Rapp Collins Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group. He had been executive creative director and managing director at the Hispanic division of the Uniworld Group, New York.  * Michael Megalli, senior consultant at Siegelgale, New York, was named to the additional post of director for a new broadband and wireless group.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of charts accompanying May 14 round-table discussion by executives of six fast-growing European companies (S)

headline: Conseco to Sell Loan Unit, Giving Up Brief Effort to Diversify
abstract: Conseco Inc, once highflying insurance company that stumbled badly when it diversified into consumer lending, says it will sell lending operation, former Green Tree Finance, which it bought in 1998 for stock worth $7.6 billion; it will take write-off of at least $350 million after taxes; chairman-chief executive Stephen H Hilbert, during combative conference call with analysts, says company will focus on life and health insurance, and pledges that it will not diversify again; Hilbert, who in past has frequently forecast profits, declines to do so now (M)

headline: Creative Executives Switch Assignments
abstract: Recent appointments and assignments in advertising industry noted (S)

headline: Demand for Microsoft Workers, Executives Still Far Exceeds Supply
abstract: Demand for Microsoft Workers, Executives Still Far Exceeds Supply

headline: Cyberspace Programmers Confront Copyright Laws
abstract: Programmers, including some intent on challenging world's copyright laws, are at work on computer software that would make it possible to acquire or exchange such digital data as music, video, text or software anonymously and block efforts to remove data from Internet or determine its source; programs would make it possible to find and acquire files without reference to central database, providing no single target for aggrieved copyright holders; methods being developed to protect works, like requiring key to decode scrambled data, may be trumped by similar encryption that covers tracks of those doing swapping; table of most popular systems for distributing digital files (M)

headline: Class of '99 Leads Nasdaq In Comeback
abstract: Best performing initial public offerings of 1999 lead Nasdaq stock market in comeback; total of 23 new stocks ended year trading at least 10 times their original offering price; nearly all of 1999 class of hot deals were Internet related, and nearly all of them have no profits; group has performed horribly since Nasdaq market peaked on March 10; since then, Nasdaq composite is down 17.4 percent; on average group has lost 48 percent of its value in 18 trading sessions; measured from lows on April 4, these stocks are up 33.9 percent by close of trading April 5, more than twice 14.3 percent recovery of overall Nasdaq market; chart (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Reports Give Fed the Fodder for Higher Rates
abstract: Robust pace of growth in economy in first quarter, and clear warning signs of acceleration in wage and price increases, all but guarantee that Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan and his colleagues at central bank will seriously consider raising interest rates by half a percentage point rather than by quarter-point that investors and economists have been anticipating; instead of fighting theoretical possibility of pickup in inflation, Fed can now point to specific if early evidence that economy is overheating (M)

headline: On the Continent, on the Cusp
abstract: Six European entrepeneurs discuss transition from Old World to modern economy; they are Martin A Schoeller, Simon Worth, Leendert Bikker, Sylvain Forestier, Nico Willaert and Christian Hunt; photos, graph (L)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The Numbers Don't Explain the Woes of AT&T
abstract: AT&T Corp investors experience worst day in more than a dozen years, and chairman C Michael Armstrong, who has spent billions of dollars to try to reinvigorate company, has not had such unpleasant professional experience since taking over company in 1997; AT&T announces quarterly financial results that meet analysts' expectations, but company also warns that its earnings and its revenue growth for full year will be lower than expected; revenue after acquisitions had been expected to grow 8 to 9 percent, but compay cuts that projection to 7 to 8 percent; shares fall 14 percent, or $6.8125, to $41.9375; earnings in first quarter, discounting special charges and some outside investments, were 53 cents a share, or $1.7 billion, down from 61 cents a share, or $1.7 billion, a year earlier; revenue after acquisitions increased 5.8 percent, to $15.8 billion, from $15 billion in year-earlier period; including all charges, investments and acquisitions, AT&T earned 54 cents a share, or $1.7 billion, up from 38 cents, or $1.1 billion a year ago; reported revenue increased 12.3 percent, to $15.8 billion, from $14.1 billion; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: AT&T Files New Proposal On Its Rates
abstract: AT&T submits new proposal on rates to Federal Communications Commission; plan adds to customers' flexibility, but fails to deliver significant savings promised by AT&T; company claims that new rate schedule would lessen profits by one or two cents per share (M)

headline: California Medical Association Files a Suit Against 3 Insurers
abstract: Adding to the barrage of lawsuits attacking managed care, the California Medical Association yesterday accused three big insurance companies of violating federal antiracketeering laws by coercing doctors and interfering with physician-patient relationships for financial reasons. The California suit was the first broad-based legal assault on managed care by a state medical association, medical officials in several states said.     The California Medical Association, which says it has 34,000 physician members, filed a civil lawsuit under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO, against the Blue Cross of California unit of WellPoint Health Networks, the HealthNet unit of Foundation Health Systems, and PacifiCare Health Systems. The three investor-owned companies provide coverage for a total of nine million members in California, or about 4 in 10 residents in managed care.

headline: PATHOGENESIS SEEKING WAYS TO RAISE ITS STOCK PRICE
abstract: PathoGenesis Corp, biotechnology company, hires Goldman, Sachs to seek out 'strategic options' to raise its stock price (S)

headline: FORMER G.M. EXECUTIVE SOUGHT
abstract: US Justice Dept petitions Spain to extradite former General Motors employee Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, accused of stealing vast quantities of GM documents (S)

headline: The Paperless Newspaper
abstract: Letter by Robert Stein responds to May 25 article on cyberspace news; says article brings to mind the psychological significance of newspaper reading

headline: A Buyer's Guide to China's Latest Cars
abstract: a buyer's guide to chi

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro declines against US dollar as European finance officials gather to discuss currency stance ahead of summit meeting next week; euro settles at 95.45 cents, down from 95.97 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: A Summer Vacation That's On the House
abstract: Homeowners in cities where hotel rooms are expensive might want to think about renting out their homes while they are away on summer vacation, as a way a defraying vacation cost; no tax is due on income from out home for fewer than 15 days a year (M)

headline: A Lilliputian Printer For Palm Handheld Devices
abstract: Monarch Marking Systems has developed small portable printer for use with Palm handheld computer; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Chicago exchanges feel some heat to step up merger talks.
abstract: Chicago Board of Trade and Chicago Board Options Exchange have stepped up merger talks in face of bill that would allow sale of futures contracts on individual stocks; Chicago Board Options Exchange fears change could undercut sales of options on individual stocks; table of data on exchanges; graphs of trading volume (M)

headline: NESTLE TO INVEST IN E-COMMERCE
abstract: Nestle plans to invest as much as 3 billion Swiss francs ($1.8 billion) in electronic business and information technology in next six years; graph (S)

headline: Clothing Site Shuts Down in Britain
abstract: Clothing Site Shuts Down in Britain

headline: Diageo Reported in Talks To Buy Part of Bestfoods
abstract: Diageo PLC reportedly is in talks to buy all or part of Bestfoods, which seeks to stave off Unilever bid (M)

headline: ALANTRO COMMUNICATIONS AGREES TO A $300 MILLION DEAL
abstract: Texas Instruments agrees to acquire chip-manufacturer Alantro Communications for $300 million (S)

headline: GE MEDICAL AGREES TO BUY DIAGNOSTIC SYSTEMS MAKER
abstract: GE Medical Systems agrees to acquire Lunar Corp, manufacturer of bone disease diagnostic systems, for about $150 million in stock (S)

headline: Chase Will Pay $7.7 Billion In Cash and Stock for Fleming
abstract: Chase Manhattan formally agrees to acquire Robert Fleming Holdings for $7.7 billion, part of effort by Chase to strengthen its presence in Europe and Asia; deal means end of independence for Fleming, one of last privately held investment banks based in Britain; acquisition is expected to be completed by July or August; Fleming's current chief executive William Garrett will continue to run business; Chase says no layoffs are expected; photo (M)

headline: Would A Breakup Matter?
abstract: THE Proposed Final Judgment in the case of the United States v. Microsoft Corporation is on the Internet at www.usdoj.gov/atr/cases/ms

headline: Foundations' New Force
abstract: Foundation Center reports charitable contributions by nation's 47,000 foundations rose to $22.8 billion in 1999, 17 percent rise from previous year; foundation endowments rose 16.7 percent, to $385.1 billion in 1998; stock market gains and new wealth credited (S)

headline: Private Sector; Chipper Days for Dr. Gloom
abstract: Henry Kaufman, author of forthcoming On Money and Markets: A Wall Street Memoir, links risk-taking in the market to ignorance of financial history; photo (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of May 9 map with article about renaming of German army base for German sergeant who saved hundreds of Jews in Lithuania in World War II and was executed by Nazis, regarding geographical description

headline: NORWAY TO INCREASE OIL OUTPUT
abstract: Norway, world's second-largest oil exporter, will lift limits on its oil output starting July 1, allowing production to increase 3 percent; Norway will add 100,000 barrels a day to its current daily oil production of 3.2 million barrel; Olav Akselsen, Norway's oil minister, says there seems to be need for more oil in the market; photo (S)

headline: Life Stories Told in 200 Pages or Less
abstract: Sales of first eight books in Penguin Lives series of short biographies have exceeded expectations of publishers Penguin and Lipper Books; series, introduced last year, matches range of subjects with major writers; Penguin, which committed to 18 books over three years, has agreed to publish 18 more; Lipper is exploring two other series, on scientific discoveries and business; photos (M)

headline: Top Cleric Attacks Iran's Silenced Press as an Opponent of Islam
abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's most powerful Muslim cleric, calls country's now-silenced liberal press a deviant force bent on turning country against Islam; scattered protests continue against abrupt closing of 13 newspapers; Khamenei praises Pres Mohammad Khatami, champion of reform movment, in effort to distinguish between Khatami and his journalistic and political supporters (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Automatic Data Processing Inc  Synovus Finl Corp    TUESDAY  Acadia Rlty Tr  Bestfoods  Central Newspapers Inc  Cross Timbers Oil Co  Donnelly Corp  Florida East Coast Inds Inc  Gallagher Arthur J & Co  Georgia Gulf Corp  Great Lakes REIT Inc  Longs Drug Stores Corp  Questar Corp

headline: Lebanese Holiday Is Born And Old Prison Is Preserved
abstract: Lebanese proudly celebrate new holiday, National Resistance Day, as Israeli troops withdraw; jubilant rally is held at now empty Khiam prison, notorious there for reported torture of guerrilla fighters by Israel's allies in South Lebanon Army militia; guarded hopefulness transfuses country as Lebanese consider possibility they might be entering rare era without bloodshed; there is fear that Israel's threat to treat cross-border fire as 'act of war' means stakes are much higher; at border, curiosity seekers mingle with guerrillas and freelance hooligans to create alternately festive and provocative scene (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: ASIA; CHEVRON RAISES STAKE IN CASPIAN FIELD
abstract: Chevron Corp, in move aimed at increasing its investment in the largest proven oil field on the Caspian Sea, signs an agreement to pay $450 million for 5 percent of the Tengiz field in Kazakhstan in addition to other cash payments to help the country (S)

headline: Webvan to Deliver Electronics and Entertainment Goods
abstract: Webvan to Deliver Electronics and Entertainment Goods

headline: Lycos and Spanish Phone Giant Are Seen in a $12 Billion Deal
abstract: Lycos, one of nation's biggest portals, agrees to be acquired by Telefonica of Spain in sweeping deal across borders and languages worth more than $12 billion; deal would combine Lycos with Terra Networks, Internet arm of Telefonica, and link new hybrid in partnership with German media conglomerate Bertelsmann; portal would have millions of users from Europe to Latin America; purchase would give Terra--fastest-growing European Internet company--wide opening into North America to sell Web services to expanding Hispanic population in US; alliance would broaden Bertelsmann's global reach, allowing it to sell novels through Lycos in US or offer music that can be downloaded through Telefonica cellular telephones in Europe or Terra portals in Brazil; Telefonica would pay Bertelsmann undisclosed sum of 25 percent stake in new online bookstore that it will create called Bol.com South America; Bertelsmann would retain other 75 percent; European companies are expected to sign five-year agreement that would make make Bertelsmann 'preferred content provider' on Lycos in US in exchange for $1 billion; photos of Bertelsmann chairman Thomas Middelhoff, Lycos chairman Bob Davis and Telefonica chairman Juan Villalonga (M)

headline: GERMAN CABLE PURCHASE
abstract: United Pan-Europe Communications NV, based in Amsterdam, Europe's number 2 cable television company, will buy EWT/TSS Group, Augsburg, Germany, for one billion euros ($950 million) in cash, stock and assumed debt; EWT has 650,000 subscribers (S)

headline: Rally in Belgrade Protests Early Closing of Serbian Universities
abstract: Several thousand students, teachers and parents rally to protest closing of universities week early by government of Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic; photo (M)

headline: MANAGEMENT: You've Got Inappropriate Mail; Monitoring of Office E-Mail Is Increasing
abstract: Hundreds of companies are looking at workers' electronic mail correspondence on routine basis, and number of companies doing so is soaring; market for e-mail monitoring has doubled in size over last year; managers are on lookout for oversize e-mail attachments that clog networks; others seek to dissuade employees from using their systems for personal activities; and others want to make sure employees are not sending harassing messages; snooping is raising ethical questions; in last six months, software has become more advanced, enabling companies automatically to record, filter and sort every word that streams through their networks; SuperScout, product made by SurfControl, can generate bar charts showing 10 people who get most e-mail messages, 10 who send most and 10 who send biggest messages; another product, xVail, made by xVault, enables managers to view and search text of messages; Symantec and GFI Fax and Voice have also introducted e-mail monitoring products the last few months; Andrew Quinn, systems manager at Canada's Ritvik Toys, comments on monitoring workers' e-mail; graph; chart; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: World coffee price rises 4 percent; other commodities prices noted; graph (S)

headline: A Disruptive Virus Invades Computers Around the World
abstract: A rogue software program, borne by an e-mail message proclaiming ''I love you,'' propelled itself around the world yesterday, jamming and crashing e-mail systems and destroying data on hundreds of thousands of computers.    To defend themselves, thousands of corporations unhooked their computer systems from the Internet and began a laborious process of purging the program internally.

headline: COREL REPORTS LOSS
abstract: Canadian software developer Corel Corp reports loss of $23.6 million for second quarter ended May 31, on revenue of $36.6 million; profit a year ago was $9.2 million on sales of $70.5 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar falls, dragged down by tumbling United States stocks, trading at 105.09 yen; graphs (M)

headline: Europeans To Scrutinize U.S. Merger Of Airlines
abstract: European Commission says it will probably have to take a close look at the competitive aspects of the UAL Corp's proposed takeover of US Airways; both airlines offer trans-Atlantic flights (M)

headline: United Plans to Buy US Airways, Creating Giant in the Northeast
abstract: United Airlines, world's largest airline, to buy US Airways for $4.3 billion and assumption of $7.3 billion in debt; says it will sell many of US Airways' routes at Ronald Reagan National Airport, near Washington, DC, to US Airways board member Robert L Johnson, who plans to run new airline with those planes, employees and routes; will retain US Airways' lucrative shuttle service between Washington, New York and Boston and dominate many markets in East; pledges not to raise fares on some domestic routes for at least two years, except to cover inflation and higher fuel costs; will not lay off any US Airways workers; James E Goodwin, chief executive of United's parent, UAL Corp, will run combined company; United backed away from similar 1995 deal because of opposition from its powerful pilots' union, which is expected to again oppose deal; maps; graphs and tables of market share (M)

headline: Brazil Is Allowing U.S. Companies to Use Launching Site
abstract: Brazil reaches agreement with US to allow American companies to use equatorial launching site, Alcantara, advancing ambitions of Latin America's largest country to tap lucrative satellite-launching industry; under accord, Brazil will not be permitted to gain access to technology of American companies and their clients that launch satellites from Alcantara; country has invested more than $200 million in Alcantara, which is south of equator; satellite launchings from equator are less expensive because satellites reach orbit more quickly and require less fuel; with capacity for 14 launchings a year, base could bring Brazil estimated $30 million each year (M)

headline: Online retailers have set their sights on a lucrative standby of their conventional rivals: private-label merchandise.
abstract: Internet retailers are turning to private-label manufacturing, old retailing standby, to give them better profit margins and control of inventory; are selling own goods alongside well-known brands; Ashford.com, online seller of jewelry, apparel and other goods, is among latest companies to announce private-label effort; photo (M)

headline: PAINEWEBBER TO CLOSE INVESTMENT BANK UNIT
abstract: PaineWebber Group Inc to close its investment-banking unit J C Bradford & Co, brokerage firm it agreed to buy for $620 million last month; plan will eliminate about 90 positions in Nashville (S)

headline: Terrorism Panel Faults U.S. Effort on Iran and 1996 Bombing
abstract: Report by bipartisan National Commission on Terrorism faults Clinton administration for not doing enough to press Iran for cooperation in investigation of 1996 bombing of Khobar Towers military complex in Saudi Arabia that killed 19 American servicemen, despite evidence of Iranian involvement; concludes administration has done little to mount international campaign to put diplomatic pressure on Iran to cooperate; its findings discussed (M)

headline: Building Investor Confidence; South Africa Buttressing Its Insider Trading Rules
abstract: South Africa is trying to overcome view that its stock exchange is hotbed for insider trading; country wants to maintain its growth and help assure foreign investors that it is just as attractive as other emerging markets; regulators, backed by new law, have taken aim at insider traders; country is slowly rebuilding its economy, and it craves foreign investment thriving stock exchange could bring; Peter Redman, former chairman of Johannesburg Stock Exchange, is senior surveillance adviser for market; Johannesburg Stock Exchange's trading volume increased nearly ninefold, from 5.2 billion shares at end of 1995, to 43.1 billion at end of 1999; charts; photos (M)

headline: Blair and His Wife Have a New Son, Their 4th Child
abstract: Cherie Blair, wife of British Prime Min Tony Blair, gives birth to son, their fourth child, at London hospital (S)

headline: TAIWAN PRICES RISE
abstract: Taiwan's consumer price index rises 1.25 percent in Apriil from April 1999 (S)

headline: DRESDNER EXECUTIVES REPLACED
abstract: Dresdner Bank, still reeling from collapse of its $29 billion merger with Deutsche Bank, replaces three top executives; announces resignations of Gerd Hausler, head of investment bank Dresdner Kleinwort Benson; Ernst-Moritz Lipp, who oversaw corporate finance and corporate banking; and Andreas Bezold, who was in charge of risk management; Leonhard Fischer, head of asset management, will oversee investment banking; in recent weeks, more than 100 executives have quit Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, and bank is now guaranteeing bonuses to retain people (S)

headline: Support for the Psion
abstract: Ilene Miner letter praises her Psion 7 (S)

headline: Relying on the Act: Sherman Antitrust
abstract: Federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's decision against Microsoft Corp in Justice Department's antitrust suit is based on specifics of Sherman Antitrust Act, passed in 1890 (S)

headline: 2-Day Surge Ends Abruptly As Dow and Nasdaq Falter
abstract: Nasdaq composite index falls 87.16 points, or 2.3 percent, to 3,706.41, while Dow Jones industrial average drops 92.46 points, or 0.9 percent, to 10,674.96; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is off 14.1 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 1,427.47; graph; charts (M)

headline: Former Writer Back as 'Incorrect' Producer
abstract: Jerry Nachman, former newspaper editor, is named co-executive producer of ABC program, Politically Incorrect With Bill Maher; photo (M)

headline: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; The Other Retirement Planning
abstract: Judith L Steininger My Money, My Life column finds most retirement planning focuses on financial planning and activity planning, but fails to address emotional distress that come from leaving a much-loved job; recalls her own retirement after 30 years teaching college; drawing (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY -- None    TUESDAY -- None

headline: Fear of Failure? Back Up
abstract: Letter from Steven A Ludsin says May 18 article on making backups did not mention Iomega's Jaz drive for storage and backup

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Expedia Beats Estimates as Sales Triple

headline: CHINESE MINING VENTURE
abstract: Billiton PLC, international mining giant, announces joint venture with LanPing Nonferrous Metals Co to develop Chinese mine, Yunnan province, that it considers one of the world's most promising sources of zinc (S)

headline: CANADA G.D.P. SLIPS
abstract: Canadian GDP dropped 0.4 percent in February (S)

headline: A big new Internet services company is determined to make its entry with a splash.
abstract: Stuart Elliott (Advertising column) discusses efforts of MarchFirst Inc, recently formed company offering variety of Internet professional services, to stand out from competitors through an extensive--and expensive--offline and online media campaign; notes brief 'teaser' campaign ran in newspapers to introduce company name, which was created by members of McKinney & Silver ad agency; says second, much larger phase of MarchFirst campaign, also produced by McKinney & Silver, will begin soon; says budget is $50 million (M)

headline: Citigroup Reviewing Citibank Account
abstract: Citigroup is beginning review for Citibank assignments in United States now handled by Young & Rubicam Advertising (S)

headline: BAA PROFIT FALLS
abstract: BAA, world's biggest airport operator, says second-half profit fell 8.2 percent to 145 million pounds ($219 million), from 158 million pounds in same period year earlier (S)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: U.N. Plans Internet Conference

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SOUTHERN CO., Atlanta, a power producer, said it planned to build a natural-gas-fired power plant in southwestern Michigan. The cost was not disclosed.    DELPHI AUTOMOTIVE SYSTEMS CORP., Troy, Mich., the largest auto-parts maker, agreed to buy more interior and engine parts from the closely held Regal Plastics Co., Roseville, Mich., to increase the variety of door handles and other parts it offers. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Pierre Pflimlin, 93, a Politician Who Helped to Rebuild France
abstract: Pierre Pflimlin, French politician who promoted Western Europe's postwar reconciliation and briefly, as prime minister, had to cope with uprising in Algeria and temper of Charles de Gaulle, dies at age 93; photo (M)

headline: BANK ONE SELLS CREDIT CARD DIVISION IN CANADA
abstract: Bank One Corp sells its year-old credit card business in Canada to Royal Bank of Canada for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: U.S. Spends More Than All Others, but Ranks 37 Among 191 Countries : WHO Lists France First In Providing Health Care
abstract: GENEVA—  The World Health Organization, for the first time, has ranked the health systems of its 191 member countries, and France tops the list for providing the best overall health care.

headline: WEATHERFORD INTERNATIONAL TO BUY ALPINE OIL SERVICES
abstract: Weatherford International Inc agrees to buy Alpine Oil Services Corp of Calgary, Alberta, for around $55 million in stock (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: ASIA    JAPAN: PREMIER APOLOGIZES -- Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori apologized for remarks last week that seemed to endorse emperor worship. After several days of heavy criticism, Mr. Mori, left, expressed regret in a tense news conference that his remarks had caused misunderstanding, but declined to retract his statement altogether. In his original remarks, which critics said echoed Japan's prewar militarism, Mr. Mori said Japan was ''a divine nation with the emperor at its core.''    Howard French (NYT)    SRI LANKA: MILITARY PLEA -- The government asked retired officers and policemen to re-enlist in the armed forces in hopes of bolstering 30,000 troops under assault from separatist ethnic Tamils in the northern Jaffna Peninsula. Those who rejoined would take the noncombat positions of younger soldiers, who would then be shifted to the front lines. The rebels threatened a bloodbath for soldiers who failed to surrender by today.      Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

headline: People
abstract: Neve Savage, vice president for client results at Avenue A ad agency, is named president at new international division, to open in London (S)

headline: POSSIBLE FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN MEDIA-MOST
abstract: Media-Most, Russia's biggest independent media conglomerate, says major international investor might buy stake in company, which could help alleviate pressure on it just weeks after its offices were searched and its owner, Vladimir A Gusinsky, was temporarily detained by prosecutors on embezzlement charges; investor, who is not identified, has expressed interest in buying $211.6 million debt Media-Most owes to Gazprom, country's natural gas company; photo (S)

headline: First-Quarter Earnings Beat Expectations At 2 Banks
abstract: Bank of America and Bank of New York report first-quarter profits that beat expectations; earnings at Bank of America rose 17 percent; Bank of New York profit rose 6.8 percent; Bank of America's net inocme rose to $2.24 billion compared with $1.91 billion a year ago; noninterest income grew 26 percent, to $4.95 billion, and was 47 percent of total revenue, up from 41 percent a year earlier; net interest income fell 1 percent, to $4.6 billion; net income at Bank of New York rose to record $338 million compared with $316 million; net interest income rose 5.5 percent, to $460 million (M)

headline: Painful Glimpse of Home for Palestinians
abstract: Israeli withdrawal from southern Lebanon is bittersweet experience for Palestinian refugees who have lived in squalid, supposedly makeshift camps there for nearly half century; their goal of returning to West Bank homeland remains as elusive as ever since many feel abandoned by Palestinian leadership in Gaza City; even if peace agreement is reached and Palestinian state declared, mass migration of millions of refugees to Palestinian-ruled West Bank and Gaza, as well as some parts of Israel under family reunification policy, is seen as extremely unlikely and issue is likely to be deferred; maps; photos (M)

headline: To Colombians, Drug War Is Toxic Enemy
abstract: American-sponsored fumigation program to eradicate heroin poppy cultivation in Colombia is reportedly damaging residents' health and crops; critics accuse government planes of deliberately spraying buildings and fields not intended to be targets, causing rash of ailments; say US and Colombian governments are ignoring reports of mistakes and abuses by Colombian pilots of antinarcotics planes, even as State Department officials deny that indiscriminate spraying takes place; local leaders in town of Rioblanco de Sotara describe problems allegedly caused by spraying; say situation remains one of crisis; photos; map (M)

headline: Icahn Says He Is Set to Pay More for Nabisco
abstract: Carl C Icahn says he is willing to raise his offer for Nabisco Group to about $6.5 billion in cash and short-term debt; photo (M)

headline: Reluctant Underwear Shopper Finds a Method That Clicks
abstract: Lisa Napoli article on shopping for lingerie online; photos (M)

headline: U.N. Aide in Kosovo Faults NATO on Unexploded Bombs
abstract: Boy is killed and two other children seriously wounded by cluster bomb in Kosovo, Serbia; UN official blames NATO for delay in removal of unexploded bombs; since refugees returned to Kosovo in June 1999, more than 100 people have died and hundreds have been wounded in mine and bomb accidents; estimated 40 percent have been victims of cluster bombs (M)

headline: BIG AIRBUS ORDER
abstract: Airbus Industrie books order for up to 50 aircraft with list price of more than $3 billion from International Lease Finance Corp, unit of American International Group (S)

headline: New Technology Is Aimed At Increasing Web Privacy
abstract: Major Internet companies and World Wide Web's standard-setting body, World Wide Web Consortium, unveil some long-awaited technology that would alert computer users before they visited Web sites that collect more personal information than they are willing to share; although new standard, called Platform for Privacy Preferences, or P3P, is billed as just one step in improving state of privacy on Internet, it is immediately denounced by some privacy advocates as way for companies to avoid new laws and tool that would give consumers false sense of security; if technology proves to be widely accepted by Internet companies and Web sites, it would give consumers a way to more easily control whether and how companies track their Web movements and gather information about them (M)

headline: G.M.'s New Chief Sticks to Company Plans
abstract: G Richard Wagoner Jr, who at age 47 became the youngest chief executive of General Motors last week, outlines his plans to bolster sales, including maintaining current business strategies, speech at company's annual meeting; says he expects new truck models and emphasis on Internet marketing to lift GM market share, which is currently 28 percent and has been falling slowly since the 1960's, an erosion that no team of GM executives has been able to halt; Wagoner photo (M)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Watchdog Group Announces Settlements With 20 Software Pirates

headline: Lucent Picks Boeing Executive as Finance Chief
abstract: Lucent Technologies names Deborah C Hopkins, Boeing Co's chief financial officer, to be its chief financial officer; Hopkins replaces Donald K Peterson; photo (M)

headline: LATIN PURCHASES BY AES
abstract: AES offers to buy all outstanding nonvoting shares of Brazilian electricity distributor Electropaulo Metropolitana (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper rises as surging US stocks signal investors expect economy to keep growing; in New York, copper for May delivery rises 2.1 cents, or 2.8 percent, to 76.45 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: GO.COM IS SELLING ULTRASEEK TO INKTOMI FOR $344 MILLION
abstract: Go.com, Walt Disney's Internet unit, to sell its Ultraseek subsidiary to Inktomi Corp for $344.7 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: A flood of trademark applications clearly shows that the Internet is a place businesses want to be.
abstract: United States Patent and Trademark Office received 33,731 applications for trademarks that covered Internet-related products or services in 1999; in 1994, number of such applications was 307; study was done by law firm specializing in Internet law (M)

headline: A 'Silent' Generation Speaks Up, and Not So Softly
abstract: Marion K Pinsdorf, letter, responds to Fred Brock's May 7 article on 'silent' generation, those Americans, now in the mid-50's to early 70's, who are too young to have fought in World War II but too old to be considered baby boomers; drawing (M)

headline: Beirut Says It Can't Prevent Palestinian Attacks on Israel
abstract: Officials in Beirut, in new sign of Arab unease, warn they could not, and would not, prevent Palestinian militants from using Lebanese territory to mount attacks on Israel after its army withdraws unilaterally from southern Lebanon; Lebanon Pres Emile Lahoud says 'daily miniwars' could break out along border with Israel unless United Nations disarms Palestinian refugees living in miserable camps scattered across Lebanon--and unless it actively prevents Israeli retaliation against any Palestinian operation (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Philip Morris and Reynolds To Buy Parts of Nabisco  The Philip Morris Companies, owner of Kraft Foods, said it had reached an agreement to buy Nabisco Holdings, maker of Oreo cookies and Grey Poupon mustard.    After that sale is completed, Nabisco Group Holdings, which holds an 80.6 percent stake in the Nabisco operating company, said it would accept an offer from its former unit, R.J. Reynolds Tobacco. [Page A1.]

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: E*Trade and Wit Capital Team Up for Underwriting  Acknowledging how hard it has been to break the stranglehold Wall Street has on the underwriting of new stocks, two online financial-services companies, E*Trade Group and Wit Capital Group, said they would team up to compete against their off-line rivals.    E*Trade said it would form an alliance with Wit Capital after that online investment bank acquires E*Offering, a rival that E*Trade helped to finance a year ago. Wit Capital plans to issue stock worth $328 million to the shareholders of E*Offering. [Page C2.]

headline: Rebels Free Half of Force From the U.N. In Africa War
abstract: Rebels in Sierra Leone release 29 more hostages or nearly half of 500 UN peacekeepers who were seized; officials voice optimism releases will continue in coming days; rebels call for release of leader Foday Sankoh, raising concern that they may continue to hold troops while bargaining for his freedom; photo (S)

headline: U.N. Allows Cambodians to Take Part in Trial of Khmer Rouge
abstract: United Nations concedes to Cambodia right to appoint one of two prosecutors in war crimes trials for Khmer Rouge; compromise seems to have surmounted major hurdle in eventually bringing former Khmer Rouge leaders to trial; human rights groups score deal, which also calls for three of five judges to be Cambodians; Clinton administration reportedly strongly backed deal (M)

headline: Treasuries Drop in Price As Equities Draw Money
abstract: US bond prices decline; price of 30-year bond declines 3/32, to 106 19/32; yield rises to 5.79 percent from 5.78 percent; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Israel's Allies Flee, Fearing for Their Lives and Leaving Everything Behind
abstract: Some 3,000 members of Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia and their families flee into Israel ahead of complete Israeli withdrawal; fear prison or even death at hands of Hezbollah guerrillas overrunning villages; abandon homes, goods and finally their cars in desperate flight; photo (M)

headline: Turkey Considers Scaling Back Military Challenge to Greece
abstract: Turkish Prime Min Bulent Ecevit weighs proposal by adviser, retired Adm Guven Erkaya, to disband 100,000-man Aegean Army, which serves in zone of military confrontation with Greece; prominence given plan, which general staff says is not on agenda, has spurred national debate over issue; debate follows nearly year of improving ties with Greece; Greece and Turkey are locked in tangle of sovereignty disputes over sea lanes, air rights and barren islets in Aegean Sea (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises against US dollar on relief that downgrade to Japan's credit rating is not steeper; in New York, dollar settles at 105.06 yen, down from 105.60; graph; chart (S)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Regulators Take Steps to Halt Profit Claims by 14 Online Firms

headline: People
abstract: Dan Igoe, executive vice president at Barnhart/CMI Marketing, Advertising and Public Relations, is named president, succeeding Terry Barnhart, who remains chairman; Alice Connery is named to vacant post of president at Thompson Connect; John Englehart, worldwide executive vice president at Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide, is named to new post of executive vice president for worldwide client services; John Leonard, executive vice president and global brand manager for Philips Electronics account at Paris office of Euro RSCG Worldwide, is named to new post of global client director at Euro RSCG Tatham, Chicago (Advertising column) (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper falls on speculation that increase in interest rates would slow demand from builders and manufacturers; graphs (S)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Yahoo Names Google to Replace Inktomi on Searches

headline: Spy Software Puts Home PC's Under Surveillance
abstract: Peter H Lewis (State of the Art) article discusses software known as snoopware, that records everything that shows up on a computer screen; says one example of such software is Spector, $49.95 Windows program from SpectorSoft; company says software was originally designed to allow parents to spy on their children to make sure they were not visiting inappropriate Web sites; says that in short time software has been on market, parents have not turned out to be main customers; instead, according to SpectorSoft, program has found an enthusiastic audience among tens of thousands of suspicious spouses, distrustful bosses and private investigators (L)

headline: Publishing Executive to Be Named
abstract: American Express Publishing is expected to name Ed Kelly president and chief executive, succeeding Daniel B Brewster, who resigned (S)

headline: 7 Villagers in Kashmir Slain During Anti-Police Protest
abstract: Seven demonstrators against recent killings of villagers by police are killed in Kashmir and at least another four are wounded; are part of march of about 1,000 people from their villages to district police headquarters in Barakpura; photo (M)

headline: When Modems Fail To Stay Connected
abstract: Q. I am often disconnected from the Internet when I am trying to download files from the Web. Is it my computer or the site I'm on that's causing this?    A. There are several things that could be causing the problem, and you may want to start keeping track of the disconnection incidents to see if you can spot any patterns. If other files of the same size download with no problems, but you find yourself repeatedly bumped offline when trying to download a particular file, the problem could be with that file or the site it is on.

headline: Mindful of China, U.S. Agrees To Weapons Deal for Taiwan
abstract: Clinton administration, seeking to avoid further roiling China-Taiwan tensions, agrees to sell Taiwan upgraded versions of three missiles and long-range radar system, but not four technology-laden destroyers; national security adviser, Samuel R Berger, Defense Sec William S Cohen and Deputy State Sec Strobe Talbott agree on plan at White House meeting; some senior Republicans, including Sen Jesse Helms, call for more robust arms deal (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: JOSEPH STEVENS & CO., New York, named Jeff Lederer, a consultant to the company, to the post of president. He succeeds Steven Markowitz, who remains chairman.    LISTEN.COM, San Francisco, named Sean Ryan, vice president for business development, to the post of president and chief operating officer.

headline: NO CHANGE IN BRITISH RATE
abstract: Bank of England's monetary policy committee leaves benchmark interest rate unchanged at 6 percent; photo (S)

headline: Cattle Disease Inflicts a Toll on South Korea
abstract: Livestock markets throughout Far East are upset by news of outbreak in South Korea of foot-and-mouth disease, one of most destructive cattle diseases known; South Korea has taken increasingly muscular measures to prevent spread of extremely contagious viral disease; it poses no threat to humans; last confirmed outbreak, in Taiwan in 1977, forced slaughter of over three million pigs; map (M)

headline: SWISS RAISE RATES
abstract: Swiss National Bank raises its benchmark interest rate by greater-than-expected 50 basis points, or half a percentage point; increase puts benchmark three-month rate target range at 3 percent to 4 percent; economists had expected quarter-point increase; Switzerland's economy is growing at fastest pace since 1989 (S)

headline: U.S. INDUSTRIES HIRES ADVISER FOR LIGHTING UNIT
abstract: U.S. Industries, maker of Jacuzzi baths and other household products, hired a financial adviser yesterday to explore alternatives for its lighting division, including a possible sale. The adviser, Compass Partners International, will look at options for the division, the Lighting Corporation of America, whose brands include Columbia, Dual-Lite and Prescolite. Sales of lighting fixtures and related products at U.S. Industries were $805 million in the 1999 fiscal year. In January, U.S. Industries, based in Iselin, N.J., agreed to sell its diversified business unit, which includes the vacuum cleaner maker Rexair, EJ Footwear and Bilt Best Windows.

headline: Media Metrix Plans to Merge with Jupiter Communications
