abstract: Media Mertrix Inc, influential arbiter of who's hot and who's not in Internet world, will acquire Jupiter Communications, leading analyst of Internet trends; shares of Media Metrix fall 17 percent, while Jupiter's drop 8 percent; stock swap, which was valued at about $414 million when deal was announced, was worth $343 million by end of trading (M)

headline: Little Relief Is Seen From High Gas Prices
abstract: OPEC ministers meeting today in Vienna are expected to agree on a modest increase in oil production, but the move is unlikely to bring much relief to American gasoline consumers, who are paying more than $2 a gallon in some regions.    Worldwide demand for oil continues to grow and quickly absorb any increases in supply.    Business Day, Page C1.

headline: The Paperless Newspaper
abstract: Letter by Elizabeth C Gorski responds to May 25 article on cyberspace news; says article failed to mention the decades-long interactive feature of print newspapers: crossword puzzle

headline: Patience Doesn't Pay For Social Security
abstract: Charles A Miller letter responds to May 28 Economic View column; points out that many people are not in position to wait until age 70 before taking Social Security retirement benefits (M)

headline: Priceline Shares Fall as Airlines Plan to Invest in a Rival Web Site
abstract: Shares of Priceline.com drop 8.4 percent after report in Wall Street Journal that six major airlines plan to invest in competing Web site for customers looking for discounts on plane tickets online; airlines have invested in Hotwire.com, San Francisco start-up scheduled to begin operating this fall; Hotwire has $75 million in financing, primarily from Texas Pacific Group; Priceline says it expects no negative impact from Hotwire (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   9.00   9.00   7.75       Discount rate   5.50   5.50   4.50       Federal funds   6.06   6.05   4.60       3-month T-bills   5.73   5.73   4.47       6-month T-bills   5.94   5.93   4.47       10-yr. T-infl.   3.97   3.96   3.84       10-yr. T-note   6.39   6.30   5.39       30-yr. T-bond   6.11   6.01   5.70       Telephone bd.   8.35   8.22   7.46       Municipal bds.   6.10   6.06   5.31          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: REORGANIZATION BY SAP
abstract: German business-management software manufacturer SAP plans reorganization of program-development unit following complaints from customers about faulty products (S)

headline: EBay Doubles Quarterly Profit
abstract: EBay Doubles Quarterly Profit

headline: Real Libraries, Real Joys
abstract: Eileen Potts Dawson letter says June 15 article comparing library with Internet research failed to note the possibility of meeting someone special at a library

headline: U.S. Settlement Seen With Options Markets
abstract: US options exchanges will be required to increase their combined enforcement budgets by as much as $11 million a year under price-fixing settlement being discussed with Securities and Exchange Commission; agreement would require increase of up to 50 percent in annual enforcement budgets at each of four exchanges; second settlement, under negotiation with Justice Department, would require four exchanges to adopt rules aimed at halting possible anticompetitive trading practices (M)

headline: At Last, A Pipe Fitter's Wrench Of Her Own
abstract: Article on how tight labor market is breaking the gender 'rules' a lot easier in jobs that once were male dominated; focuses on Nannette Cooper, who has set her sights on becoming premier pipe fitter and welder; Cooper comments; photo (M)

headline: FRANCE TELECOM TO SELL CROWN CASTLE SHARES
abstract: Crown Castle International Corp, operator of communication towers, says French phone company France Telecom has agreed to sell 24.9 million Crown Castle shares for $693.1 million in public offering; French Telecom is selling the shares because of its pending investment in competitor in cellular transmission tower business, NTL Inc, NY (S)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Letters to the Editor

headline: EIRCOM SHAREHOLDERS EXIT
abstract: Telecommunications companies Royal KPN of Netherlands and Telia of Sweden will sell their combined 35 percent stake in Eircom, former Irish state phone company, to institutional and private investors; graph (S)

headline: What the Numbers Mean, and How They Were Calculated
abstract: Charts showing compensation for new-economy and old-economy executives reported for 1999 and compiled by Executive Compensation Advisory Services (L)

headline: 2 Trials Focus Attention on Iranian Justice
abstract: In a packed courtroom covered with flowery oriental carpets, two smiling young men told a judge today that they had decided to shoot one of the country's leading reformers because they believed that he was corrupt and an enemy of Islam.    The trial, in which eight men are charged in the attempted assassination of the reformer, Saeed Hajjarian, an editor and political strategist close to President Mohammad Khatami, has mesmerized this city.

headline: Champion Ready to Talk to New Suitor
abstract: International Paper Co says rival, Champion International Corp, has agreed to talk about its unsolicited $6.2 billion offer, setting up potential bidding war with Finnish company UPM-Kymmene Oyj; International Paper offered to buy Champion for $64 a share in cash and stock two weeks ago; UPM-Kymmene's offer, made in February, is now valued at about $5.3 billion (S)

headline: Ariba, Bank of America Form Alliance
abstract: April 04, 2000

headline: Israeli High Court Orders Release of 8 Lebanese Prisoners
abstract: Israel's Supreme Court reverses itself, ruling that Israel is not justified in holding Lebanese detainees as bargaining chips for missing Israeli soldiers; court orders that 8 of 15 Lebanese detainees who have been imprisoned without charges for more than decade be released immediately; after court rules, Israeli prison authorities say they will release 13 of 15 detainees; two others, Mustafa al-Dirani and Sheik Abdel Karim Obeid, are high-ranking guerrilla leaders who are being held in secret location by army; Justice Min Yossi Beilin says government would try to retain them as security risks; Prime Min Ehud Barak expresses his opposition to prisoner release but says he would abide by court's ruling; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: I.M.F. to Consider Changes In Conditions Put on Loans  The International Monetary Fund, which has ordered developing nations to enact wrenching reforms as the price for emergency aid in recent years, is likely to curtail the demands it makes of clients who borrow money in the future, a senior fund official said.    Streamlining the conditions the I.M.F. imposes on borrowers is one of the changes Horst Kohler, the new managing director, is weighing as a panel he set up to study the agency's role finishes a draft report. [Page C2.]

headline: When Only a Code Warrior or XML Guru Will Do
abstract: History of exotic job titles in cyberspace industry discussed in light of current use of such titles to attract employees (M)

headline: Two-Way Radio Days
abstract: Andrew Greene letter on Apr 6 article cites benefits of using two-way radios

headline: Russia and Poland Seek to Heal Rift
abstract: Pres Vladimir Putin signals desire to improve Russia's relations with Poland, which were marked by public feuds earlier in year; influential Polish officials welcome overtures, but see more difficult times ahead; some Polish analysts say a new government is likely to take a softer line toward Moscow in any case (M)

headline: Printing Photos at Home
abstract: Letter by Craig Delsack responds to June 15 article on home-printed snapshops; says article did unfair comparison of printers

headline: Rambus Climbs Again as More Licensing Deals Are Seen
New South Korea Airport a Safety Challenge
abstract: SEOUL—  Congestion in the Air

headline: Parties Squabble Over Digital Signatures Bill
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Inflation Rate Flat in May, But Up Over Last 12 Months  The national inflation rate, which has been inching up this year, leveled off in May, the Labor Department reported.     The Consumer Price Index, the best known measure of American inflation, rose 0.1 percent in May. Measured over 12 months, however, the inflation rate through May was half a percentage point higher than it was last fall. Excluding energy and food prices, the index was up 0.2 percent in May. [Page C14.]

headline: Settlement Reported in Bond-Pricing Case
abstract: More than a dozen Wall Street securities firms, led by Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup, agree to pay more than $120 million to end long-running federal investigations into whether state and local governments nationwide were overcharged for Teasury securities they bought; with the settlement, Securities and Exchange Commission, Justice Department and Internal Revenue Service are wrapping up their investigations into practice known as yield burning; PaineWebber Group is paying about $26 million to US Treasury and to clients that issued municipal bonds; that amount ranks Paine Webber second only to Salomon Smith Barney, which is paying about $40 million (M)

headline: New Policy Irks Gorbachev
abstract: Former Pres Mikhail S Gorbachev disagrees with Russia's new national security doctrine that calls for first use of nuclear weapons in event of large-scale attack on Russia by conventional forces, or those employing weapons of mass destruction (S)

headline: Unilever Deal For Bestfoods Signals More Acquisitions
abstract: Bestfoods accepts Unilever's offer of $20.3 billion, or $73 a share, creating world's second-largest packaged foods company; Unilever will be rivaled only by Nestle, world's largest food maker; hopes that in acquiring Bestfoods that it can regain power with supermarkets that has eroded over the last two years; acquisition is likely to accelerate mergers in food business, with Nabisco Holdings and Quaker Oats among the likely takeover targets; analysts note that Bestfoods recent statement indicating possible merger with Campbell Soup Co appears to have been part of strategy to coax better offer from Unilever; photo of Bestfoods products; chart profiling both Bestfoods and Unilever; graphs on food company rankings within industry (L)

headline: CNNfn's President Faces Tough Fight In a New Arena; Varied Career Brings Journalist Up Against a Viewer Favorite
abstract: Interview with C Shelby Coffey 3d, president of CNNfn; he discusses efforts to compete in financial news arena against stronger CNBC; tables; photos (M)

headline: Microsoft Cites AT&T to Fight Breakup
abstract: Microsoft Corp lawyer, Brad Smith, says there is big difference between proposed breakup of Microsoft and AT&T's breakup in 1980's; says Microsoft, unlike AT&T, is operating in global marketplace, and if Microsoft is replaced as technology leader, its successor may not come from United States; both sides in Microsoft antitrust case are drawing on experience of AT&T to support their legal and political arguments; some of Microsoft's darkest predictions mirror arguments AT&T made 20 years ago--predictions that never came to pass; Microsoft, in invoking AT&T case to justify some of its arguments, is in some instances misstating record; photos (M)

headline: IBM, Nortel, Toshiba, Others to Start Tech B-to-B Marketplace
abstract: June 7, 2000

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro falls after Ernst Welteke, member of European Central Bank, predicts no interest-rate rise before September; in New York, euro settles at 95.35 cents, down from 95.96 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: Roadblock Seen In Sprint Merger With WorldCom
abstract: Staff of Justice Department's antitrust division recently recommended that government block proposed $115 billion merger of WorldCom Inc and Sprint; recommendation was made in 'fact memorandum' sent to Joel I Klein, assistant attorney general in charge of antitrust division, who has scheduled series of meetings with government lawyers and company executives to decide whether to accept memorandum's findings; talks are expected to last through most of summer and may lead to talks over what assets companies need to shed to satisfy regulators' concerns; photo of WorldCom chief executive Bernard J Ebbers and Sprint chief executive William T Esrey; photo (M)

headline: Economic Scene; The arrival of open-source software arouses researchers' curiosity on what motivates programmers to work free.
abstract: Virginia Postrel (Economic Scene) column on arrival of open-source computer software focuses on what motivates programmers to work free; says there are thousands of open-source projects, with most popular being Linux operating system created by Linus Torvalds; Prof Josh Lerner of Harvard Business School, Prof Jean Tirole of Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Eric S Raymond, programmer and movement observer, comment on what motivates programmers to volunteer their services and movement's impact on marketplace; photo (M)

headline: Import Goods Index Rises Again, Led by Oil and Raw Materials
abstract: Labor Department reports Import Price Index increased 0.3 percent in March after surging 2 percent in February; prices that businesses paid for imported goods rose as costs for oil and other raw materials increased; International Monetary Fund says global economy will probably grow 4.2 percent this year compared with growth of 3.3 percent in 1999 (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: F.T.C. Is Seeking Authority To Protect Privacy Online  Concluding that companies on the Internet have not properly protected the privacy of consumers, the Federal Trade Commission has decided to ask Congress for authority to impose tough consumer privacy safeguards.    The F.T.C. approved a staff recommendation in an unannounced vote to seek legislation giving it such authority. The action comes as the agency has stepped up investigations of several major Internet companies over their use of consumer data. It represents a sharp departure from the agency's previous policy of relying almost entirely on the industry to police itself. Democratic lawmakers in both the House and Senate, however, said this week that the prospects for final passage of any privacy measure were not strong. [Page A1.]

headline: Germany's Pledge to Close Nuclear Plants: That's Green Power
abstract: Government decision to close 19 nuclear power plants in Germany over next 20 years reflects power of environmentalist movement; agreement reached by Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's 'Red-Green' coalition sets out program for fastest elimination of nuclear energy ever pursued by a major economic power; plan would deprive Germany of current source of one-third of its electric power (M)

headline: Beirut's Unwanted Goal
abstract: Susan Sachs analysis holds that Lebanon and Syria seem strangely flustered by prospect that Israel will withdraw from southern Lebanon; maintains that from Lebanese Pres Emile Lahoud on down, promised Israeli retreat has been called everything from ruse to sinister plot aimed at igniting internal religious tensions; map (M)

headline: Fox Hopes to Turn Lurid TV into Web Gold
abstract: Fox creates Web site for lurid 'reality' shows it has forsworn to broadcast (S)

headline: ECOLAB TO REPURCHASE $200 MILLION OF ITS STOCK
abstract: Ecolab Inc will buy up to $200 million of its shares, roughly 4 percent of its stock outstanding (S)

headline: Microsoft Argues U.S. Already Rejected Breakup
abstract: Microsoft Argues U.S. Already Rejected Breakup

headline: PHILIPS TO SELL STAKE IN ASM
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics, Europe's second largest chip maker, will sell most of its stake in ASM Lithography Holding for about $2.87 billion (S)

headline: Investors File Suit Against Jenny Craig
abstract: Jenny Craig Inc, which operates more than 500 weight-loss centers, is sued by investors who say company's shares have been undervalued in proposed $25.6 million buyout offer by its founders, Sid and Jenny Craig (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises on speculation that higher interest rates will slow economic growth in US, reducing demand for its financial assets; in New York, dollar settles at 106.58 yen, down from 107.10; graph; chart (S)

headline: Again, Xerox Warns Wall St. About Its Quarterly Earnings
abstract: Xerox Corp warns second-quarter earnings will be below analysts' forecasts; stock falls 18 percent (M)0

headline: Economic Scene; Democracy has the edge when it comes to advancing growth.
abstract: Jeffrey Madrick (Economic Scene) column on Amartya Sen, author of book Development As Freedom, who argues that economic value of democracy should not be judged on its contribution to economic growth; says Sen believes democracy should be sought as economic end in itself, just like higher incomes; holds Sen argues that freedom is essential to full life; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Industrial Production -- April  Capacity Utilization -- April    TUESDAY  Consumer Price Index -- April  Housing Construction -- April

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of June 4 article about Congressional campaign of Larry Otis Graham of Chappaqua (NY); Graham is married to CNBC.com chief executive Pamela Thomas-Graham (S)

headline: DE BEERS IN BID FOR WINSPEAR
abstract: De Beers Consolidated Mines of South Africa makes bid worth 259 million Canadian dollars, or $176 million, for Winspear Diamonds of Vancouver, British Columbia, which controls diamond property in northern Canada; Winspear calls offer hostile and insufficient; graph (S)

headline: FIRST PLACE TO ACQUIRE FFY FOR ABOUT $72 MILLION
abstract: First Place Financial Corp will acquire FFY Financial Corp for $10.48 a share, total of about $72 million (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  LURIE, JACK
abstract: LURIE-Jack. The Board of Governors and members of Brae Burn Country Club record with great sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Jack Lurie. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife, Marjorie; his children, Ed, Ellen and Bill and to his grandchildren. Len Shendell, President Judith Tarter, Secretary

headline: Spy Trial of 13 Leaves the Jews of Iran Shaken
abstract: Charges of spying for Israel brought against 13 Jewish men has deeply shaken many of the 30,000 Jews in Iran, with some moved to willful silence and others to thoughts of emigration; case is drawing intense international interest, with Jewish and human rights groups criticizing secret proceedings and treatment of the accused, especially those paraded on state television to make confessions; many Jews say privately that spy case is reminder of how capricious Iranian government can be and how easily suspicions against a few Jews could affect lives of all in a country that regards Israel as its archenemy; situation in Hamadan, where only 35 Jews remain in what was once vibrant Jewish community, described; map; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: 'Friends' Stars Accept Deal That Will Keep Show on Air  Under pressure to take a deal worth more than $40 million a year each, or face cancellation of their series, the stars of the NBC comedy ''Friends'' agreed to a deal that will bring the show back for two more seasons.    The six stars of the show -- Lisa Kudrow, Courteney Cox, Jennifer Aniston, David Schwimmer, Matthew Perry and Matt LeBlanc -- accepted $750,000 an episode for the next two seasons as well as a higher percentage of future profits in the show. [Page C8.]

headline: FREESERVE'S STOCK JUMPS ON RUMOR
abstract: Stock of Britain's largest Internet service provider, Freeserve PLC, rises 24 percent after it is reported that T-Online International AG, Europe's biggest Internet service provider, wants to buy Freeserve from Dixons Group PLC for 6.5 billion pounds ($9.7 billion); T-Online, majority owned by Deutsche Telekom AG, plans to offer about 650 pence a share for Freeserve (S)

headline: Summit Glow Fades as Koreans Face Obstacles to Unity
abstract: Euphoria that followed summit meeting fades as North and South Korean leaders face reality of trying to reunite nations with common ancestry and language but drastically different ideologies and fortunes; Kim Jong Il releases number of provocative statements urging North Koreans not to stray from Communist principles; South Korea's main political opposition levies barrage of criticism against North Korea and peace plan; photo (M)

headline: A RUNOFF IS LIKELY
abstract: Pres Alberto K Fujimori of Peru falls short of first-round re-election victory in vote hotly contested by Alejandro Toledo, who says government is trying to steal election; Toledo and five other opposition candidates vow to fight election fraud; campaign has been riddled by smear tactics that crippled other challengers; pollsters say popular and international outcry over what appears to be growing and systematic attempt to steal vote peeled away Fujimori's support and robbed him of his expected first-round victory; Fujimori seeks unprecedented third term after defeating two terrorist insurrections and ending years of hyperinflation; Toledo has capitalized on disaffection campaign has created, as well as unhappiness over economy and appeal of his own personal story as one-time shoeshine boy who rose from poverty; photos (M)

headline: Top Executive at Gannett Stepping Down Gradually
abstract: Gannett, nation's largest newspaper publisher, says John J Curley will step down as chief executive in June, and names Douglas H McCorkindale, who has been company's president since 1997, as his successor; Curley, who is 61, will remain chairman until he retires next year, when McCorkindale, who is 60, will assume chairman's title; photo (M)

headline: Last week's stock debacle may point to a consolidation in the online booking business.
abstract: Last week's huge drop in stock prices might lead to consolidation in online travel booking business; Americans booked $6.5 billion in leisure and business travel online in 1999, almost triple amount booked in 1998, representing only 5 percent of all travel bookings (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Cisco's $662 Million Profit Tops Forecasts
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc says its third-quarter profit ended April 29 beat expectations; reports earnings of $662 million, compared with $636 million a year earlier; sales rose 55 percent, to $4.92 billion from $3.17 billion; president-chief executive John Chambers comments; photo (M)

headline: Two Mergers Highlight E-Commerce Trends
abstract: Vignette Corp to buy OnDisplay Inc in $1.7 billion stock swap and Web Methods Inc is buying Active Software Inc in stock deal valued at $1.3 billion as consolidation of business-to-business software market accelerates; analysts expect more such mergers as competitors expand into new product categories (M)

headline: 2 Companies Take Separate Paths To Speed Delivery of Web Pages
abstract: Inktomi and Akamai, leaders in Web-performance industry, are taking different approaches to technology of speeding Internet transmissions and to how they should be paid for services; Inktomi, with America Online as trophy client, aims to make Web traffic flow faster by storing or 'caching' most frequently requested data on network server computers nearest to people who request it; Akamai, with Yahoo among big clients, uses content distribution technique, with only first request going to Yahoo's main server and balance of page delivered from Akamai server with best link to user; diagram; graphs and tables of corporate data; photos (M)

headline: INTEL SEEKS ISRAELI AID
abstract: Intel Corp is seeking Israeli state financial assistance for expansion of its $1.6 billion chip factory in Kiryat Gat; company executives tell Finance Min Avraham Shochat that proposed $3 billion project would generate up to 3,000 new jobs and $2 billion in annual exports; Intel's current Kiryat Gat factory is subsidized by much criticized $600 million package of grants and tax credits (S)

headline: U.N. Warning AIDS Imperils Africa's Youth
abstract: UN report warns that about half of all 15-year-olds in African countries worst affected by AIDS will eventually die of disease even if infection rates drop substantially in next few years; if infection rates remain high, more than two-thirds of 15-year-olds will die in countries like Botswana; report is issued for International AIDS Conference in South Africa; countries like South Africa and Zimbabwe, where at least fifth of adults are infected would see deaths of about half of all people now aged 15; Dr Peter Piot warns that AIDS, spread in Africa mostly through heterosexual sex, is decimating families, destroying national economies and killing off so many teachers that education systems are undermined; Piot says $300 million in annual aid should be $2 billion; bright spots include Uganda, which has pushed infection rate down to 8 percent; rates for each country listed (M)

headline: FRENCH COMPANY AGREES TO A DEAL TO  BUY  SEAGRAM
abstract: Seagram Company reportedly agrees to acquisition by Vivendi SA, French conglomerate, for $34 billion in one of largest media deals ever that would end Bronfman family's control over Seagram which it has maintained since 1928; new company will be called Vivendi Universal and will be based in Paris; Seagram chief Edgar Bronfman Jr will become vice chairman; plans by Vivendi to sell Seagram's liquor business and to leverage other parts of company discussed; photo (M)

headline: Aid for Women's Ventures
abstract: FleetBoston Financial Corp, New England's largest bank and the eighth-largest bank in the country, says it will invest $2 billion in businesses owned by women in the Northeast over a five-year period; sets up Women Entrepreneurs' Connection in NY to provide financing and consulting services (S)

headline: Workers Plan Bias Lawsuits Against Nextel
abstract: More than 300 current and former employees of Nextel Communications Inc intend to file complaints of racial and sexual discrimination at the company; lawyers say they intend to file 25 complaints with Equal Employment Opportunity Commission against Nextel on behalf of workers in Colorado, Georgia, Illinois, New Jersey, Ohio and Tennessee; later in week, lawyers intend to file 25 additional complaints representing employees in states including Alabama, California, Florida and Virginia; lawyers intend to seek class-action status for lawsuit and intend to seek millions of dollars in damages; also intend to ask that Nextel be required to make multibillion-dollar commitment to sensitivity training and diversity in hiring and promotion (M)

headline: Business Travel; It's easy to focus on the world of airlines, but most business travel is done on the ground.
abstract: Business Travel column on business travel that is done on the ground; says Natigonal Business Travel Association says 51 percent of business travelers used their own car on their most recent business trip, and another 8 percent used a company car; National Business Travel Monitor survey by Yesawich, Pepperdine & Brown and Yankelovich Partners Inc shows more than half of business travelers said they used personal or company automobile on business trips (as opposed to those who flew to destination and rented a car) in 1999; survey shows two percent of all business travelers traveled by railroad (M)

headline: www.layoffs.com; Internet Work Force Has Its First Brush With Downsizing
abstract: Dozens of dot-com companies across country are unloading employees in effort to make a profit; layoffs signal end to unbounded optimism of some dot-com employees who flocked to start-ups in hopes of developing sudden wealth, but who now say they are approaching new job offers with more caution; very stock market that once held keys to new wealth may now be equally responsible not just for lowered expectations, but for lost jobs; analysts say reversal of fortune for many companies, and their employees, can be traced in part to stock market turmoil on April 14; when Nasdaq plunged that day, investors signaled they no longer would finance dot-coms that sought to grow at all costs, ignoring at least temporarily, concept that successful businesses take in more than they spend; Laura Schmidt, who has been laid off from ThirdAge Media, comments; graphs (M)

headline: An MP3 Player That Goes Clik With Technology From Iomega
abstract: Iomega Corp is collaborating with consumer electronics companies to produce a new kind of audio player that uses its relatively low-cost, mechanical Clik drive; RaveMP2300 digital media player, made by Sensory Science, will permit users to cheaply store downloadable music and other audio files for palm-size devices; photo (S)

headline: Israeli Printer-Maker Deal
abstract: NUR Macroprinters Ltd, Israeli maker of inkjet printers, agrees to buy digital printing company Salsa Digital Ltd of San Antonio for $30 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: A Powerful Banker's Other Hat
abstract: Profile of Bank of America chmn and chief exec Hugh L McColl Jr focuses on his forceful pursuit of liberal civic goals, at times over opposition of local politicians and some bank shareholders; McColl's willingness to pursue his civil rights and urban renewal goals nationally has helped make McColl Pres Clinton's favorite banker; McColl has had Clinton's ear since they met in 1992; those who do not share his enthusiasms grumble about McColl's 'heavy-handed social crusading'; photo (M),

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: EURO DOWN AGAIN. The euro fell further on expectations that a strong U.S. economy will lead to more interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve. In New York, the euro fell to 88.99 cents from 89.61 cents late Wednesday.

headline: Microsoft Announces Internet Tools to Control Web Privacy
abstract: Microsoft Announces Internet Tools to Control Web Privacy

headline: The Compulsively Connected
abstract: Steven A Ludsin letter on Mar 30 article urges people consumed by communications devices to turn them off occasionally

headline: Ireland May Sue for Smoking Illnesses
abstract: Irish government is taking aggressive steps that could result in Ireland being first European country to seek damages from tobacco companies for cost of treating smoking-related illnesses; Irish officials are seeking advice from people involved in US lawsuit settlements (M)

headline: CALPERS AND INVESTOR GROUP BUY RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPER
abstract: California Public Employee's Retirement System says it leads group of investors that agreed to pay $223 million for unit of British American Tobacco that develops residential communities in US; Calpers put up 90 percent of purchase price for Genstar Land Co and its partners, Newland Communities and Institutional Housing Partners, put up the rest (S)

headline: Hanover Journal; A World's Fair Beckons; the Superpower Declines
abstract: Hanover Journal on plans for Expo 2000, German's first world's fair; photo; map; air of distinctly un-German disorder prevails, with many of 170 national pavilions unfinished and minor fiascos erupting all the time; US, underwhelmed, is skipping event altogether (M)

headline: Microsoft Preparing A Reply on Breakup
abstract: On Wednesday, Microsoft must submit its reply to the government's proposal to split the company in two and offer its own suggested remedies in the antitrust case. Microsoft will not say precisely what its recommendations will be. But they are expected to consist mainly of proposals Microsoft has made repeatedly during settlement talks with the government over the last two years.

headline: Time Warner-Disney Fight Is a Boon for Satellite TV
abstract: The dispute between Time Warner and the Walt Disney Company that led to ABC's being blocked from 3.5 million homes earlier this week is proving to be a boon for the satellite television industry.    About 25,000 Time Warner subscribers have asked for the coupons that entitle them to receive free equipment from DirecTV, a unit of Hughes Electronics, which is a division of General Motors, and thousands more have subscribed to the Dish Network of EchoStar Communications.

headline: The Side Effects Of Surfing on the Job
abstract: Survey commissioned by Pogo.com, an online games service, finds nearly 10 percent of 1,000 people surveyed say their work performance has suffered as a result of the time they spend online, while an additional 13 percent blame Internet for their inability to stay focused at work (M)

headline: Crisis Grips Sri Lanka As Guerrillas Gain in North
abstract: The Sri Lankan cabinet took emergency steps tonight to save money to support the war effort at the northern tip of this island nation, where government forces are battling Tamil rebels -- and the rebels are winning.    The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, a guerrilla group that is notorious for its suicide bombers, today lobbed mortar fire into a strategic military base on Sri Lanka's northern peninsula in the latest phase of a powerful offensive.

headline: Jews Are Caught Up In the Turmoil in Iran
abstract: Thirteen Jews are to go on trial in Iran's Revolutionary Court, accused of spying for Israel. Jewish groups and human rights organizations have condemned the case as a political show trial aimed at frustrating President Khatami's attempts to develop warmer relations with some of the country's traditional enemies, including the United States.    Article, Page 12.

headline: The Tentacles of Technology
abstract: Foreign funds are resembling domestic ones in their commitment to technology, sometimes to same stocks; graphs (M)

headline: LSI LOGIC TO ACQUIRE HARDWARE COMPANY FOR $70 MILLION
abstract: LSI Logic Corp, Milpitas, Calif, maker of communications chips and circuits, says it will acquire IntraServer Technology Inc, Holiston, Mass, manufacturer of adapters for peripheral hardware, for about $70 million (S)

headline: Australians Seek a Role in Their Region : 'The White Tribe of Asia' ?
abstract: HONG KONG—  The nearly full-page picture shows three Australians, each with a beer bottle in his hand, each wearing shorts, sitting in a row of chairs. They are surrounded by muddy water up to their knees, and for all their nonchalance, they seem to be in the middle of a flood.

headline: Charities' Investing: Left Hand, Meet Right
abstract: Stephen Viederman, who until recently oversaw $90 million endowment of Jessie Smith Noyes Foundation, urges charities to align their investments with their social aims; insists foundations have responsibility to consider the 'social and environment consequences of their investments'; cites Bill and Melinda Gates Foundations' investments in Philip Morris bonds, despite stated aim of 'helping to improve people's lives though health and learning'; finds most foundations, liberal or conservative, seem to believe that maximizing investment returns to fund's charitable mission is their sole responsibility and do not engage much in shareholder activism; photos (L)

headline: MORE ON THE MARKET
abstract: STOCKS DROP IN ASIA -- Stocks fell sharply today in Japan, South Korea and Hong Kong as investors responded to Friday's rout in the United States. PAGE A17    WAITING FOR THE BELL -- Stock strategists were trying to divine what owners of technology shares are likely to do today after a weekend of brooding. PAGE C1

headline: Amid 11th-Hour Wrangling, Israel Releases 13 Lebanese
abstract: Israeli soldiers release 13 Lebanese detainees after Israeli Supreme Court rejects 11th-hour petition to keep them behind bars; men have spent years in prison without charges, held as 'bargaining chips' for missing Israeli soldiers; released men are mobbed by welcoming friends and relatives at Israeli-Lebanese border; photo (M)

headline: European Microsoft Case May Continue
abstract: European Microsoft Case May Continue

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of advertising account changes (S)

headline: To the Barricades, You Users of Laptops
abstract: Matt Richtel humorous comment on whether new Micro Scan Pen, made by Docu-Port, is truly a 'revolutionary' product; drawing (M)

headline: Brokers Find a Niche Escorting Novices Into the World of eBay
abstract: LIZ PARELLA had a big problem. She needed to sell a Baldwin baby grand piano that was taking up too much space in her Manhattan apartment. She got in touch with an antiques dealer, but the dealer offered her only $1,000, far less than what she thought the piano was worth.    By chance, Mrs. Parella, a secretary at a  financial management firm, saw a magazine advertisement for an eBay broker service. Although she knew about online auctions, at that point she had never used the Internet. On a whim, she decided to give the broker a call and subsequently entered the online auction market by proxy.

headline: Brownouts in Kenya Highlight Its Chaos and Misrule
abstract: Kenya's long-standing problems are approaching near-crisis, and Pres Daniel arap Moi, who has ruled for 22 years, refuses to accept any blame; economy is strangling from years of corruption and poor management; Kenya is so corrupt that World Bank and International Monetary Fund cut off aid three years ago; now a severe drought is choking region, and estimated 2.2 million people face serious prospect of starvation; Moi says he cannot control weather, but neighboring nations, hit by same weather, do not have nearly as many problems as Kenya, where electricity is in such short supply that people dine by candlelight half the time; photo (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: AUTONATION INC., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., named Craig Monaghan chief financial officer, suceeding Michael Karsner, who was named president and chief executive of ANC Rental Corp., the car-rental unit AutoNation plans to spin off in June. Mr. Monaghan had been chief financial officer at iVillage Inc.    McDERMOTT INTERNATIONAL INC., New Orleans, named Bruce Wilkinson president and chief operating officer. He had been interim president and chief executive at Proler International Inc. and Tyler Corp.

headline: Cambodia Agrees to Tribunal Setup for Khmer Rouge Trials
abstract: cambodia agrees to tribunal se

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: ASIA    INDONESIA: ACEH TRUCE -- The government and representatives of separatist rebels from Aceh Province signed an agreement described as a ''humanitarian pause,'' resulting in the first cease-fire in more than two decades. While both sides welcomed the truce, signed at an undisclosed location in Geneva, as a milestone, both sides were quick to qualify it. The rebels pledged to continue pushing for independence, and Jakarta ruled out recognizing the insurgents. The cease-fire will begin June 2.    Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

headline: NAVIGANT RETAINS LEHMAN BROS. TO ADVISE IT ON OPTIONS
abstract: Navigant Consulting Inc, whose shares have fallen about 90 percent in eight months, hires Lehman Brothers Inc to advise it on alternatives; names William Goodyear chairman and chief executive (S)

headline: OIL COMPANY REJECTS HOSTILE BID
abstract: Directors of Ulster Petroleum Ltd of Calgary, Alberta, reject hostile takeover bid valued at 512 million Canadian dollars ($353 million) from Hunt Oil Co of Dallas and have hired financial advisers to find better offer; graph (S)

headline: Proposal on ABM: 'Ready to Work With Russia'
abstract: Excerpts from document that America negotiators have presented to Russians with proposals for amending 1972 antiballistic missile treaty, in order to alow United States to build limited national missile defense system (M)

headline: PrivateSector; Selling Natural Food to the Crowd
abstract: Profile of and interview with Irwin D Simon, chef exec of Hain Foods; Simon has acquired half-dozen natural-foods producers in last three years; his goal for Hain is to acquire as many of companies as possible, build the brands into household names through improved packaging and marketing, and make natural foods as essential to American grocery stores as, say, soft drinks or paper towels; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Purchase of Robert Fleming By Chase Is Seen This Week  Robert Fleming Holdings, one of Britain's last independent banks, is expected to announce this week that it will be acquired by Chase Manhattan for close to $:5 billion, or nearly $8 billion, executives close to the talks said.    That price is higher than most analysts expected when reports of the negotiations first emerged last month. [Page C20.]

headline: Argentina's President Wins Reform of Rigid Labor Code
abstract: Opposition-controlled Argentine Senate gives Pres Fernando de la Rua a much-needed lift by passing his labor reform bill, which is intended to lower 14 percent unemployment rate by reducing labor costs for businesses and curtailing power of big labor; overwhelming vote of approval caps six weeks of intense political maneuvering and sometimes violent labor union protests that made new de la Rua government look increasingly unadept as cabinet ministers publicly second-guessed themselves (M)

headline: An Electronic Newsletter Rattles And Amuses Chicago's Start-Ups
abstract: Ron May's May Report, newsletter on Chicago-area dot.coms, has become one of most influential high-tech publications in Midwest; newsletter, e-mailed free to some 15,000 subscribers and posted on Web site, is odd mixture of news, gossip, job listings and e-mail from readers and personal and philosophical musings from May; many executives charge May with shoddy journalism, holding he publishing rumors that then filter into mainstream media; May defends practices; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Will Oppose World Bank Loans to Iran
abstract: Clinton administration opposes $232 million in loans to Iran, first offered by World Bank to Iran in seven years; says bank executive board will likely approve loans, despite United States lobbying of its European allies (M)

headline: Insurer Fighting Microsoft Over Claims
abstract: Zurich American Insurance, Microsoft Corp's primary insurer, wants to bar company from claiming coverage for cost of defending barrage of private antitrust lawsuits; insurer filed suit in Federal District Court in Washington asking judge to declare that its general liability policy does not cover legal expenses caused by Microsoft's antitrust problems; Microsoft already has started submitting insurance claims for cost of defending about 140 private suits (S)

headline: Jack Is Put Through the Wringer, So You Won't Be
abstract: Several companies and universities develop 'intelligent' virtual humans, computer simulations that are programmed to move and even respond like people; such simulations are used for tasks like training and design production; software users equipped with virtual reality helmet or video screen can even see through virtual human's eyes; photos (M)

headline: AMAZON HEAD FILES FOR FIRST SALE OF SHARES SINCE '98
abstract: Jeffrey Bezos, chief executive of Amazon.com Inc, files to sell 380,000 shares of company, in his first sale since 1998 (S)

headline: CREO CLOSES STOCK PURCHASE OF SCITEX FOR $551 MILLION
abstract: Creo Products Inc closes acquisition of digital preprint and print-on-demand assets of Scitex Corp for 13.25 million Creo shares, valued at about $551 million (S)

headline: A Portrait of the Artist As an Internet Marketer
abstract: Problems faced by authors and artists in trying to market their works on Internet discussed; Eve Smith, project manager for Open Studio: The Arts Online, says slogan 'if you build it, they will come,' does not apply to artists who leap onto Internet with single-serving Web site and expect to be discovered; Open Studio is four-year-old project financed by Benton Foundation and National Endowment for Arts that helps authors, artists and arts groups learn how to use Web to promote their work (www.openstudio,org); other Web sites that assit artists and authors also noted; photo (M)

headline: Bank of America Says It Is Planning To Open Israel Office
abstract: Bank of America Corp says it plans to open office in Israel to serve country's growing computer, telecommunications and other technology businesses; two competitors, Citibank Inc and HSBC Holdings PLC, have already announced plans to open branches in Tel Aviv; entry by foreign banks will pose challenge to Bank Hapoalim Ltd and Bank Leumi Le-Israel Ltd, country's two biggest financial institutions (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRY, JOHN J.
abstract: BARRY-John J. On April 9, 2000. Beloved husband of the Honorable Maryanne Trump Barry. Devoted father of Barbara Coates and stepfather of Dr. David W. Desmond. Cherished grandfather of Laura and Ryan Coates and Robert Desmond. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street Tuesday and Wednesday 3-5PM and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 84 Street, Thursday 10AM. Interment private. Contributions in his name may be made to The Society of Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, 1233 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021.

headline: Nielsen Releases Local Internet Data
abstract: First monthly data on Internet use in 20 largest local markets from Nielsen Net Ratings, Internet measurement service, show interesting variations among different parts of country; in the study, compiled in February, four of five top local markets with percentage of people with Internet access were on West Coast; in terms of Internet audiences, total number of people online, number 1 market was New York (S)

headline: Gates Appears in Microsoft Television Ad
abstract: Microsoft Corp has begun television advertising campaign featuring its chairman William H Gates, pointing to Microsoft's record of innovation and determination to carry on; 30-second commercial does not directly mention antitrust case brought by Justice Department and 19 states; new commercial is first time Gates has been used on television in his own company's advertising; photo (M)

headline: Stock Offerings Are Set
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Community Health Systems Inc., Brentwood, Tenn., an initial public offering of 18.8 million shares, 15.9 million in the United States and Canada. Merrill Lynch.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Syrians Bury Only Leader Many of Them Ever Knew
abstract: Syrian Pres Hafez al-Assad is buried in hometown of Qardaha after daylong rites across nation; funeral procession, which began in Damascus, draws tens of thousands of people; French Pres Jacques Chirac is only Western head of state to attend; photo (M)

headline: Milton Freeman, 88; Wrote Securities Fraud Law
abstract: Milton Victor Freeman, senior partner in Washington law firm of Arnold & Porter and an architect of 1940's regulations against securities fraud, dies at age 88; photo (M)

headline: WATSON PHARMACEUTICALS AGREES TO BUY A RIVAL
abstract: Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc to buy rival Schein Pharmaceuticals Inc, drugmaker with losses and regulatory troubles, for at least $644.2 million (S)

headline: Indonesia Strengthens Navy to Unify and Protect Its Islands
abstract: Jakarta — President Abdurrahman Wahid, in his policy speech after being elected in October, promised to enlarge and strengthen the Indonesian Navy, which was long treated by former President Suharto as a poor relation to the politically powerful army.

headline: IRELAND ADMONISHED ON INFLATION
abstract: European Economic and Monetary Affairs Commissioner, Pedro Solbes, criticizes Ireland for its accelerating inflation rate; says government should act to prevent the economy from overheating; Irish inflation reached 4.9 percent in April (S)

headline: Fujimori Proposes Plans to Strengthen Democratic Safeguards
abstract: Peru's Pres Alberto K Fujimori promises new efforts to strengthen democratic safeguards in reaction to flurry of international criticism over his re-election in vote widely viewed as flawed; pledges to reduce size and powers of intelligence service and to overhaul judicial system (M)

headline: Iran's Jewish Minority Caught Up in Turmoil
abstract: Focus on plight of Iran's Jewish minority, which has survived in City of Shiraz for past 2,700 years but currently finds itself squeezed in conflict between hard-line Muslim hierarchy that controls judiciary and reformers backing Pres Mohammad Khatami's efforts at liberalization; local Jewish leaders are troubled by upcoming trial before Revolutionary Court of 13 of their number, who are accused of spying for Israel, calling it worst event in anyone's memory to befall dwindling minority; condemn case, along with human rights officials, as political show trial aimed at frustrating Khatami's attempts to develop warmer relations with some of country's traditional enemies, including US; photo (M)

headline: F.T.C. Approves Merger of BP Amoco and ARCO
abstract: Federal Trade Commission, 5-0, approves BP Amoco's purchase of Atlantic Richfield Co; vote allows BP Amoco to acquire ARCO in deal valued at about $30 billion (S)

headline: British Internet Provider to Pay Physicist Who Says E-Bulletin Board Libeled Him
abstract: Demon Internet, British Internet service provider, agrees to pay $25,000 and court costs to Laurence Godfrey, physicist who says he was libeled in messages posted on electronic bulletin boards carried by company; Demon's decision to settle case, in face of mounting evidence that it would not have won in court, is significant; it establishes that British Internet service providers are liable for messages posted on forums they carry, regardless of where messages originate; it will obligate providers to respond quickly to complaints about messages, and remove those that might be libelous (M)

headline: This Call's for You
abstract: Ray Fisher letter on buying toy cell phone and using it to show noisy talkers just how rude they are (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls as traders buy dollars and euros in case Japan wins solid support for weaker yen at meeting of seven major industrial nations on April 15; dollar settles at 107.09 yen, up from 106.47; graph; chart (S)

headline: With Peace Effort a Peripheral Issue, Jordan's King Visits Israel
abstract: King Abdullah II of Jordan pays his first official visit to Israel, meeting in Eilat with Prime Min Ehud Barak; at king's request, talks focus on economic issues, not regional peace talks; Abdullah is actively courting Israeli high-tech entrepreneurs (M)

headline: 'Millionaire' Will Face 'Survivor,' Again
abstract: ABC will again pit Who Wants to Be a Millionaire against CBS's Survivor, which did remarkably well against Millionaire with young viewers on its first night; any drop in powerhouse status of Millionaire could have serious financial implications for ABC; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A favorable Supreme Court ruling lifts health care company stocks, but more lawsuits loom.
abstract: Supreme Court's ruling that allows managed care insurers to offer financial incentives to doctors who limit costs by restricting care lifts health care company stocks; Supreme Court leaves open whether insurance companies can be punished under federal pension and health care law for failing to disclose to consumers that they use such inventives and other business methods that affect patient care (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Nasdaq Rises Again as It Ends Its Worst Month Since '98
abstract: Nasdaq index rises 86.63 points to close at 3,860.66, ending its worst month since 1998; graph (M)

headline: Lowe Lintas Drops KPMG's Account
abstract: Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide resigns United States account of KPMG International (S)

headline: INGERSOLL-RAND TO BUY GERMAN SOFTWARE MAKER
abstract: Ingersoll-Rand Co acquires Interflex Datensysteme, privately held German software and manufacturing company; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FPL GROUP INC., Juno Beach, Fla., owner of the largest utilities in Florida, said it bought the rights to build a natural-gas-fired 500-megawatt power plant in Johnston, which is near Providence, R.I., from Reliant Energy Inc., Houston, for an undisclosed price.    VERISIGN INC., Mountain View, Calif., a maker of online security software, said it was chosen by Pennsylvania to provide encryption services for the state's law-enforcement agencies over the Internet.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper rises as falling inventories signal strengthening demand from manufacturers; copper for July rises 2.1 cents, or 2.6 percent, to 84.05 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Sony Sets U.S. Debut of PlayStation 2
abstract: Sony Corp will begin selling PlayStation 2 in US in late October for suggested retail price of $299 (S)

headline: WESTFIELD UNIT IS ACQUIRING OLD GUARD FOR $45 MILLION
abstract: Old Guard Group Inc agrees to be acquired by Ohio Farmers Insurance Co for about $45 million; Ohio Farmers is unit of Westfield Companies (S)

headline: Reasonable and Customary, But in Whose Eyes?
abstract: Money & Medicine column by Jennifer Steinhauer discusses advantages, for those not in managed care, of establishing flexible medical spending account--plan that lets pretax dollars be set aside for paying medical bills; says one drawback is that any money set aside must be spent in that year, or lost at end of year; drawing (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Construction Spending -- Feb.    TUESDAY  Leading Indicators -- Feb.

headline: The Inkjet Color Image, Born in a Rainbow of Tiny Drops
abstract: TEN years ago, the computer industry gave desktop computer owners a choice of options when it came to printers. But it was pretty much a Henry Ford kind of choice: you could print in any color as long as it was black.     At the time, most people used typewriter-style daisy-wheel printers or clacking dot-matrix printers to put ink on paper. If you wanted a silent printer, your cheapest option was an inkjet machine -- and back then, that would cost you more than $1,000.

headline: Zenith Electronics Names a New Agency
abstract: Zenith Electronics names Cramer-Krasselt to handle its advertising account; billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million (Advertising column) (S)

headline: SHARES FALL AS STAFF LEASING DROPS SALE OPTION
abstract: Shares of Staff Leasing Inc fall 28 percent after company says it plans to remain independent after evaluating buyout options and other alternatives; shares close at $4.1875, down $1.625 (S)

headline: Chief Is Named At Ameritrade
abstract: Ameritrade Holding Corp says Thomas K Lewis Jr has been appointed chief executive, succeeding founder J Joe Ricketts, who remains chairman (S)

headline: SENATE APPROVES $1 BILLION TO AID COLOMBIA MILITARY
abstract: Senate endorses nearly $1 billion in aid to Colombia to help equip and train security forces to combat drug traffickers in nation where narcotics trade and guerrilla insurgency support each other; aid is in addition to $300 million in earlier military bill; House and Senate leaders meet on reconciling their competing aid packages and finding legislative vehicle for eventual compromise that both chambers can vote on before July 4 recess; Senate critics warn aid could ensnare United States in open-ended civil war (M)

headline: A Resurrected Picture of the Vietnam War, From the Other Side
abstract: American researchers Doug Niven and Chris Riley are gathering selection of photos of Vietnam War taken by photographers on Communist side and have tracked down in Vietnam dozen of aging photographers who risked their lives to take photos; are producing new visual record of war; seven of photographers discuss their work, interviews; photos (M)

headline: Challenges Lure New Workers
abstract: WetFeet.com survey finds college and graduate students rank challenging work as top priority in career decisions, followed closely by training for future work; salary ranks fourth (M)

headline: Teacher, Cheerleader and C.E.O.
abstract: Betsy D Holden, 44, who last week was named chief executive of Kraft Foods, has wanted to run a business as chief exec since she was in college and never saw her gender as an obstacle; her new post makes her one of highest-ranking women in corporate America, putting her in charge of largest US food packager, with more than $18 billion in revenue and some of world's most recognizable brands; a graduate of Northwesten University's Kellogg Graduate School of Management, Holden regrets that sometimes more emphasis is put on fact that she is a woman than on results she delivers; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro stabilizes somewhat as traders pull back from sharp sell-off day before that sent currency to new low; in New York, euro settles at 92.33 cents, up from 92.08 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: Resume Virus Seen Causing Little Damage
abstract: US authorities say malicious e-mail computer program masquerading as resume will likely cause relatively little damage, though FBI warns workers to remain cautious about unexpected e-mail attachments (S)

headline: NEXTLINK BUYING FIBER OPTIC NETWORKS IN EUROPE
abstract: Nextlink Communications Inc agrees to buy multiple European fiber optic networks from Level 3 Communications Inc for $306 million; Nextlink will receive $400 million investment from Forstmann Little & Co, investment vehicle of buyout specialist Nicholas C Forstmann; investment will increase Forstmann Little's stake in Nextlink to 10 percent (S)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for BIJAN NAMDAR ZANGANEH; Toward Oil Price Stability, Step by Step
abstract: Iranian petroleum minister Bijan Namdar Zanganeh, like other OPEC representatives, craves oil price stability after enduring dips and rises of the past 18 months; Zanganeh had opposed OPEC production increase in March, complaining of undue pressure from US, but backs latest production increase of 708,000 barrels a day; interview; photo (M)

headline: Montenegro Election Seen as Barometer on Tie to Serbia
abstract: Local elections held in Montenegro today, closely watched as a barometer of this small republic's future, suggested that it remains perilously divided between following the West, or staying with President Slobodan Milosevic and Serbia.    Ostensibly, voters in the Montenegrin capital, Podgorica, and in the seaside town of Herceg Novi, were simply electing new mayors and local assemblies.

headline: Citron Haligman Gets Palm Account
abstract: Palm Inc names Citron Haligman Bedecarre to handle its advertising account, with billings estimated at $70 million (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Investing; Out on a Limb, and Carrying an Ever-Heavier Bag of Stocks
abstract: Thomas Galvin, chief investment officer for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, discusses his recommendation that clients put 90 percent of their assets into stocks, a daring move even for a staunchly bullish investment strategist; says investors should be in position to catch the rebound from the technology-stock sell-off; photo; graph (M)

headline: FUNCO ISSUES A DEADLINE FOR BUYOUT OFFER
abstract: Funco gives Electronics Boutique Holdings five days notice to sweeten its $110 million buyout offer, or it will accept higher bid from Barnes & Noble (S)

headline: Minsk Journal; Sculpting a Monument to a Vanished Democracy
abstract: Sculptor Ivan Y Misko plans to unveil bust of Gennadi Karpenko at late democracy advocate's tomb in rite that will be political act in authoritarian Belarus; Karpenko, until death in April 1999 under mysterious circumstances, led forces seeking to oust Pres Aleksandr G Lukashenko; Karpenko's wife says family, harassed by security forces, will leave nation after rite; photo (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE; CZECH BANK SEIZED
abstract: Czech central bank seizes control of Investicniï

headline: U.N. Clears Way for Peacekeepers in Southern Lebanon
abstract: Sec Gen Kofi Annan certifies Israel's withdrawal from southern Lebanon, opening way for more robust UN peacekeeping presence along border; photo; Lebanon charges Israel is stilly occupying some Lebanese territory (M)

headline: A Place to Peek Into Lost Luggage
abstract: Michelle Slatalla (Online Shopper) article discusses online shopping site called Unclaimedbaggage.com where person can actually buy contents of unclaimed suitcases left at airports; evaluates site, which is operated by Unclaimed Baggage Center; Bryan Owens, owner, comments (M)

headline: Phone Giant Buys Lycos for $12.5 Billion
abstract: Lycos agrees to be bought by Terra Networks, Internet unit of Spanish telephone giant Telefonica, for $12.5 billion in stock; combination includes partnership with Bertelsmann AG, which agrees to spend $1 billion over next five years to promote its books and music sales operations and its various media properties on Terra Lycos, as new portal and combined company will be known; it is also partner in America Online's European operations (M)

headline: SHAKE-UP IN INDONESIA
abstract: Indonesia's Pres Abdurrahman Wahid dismisses key economic ministers after being pressed by International Monetary Fund managing director Stanley Fischer to produce more cohesive econonomic policies and speed financial and economic changes; Pres Wahid says Trade and Industry Min Yusuf Kalla will be replaced by Indonesia's ambassador to Singapore Luhut Pandjaitan; photo (S)

headline: Erich Mielke, Powerful Head of Stasi, East Germany's Vast Spy Network, Dies at 92
abstract: Erich Mielke, former head of East German security agency known as the Stasi, dies at age 92; career sketch; photo (L)

headline: 'Sopranos' Remains Boss at Season's End
abstract: HBO hit series The Sopranos finishes second 13-episode season with ratings up over 60 percent, even though show did not get surge of media coverage that accompanied first season; HBO chairman Jeffrey L Bewkes says show helps boost subscriber list; plans to start airing third season next Mar; table of top prime-time broadcast shows; photos (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; INTERVENTION AT AEROMEXICO
abstract: Mexican government takes control of Aeromexico, nation's largest airline, minutes after its flight attendants go on strike; airline is working normally; nearly 1,500 striking flight attendants are told by government managers to stay on job while their union representatives negotiate with carrier for 16 percent wage increase, pension benefits and day-care center that management promised last time attendants went on strike in June 1998 (S)

headline: College Offers Incentive to Log Off
abstract: College Offers Incentive to Log Off

headline: Small Booksellers Seek Browsers Online
abstract: Two new Web sites built on very different business models are planned to promote independent booksellers; American Booksellers Association plans Booksense.com, which will act as hub site for individual Web sites of hundreds of stores; Steven T Brill will offer Contentville, site on which independent stores will provide editorial content for fee, not sell books, and get equity stake in company should it go public; sales graph; photo (M)

headline: Japanese Unemployment at Record High Ahead of Elections
abstract: Number of Japanese workers looking for jobs climbed to record high in February, casting another shadow over ruling party's prospects ahead of election that must be held by October; government officials warn that joblessness in next few months may be even higher; unemployment rate increased to 4.9 percent, as bankruptcies rose and companies trimmed jobs in aftermath of economic downturn last fall and winter; economy lost 160,000 jobs in February, leaving record 3.3 million people looking for work; several economists say unemployment figures almost ensure that government will create supplemental spending budget to keep economy moving, even though Parliament recently approved record 85 trillion yen budget for fiscal year 2000, which begins April 1; graph (M)

headline: SHAREHOLDER GROUP WITHDRAWS BID FOR HAYES LEMMERZ
abstract: Hayes Lemmerz International Inc says its majority shareholders withdrew their $131.3 million bid for company because sides cannot reach agreement on price; shareholder group led by Joseph Littlejohn & Levy in January offered $21 a share for 25 percent of common stock it does not already own (S)

headline: Going From Carmen Sandiego To an Online Recruiting Site
abstract: Group of former Broderbund Software engineers, including Broderbund co-founder Douglas Carlston, have formed ICplanet, online recruiting site that uses sophisticated search technology to match recruiters and managers with temporary contractors in number of fields (M)

headline: Tokyo Journal; TV Invents What Japan Sorely Lacks: Impoliteness
abstract: One of Japan's most popular television programs is Strange Things About the Japanese, weekly show in which Japanese-speaking foreigners mix idiocy and bully boy cruelty to criticize life in Japan and Japanese people in general; show slyly uses foreigners to criticize aspects of society that much of Japanese news media treats with kid gloves; show works as Japanese entertainment, unthreateningly highlighting country's unusual situation as island of high prosperity inhabited by provincial, nearly homogenous and inwardly turned people; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar is mixed as US stock prices rebound; in New York, euro settles at 95.38 cents, down from 95.96 cents on April 14; dollar trades at 104.26 yen, down from 105.09; graph; chart (S)

headline: Change Jobs Like Clothes? Click Here
abstract: Job applicants and employers are increasingly turning to Internet, which has mushroomed with e-cruiting sites; electronic recruiting sites pushed Web hiring into mainstream by spending millions of dollars on high-profile commercials encouraging job seekers to post their resumes without cost; these companies let job seekers search sites by category and location and forward their data to listed employers electronically; photos (M)

headline: Surge in Wireless Customers Bolsters AT&T Unit's Revenue
abstract: AT&T says revenue at its wireless unit rose 41 percent in first quarter to $2.2 billion, compared with $1.56 billion in period a year earlier; net income undisclosed (M)

headline: CHINA INDICATING CAUTION ON TAIWAN
abstract: Chinese leaders tell Clinton administration they will adopt 'wait and see' attitude toward Taiwan's new president, and they are open to resuming dialogue with estranged island; Chinese have decided, at least for time being, to try to reach accommodation with government of Pres-elect Chen Shui-bian, who has only recently muted his call for independence from China; American Congressional leaders say any flare-up in tension between China and Taiwan would almost certainly derail Clinton administration's hopes of winning passage of measure granting China permanent trading rights in American market (M)

headline: Ratings That Know What You're Looking at, and When
abstract: Hillary Appelman article on Internet audience rating business; notes companies can track every link followed by their thousands of volunteer panelists as they surf Web and know when users stop interacting with computer; Media Metrix Inc and Nielsen/Net Ratings compete to become dominant company in field (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: New Wave of Growth in Asia Is Reminiscent of 1980's  Less than three years after a plunge in the value of Thailand's currency set in motion a devastating economic crisis across much of Asia, the region is riding a wave of growth reminiscent of the Asian miracle of the 1980's.    The latest evidence of the resurgence came with a report that Hong Kong's economic output rose 14.3 percent in the first three months of the year. It was the territory's fastest quarter of growth since 1987, and seemed to make the Asian crisis a distant memory. [Page A1.]

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of May 11 letter to editor in Circuits, regarding Web address for Antiquarian Booksellers' Assn of America

headline: 'Seinfeld' second bananas are enjoying second careers.
abstract: Supporting actors in Seinfeld, popular television series that broadcast last episode two years ago, are being featured in wide array of advertisements; such interest among marketers and agencies in characters with smaller roles is unusual after show ends production; photo (M)

headline: Shares Fall on Profit Taking and the Fed's Rate Warning
abstract: Stocks decline as investors take some profits and re-examine potential effect of the Federal Reserve's half-point increase in interest rates; Dow Jones industrial average falls 164.83, to 10,769.74; Nasdaq composite index declines 72.61, to 3,644.96; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declines 18.24, to 1,447.80; graph; chart on some stocks with large percentage gains and losses (M)

headline: Labor Issues Could Thwart Airlines' Plans
abstract: Labor unions have been thorn in side of UAL Corp and US Airways Group, and now that two airlines are planning to combine, experts wonder if unions have enough power to squash deal; experts say airline unions are so powerful that they could pose huge problems not only in voting to approve UAL's proposed takeover of US Airways, but in determining how and whether two major airlines can unite; United Airlines employees control more than 50 percent of airline, and most of its employees are members of one of several unions, like Air Line Pilots Association; photo (M)

headline: Hot Seat Awaits New Chief At P.& G.
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin, Market Insight column, interviews Merrill Lynch analyst Heather Hay on ouster of Procter & Gamble chief exec Durk I Jager after 18-month tenure, task facing Jager's successor, A G Lafley, and prospects for company; notes Hay predicts Lafley will focus on core businesses and be less inclined toward risk-taking; photo (M)

headline: Industry Is Cool To Frequent Disclosure
abstract: Investment Company Institute reacts coolly to request that it endorse more frequent disclosure of mutual-fund portfolios; 60-year-old SEC rule requires funds to disclose their holdings twice a year, though some funds voluntarily do so more often (M)

headline: 'Leading Edge' Principles
abstract: Dennis N T Perkins, author of Leading at the Edge, distills 10 rules for leadership from experience of Sir Ernest Shakleton during ill-fated Antarctic expedition; photo (M)

headline: Kirshenbaum Gets Hilfiger Fragrances
abstract: Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners is named to create domestic and international advertising campaigns for Tommy Hilfiger fragrance line sold by Aramis division of Estee Lauder Cos; fragrances, previously handled by AG Worldwide, have been unassigned since Aug (S)

headline: Harry J. Volk, 94, a Bank Executive Known for Innovations
abstract: Harry J Volk, finance executive whose impact was felt as much in world of philanthropy as in business, dies at age 94; photo (M)

headline: CHINA TELECOM NET FALLS
abstract: China Telecom (Hong Kong) says 1999 profit fell 30 percent because of writeoff of 8.24 billion yuan on older network equipment; company earned net profit of 4.8 billion yuan in 1999, compared with profit of 6.9 billion yuan in 1998 (S)

headline: Judge Backs Search Engine's Use of Copyrighted Images
abstract: Federal Judge Gary A Taylor has ruled that copyrighted images used by Ditto.com to build index for image-based Internet search engine are not protected by copyright laws because use is 'less exploitative' than traditional commercial uses; Leslie A Kelly, whose photographs were used without permission, is appealing (M)

headline: Ford and Toyota Test the Sale of Cars Online in Canada
abstract: Canada has become laboratory for automobile industry's experiment with selling cars to consumers over Internet; Canadian subsidiaries of Ford Motor and Toyota Motor have established test Web sites to let consumers in three regions of country log onto Internet to buy vehicles--tests that could foreshadow companies' global strategies (M)

headline: Headline TK
Wealthy Nations Agree On Changes in I.M.F.
abstract: Finance ministers of Group of 7 wealthy nations approve United States proposal for International Monetary Fund to charge variable interest rates to discourage nations from borrowing too often and to spur them to repay loans quickly; move only partially addresses concerns of critics who want IMF to phase out long-term lending in favor of short-term emergency loans that were fund's original mandate (M)

headline: Shaking Things Up in Japan Inc.
abstract: Profile of Tatsuyuk Saeki, president and chief executive of Nasdaq Japan, National Assn of Securities Dealers' biggest effort so far to go global; Nasdaq Japan, which begins trading June 19, will cater to small companies that would otherwise be unable to find funding in Japan's clubby, hidebound and heavily bureaucratized financial system; Saeki intends Nasdaq Japan to radically overhaul Japanese capital market and initiate revolution in the way Japan Inc functions, breaking up cozy relationship between government, banks and industry; photo (M)

headline: CORNING ACQUIRES REST OF INTELLISENSE FOR $500 MILLION
abstract: Corning Inc to buy 67 percent of IntelliSense Corp it does not already own for $500 million in stock (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Ice for a Hot Economy?
abstract: News analysis of stock market sell-off and possible effect on US economy; some economists believe economy will cool quickly since crash will have much more immediate impact on consumer spending than interest rate hikes (M)

headline: A Tangled Web
abstract: Letter by Judith Stein Coleman responds to April 13 article on Priceline grocery service policies; opposes idea of making illegal product substitutions

headline: Pack a Bag, Then Pack a Handheld P.D.A. With Travel Plans
abstract: Advice for travelers on using handheld personal digital assistants to keep track of travel related data; wide range of travel information is available for handhelds; photo (M)

headline: It Takes One to Tango on This Site
abstract: Larry Carroll, a software engineer at Boeing Co, comments on the online manual he created to teach the tango; photo (S)

headline: MEDICAL ASSURANCE IS SET TO ADD PROFESSIONALS GROUP
abstract: Medical Assurance Inc will purchase Professionals Group Inc for $232 million plus debt; this creates third-largest US medical malpractice insurer (S)

headline: EMC TO REVISE PLAN TO BUY I.B.M. HARD DRIVES
abstract: EMC Corp drops plan to buy $3 billion of hard drives from IBM, citing IBM production delays (S)

headline: Calling Novel an Insult to Islam, Students in Cairo Battle Police
abstract: Police in Cairo, Egypt, clash with students protesting 17-year-old novel they charge insults Islam; novel Banquet of Seaweed by Syrian writer Haider Haider was first published in Cyprus in 1983; was reprinted by Egypt's Ministry of Culture in 1999 to promote major works of modern Arabic literature (S)

headline: Warned by the Music Industry, Web Site Files Suit
abstract: MP3Board.com Inc files lawsuit against Recording Industry Assn of America asking Federal District Court, San Jose, to declare that MP3Board.com should not be held liable for copyright infringement if it provides results of automated Internet search that may include pirated copyrighted works; Recording Industry Assn, which has complained to MP3Board.com, says results of its searches turn up hundreds of links to priated songs; legal experts say case has profound implications because association is seeking to hold MP3Board.com liable for linking to copyrighted material produced during an automated Web search (M)

headline: Eritrean Town Is Empty After Ethiopians Take Control
abstract: Ethiopia takes reporters on tour of territory captured since it mounted offensive in border dispute with Eritrea; says it wants to end war quickly because of cost; tour shows fighting continues; Eritrea denies Ethiopia has pushed far into its territory, holding lines remain fluid; map; photo (M)

headline: NEW OFFER FOR ICOPAL
abstract: Group that includes Carlisle Companies of Syracuse and Caik Holding, agrees to buy Icopal, Danish maker of building materials, for 4 billion kroner ($520 million), beating bid from Trelleborg AB of Sweden; Icopal stock price graph (S)

headline: Antitrust Alliance Not Quite Solid
abstract: Justice Dept and 19 state attorneys general are at odds about antitrust suits they filed together against Microsoft Corp almost two years ago; states reportedly feel Justice Dept is trying to ram through inadequate settlement proposal without involving them; lawyer close to settlement talks says states are tring to snatch credit for sinking talks in part because they feel left out; Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson has made it clear that he wants state and federal litigants to cooperate, and to present to him only one remedy proposal (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Mexico Farmers Protest Cheap Imports From El Norte
abstract: Mexican dairy farmers have grown increasingly angry over powdered milk imports from US that they say are filling supermarket shelves and destroying local production; their recent street demonstrations in Mexico City, notably mass dumping of rancid milk they could not sell, have highlighted broader problems for many Mexican dairy and grain producers who feel threatened by price competition from abroad because of Mexico's increasingly open trade policies; some farmers blame Mexico's trade ministry for allowing these imports to flood into country; milk dispute has arisen partly over wrinkle in Mexico's trade law that allows Mexican dairy bottlers to import subsidized powdered milk as 'food preparations' to avoid higher tariff on powdered milk; dairy farmers spokesman Felipe Zedillo Vega says in addition to 150,000 tons of powdered milk that legitimately enter Mexico annually, further 50,000 tons of 'technical' contraband in form of milk powder described as food preparations enter each year; Mexico is number 1 importer of semiskinned milk powder in world; grain farmers feel they also have been victims of Mexico's increasingly open trade policies; incomes of many grain farmers have fallen since government ended price guarantees on domestic corn and beans in spring 1999; trade ministry has allowed corn imports to exceed quotas set by North American Free Trade Agreement almost continuously since 1994; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Antitrust Case Settlement Could Lower Prices of CD's  The Federal Trade Commission settled an antitrust case against the nation's five largest music companies that could result in significant price cuts for compact discs.    Officials said the settlement completed a two-year investigation that found the companies used illegal marketing agreements to end a price war, inflate the prices of compact discs and sharply restrict the ability of retailers to offer discounts. Agency officials estimated that consumers were overcharged by $500 million over the last four years. [Page A1.]

headline: Sri Lankan Rebels Renew Assault on Jaffna
abstract: Separatist rebels in Sri Lanka reject government offer of cease-fire and resume their offensive, striving to take back Jaffna peninsula (M)

headline: The Quiet Allure of Coupon Clippers
