abstract: Alex Berenson, Portfolios Etc column, comments on staid competition of Valaddis Communications and New Corporation, which hold roughly equal shares of market for printing and distributing coupon inserts that fatten Sunday newspapers nationwide; finds Valassis shares 'absurbly cheap,' noting company enjoyed 40 percent gross profit margin in 1999 and had net income of $121 million on sales of $794 million; finds it is difficult for new entrants to crack market because of high fixed costs that cannot be recouped without a critical mass of advertisers; graph (M)

headline: FUNCO SAYS ELECTRONICS BOUTIQUE HAS RAISED ITS BID
abstract: Funco Inc says Electronics Boutique Holdings has raised its bid for company to $21 a share, or $135 million, matching offer by Barnes & Noble (S)

headline: Texas Radio Station Deal
abstract: Hispanic Broadcasting Corp agrees to buy San Antonio, Tex, radio stations KBUC-FM from Redding Enterprises and KRNH-FM from Radio Ranch Management for about $45 million in cash (S)

headline: Vietnam Begins Testing a Stock-Trading System
abstract: Vietnam is testing systems that will run country's first stock market; opening bell may ring in July, but like Vietnam's tentative experiments in recent years with 'market socialism,' tests are getting mixed results and reviews; there are some early indications that Ho Chi Minh City Securities Trading Center is getting off to rocky start, despite assistance from Stock Exchange of Thailand (M)

headline: Hillary Clinton Wins Praise At U.N. Meeting on Women
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton delivers spirited speech on women's rights at UN during week-long General Assembly session to assess progress of women worldwide; is greeted with warmth and enthusiasm by international audience of women (M)

headline: In a Land of Want, an Expensive War
abstract: Ethiopia is waging expensive war against Eritrea, estimated to cost $500,000 per day in salaries alone, while its eight million people struggle through worst food shortage in nearly 20 years; experts say while prime culprit is three years of poor rains, war has diverted attention and resources, complicating solutions and providing point of soreness that has distracted both Ethiopian officials and rich outside nations that would help alleviate hunger; situation has prompted difficult questions over whether outside nations are obligated to help country that is spending its own money on costly war even as its residents starve; map; photo (M)

headline: Government Opposes Microsoft's Request for a Stay
abstract: Justice Department rebukes Microsoft Corp in court filing, saying company's request for stay of trial Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's ruling against it last week was actually disingenuous attempt 'to manipulate the court' and thwart taking antitrust case directly to Supreme Court; law known as Expediting Act allows antitrust cases 'of general public importance' to be sent directly to Supreme Court for review, and Jackson says he favors such a step; Microsoft wants to take case to Court of Appeals, which has issued rulings favorable to Microsoft in the past (M)

headline: Intuit Exceeds Expectations; Novell Tops Reduced Forecast
Marc van Gelder Appointed CEO and President of Peapod
ALCON LABORATORIES TO BUY SUMMIT TECHNOLOGY
abstract: Nestle SA's Alcon Laborator

headline: Jitters Over Profit Reports Push Dow Sharply Lower
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 122.68 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,435.16; Nasdaq composite index gains 23.53, or 0.6 percent, to 4,013.36; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slips 10.05, or 0.7 percent, to 1,475.95; graph; chart (M)i

headline: GOLDMAN SACHS AWARDING SHARES TO RETAIN EMPLOYEES
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group will distribute two million shares to its junior employees as firm seeks to keep talent from fleeing to dot-coms; will allot shares--worth about $200 million at current prices--to 8,000 analysts and associates based on percentage of last year's pay (S)

headline: Grand Jury Inquiry On Diet Drug Filings
abstract: Federal grand jury is looking into whether American Home Products hid reports from US Food and Drug Administration that its withdrawn diet drugs Pondimin and Redux caused potentially fatal side effects in users; American Home received grand jury subpoena from federal prosecutors in Maryland earlier this month seeking information about company's system for reporting so-called adverse events connected to two diet drugs, once part of fen-phen diet combination (S)

headline: True North Unit Quits Little Caesars Account
abstract: Advertising agency FCB Worldwide, part of True North Communications, is parting ways with Little Caesars, part of Little Caesar Enterprises; billings estimated at $40 million (Advertising column) (S)

headline: HYUNDAI ALLIANCE PLANNED
abstract: DaimlerChrysler announces formation of alliance with Hyundai Motors; they will cooperate in vehicle production and, perhaps, bid jointly for Daewoo Motors (S)

headline: Ordering Brides on the Web: Old Business, New Source
abstract: Julie Checkoway article on online matchmaking sites; notes those that promote international marriages are fastest growing, largely because of increased Internet access worldwide, low overhead and startup costs and abundance of eligible foreign women; photos (M)

headline: Intel Unveils Linux-Based Consumer Web Appliance
abstract: Intel Unveils Linux-Based Consumer Web Appliance

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ALPHARMA INC., Fort Lee, N.J., a maker of generic drugs, agreed to sell five million shares of its Class A stock to the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. for $186 million after fees and expenses.    TEXAS INSTRUMENTS INC., Dallas, whose semiconductors power two-thirds of the cellular telephones in the world, said it would spend $450 million to expand its plant in Freising, Germany, which would add about 300 jobs and double the manufacturing capacity at the factory.

headline: CROSS TIMBERS OIL BUYS OUT LEHMAN NATURAL GAS STAKE
abstract: Cross Timbers Oil Co acquires remaining 50 percent stake in natural gas fields in Arkansas and Oklahoma from Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc for $111 million; two companies bought fields from Ocean Energy Inc in September for $231 million (S)

headline: Business Travel; The World Bank gauges the toll travel takes on employees and looks for ways to soften the effect.
abstract: World Bank held two-day symposium last month called Stress, the Business Traveler and Corporate Health in Washington, DC; in last two years, bank has sponsored seminars intended to make employers think more responsibly about effect ever-increasing travel has on employees and on people closest to them (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: A Little Light Reading, Anyone?; When Weighty Issues Are the Magazines Themselves
abstract: Many magazines are getting bigger, breaking all previous records for number of pages; as economy continues to thrive, some magazines have become so fat with advertising that editorial content is sometimes relegated to increasingly hard-to-find nether reaches of publication; Bride's magazine's Februray-March issue made it into Guinness Book of Records as largest magazine ever published, at 1,271 pages; Magazine Publishers of America says advertisers bought $1.2 billion in consumer magazine advertising for February, increase of 15.4 percent over February 1999; other magazines that are flourishing include W, In Style, Vogue, Vanity Fair and Fortune; graph; photos (M)

headline: Shares Sink on Worries Over 2nd-Quarter Earnings
abstract: Nasdaq composite index falls 106.93, or 2.8 percent, to 3,767.91; Dow Jones industrial average slips 49.85, or 0.5 percent, to 10,564.21; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 10.95, or 0.8 percent, to 1,446; graph; charts (M)

headline: Diane Sawyer Scheduled After 'Millionaire'
abstract: ABC says Diane Sawyer will be co-host for news magazine program, Prime Time Thursday, starting in fall; photo (S)

headline: Prosecutors' Appeal Seeks Execution of Ousted Pakistani Premier
abstract: Pakistani prosecutors seek death penalty for Nawaz Sharif, ousted prime minister who appeals life sentence for hijacking and terrorism (M)

headline: CMG TO BUY ADMIRAL
abstract: British-Dutch computer services and software company, CMG PLC, agrees to buy rival, Admiral PLC, for 1.4 billion pounds ($2.2 billion) in stock (S)

headline: Spanish Company Is in Talks With Lycos
abstract: Terra Networks SA, Internet company controlled by Telefonica SA, tells Spanish stock market regulators that it is in talks with Web search company Lycos Inc (M)

headline: Japan's Jobless Rate Fell to 4.8% in April
abstract: Japan's jobless rate fell for first time in seven months in April and number of jobs offered rose to two-year high; jobless rate fell to 4.8 percent seasonally adjusted; decline may be helping to bolster consumer spending, which so far has been missing from Japan's economic recovery; spending among salaried households rose 6.7 percent, seasonally adjusted, in April from March; Bank of Japan governor Masaru Hayami says bank could consider raising interest rates once wages stop falling and spending rises (S)

headline: Sony to Shrink PlayStation And Add Phone Connection
abstract: Sony will introduce PS One game system, smaller version of PlayStation that can connect to mobile phones (S)

headline: Rallying Round the China Bill, Hungrily: Entertainment; Hollywood Wants A Bigger Box Office
abstract: Unusually wide range of US companies has banded together to lobby Congress in support of pending China trade bill; US motion picture industry currently does about $25 million of business a year in China, a fraction of what it might make if Hollywood movies were given Chinese release; China until recently limited US companies to exporting 10 movies a year there, with China taking half the revenue, though studios may sell any number of movies, 40 to 50 films in recent years, to Chinese distributors for flat fee (M)

headline: PHILIPS'S PROFIT RISES 61%
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics, Europe's largest consumer-electronics maker, says its first-quarter profit rose 61 percent; profit from operations rose to 493 million euros ($466.7 million) from 306 million euros in year-earlier period, beating analysts' estimates; photo of chief executive Cor Boonstra (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None  TUESDAY  Housing Starts -- March

headline: Engineer of the Executive Pay Express
abstract: Interview with attorney Joseph E Bachelder 3d, a leading executive compensation negotiator, focuses on whether soaring executive pay, which many deem excessive, can be justified; Bachelder insists salary packages of corporate chief executives have grown at rate of about 2 percent over Consumer Price Index over the last 50 years, though he concedes bonuses have risen dramatically in that period; calls chief executives the chief custodians of economic growth; photo (M)

headline: Keeping Domain Nameson Ice for Eventual Use
abstract: Keeping Domain Names on Ice for Eventual Use

headline: Bobby Big Fish Gets Many Bites
abstract: Interview with Bobby Lienau, who maintains sport fishing Web site; photo (M)

headline: PNC BUYS THE RIGHTS TO SERVICE FLEETBOSTON MORTGAGES
abstract: PNC Financial Services Group Inc will buy from FleetBoston Financial Corp rights to service $5.2 billion in home mortgages, with rights to collect payments on 53,000 mortgages on behalf of such companies as Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac (S)

headline: REIT Considering a Sale
abstract: Western Properties Trust hires investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc to advise it on possible sale or merger; company has market value in stock and debt of about $425 million (S)

headline: Hand-Held Systems Tempt News-Hungry City
abstract: Mobile Internet access, still limited in Europe, is expected to be particularly popular there because of unified standards and large number of cellular phone users; newspapers and other data providers are rushing to format their content for mobile phones and to negotiate deals for placement on phones; Vodafone AirTouch PLC has long waiting list for new phones, having returned early model to Nokia because of glitch (M)

headline: A Revolution in the Fish Industry That Hasn't Quite Taken Hold
abstract: Flurry of online trading sites suggests change may be coming very fast to $350 billion United States seafood industry, amalgamation of range of businesses that have never had centralized clearinghouses; dozen of more companies now provide business-to-business Internet services, including Gofish.com and Fishmonger.com, early leaders in establishing online sites for buying and selling of seafood; photo (M)

headline: Investing; Time to Reach for the Aspirin, or the Phone?
abstract: Investing column on strategies for market that has suddenly turned down (M)

headline: 24/7 Sues DoubleClick for Patent Infringement
abstract: 24/7 Sues DoubleClick for Patent Infringement

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Platinum falls on report that Russia, world's second-biggest supplier, has resumed exporting metal after yearlong halt; in New York, platinum for July delivery falls $9, or 1.9 percent, to $462.80 an ounce; graph; chart (S)

headline: Soccer Fans Can Follow Euro 2000 on Web
abstract: News Watch: Soccer Fans Can Follow Euro 2000 on Web

headline: New Agency Posts For the Americas
abstract: FCB Worldwide in New York, part of True North Communications, names Mike Bosman president and chief operating officer at FCB North America; Bates Worldwide, part of Cordiant Communications Group, names Gary McBride president at Bates Latin America (S)

headline: Let Someone Else Look for Bargains
abstract: Michelle Slatalla (Online Shopper) discusses her pleasure in finding a bargain while shopping online; says in her quest to develop systematic shopping strategy for finding bargains she came across Bargaindog, Web site (www.bargaindog,com) that points shoppers toward latest discounts, freebies and sales offered by about 300 online merchant partners; says she did independent search for some of Bargaindog's items online and did not find lower prices (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Coffee rises as some roasters take advantage of prices that have fallen to six-month low to secure supplies; in New York, coffee for July delivery rises 1.4 cents, or 1.4 percent, to 99.4 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Indonesia Recoils at Island's Unchecked Wave of Killings
abstract: Terrifying surge of communal violence, apparently fueled by anti-government agitators in Jakarta, is tearing apart remote and beautiful islands of Maluku, raising fears of destabilization throughout Indonesia's ailing archipelago; more than 200 people are reported killed in last week; photo of Muslim warriors heading for village where more than 100 Christians died; situation in old Spice Islands challenges Pres Abdurrahman Wahid, who faces array of powerful, vengeful forces disenfranchised with overthrow of Pres Suharto (M)

headline: FINMECCANICA SELECTS PARTNER
abstract: Finmeccanica, Italian state-owned military and aeronautics company, choses European Aeronautic, Defense and Space as partner for its Alenia aerospace unit in making military planes; spurns rival bid from BAE Systems (S)

headline: Israel Frees One of 16 Lebanese It Held to Trade for Its Soldiers
abstract: Israel frees one of 16 Lebanese prisoners who have been held without charges as 'bargaining chips' for potential release of Israeli soldiers captured in Lebanon; Zvi Rish, attorney for released man, Ghassan al-Dirani, says his client spent most of his 10 years in captivity isolated in prison hospital and attempted suicide several times (M)

headline: North Korea Shyly Courts Capitalism
abstract: Still-small modern sector of North Korea's otherwise failing economy has risen impressively in last year; sector represents nation's first tentative steps into global capitalism; planned summit conference with South Korea could lead to improved ties that could spur trade, aid and finance needed to stave off economic collapse; map; photo (M)

headline: Times Co. Delays Meeting
abstract: The New York Times Co postpones its annual meeting, originally planned for April 27, to give shareholders more time to evaluate various proposals, including one to create tracking stock for New York Times Digital, company's Internet business division; new date for meeting has not yet been scheduled, and company has not yet sent shareholders its 1999 annual report or proxy material; it expects to do so before April 30 (S)

headline: Apprehension and Hope For Stability in Mideast
abstract: Death of Pres Hafez al-Assad, who managed to keep Syria a political power in Middle East, brings expressions of apprehension and cautious hope for stability from regional and world leaders; photo (M)

headline: Seeing Threats Beyond Arms, President Urges Cooperation
abstract: Pres Clinton tells graduating class at United States Coast Guard Academy in New London, Conn, that congressional vote for extending trade preferences to China will have deep implications for American security; says 'no' vote to trade would invite future of dangerous confrontation and constant insecurity; photo (M)

headline: Island Talks Get New Push From Japan And Russia
abstract: Russian Pres-elect Vladimir Putin and Japanese Prime Min Yoshiro Mori hold first meeting as leaders, pledging to meet often, call each other by nicknames and try to conclude peace treaty on Kurile Islands chain; islands, which Japan calls Northern Territories, were seized by Russia at end of World War II; Russia recently reasserted claim by boarding Japanese fishing vessel (M)

headline: MEXICAN RADIO DEAL
abstract: Grupo Televisa SA offers to buy controlling stake in Grupo Radio Centro to create Mexico's biggest network of radio stations; Radio Centro owns 11 radio stations and operates 2 more (S)

headline: First Results From Haitian Election Show Aristide Gaining Senate
abstract: Preliminary results indicate party of Jean-Bertrand Aristide, former president of Haiti, gained firm control of Haitian Senate in May 21 election; party gained 14 of 19 Senate seats in first parliamentary election since 1997 (M)

headline: PrivateSector; A Child Thanks 3Com But Overstates the Case
abstract: Pres Clinton, in speech on eliminating digital divide, cites 3Com's pledge of $3 million to YWCA over three years to provide technology training and mentors for girls; 9-year-old girl, thanking 3Com at news conf in NYC, inadvertently refers to company as 5Com (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro drops after business survey shows unexpected drop in confidence last month in German economy; in New York, euro settles at 94.80 cents, down from 95.38 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: Dick Tracy's Cellular Swatch Watch
abstract: Swatch Group plans to make Dick Tray's two-way wrist radio a reality when it introduces Swatch phone watch in 2001; Samsung Electronics has already begun selling phone watch on Internet in South Korea; Motorola has developed version with Timex; analysts are skeptical about consumer demand; photo (M)

headline: ROBERTSON-CECO ACCEPTS $56 MILLION BUYOUT OFFER
abstract: Robertson-Ceco Corp accepts sweetened offer of $11.50 a share, or $56 million, for rest of it shares from its majority shareholder, Heico Co (S)

headline: BRAZIL SHOWS BIG SURPLUS
abstract: Brazil's budget surplus rose to record in March, reflecting government's efforts to control spending; surplus rose to $3.1 billion, compared with $2.1 billion in February; for first quarter, Brazil posts $7.4 billion primary surplus, almost doubling target of $3.95 billion agreed upon with International Monetary Fund (S)

headline: The Andes in Tumult, Shaken by Political Tremors
abstract: Recent discontent dividing Andean nations of Colombia, Venezuela, Ecuador, Peru and Bolivia differs from conflicts of past, being generated less by disagreements over type of government than by quality; urgent need for more effective governments is converging with desire that governments be democratic and longing for more representative and responsive governance is now greater than ever before among region's 100 million people; aspiration increasingly bumps up against governments that have been unable to provide equitable sharing of power and wealth; situation especially in Venezuela and Peru discussed; map; photo (M)

headline: Tribunal Gains Steam as It Tries Balkan Horrors
abstract: International tribunal in The Hague dealing with Yugoslav war crimes gains momentum after slow start; it has opened first United Nations trial ever to focus exclusively on sexual violence against women, including gang rape and use of women as sexual slaves as part of war strategy; it has begun trial of one of top generals accused of being responsible for carnage in 1995 in Srebrenica, and announced capture of Momcilo Krajisnik, senior Bosnian Serb politician; recent momentum is result of slow shifts by Western governments, which long appeared to pay only lip service to court; public complaints from Louise Arbour, former chief prosecutor, prompted NATO countries to release more intelligence reports and to use peacekeepers to seize key documents in Bosnia; photos (M)

headline: Better by Half
abstract: Elizabeth Ellers letter on Apr 6 article describes benefits of selling books via Half.com

headline: Smart Appliances
abstract: Letter by John Woo responds to April 13 article on smart appliances; says proponents of such appliances should instead concentrate on how to make millions of personal computers more reliable and easier to understand

headline: Poul Hartling, 85, Ex-Head Of U.N. Agency for Refugees
abstract: Poul Hartling, former prime minister of Denmark who headed office of United Nations high commissioner for refugees when agency won 1981 Nobel Peace Prize, dies at age 85; photo (M)

headline: 3Dlabs in Acquisition
abstract: 3Dlabs Inc agrees to buy Intense 3D, unit of Intergraph Corp, for $24.7 million in stock (S)

headline: Stock Sell-Off Picks Up Speed As Technology Shares Decline
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average loses 168.97 points, or 1.6 percent, to 10,367.78; Nasdaq composite index drops 200.28 points, or 5.59 percent, to 3,384.73; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 29.09 points, or 2.06 percent, to 1,383.05; graph; charts (M)

headline: INC.UBATOR CAPITAL BUYS THEMEWARE FOR $135 MILLION
abstract: Inc.ubator Capital Inc will acquire Internet service provider ThemeWare Corp for $135 million in stock and will invest $5 million in cash in company in next 12 months (S)

headline: Abbott Reports A Higher Profit
abstract: Abbott Laboratoriews says first-quarter profit rose 3.6 percent to $693 million, from $669 million a year earlier; sales rose to $3.35 billion from $3.31 billion (S)

headline: News Analysis; Peru Election Turmoil: Stability vs. Democracy
abstract: News analysis of controversy and issues surrounding Peru's Presidential election in which Pres Alberto Fujimori won third consecutive term in vote international observers say was fixed, and from which opposition candidate Alejandro Toledo withdrew in protest; photo (M)

headline: First Winner Is Ruled Out Of an Award
abstract: Amazon.com is publishing short story by Meera Nair on its Web site despite some complaints over graphic descriptions of sex and discovery that writer is ineligible for PEN/Amazon.com Short Story Award because her fiction was previously published in national magazine with circulation of over 10,000; judges give $10,000 prize to runner-up, Marlene Reed Wetzel; Nair had told Amazon about previous publication, but neither she nor Amazon initially realized magazine's circulation; Nair will also keep $10,000 (M)

headline: Bush Adviser Apologizes for Lobbying Effort
abstract: Ralph Reed, senior consultant to Gov George W Bush's presidential campaign, apologizes for lobbying Bush on behalf of Microsoft Corp and promises not to lobby him again on behalf of Microsoft or anyone else; Bush campaign official says Bush had not known that Reed's organization, Century Strategies, was lobbying him; New York Times article on April 11 said Century Strategies was carrying out quiet lobbying campaign on behalf of Microsoft to persuade prominent Bush supporters to write Bush on behalf of Microsoft in effort to undermine government's antitrust suit against company (M)

headline: Healtheon/WebMD Quarterly Loss Deepens
abstract: Healtheon/WebMD Corp says first-quarter loss widened to $431.5 million because of marketing and acquisitions; loss increased from $18.6 million a year earlier; revenue almost quadrupled to $65.9 million from $17.6 million; sales from subscriptions more than doubled, to $6.8 million from $2.7 million in fourth quarter of 1999 (M)

headline: Business & Investing; Microsoft's Woes Bring Little Good for Others
abstract: Analysts say they expect Microsoft's pain to have little impact on other computer and software company stocks; others companies' stock performance, up or down, is seen independent of Microsoft's fortunes; photo of Bill Gates (M)

headline: New ThinkPads: Laptop as S.U.V.
abstract: IN a world where nearly everything seems to be getting miniaturized, the new I.B.M. Thinkpad T20 portable computer is traveling in the other direction. If it were any larger, I.B.M. could have equipped this impressively redesigned laptop with folding legs and offered it as a card table.    It would be an expensive card table, to be sure, given that the fastest model starts at about $4,000, not counting the broad array of options that I.B.M. is offering for it. But hey, thanks to the games built into the Windows operating system, this would be a card table that came with its own game of solitaire.

headline: Compressed Data; Bill on E-Signatures Moves Toward Approval
abstract: Congress is expected to pass legislation this week that would make electronic signatures and records as legally binding as pen-and-paper versions. Passage would end a long stalemate over how far a law should go in freeing financial institutions from current consumer notification laws.     The compromise bill, approved by a House-Senate conference committee late last week, would confirm that electronic signatures and electronic records were legal. It would also provide a way for banks and insurers to notify consumers of late payments or changes in credit card or loan contracts via e-mail rather than postal mail, and it would allow financial institutions to begin keeping more records electronically.

headline: Putting a Chip in Every Pot
abstract: Publicity heralding coming era of 'smart' appliances is leading appliance makers and others to weigh whether consumers want appliances linked by embedded computer chips that can communicate wirelessly and be remotely instructed to embark on tasks; dozens of appliance makers are trying to figure out which pervasive-computing devices will come to be considered necessary; drawing; photo (M)

headline: An Eye on the Next Step
abstract: Stephen Labaton analysis holds that Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, in ruling that Microsoft Corp violated nation's antitrust laws, constructed cautious argument aimed at surviving Supreme Court review (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    SCOTLAND: SEEKING LOCKERBIE DELAY -- After surprise defense plans to produce more than 100 witnesses from abroad, prosecutors will ask the Scottish High Court to postpone the May 3 start of the trial of two Libyans in the bombing of a Pan Am jet over Lockerbie that killed 270 people. The request will be heard tomorrow at a former Dutch military base where the case is to be tried under Scottish legal procedures. Prosecutors say that despite frequent requests, they were given no advance notice of the 119 witnesses.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Actors Strike Against Radio and Television Advertisers
abstract: Screen Actors Guild and American Federation of Television and Radio Advertisers, for first time in 12 years, calls on their combined membership of about 135,000 actors to stop working on all television and radio commercials at 12:01 am on May 1 until agreement can be reached with advertisers; residual payments for commercial work are at heart of disagreement; for years, actors in commercials used on network television have received payments every time an ad runs in practice known as 'pay per play'; for commercials on cable television actors receive flat rate; commercial advertisers want flat rate used by cable to be adopted across the board, while unions want to see pay-per-play extended to cable advertisers; actors demonstrate in New York City, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Chicago; photo (M)

headline: Grey Advertising's chairman begins to answer the succession question --but does it his way.
abstract: Grey Advertising chairman-president-chief executive Edward H Meyer, 73, is finally making first steps toward outlining future of Grey by announcing reorganization; Meyers will become head of new holding company, Grey Global Group; several senior managers will join Meyer in stepping up from core advertising agency operation, to be renamed Grey Worldwide; Meyer will become chairman and chief executive at Grey Global; Robert L Berenson will be vice chairman and general manager and Steven G Felsher executive vice president for finance; Bernd Michael and Eric Rosenkranz will be regional managers at Grey Worldwide; some other appointments noted (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Taking Advantage of the Mobile Office: Homeward Bound
abstract: Consulting firm Joanne H Pratt Associates says more than 19 million people worked at home at least once a month during normal business hours in 1999, a 390 percent increase from 4 million in 1990; known as telecommuting, movement has been fueled by Internet, which makes communications between home and office much easier; Hewitt Associates survey shows that number of large companies offering work-at-home option has increased yearly since 1993, reaching 27 percent in 1998; graph (M)

headline: ORACLE JAPAN OFFERING
abstract: Oracle Corp and its Japanese unit have raised 797.6 billion yen ($7.5 billion) in Japan's second-biggest public offering ever (S)

headline: The Pain of Technology Funds
abstract: Technology funds tracked by Lipper Inc are up 30.3 percent for year as of Mar 23; gain is cut to 15.9 percent after heavy trading in week (S)

headline: MDSI MOBILE DATA WILL ACQUIRE CONNECTRIA FOR STOCK
abstract: MDSI Mobile Data Solutions Inc agrees to acquire Connectria Inc for stock valued at $45 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen declines to 106.83/$US; other international exchange rates noted; graph (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls on concern that Japan's economic rebound may not be as strong as previously thought; in New York, dollar settles at 107.77 yen, down from 106.58; graph; chart (S)

headline: Market Intervention by Japan Sends Yen Down vs. Dollar
abstract: Japanese yen posts its biggest decline in 10 months against US dollar and sinks against euro after nation's central bank sells yen in effort to keep exports competitive and modest economic recovery on track; graph; chart (M)

headline: Putting the Clamps on Consumers Accustomed to Borrowing Freely
abstract: Consumers will quickly begin to feel pinch of Federal Reserve's half-point increase as borrowing becomes more expensive; rates on fixed-rate mortgages have already climbed and may even retreat some from their current level of about 8.5 percent; consumers with money to invest will most likely benefit from Fed's action, though rates that banks pay on investments like certificates of deposit and money market accounts tend to rise less fully or with a lag, depending on various factors, including amounts involved (M)

headline: Polluting Siberia Paper Mill Seen as Relic of Soviet Ways
abstract: Baikalsk Pulp and Paper mill managers in Russia, assailed for chlorine discharge into world's largest freshwater body, Lake Baikal, plan to convert mill to cheaper grade of pulp that does not require bleaching; international campaign is seeking to close plant, and Greenpeace is running television advertisements assailing factory; even as critics say mill threatens lake, management says demands for shutdown are blocking efforts to clean the plant up; throughout former Soviet Union, industry has turned waterways into environmental catastrophes; map; photo (M)

headline: Japan Moves to Correct a Deliberate Omission of Data
abstract: Economic Planning Agency says it will correct its deliberate omission of data made in recent report on Japan's economic growth; says corrected data will be reflected in economic growth figures released June 10; denies it omitted data for Oct-Dec period to make report appear stronger that it really was; also says that when data is included, gross domestic product in that quarter will show 1.6 percent decline from year before, rather than drop of 1.43 percent indicated in the original report (M)

headline: AOL and Hughes to Test Satellite Service in 16 Cities
abstract: AOL and Hughes to Test Satellite Service in 16 Cities

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar rises as stocks gain and traders expect jobs report to underscore that US growth is outpacing that of Europe; in New York, euro settles at 95.97, down from 96.28; graph; chart (S)

headline: RUINED EAST TIMOR AWAITS A MIRACLE
abstract: Little has changed in ruined East Timor as United Nations passes six-month mark in its first experiment in building a new nation; whole towns and villages still stand burned, roofless and silent, devastated by rampage of destruction of that followed East Timor's vote last August to end 24 years of Indonesian occupation; as many as 80 percent of territory's 700,000 people still have no jobs; another 100,000 or more remain in camps across border in Indonesian West Timor, still afraid to return; desperation of East Timor's unemployed, and first spasms of violence it has spawned, are sharpest signs of swelling discontent; aid workers and diplomats say they fear that this discontent could lead to lawlessness and political disarray and could open door to trouble from Indonesian-backed militias that crossed border to Indonesian West Timor after laying waste to territory last September; there is still no working police force or justice system, no government structure, few schools, no working water or power or transportation system, no post office, not much of an economy, little reconstruction; scene in Dili described; map; photos (M)

headline: Ready For Fences To Fall In Europe
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin, Market Insight column, interviews Michael Levy, head of international equities at Deutsche Asset Management and manager of Deutsche European Equity Fund, concerning changes in European capital markets; photo (M)

headline: CARDINAL HEALTH UNIT TO BUY PART OF ADVANCED POLYMER
abstract: Drug wholesaler Cardinal Health buys rights to two skin medications from Advanced Polymer Systems Inc for $25 million (S)

headline: Ethiopia and Eritrea Renew Border War With Fierce Intensity
abstract: Ethiopia reports capturing more ground in third day of clashes with neighboring Eritrea; Eritrean officials dismiss report as propaganda aimed at voters in Ethiopia's nationwide elections; fighting along disputed border marks resumption of fierce two-year war; map (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas prices rise 7 percent after an industry report shows inventories rose less than expected last week; in New York, natural gas for June delivery rises 24.1 cents, to $3.689 per 1,000 cubic feet; graph (S)

headline: Advertising Takeover
abstract: Young & Rubicam, a Madison Avenue icon that gave the world the Jell-O jingle and the numbered Excedrin headaches, ended 77 years of independence by agreeing to a $5.7 billion takeover by the WPP Group, a rival based in London. Executives of the companies were expected to announce the deal today. The takeover, which ends four months of talks,  would make WPP the largest advertising company in the world.  Article, Page C1.

headline: FRENCH CONSUMER SPENDING JUMPS
abstract: French consumer spending on manufactured goods rose 2.6 percent in May from April, double analysts' expectations, after falling in previous two months; government reports annual 6 percent increase in construction of new homes for three months ended in May; graph (S)

headline: Corporate-News Proposal Criticized by Dow Jones
abstract: Dow Jones & Co, owner of The Wall Street Journal, Barron's and Dow Jones Newswires, complains to Securities and Exchange Commission that proposed rule intended to prevent companies from giving information to hand-picked group of investors would result in 'less informative, less objective and less timely reporting'; SEC proposed rule in December, after issue had been publicly championed for months by commission's chairman Arthur Levitt; Journal's opposition highlights increasing scrutiny given to how, and to whom, companies provide information in era when new technologies and hair-trigger markets have made information more valuable and sensitive commodity; Bloomberg News, financial service that is competitor of Dow Jones, questions Dow Jones's criticism (M)

headline: Dust Settles on Markets That Are More Volatile
abstract: Dust settles on stock markets that are more volatile; professional traders say US markets have become bigger, more volatile, and more uncontrollable than ever before; even billions of dollars that Wall Street firms put up to 'make markets'--to buy and sell stocks from individual investors and mutual funds--is no longer enough money to significantly slow moves in companies like Microsoft and Intel, which are valued at well over $400 billion each; commissions paid by individual investors to trade shares have dropped, leading to more trading than ever before and adding to volatility; billions of shares worth hundreds of billions of dollars now routinely change hands every day on Nasdaq stock market and New York Stock Exchange; photo (M)

headline: After a Rout, Still Fighting
abstract: Analysis of outlook for breakup of Microsoft Corp in light of Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's breakup order and of possible outcomes of appeals process in which Microsoft will try to reverse every element of his antitrust ruling; experts say Microsoft is unlikely to win outright on appeal, but might avoid breakup; diagram of appeals process (M)

headline: Art Museum Abandons Its Real-World Space
abstract: June 8, 2000

headline: Of Fathers and Their Corporate Sons
abstract: Sylvia Nasar coü

headline: Risks of Hard Drive Backups
abstract: Letter by Laura Colby responds to May 18 article on backing up data on hard drive; disagrees with letters responding to article that suggest using second hard drive as means of backup

headline: Israeli Judge Delays Ruling on 2 Abducted Guerrilla Leaders
abstract: Israeli Court delays decision on whether to release two abducted Lebanese guerrilla leaders whose freedom has been demanded by Hezbollah as condition for halting anti-Israeli hostilities; will rule on July 12 on cases of Sheik Abdel Karim Obeid of Hezbollah, who was seized in 1989, and Mustafa al- Dirani of Amal movement who was seized in 1994; both were forcibly taken in Lebanon and have been used as bargaining chips for release of Capt Ron Arad, Israeli airman whose plane was lost over Lebanon in 1986 (M)

headline: Tyco and Global Crossing Shares Fall
abstract: Shares of Tyco International Ltd fall after company, world's largest maker of undersea fiber optic cable, is sued by Global Crossing Ltd, which accuses it of stealing trade secrets; Global Crossing hired Tyco Submarine Systems in 1998 to build fiber optic network circling South America; company contends that Tyco shared information with Global Crossing's rival, Telefonica, which is developing its own system (S)

headline: Holiday Motorists Face Soaring Prices at Pump
abstract: Gasoline prices have soared to highest levels of year in many parts of United States; analysts say tight supplies, particularly in Midwest, could push prices higher as demand increases with beginning of summer driving season and as parts of country struggle to meet June 1 deadline for using cleaner-burning reformulated fuel as required by federal government; oil prices have more than doubled since early last year, when OPEC decided to cut back production and cartel members largely adhered to new limits on output; photo; graph (M)

headline: U.N. Warns That Trafficking In Human Beings Is Growing
abstract: Pino Arlacchi, top anti-crime official at United Nations, says trafficking in people is now fastest-growing business of organized crime, and is being run by new, barely understood networks that have sidelined traditional criminal syndicates; cites recent deaths of 58 Chinese migrants trying to reach Britain as tip of iceberg; says estimated 200 million people may now be in some way or other under sway or in hands of traffickers of various kinds; he is considering recommending temporary residence to would-be immigrants who cooperate with authorities in identifying criminals who traffic in people (M)

headline: BROADCOM AGREES TO ACQUIRE INNOVENT FOR $438 MILLION
abstract: Broadcom Corp, maker of broadband chips, acquires Innovent Systems Inc, manufacturer of integrated circuits for short-range wireless communications, for about $438 million in stock (S)

headline: Continental Is Suing United Over Carry-On Bag Limits
abstract: Continental Airlines sues United Airlines and committee that oversees operations at Washington Dulles International Airport, contending that recently installed baggage-sizing templates inhibit competition; suit, filed against United and Dulles Airport Airline Managment Council, comes after smaller plastic templates were installed on April 15 at X-ray security checkpoints at Dulles; United had proposed installing templates; carrier uses equipment to screen bags at 24 other US airports; Continental, which says it has more overhead bin space on its planes and uses that as marketing tool to attract customers, opposes templates, contending they would prevent its passengers from carrying their bags on its aircraft; Kieran Sheridan, chairman of Dulles Airline Management Council and general manager at Northwest Airlines at airport, says decision to use templates was made only after majority vote by council, which includes Continental; United declines to comment on lawsuit (M)

headline: Technology And Timing Can Outfox The Bears
abstract: Interview with Ron Berry, co-manager of RS Information Age Fund, focuses on outlook for technology stocks; Berry reckons worst of selloff is over, but predicts market will remain volatile for a while; notes fund is down 7.5 percent for year, but has outperformed Nasdaq composite index, which is down 21.1 percent; credits fund's weighting in semiconductor firms and large-cap technology companies; drawing (M)

headline: Acquisitions by the technology companies of start-up small-fry offer a sampler on how deals can go wrong.
abstract: Communications equipment industry, sector in which obscure start-ups with little or no revenue are routinely acquired for large sums in stock by industry giants, provides examples of risks of get-bigger-by-buying strategy; drawing (M)

headline: Europeans Learn They're Growing Genetically Altered Plants
abstract: Farmers in England, France, Germany and Sweden find they unwittingly planted rapeseed oil crops for two years from bags of Canadian seed that inadvertently contained scattering of genetically modified seeds; Europeans are opposed to use of genetic engineering, and newspapers there are referring to fields as tainted and contaminated; European governments say there is no health risk from oil produced from crop, noting that less than 1 percent of seeds had bioengineered genes; newspapers are calling for seed company, Advanta of Netherlands, to pay for destroyed crops (M)

headline: In Silicon Valley, Loyalty Means Paying a High Price; Cultural Strengths Help Offset Loss of Paper Wealth
abstract: More than 100 employees of Calico Commerce were millionaires when company stock peaked in November 1999, but shares have fallen 80 percent since then, wiping out paper wealth of many employees; nevertheless, only 15 of company's 330 employees have left company so far this year, for annual turnover rate of 12 percent, less than half the typical rate at Silicon Valley companies; Calico's stability derives from strong company culture that makes employees feel like partners and fosters commitment to long-term success of company; still, Calico expects to begin to lose people eventually if stock price remains depressed; photo (L)

headline: KLLM TRANSPORT AGREES TO $33 MILLION BUYOUT
abstract: The trucking company KLLM Transport Services Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to accept a $33 million buyout offer from a company formed by the president and chief executive of KLLM and the chief executive of WorldCom Inc. The deal, for $8.05 a share, tops a previous unsolicited buyout offer of $7.75 a share, which KLLM said shareholders should reject. The shares of KLLM, which is based in Jackson, Miss., rose $1, to $7.8125, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of May 11 front-page article about settlement of antitrust case involving pricing of compact discs, which omitted a passage at the continuation in some copies because of production error

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro hits one-month high, ending its best week since its debut 17 months ago, on speculation European central banks will buy euros; graphs; table (S)

headline: Netscape Strikes Back
abstract: Peter H Lewis column assesses preview version of Netscape's next-generation Internet browser; drawing (M)

headline: Better Eating Through Science
abstract: Team of student researchers at Cornell University has found a way to pack a whole salad--freeze dried --into a 5-by-2 inch snack bar, one of six finalists in Institute of Food Technology competition (M)

headline: Beyond the Organizer: Handhelds Add Power and Peripherals
abstract: Peter H Lewis State of the Art article surveys pocket-sized handheld computers that are appearing with capabilities that go far beyond their original task of organizing personal data; newer models can perform wide range of functions, including acting as digital cameras, voice recorders and books, when software or hardware attachments are added; photos (M)

headline: A Letter to the President, a Lesson in Style
abstract: Anya Provorova, 17-year-old Russian student, puts her academic future at great risk after writing a letter to Pres Vladimir Putin with a punctuation error, embarrassing local school authorities in Vologda Province; Moscow newspapers and television stations seize on story, and provincial government opens an inquiry into the case; photo (M)

headline: Army Hires Burnett In Recruiting Campaign
abstract: US Army ends unusually public review for its advertising account, with spending estimated at $95 million, by hiring new lineup of agencies led by Leo Burnett Worldwide in Chicago (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Levitating Earnings: An Act, Or a Fact?
abstract: First-quarter 2000 corporate earnings rise 20 percent from 1999, but some accounting professionals express concern about balance sheets obscuring actual profits from corporations' continuing operations; chart and drawing (M)

headline: NEW SINGAPORE NEWSPAPERS
abstract: Singapore Press Holdings, which publishes Singapore's largest English daily, will start second newspaper in September to take on new rivals as its industry monopoly ends; publishes Straits-Times and nine other newspapers in four languages (S)

headline: Government's Buybacks Leaving Fewer Treasuries to Go Around
abstract: Government's bond buyback is specter haunting mutual funds that invest primarily in federal government debt; Treasury in January announced plans to buy back and retire up to $30 billion in outstanding Treasury debt: some $2 billion worth has already been bought; as result, demand for Treasury notes and bonds has already surged; an impending scarcity has helped some bond funds; table shows some Treasury bond funds (M)

headline: RICHER CHOCOLATE
abstract: Profits at Swiss confectioner Lindt & Sprungli rose 11 percent to $42.1 million in 1999; sales grew 7.1 percent, far outpacing overall industry sales of less than 2 percent (S)

headline: OPTIMISM ON CHINA TRADE DEAL
abstract: China and European Union will resume talks soon on country's entry to World Trade Organization; Chinese Foreign Trade Min Shi Guangsheng says it will not be long before China joins global trade body; agreement with European Union is last major step China must complete before it can enter WTO (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: BLAIR DEFIANT  In his first speech since his most significant setback in three years in office, Prime Minister Tony Blair said he would not change his government's program to suit his critics. ''Come fair weather or foul we intend to stick to the course we have set out,'' he said in an uncompromising address to the Periodical Publishers' Association. In elections last week, Mr. Blair suffered the loss of nearly 600 local council seats and the indignity of seeing Ken Livingstone, whom he opposed, become London's first elected mayor.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: SOFTBANK'S OUTLOOK WORSENS
abstract: Shares of Japanese Internet company, Softbank Corp, fall 4 percent, to 70,500 yen ($673) apiece, after company issues earnings warning; says it will post 55 billion yen ($525.4 million) loss for year ended March 31, far below expectations; investors are also concerned that company will have trouble paying capital gains taxes as it starts cashing out some of its older, larger investments (S)

headline: CANADIAN UNEMPLOYMENT STEADY
abstract: Canada's unemployment rate was 6.8 percent in March, holding for fourth consecutive month at 24-year low; economy added 30,000 jobs; Toronto investment dealer Nesbitt Burns Inc says wage inflation has begun to show, with incomes rising at 3 percent annual rate in March, compared with 2.4 percent a year earlier (S)

headline: Troubled Drkoop.com Boosted By New Financing
abstract: Troubled Drkoop.com Boosted By New Financing

headline: A Day After a Record Gain, the Nasdaq Declines 1.7%
abstract: Nasdaq composite index drops 58.57 points, or 1.7 percent, to 3,400.91; Dow Jones industrial average edges down 4.80 points, to 10,522.33, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index eases 1.85 points, or 0.13 percent, to 1,420.60; graph; chart (M)

headline: Wieden & Kennedy Creative Departures
abstract: Michael Prieve and Stacy Wall, creative directors at New York office of Weiden & Kennedy, to leave during summer in departures that will mean all top-office leaders will be new (Advertising column) (S)

headline: BANK EARNINGS BARELY RISE
abstract: Bank of Scotland posts profit that is lower than expected for second half of its fiscal year ended Feb 29; profit edged up slightly to 287 million pounds, or $453 million, from 286.2 million pounds a year earlier; graph (S)

headline: ENERGIZER SHARES RISE IN FIRST TRADING AFTER SPINOFF
abstract: Shares of Energizer Holdings Inc rise on their first day of trading after spinoff by Ralston Purina Co; Energizer rises 6.25 cents a share, to $21.3125, valuing company at $2.1 billion, about 25 percent less than analysts had expected (S)

headline: Cisco Overvalued?
abstract: Dr Stewart B Dunsker, letter, disputes May 7 article on valuation of Cisco Systems stock (M)

headline: Talking Bluntly, Carrying a Torch
abstract: Profile of Norman P Blake Jr, former business executive who was appointed head of United States Olympic Committee in February; his comments about overhauling USOC have reaffirmed reputation for bluntness and impatience; he is presently conducting 90-day review, evaluating managers, assessing operations and analyzing what he sees as hidebound structure; Blake's approach contrasts sharply with mild manner of Dick Schultz, USOC's last executive director, who came from world of athletics and lacked authority given to Blake; photo (M)

headline: Officials Trace Computer Virus In Philippines
abstract: Law enforcement agents raid apartment in Manila, Philippines, believed to be source of malicious 'I Love You' computer virus that disrupted computer systems wordlwide; take resident into custody and order roommate to turn herself in; seize computer-related equipment; say suspects, bank employees identified as Reomel Ramones and Irene de Guzman, are not necessarily creators of virus and that there may be more suspects; photo (M)

headline: NETERGY NETWORKS TO PURCHASE CLOSELY HELD UFORCE
abstract: Netergy Networks Inc will purchase closely held Uforce for about $51 million in stock (S)

headline: Lockerbie Trial Hears Police Minutiae, Defense Hints and, at Day's End, List of Dead
abstract: Police officers who searched scenes of crash of Pan Am 103 in Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988 take stand in trial of two Libyans accused of blowing up plane; defense lawyers try in vain to get witnesses to say that CIA and FBI agents had many opportunities to plant or steal evidence at crash site (M)

headline: At a Wall Street Firm, Juniors' Voices Roar
abstract: Salomon Smith Barney executives, in response to list of demands compiled by junior investment banker Paul Leung, are piling on perks to stem flow of young employees defecting to Internet companies; are offering them more meal money, better laptop computers and access to company gym on weekends; memo contains list of 36 suggested ways firm can retain its bankers-in-training, pool of 500 people known as analysts (M)

headline: On the Anti-Snoop Patrol
abstract: Profile of Gordon Mitchell, president of Bug-Killer.com, which helps companies and individuals who think they are being bugged by competitions; Mitchell comments (M)

headline: China Arms Expert Warns U.S. Shield May Force Buildup
abstract: China's chief arms negotiator says American proposal to build anti-missile defensive shield poses unacceptable threat to China's security and could force Beijing to significantly expand its own nuclear forces in response; official, Sha Zukang, says Chinese are doubtful about American claims that proposed 'national missile defense' is intended only to counter threats from small 'rogue' states; says proposed system would destroy China's ability to deter nuclear attack by neutralizing its relatively small force of nuclear missiles; this is China's most detailed public warning yet of its possible military responses, ranging from producing more nuclear warheads to devising ways to undermine American missile shield; Sha says American proposal would spark new global arms race; proposal is also vehemently opposed by Russia, which like China fears system would blunt its power and, also like China, wants to avoid costly arms race (M)

headline: Citing Cost-Cutting Drive, Unilever Reports Higher Income
abstract: Unilever, citing cost-cutting drive, says first-quarter operating profit rose 12 percent, to 716 million euros, or $659 million, compared with 640 million euros in year-earlier period (M)

headline: MANAGEMENT: Out to Pasture, Greener Pasture; Older Workers Are Thriving In Tight Job Market
abstract: Older workers are thriving in tight job market; older workers bring years of experience and connections to the table, and they often surprise their new bosses by showing nearly as much vigor as their younger colleagues; Census Bureau figures show number of 20-to-34-year-olds in US has declined by 6 million the last decade while number of people over 50 has increased by 12 million; says in next decade, number of people over 50 will increase by 21 million more, while number of 20-to-34-year-olds will increase by only 4 million; increasing number of companies are adjusting to changing dynamics of job market by dipping deeper into over-50 pool of talent; Hank Merrill and Hershel Sarbin, who have chosen to work instead of taking retirement, comment; graph; photos (M)

headline: Rambus Rises 18% as Hitachi Agrees to Pay Royalties
abstract: Rambus Rises 18% as Hitachi Agrees to Pay Royalties

headline: Jane Trahey, Ad Executive And Author, Is Dead at 76
abstract: Jane Trahey, one of most prominent advertising women of 1960's, dies at age 76; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Credit Offerings For Sale This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    American Capital Strategies Inc., Bethesda, Md., 4.5 million shares. Robertson Stephens.    Amphenol Corp., Wallingford, Conn., 6 million class A shares. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

headline: Dot-Coms: A Way to Burn Money, or to Fuel the Future?; Venture Capital Is Opening Doors
abstract: Venture capitalist Timothy Draper article defends financing mechanism for Internet startups, which he holds are changing way world works; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas surges on expectations that record heat in the West will spur utilities to burn more fuel; in New York, natural gas for July delivery rises 20.7 cents, or 4.9 percent, to $4.463 per million BTU's; graph; chart (S)

headline: A Bit of This and That: The Net as a Flea Market of Ideas
abstract: A Bit of This and That: The Net as a Flea Market of Ideas

headline: VA LINUX CHANGES TERMS FOR ACQUISITION OF ANDOVER.NET
abstract: VA Linux Systems cuts $60 million in cash from its agreement to buy Andover.Net and will acquire company for $279.3 million in stock; VA Linux agreed on Feb 3 to buy Andover.Net in cash and stock transaction then valued at $1.04 billion (S)

headline: CARLTON BUYS BIGGEST MOVIE ADVERTISING COMPANY IN U.S.
abstract: Carlton Communications buys Screenvision Cinema Network for $93.3 million (S)

headline: Reactions on Microsoft Decision Vary Greatly
abstract: April 3, 2000

headline: Can Internet advertisers police themselves? Washington remains unconvinced.
abstract: Internet advertisers are having tough time convincing US Government that they can police themselves despite months of effort; Federal Trade Commission and advertisers say they have made progress negotiating set of voluntary privacy standards that companies should follow when building profiles of Web surfers; but commission is not ready to say whether such agreement will go far enough to eliminate need for federal legislation (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Investing; Wireless Choices Rise Over the Static in Europe
abstract: Selloff among technology stocks prompts many European investors to move funds out of smaller, riskier companies and into the blue chips like the mobile phone makers Nokia and Ericsson, along with proven network providers like Vodafone; photo; graph (M)

headline: Pixelon.com Founder Was Fugitive From Virginia
abstract: Pixelon.com Founder Was Fugitive From Virginia

headline: A Secretive Team, on Guard for Nuclear Terror
abstract: WASHINGTON—  - The Nuclear Emergency Search Team — the Energy Department unit likened to a nuclear bomb squad that kept sensitive information on the two computer disks that disappeared at Los Alamos — is a highly secretive outfit little-known to the public.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper rises as report showing rebound in home construction signals robust demand for wire and pipes from builders; in New York, copper for July delivery rises 1.05 cents, to 85.1 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Rallying Round the China Bill, Hungrily: Pharmaceuticals; Approving Factories, But Not the Drugs
abstract: An unusually wide range of US companies has banded together to lobby Congress in support of pending China trade bill; pharmaceutical industry says pact would strengthen protection of patents and other intellectual property rights, lower tariffs and allow foreign drug companies to distribute their products themselves; current barriers to trade are such that some companies have built factories in China, only to be denied approval for some drugs they planned to make there; US drug companies already sell about $700 million worth of drugs to China (M)

headline: Rape of Mexican Teenager Stirs Abortion Outcry
abstract: Feminist groups and some prominent intellectuals in Mexico take up cause of teenage rape victim who was dissuaded from abortion by doctors and by senior state officials, even though abortion is legal for rape victims in Mexicali, where she lives; no official ever refused her the abortion, but they counseled her against it so openly and forcefully that she and her family became frightened and desisted; as many as half million women terminate their pregnancies clandestinely each year in Mexico; photo (M)

headline: With the Loss Of an Old Foe, Israelis See A Cloud Lifted
abstract: Israeli leaders proclaimed today that the death of President Hafez al-Assad of Syria had ushered in a new era or at least ushered out an old one in the Middle East. But no one could predict what that portended beyond a potentially problematic transition period.     There was no mourning, no celebration of the death and no reassessment here of an Arab leader familiar to generations of Israelis as a sworn enemy of their state yet one who inspired sometimes ambivalent feelings as a cunning leader and a worthy adversary, too.

headline: ELECTRONIC DATA BIDS FOR POLICY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS
abstract: Shares of Policy Management Systems Corp rise as much as 45 percent after Electronic Data Systems Corp offers to buy Policy Management for $18 to $20 a share, topping bid by Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe; Policy Management shares rise $5.375, to $18.625; EDS offer values Policy Management at $640.6 million to $711.8 million (S)

headline: Japanese Mobile Phone Operator to Cut Back
abstract: NTT DoCoMo Inc, Japan's largest mobile phone operator, says it will sharply cut sales of cellular telephone handsets that offer Internet access through end of May to ease load on its overtaxed infrastructure; will also suspend ads for its Internet access service, called i-mode, until it fixes its service problems by increasing capacity of its servers; promises to refund 140 million yen, or $1.3 million at current exchange rates, to i-mode users who have had difficulty connecting to network between March 28 and April 19 (M)

headline: Summer Movie Sites Lack Hollywood´s Digital Magic
Paid Notice: Deaths  EGAN, JANET
abstract: EGAN-Janet, on April 12, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence. Devoted mother of Francis, Robert and Lawrence. Dear sister of Hugh McGuire. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Reposing: John F.X. McKeon Funeral Home, 3129 Perry Avenue, Bronx, NY, Thursday 2-5, 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Brendan's Church, Friday, 1 PM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    GERMANY: COMPENSATION FOR NAZIS' SLAVES -- The upper house of Parliament unanimously approved a bill that would provide Nazi-era slave laborers with $4.6 billion in compensation. The legislation now goes to the lower house. American and German officials hope to work out the unresolved issues -- like calls by German companies for immunity from future claims -- before President Clinton arrives in early June to sign an accord with Chancellor Gerhard Schroder.   Alan Maimon (NYT)    SWITZERLAND: AN AUSCHWITZ SETTLEMENT -- The government reached a settlement with a brother and a sister whose parents died in Auschwitz after the family was deported from Switzerland in 1942, the first such voluntary payment by Switzerland. The Finance Ministry and the lawyer for the two, Charles and Sabine Sonabend, said Switzerland had agreed to pay 200,000 Swiss francs ($115,100). The Sonabends withdrew lawsuits seeking compensation.   (Reuters)    CROATIA: 11 SERBS GUILTY OF WAR CRIMES -- A court in Vukovar found 11 Croatian Serbs guilty of war crimes, the HINA news agency reported. Twenty-two Serbs had been indicted, of whom 21 were tried in absentia for genocide and war crimes against civilians during the Serbian siege of Vukovar in 1991. The court rejected the accusations of genocide, HINA said. The sentences range from 3 to 20 years.   (Agence France-Presse)    BELARUS: EX-PREMIER SENTENCED -- A court sentenced Mikhail Chigir, a former prime minister and leading opposition figure, to three years in prison, suspended for two years, for abuse of power, and thus barred him from coming elections. A judge at Minsk Municipal Court said Mr. Chigir's favoritism toward a company had caused damage to the state, and also ordered him to pay $209,000 in damages, a huge sum in impoverished Belarus.   (Reuters)    RUSSIA: EXTENSION ON CHEMICAL WEAPONS -- The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons has given Russia until April 2002 to begin destroying its 40,000-ton arsenal of chemical weapons. The first 1 percent was to have been destroyed last month. Now, 20 percent is to be destroyed by April 2002. Russia holds the world's largest stockpile, followed by the United States, which has destroyed 17 percent of its 32,000 tons.   (Reuters)    THE NETHERLANDS: FIREWORKS OWNERS HELD -- The police arrested an owner of the fireworks factory that exploded last weekend, killing at least 17. The man, W. Pater, turned himself in. The authorities had issued a warrant for Mr. Pater and his partner, R. Bakker, on suspicion that they had broken regulations for storing fireworks. Arson is also suspected.   (Reuters)    ITALY: SOCCER 'PEACE MATCH' -- Palestinian and Israeli soccer players plan to play together against a team of Italian pop stars in Rome on Thursday. The idea came from Archbishop Pietro Sambi, the papal nuncio in Israel, who has contacts in Italian show business. Uri Savir, the Israeli organizer, said: ''Palestinians and Israelis have never competed against each other, at least not in soccer. It is no small matter that they will play on the same team.''   Alessandra Stanley (NYT)    GREECE: TURKISH WARPLANES ARRIVE -- A dozen Turkish F-16 warplanes landed near Volos, in central Greece, for NATO exercises, the first presence of such Turkish aircraft on Greek territory, according to Ioannis Papatheodossiou, a spokesman for the Greek military command. In past exercises, they had avoided involvement with each other.   (Agence France-Presse)    ASIA    PHILIPPINES: NEW HOSTAGE TALKS -- Malaysia is trying to break the impasse in efforts to free 21 hostages held by rebels in the southern Philippines after talks between negotiators and the captors stalled. The Malaysian ambassador, Muhammad Arshad Manzoor Hussain, met four commanders of the rebel group Thursday, and though their demands were unclear, no ransom demands were made. The 21 hostages -- nine Malaysians, three Germans, two French citizens, two Finns, two South Africans, two Filipinos and a Lebanese -- were kidnapped at Malaysian resort across the sea border on April 23.   (Agence France-Presse)    PAKISTAN: STRIKES HALT BUSINESS -- Commerce was shut down in all major cities by twin strikes, one called by business people protesting the military government's efforts to impose new taxes, the other led by religious political parties angry over the killing of Muhammad Yusuf Ludhianvi, a prominent Muslim scholar.   Barry Bearak (NYT)    SRI LANKA: PEACE NEGOTIATOR FROM NORWAY -- In an effort to broker a peace agreement between the government and the Tamil Tiger rebels, Norwegian diplomats said, they will visit Colombo, the Sri Lankan capital, next week.   Barry Bearak (NYT)    THE AMERICAS    CANADA: VAST PERSONAL DATABASE -- The privacy commissioner, Bruce Phillips, disclosed that the government has compiled a database on 33 million Canadians, living and dead. The Longitudinal Labor Force File contains up to 2,000 pieces of information on each subject, including ethnicity, education, travel, marital status, disabilities and tax and employment details. In the face of opposition criticism, Jane Stewart, whose ministry, Human Resources, maintains the database, said in Parliament, ''There is limited access and the information is secure.''   James Brooke (NYT)    CANADA: SEARCH FOR LOST JEWELS -- Lloyd's of London plans to use a small submarine this summer to vacuum the ocean floor near Halifax, Nova Scotia, where a Swissair jet carrying $200 million in diamonds and jewels crashed in 1998. In the crash, which killed all 229 people aboard, a Picasso painting worth about $35 million was destroyed, and a stainless tube packed with 4 pounds of diamonds and 11 pounds of jewels was lost. Lyn Romano, whose husband was killed in the crash, denounced the plan, adding, ''Their little suction adventure to recover their precious gems may recover something a little bit more precious to me.''   James Brooke (NYT)    AFRICA    UGANDA: REBEL LEADERS CAPTURED -- The army ambushed a group of rebels in eastern Congo, capturing five commanders of the Allied Democratic Forces, according to the army spokesman, Capt. Shaban Bantariza. Those captured included Bwambale Ali, the top commander, and two officers identified as Junju and Bilambala. The ambush came less than a month after the rebel chief, Mansur Arinaitwe, surrendered to Ugandan troops in Congo. The Allied Democratic Forces have been fighting since 1996 to oust President Yoweri Museveni.   (AP)    MALAWI: ELECTION CONFIRMED -- The High Court upheld the electoral commission's declaration that President Bakili Muluzi was the lawful winner of last year's election. Judge Isaac Mtambo said, ''Muluzi satisfied the constitutional requirement, and he won by a majority of the electorate who voted.'' The opposition had challenged the commission's declaration and said that there was evidence of vote-rigging in the election, in which Mr. Muluzi claimed 51 percent of the vote.   (Agence France-Presse)    NIGERIA: BAIL REFUSED FOR GENERAL -- A court in Lagos refused bail to a former army chief, Ishaya Bamaiyi, arguing that if released, he could seek to influence witnesses in his trial for attempted murder. Mr. Bamaiyi, who was army chief of staff under the late military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, is charged with trying to kill a former internal affairs minister and publisher, Alex Ibru, in February 1996.   (Agence France-Presse)    TANZANIA: CANDIDATES IN ZANZIBAR -- The chief minister in the semi-autonomous islands of Zanzibar and Pemba, Muhammad Gharib Bilal, joined the race to be president in elections on Oct. 29. Others seeking to run are Tanzania's deputy finance minister, Abdisalaam Khatib; two Zanzibar cabinet members, Aman Abeid Karume and Amina Salum Ali; a diplomat, Ahmed Hassan Diria; a businessman, Muhammad Raza; and the main opposition leader, Seif Shariff Hamad.   (Agence France-Presse)    SOUTH AFRICA: BAN ON PLASTIC BAGS -- The government plans to ban plastic bags, said the environment and tourism minister, Valli Moosa. A bill to ban the bags --a common form of litter -- is due next week. The cabinet has already approved steps toward banning the bags, termed daisies here because they dot so much of the countryside.   (Agence France-Presse)

headline: Canada's Anti-Corporate Crusader
abstract: Profile of Naomi Klein, whose new book, No Logo, has made her Canada's media star; Klein is at war with modern corporations, particularly their practice of farming out manufacturing to sweatshops in poorest corners of globe; she also objects to what she calls 'Big Brother branding' of products; her kind of anti-corporate, anti-marketing anger was seen boiling over in Seattle during meeting of World Trade Organization; photo (M)

headline: CANADIAN ENERGY COMPANY TO BE SOLD
abstract: Buffalo-based Natural Fuel Gas Co acquires Tri Link Resources Inc for about 340 million Canadian dollars ($230 million) in cash and assumed debt (S)

headline: Drug Wholesaler Settles With U.S.
abstract: Bindley Western Industries, fifth-largest US drug wholesaler, says it has taken $25.8 million charge against first-quarter earnings after reaching tentative settlement of federal fraud probe; in March, company said federal grand jury in Las Vegas was looking at sales from 1995 to 1997 at its Nevada and California operations; inquiry examined whether Bindley Western knowingly sold to customers who then resold discounted drugs at profit, in violation of contracts with pharmaceutical makers; Bindley Western says first-quarter profit from operations rose 25 percent to $12.1 million (S)

headline: CBS Finally Lures Coveted Young Viewers With 'Survivor'
abstract: Survivor, hit program about survival and relationship tests on tropical island, has stunned television industry by revitalizing CBS's appeal among coveted young viewers; show's success has enormous financial implications for CBS, with remaining commercials being snapped up by advisertisers at high rates; CBS weighs expanding finale from one hour to two; graphs of viewers by age; photos (M)

headline: Familiar Start-Up Story, With a Romantic Twist
abstract: Sally McGrane article on Germany's Internet startup scene profiles Inubit, software and services company that enables business-to-business marketplaces; notes business-to-business landscape is different than in United States, because corporate players in Germany are recognizing market's importance almost in tandem with startups; photo (M)

headline: The Outer Limits Of Antitrust Law
abstract: To the Editor:    ''Microsoft Will Test Justices' Prowess'' (June 4) asked whether the Supreme Court justices have the  technical competence to address the Microsoft antitrust case. As a former antitrust lawyer, I think that the court will have little difficulty.    But the important question is whether existing antitrust legislation, conceived 100 years ago, is an appropriate standard for evaluating anticompetitive behavior today.

headline: Molecules Engineered With an Inkjet Printer
abstract: Scientists at Sandia National Laboratories say they have found way to build very tiny structures on silicon chips by putting molecules into solution that is squirted onto various surfaces with inkjet printer to form patterns designed by computer; once on surface, molecules assemble themselves into desired shapes; Sandia scientists call their transparent solutions 'intelligent ink'; their approach may turn out to be practical way to build tiny molecular scaffolds called nanostructures; drawing (M)

headline: DISSATISFIED WITH STOCK PRICE, BAY VIEW WEIGHS OPTIONS
abstract: Bay View Capital Corp retains Merrill Lynch & Co to help in evaluating its options, including sale of some or all of its units (S)

headline: Dangerous Coal Mines Take Human Toll in China
abstract: Chinese officials admit country, which produces more coal than any other, also has probably world's worst mine safety record; coal bureau official says deaths hover around 10,000 annually, but mining experts say figure represents undercount and does not begin to account for nonfatal injuries; international data indicate for every million tons of coal produced, China has 11 times as many reported fatalities as Russia, 15 times as many as India and 182 times as many as US; mining conditions in some regions, such as in Datong in Shanxi Province, described; map; chart; photo (M)

headline: Andrew Choa, 76, Former Bank Executive
abstract: Andrew Choa, an international banker and professional adviser, died on May 17 in a hospital in Mount Vernon, Va. He was 76. His family said he had had vascular disease for a year.

headline: April Trade Gap Narrowed, With Easing of Oil Prices
abstract: Commerce Department says nation's trade deficit narrowed in April from record in March as decline in oil prices offset record demand for foreign-made autos; April deficit shrank to $30.44 billion from $30.6 billion in March; deficit is on track to reach $350 billion this year, compared with record $265 billion in 1999; imports of goods and services fell 0.2 percent, to $117.14 billion; imports of consumer goods rose 1.8 percent after increasing 6.4 percent in March; trade deficit with Japan grew to record $7.3 billion in April, and deficit with China widened to $5.8 billion from $5.1 billion in March; deficit with Canada rose to $3.9 billion, while deficit with Mexico fell to $1.5 billion and deficit with Western Europe fell to $4.6 billion; graph (M)

headline: Voice-Controlled Software From I.B.M.
abstract: IBM introduces software that allows individuals access to information on Internet by speaking commands over telephone (S)

headline: Iran Reformers Feeling Pressed By Hard-Liners
abstract: Reformers in Iran, two months after their triumph in parliamentary elections, have come under fierce pressure from powerful Islamic conservatives; hard-liners have jailed writers and annulled some election results; Tehran courts have ordered eight daily and four weekly newspapers to stop publishing; banned newspapers that supported Pres Mohammad Khatami, whose calls for reform of judiciary and for open political debate have won him broad public support, but also fierce enemies in clerical establishment; photo (M)

headline: Pets.com to Acquire Competitor Petstore.com
abstract: Pets.com to Acquire Competitor Petstore.com

headline: Damages Awarded in Fen-Phen Case
abstract: Oregon jury says American Home Products Corp should pay $29.2 million to Richard Wirt and his mother, Juanita Batson, who contended company's withdrawn diet drugs damaged their hearts; jurors conclude drugs--part of discontinued fen-phen diet combination--caused heart problems for Wirt and Batson and that company hid drugs' risks; American Home plans to appeal decision (S)

headline: Judging People by the Pictures They Keep
abstract: Article on photographs employees choose to display on their desks and image they try to present; tour of workspaces and photos displayed by employees at Vanguard Group in Malvern, Pa, including Vanguard's chief executive John J Brennan, discussed; photos (M)

headline: What Market Windfall?
abstract: Two-thirds of Americans surveyed for Keyport Life Insurance Co about retirement plans say they have not gained substantially from decadelong stock market boom; most expect to maintain same or higher standard of living in retirement, but most are unrealistic about how much money they will need to do so; graph (M)

headline: Trading More Now For Less Later
abstract: Recently enacted change in Social Security law gives workers in their late 60's the option of drawing full pension regardless of how much they earn; previously, people between 65 and 70 who earned more than $17,000 a year had benefits reduced, and those who earned $52,000 or more a year had benefits deferred entirely until they turned 70; new law still gives those who opt to wait until 70 larger checks thereafter, but deferring payments is a bet on beating average life expectancy; many people will be tempted to take full benefits earlier, raising possibility of facing poverty in deep old age; graph (M)

headline: CHIP MAKER'S PROFIT DOUBLES
abstract: STMicroelectronics NV, Europe's biggest chip maker, says first-quarter profit more than doubled; net income rose to $238.4 million from $105.1 million; sales rose 53 percent, to $1.7 billion from $1.11 billion; chief executive Pasquale Pistorio comments; photo (S)

headline: GEPHARDT OPPOSES CHINA TRADE BILL
