abstract: House Democratic leader Richard A Gephardt, in setback for Clinton administration, reportedly plans to oppose granting China permanent normal trading privileges; is expected to free House Democrats to vote their consciences and best interests of their districts; House vote is considered too close to call (M)

headline: Departure of Executive Is Expected at Oldsmobile
abstract: Oldsmobile division of General Motors Corp plans to announce that its general manager, Karen Francis, has resigned (M)

headline: OBITUARY : Lila Kedrova Howard, Actress
abstract: LONDON—  SAULT STE. MARIE, Ontario (AP) — Lila Kedrova Howard, who won an Oscar award and a Tony award for her role as Madame Hortense in the film and stage version of "Zorba the Greek," has died of heart failure.

headline: Organic Farming, Seeking the Mainstream
abstract: Profile of scene at Rodale Institute's 330-acre research farm in Kutztown, Pa; Rodale plants crops with goal of harvesting evidence that organic farming should be wave of future; farm manager Jeff Moyer observes that Rodale's trials show that improving quality of soil through organic processes can mean difference between a harvest or hardship in time of drought; Rodale's results in 1999 also reinforce long-term comparisons, begun by Rodale in 1981, that document how organic farming can be more profitable for small farmers--even if yields are not always as high and, by some calculations, even without premium prices that organic crops generally receive; organic movement is seen still some distance from becoming mainstream enterprise that Rodale and other advocates have long envisioned; photos; charts (L)

headline: In China Pact, Executives Sense a Hornet's Nest
abstract: White House economic adviser Gene Sperling's promotion of China trade pact, and corporate executives' concern about public and union opinion against liberalization, discussed; photo (M)

headline: QIAGEN TO ACQUIRE OPERON FOR $110 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: Qiagen NV acquires Operon Technologies Inc for about $110 million in stock (S)

headline: Bush Debates Foreign Policy With Russian
abstract: Gov George W Bush meets with Russian Foreign Min Igor Ivanov, reportedly at Ivanov's request, to air differences over missile defense system and Chechnya; Bush expresses hope that US and Russia can work together to keep peace in world; Bush, accompanied by several foreign policy advisers, says talks ranged from discussion of Pres-elect Vladimor V Putin's goals for his country, to United States investment in Russia, to American interest in developing antimissile defense system; like many other Republicans, Bush says he would back out of 1972 ABM treaty to free US to pursue its own course, should Russia refuse to amend that treaty; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil rises on expectations that OPEC will keep output levels unchanged when it meets next week; in New York, crude oil for July delivery rises 82 cents, or 2.6 percent, to $32.56 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Gannett Quarterly Profit Up, Fueled by Strong Economy
abstract: Gannett Co says first-quarter earnings rose 19 percent; says profit from continuing operations rose to $203 million, compared with $170 million a year ago; revenue increased 15 percent, to $1.36 billion from $1.19 billion (M)

headline: U.S. vs. MICROSOFT: Microsoft at the Razor's Edge; On the Inside: Soldiering On Toward Victory
abstract: Interview with Microsoft chief exec Steven A Ballmer, who was in Europe meeting with customers, when Federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson issued antitrust ruling against company; Ballmer reports support for company among European customers who want Microsoft's integrated products and foresees no let up in pace of deals; remains upbeat and intends to focus on next-generation products while appeals process goes forward; photos (M)

headline: ABC goes in search of a younger audience for its soap operas.
abstract: ABC television network has developed ambitious advertising campaign intended to stimulate demand among consumers 16 to 24 for four of its daytime soap operas; four ABC soaps are suffering declines in viewership as millions of women work outside the home; photo (Advertising column) (M)

headline: High-Tech Boom Near Santa's House
abstract: Oulu, Finland, improbable technology boomtown, is thriving as center for research on wireless data communications; driven in part by mobile phone maker Nokia, Oulu has become hotbed for start-ups; photo (M)

headline: HOMETOWN ISN'T PANICKING YET
abstract: Although it gave Seattle's roaring economy a bit of a jolt yesterday, the court ruling did not seem to generate any large sense of panic. Page C1.

headline: Gannett to Acquire Chain Tied to the Pulliam Family
abstract: Gannett Co agrees to acquire Central Newspapers Inc, owner of The Arizona Republic, Indianapolis Star and four other daily newspapers, for $2.6 billion in cash; acquisition is end of long reign of Pulliam family, descendants of company founder Eugene C Pulliam (M)

headline: California Wine Region Torn By Debate Over Use of Land
abstract: California tiger salamander's emergency listing as endangered species thwarts efforts of many cattle ranchers to convert their land into vineyards; in Santa Barbara County, with its prosperous wine market, conditions are ideal for grape growing; since 1996, amount of land dedicated to vineyards has gone from 9,000 acres to more than 20,000 in place or being developed; even before salamander entered picture, there were bitter disputes over uprooting of California live oaks for vineyards, over way some slopes were bulldozed and over social events some wineries tried to hold; debate highlights question of where capitalism ends and public interest begins; photo; map (M)

headline: World Trade Officials Pledging To Step Up Effort Against AIDS
abstract: World finance ministers and central bankers, trying to show sensitivity to poverty as protests against World Bank and International Monetary Fund meeting wind down in driving rain, Washington, DC, pledge to pay more attention to globalization's victims and to commit 'unlimited money' to fight AIDS in poor nations; hold World Bank should intensify its fight against AIDS because disease is as much problem of poverty as public health; pledge to accelerate debt relief for developing world and press rich nations to agree to import certain products from poorest ones duty free; United States waters down language on duty-free market access to bar Congressional backlash; Mayor Anthony A Williams says police handled protests properly, news conference; protests close down normal business in city, with many city and federal workers told to stay home and many streets closed, but are unable to disrupt IMF and IBRD meetings; World Bank president James D Wolfensohn complains IBRD is being accused of causing poverty when its workers are devoted to easing poverty; map; photo (M)

headline: PLX to Acquire Sebring
abstract: PLX Technology, maker of computer chips for Internet routers and switches, acquires Sebring Networks for about $48 million in stock (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Switch to 2000 Now Complete, Agency Closes
abstract: President's Council on Year 2000 Conversion shuts down after issuing report holding threat of widespread computer disruptions was real and that experience contains valuable lessons; report includes sampling of breakdowns that occurred despite hundreds of billions of dollars spent on repairs and planning; John A Koskinen, panel chairman, comments, interview; drawing (M)

headline: Lilly Reports 18% Increase In Profit for First Quarter
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co says first-quarter profit rose 18 percent; profit from operations rose to $692.3 million compared with $588.8 million in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 13 percent, to $2.54 billion from $2.26 billion; chairman Sidney Taurel comments; photo (M)

headline: AIRTEL OWNERSHIP TRUCE
abstract: Britain's Vodafone AirTouch PLC and British Telecommunications PLC agree to share control of Airtel Movil SA, second-largest Spanish mobile-phone company; Vodafone will increase its present 22 percent stake to up to 55 percent, while British Telecommunications will have option to build its stake from 18 percent to as much as 45 percent (S)

headline: APBnews.com Runs Out of Money
abstract: APBnews.com Runs Out of Money

headline: Commerce One Drops on Confirmation of AppNet Buy
On a Shoe Quest From Clicks to Mortar
abstract: Michelle Slatalla (Online Shopper) article on shopping for shoes on the Internet (M)

headline: The World of Microsoft
abstract: Letter by Arnie Huberman responds to June 1 article on computer gamers; says he got taste of what he calls predatory practice by Microsoft when it bought site, www.zone.com, and restricted access to persons using a PC running Windows or using Internet Explorer

headline: Will Today's Huge Rewards Devour Tomorrow's Earnings?
abstract: America's business leaders say their soaring salaries and stock options are justified by their companies' rising stock value; claim promise of wealth, in form of stock options, inspires them to create efficient companies that are driving longest economic expansion in American history; executives' huge stock options worry some analysts, who warn of potential for long-term problems that could undercut economic growth; say as top executives exercise their rising pile of options over next decade, other stockholders will see their stakes watered down; notes that companies are already spending billions of dollars, and taking on rising levels of debt, to buy back shares to minimize dilution; drawing (M)

headline: Fashionmall.com Swoops In for the Boo.com Fire Sale
abstract: Fashionmall.com acquires remaining units of bankrupt Boo.com, fashion Web retailer; deal opens new chapter in troubled life of Boo.com, which was originally backed by French luxury-goods magnate Bernard Arnault, Benetton family of Italy, J P Morgan and Goldman Sachs, among others (M)

headline: Caught in Swings of a Volatile Market
abstract: Capricious swings of volatile stock market force Silicon Valley companies to deal with climate that can alter their prospects in course of trading day for no easily discernible reason; employees and executives find creative ways to cope with--and tune out--what they cannot control; look inside HearMe, which makes software for voice chat over Internet, illustrates how one such company, and its rank-and-file employees, cope financially and emotionally with being caught up in market's volatility; photos; graphs (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Mayer Offman; Carlin Equities Group
abstract: Mayer Offman, chief investment strategist at Carlin Equities Group, which caters to day traders, invests about 75 percent of his own portfolio in positions that are held for no longer than a day, 15 percent in investments of two or three months and the rest in what he calls 'quirks,' such as merger candidates; may make as many as 500 trade a day in particularly active rising market; a devout Jew and ordained rabbi, Offman says his trading returns decline when he slacked off on his devotions and improved again once he resumed his synagogue worship; photo (M)

headline: PrivateSector; Chipper Days for Dr. Gloom
abstract: Henry Kaufman, author of forthcoming On Money and Markets: A Wall Street Memoir, links risk-taking in the market to ignorance of financial history; photo (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   9.50   9.50   7.75       Discount rate   6.00   6.00   4.50       Federal funds   6.50   6.63   4.91       3-month T-bills   5.65   5.68   4.69       6-month T-bills   5.94   5.95   4.90       10-yr. T-infl.   4.08   4.08   4.01       10-yr. T-note   6.08   6.10   5.92       30-yr. T-bond   5.94   5.98   6.06       Telephone bd.   8.19   8.33   7.81       Municipal bds.   5.93   5.93   5.55          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: U.N. Mission in Kosovo Proposes to Set Up a War Crimes Court
abstract: Bernard Kouchner, who heads United Nations mission in Kosovo, plans to create an internationally run court to try war and ethnic crimes in the province (M)

headline: Threat Eases As U.N. Adds To Peace Force In Sierra Leone
abstract: 300 Jordanian peacekeepers arrive in Sierra Leone and 100 UN civilian employees returnas threat to capital recedes and pro-government forces prepare to push rebels further east; photo (S)

headline: C. D. Atkins, 86, Inventor of Orange Juice Process
abstract: C D Atkins, inventor of frozen concentrated orange juice, dies at age 86 (S)

headline: Making Sure Brand-New Teachers Know Technology
U.S. Is Said to Seek New Law to Bolster Privacy on Internet
abstract: FTC, concluding that Internet companies have not properly protected privacy of consumers, will ask Congress for authority to impose tough privacy safeguards; survey has found that only about twenty percent of major Web companies have adequate safeguards; request is sharp departure from FTC's policy of relying in industry self-policing; FTC will seek authority to regulate notices to consumers on use of their information, allow FTC to set rules for keeping data secure and authorize penalties; nine Democratic senators also plan to introduce similar legislation; photo of Sen Ernest Hollings (M)

headline: Mbeki Details Quest to Grasp South Africa's AIDS Disaster
abstract: South African Pres Thabo Mbeki tells international AIDS panel of his months-long effort to understand medical evidence on epidemic ravaging his country; says he began to considered theory that HIV does not cause AIDS in effort to understand why epidemic is different in sub-Saharan Africa (S)

headline: Big Accounting Firms Agree To S.E.C. 'Look Back' Audit
abstract: Big Five accounting firms, in response to inquiry into possible breaches in independence of corporate auditors, will open up investment portfolios of partners and top managers to Securities and Exchange Commission; Pricewaterhouse-Coopers, Deloitte & Touche, Arthur Andersen, Ernst & Young and KPMG will hire independent counsel to conduct review and report violations to commission (S)

headline: MAKER OF DEVICES FOR HEART PATIENTS SELLS UNIT TO RIVAL
abstract: Edwards Lifesciences Corp to sell its Novacor unit to World Heart Corp for shares valued at $58 million (S)

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS
abstract: Perhaps it should not come as a surprise. In this country where anything that moves is likely to have an advertisement slapped on it, several California-based companies now pay drivers to adorn their cars with ads for products ranging from juice bars to Internet services.

headline: Reporter's Notebook; As Term Winds Down, Nostalgia Envelops Clinton
abstract: reporter's Notebook column on Pres Clinton's final trip to Europe as president; trip has had decidedly nostalgic air, as if much unfinished business will be left that way and as if parts of presidency are already over; photo (M)/

headline: Microsoft Urges Court to Start on Appeal
abstract: Microsoft Corp tells Court of Appeals that judges should ignore government brief asking them not to begin work on company's antitrust appeal until Supreme Court decides whether to take it (M)

headline: Trying to Give Bomb Squad Robots Brains to Match Their Brawn
abstract: Daniel Sorid (What's Next) article discusses efforts by Phil Bennett, mechanical engineer at Sandia national laboratory, to use lab's technology to make bomb squad robots better; says Bennett found that major flaw in such robots is that controls are unwieldy and, as result, they are underused by police and security officers; plans to adapt for bomb robots a software called Smart, developed at Sandia, that allows robots to use components made by different vendors (M)

headline: Statement by Fed Panel
abstract: Text of statement by Federal Open Market Committee, Federal Reserve's monetary policy panel, after its decision to raise short-term interest rates

headline: Waves of Chinese Masterpieces Storm Market
abstract: NEW YORK—  Like an unstoppable tide, China is looming ever larger on the art scene. Without anyone taking much notice, Chinese objects have now become the most expensive of all in the international market.

headline: ICAHN MAKES BID TO BUY THE REST OF STRATOSPHERE
abstract: Financier Carl C Icahn, who already controls 89.6 percent stake in Stratosphere Corp, offers to buy rest of casino operator for $44.35 a share, about $9.4 million; Icahn's offer values company at $90 million (S)

headline: What is a dot-com brand name worth? A new survey has some not-too-surprising answers.
abstract: Survey by Greenfield Online, Internet market research company, shows Microsoft.com has highest 'brand power,' defined as combination of rankings in three categories: brand familiarity, brand's ability to affect Internet landscape and brand's perceived financial strength; following Microsoft.com in survey are four well-known dot-coms: Amazon.com, Netscape.com, AOL.com and eBay.com (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Turks Have a Sense of a Swing Toward a Fuller Democracy
abstract: Inauguration Ahmet Necdet Sezer as Turkey's new president on May 16 may usher in new and fuller period of democracy; former reform-minded chief justice of Turkey's highest court favors repeal of laws that limit free speech and used to imprison journalists and politicians for voicing allegedly subversive views; has called for end to ban on teaching and broadcasting in Kurdish language; wants all government agencies, including military, to submit to rule of law; has become hero to Turks wanting to modernize political system (M)

headline: Oil Industry Balks at Priceline Gasoline Offer
abstract: Oil Industry Balks at Priceline Gasoline Offer

headline: Putin Is Made Russia's President In First Free Transfer of Power
abstract: Vladimir V Putin is inaugurated as Russia's second president, vowing to respect and guard human and civil rights; reappoints Mikhail Kasyanov as acting prime minister; ceremonies at Kremlin, attended by former Pres Boris Yeltsin, represent first democratic transfer of executive power in all of Russia's 1,100-year history; photos (M)

headline: Clinton Said to Sidestep a Sticking Point in Talk With Arafat
abstract: Pres Clinton meets with Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat at White House to try to set stage for three-way summit meeting in Washington with Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak; administration official says Clinton and Arafat are paying particular attention to proposed borders for a Palestinian state but have sidestepped issue of Israel's final withdrawal from West Bank; photo (M)

headline: Stars and Stripes Sold to IServed
abstract: Military newspaper Stars and Stripes is sold by National Tribune Corp to iServed.com; financial terms undisclosed; paper is separate from similarly titled newspapers published by Defense Department (S)

headline: China Makes Gains in Spurring Growth
abstract: Chinese official says gross domestic product grew 8.1 percent in first quarter from 1999 period, compared with 6.8 percent growth in fourth quarter; gain, vindication for Prime Min Zhu Rongji, suggests slide in China's economic growth may be ending (M)

headline: Private Sector; Executive Pay Gets a Second Look
abstract: Comment on decision by Computer Associates to have founder Charles B Wang and executives Sanjay Kumar and Russell J Artzt return 22 percent of millions of shares of stock they received following decision by Delaware Chancery Court, which ruled shares were given under plan that lacked clause adjusting their awards for splits (S)

headline: 'Privatized' Doesn't Mean Perfect
abstract: off the shelf: 'privatized' doÿ

headline: U.S. Court Upholds Limits On Size of Cable Operators
abstract: Federal appeals court upholds law limiting size of cable television companies; ruling is likely to effect largest-ever merger in that industry, of A T & T with MediaOne (S)

headline: Taiwan Is Putting U.S. on the Spot by Campaigning for Better Missile Defenses Against China
abstract: Taiwan's military is campaigning for big improvement of its missile defenses in face of China's threats and its growing force of missiles pointed at island; Taiwan has put Washington in uncomfortable position by asking to buy some of best American weaponry; United States is pledged to help Taiwan defend itself but is also trying to mend ties with China, which warns that it will regard any major weapons sales as hostile act (M)

headline: Triarc Will Spin Off Snapple Beverage Unit
abstract: Triarc will spin off part of its beverage division, which includes Snapple, Mistic and Royal Crown brands; shares in new company, to be called Snapple Beverage Group and consisting of up to 20 percent of Triarc's soft drink holdings, will be sold during third quarter of year (M)

headline: CASCADE HIRES ADVISER TO CONSIDER ALTERNATIVES
abstract: Cascade Corp, maker of lift attachments for trucks, hires Gleacher & Co to advise it on alternatives, including possible sale of company (S)

headline: Adobe Results Top Analyst Forecasts
abstract: Adobe Results Top Analyst Forecasts

headline: Eastern Europe's Foray Into 'M-Commerce'
abstract: Eastern European countries, particularly Czech Republic, are in forefront of 'm-commerce,' which brings e-commerce to consumers via mobile phone; Eastern European consumer spending has risen but credit cards and checks are viewed with suspicion, and most transactions are carried out in cash; m-commerce uses mobile phones in place of credit/debit cards; in some countries, as many as one in four households owns a mobile phone; people feel close to their mobile phones, which they perceive a trusted personal devices; expenditures are debited to bank accounts or charged to phone bills; photo (M)

headline: Russian Security Agencies Raid Media Empire's Offices
abstract: Federal agents wielding guns and wearing black masks stage raid on Moscow headquarters of Media-MOST, Russia's largest private media empire, raising alarms among politicians and journalists about prospects for independent press under pres Vladimir V Putin; Media-MOST controls influential radio and television stations as well as newspaper, news magazine and other publications; top law enforcement officials issue conflicting statements on purpose of criminal probe; Vladimir Gusinsky, president and founder of Media-MOST, says raid is meant as political pressure; photo (M)

headline: Bursting Bubbles: Web Tales of Speculation
abstract: Charles Mackay 1841 book, available on two web sites, traces three financial bubbles of past that offer lessons for today's investors: tulipmania that swept Holland in 1600's, Southsea Bubble that caused 1720 British stock market crash and Mississippi Bubble, which occured in 18th century France; other Web sites dealing with these bubbles noted; photo (M)

headline: A Huge British Telecom Latin Investment
abstract: British Telecommunications PLC plans to invest billions of dollars in Latin American region; Mexico, Brazil and Argentina are key growth markets for telecommunications and cellular telephone market; photo (M)

headline: Wall Street Views U.S. Plan for Microsoft as Old News
abstract: Wall Street Views U.S. Plan for Microsoft as Old News

headline: Egreetings Stock Jumps on Microsoft Pact
abstract: Egreetings Stock Jumps on Microsoft Pact

headline: WPP Said to Be Close to Deal To Acquire Young & Rubicam
abstract: WPP Group of Britain reportedly nears agreement to acquire Young & Rubicam Inc in New York for about $5.5 billion; deal would be largest advertising agency merger in history and would create largest advertising company in world (S)

headline: Divided against each other; united against the government.
abstract: Some members of panel on monopolies warn that planned merger of America Online and Time Warner could turn Internet from open prairie into collection of fenced and gated estates; spokesman for Disney's ABC network use Time Warner's recent ABC blackout as evidence of why merger would be dangerous; Lawrence Lessig of Harvard Law School claims that as Internet service progresses from narrow to broadband, it would be easier for those providing service to favor some forms of content--theirs--over others; surprisingly, AOL-Time Warner merger is not opposed by Joel Klein, Justice Dept official leading government's antitrust case against Microsoft Corp; Klein says technology is so powerful that there will be alternative mechanisms into the home, while in Microsoft case, company was able to restrict access to personal computers; drawing (M)

headline: Jewish Losses Cited
abstract: A report on assets seized from Jews in France during World War II concluded that the Nazis and French collaborators stole far more than was previously assumed. But it also found extensive efforts to return the property or to reimburse Jews after the war. The report was commissioned as part of an effort by the French authorities to render justice to survivors, and Jewish leaders in France generally praised it.    Article, page A4.

headline: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
abstract: May 11, 2000          Tony Cenicola for The New York Times

headline: FOREIGN BIDDERS FOR BRAZIL OIL
abstract: Petroleo Brasileiro SA, Brazil's national petroleum agency, says it authorized 44 companies from around the world, including the Exxon Mobil Corp and Texaco Inc, to bid on 23 new oil and gas exploration blocks as part of the government's effort to diversify country's petroleum industry (S)

headline: At This Web Site, Buyers Get Sales Without Circulars
abstract: Web site called Shoppinglist.com sorts through retail sales circulars and guides user to nearby store to purchase desired items (S)

headline: The Maniac Markets; An Earnings Engine
abstract: Focus on outlook for shares of Yahoo Inc following high-tech selloff; even though value of shares have fallen by approximately 50% from high of $240 in December 1999, company's fans are as confident as ever in its future; photo; graph (M)

headline: BRAZILIAN GAS AUCTION
abstract: Spanish Gas Natural SA, winning auction on Sao Paulo stock exchange, pays 534 million reais ($297 million) for rights to distribute natural gas to 93 cities in south of Sao Paulo State (S)

headline: New Flurry of Economic Data Shows Little Sign of Slowdown
abstract: Sales of new single-family houses soared in March to their second-fastest pace on record and index of growth expectations rose, suggesting record economic expansion still has legs; sales of new single-family homes unexpectedly rose 4.5 percent in March, to seasonally adjusted annual rate of 966,000 units after falling 0.6 percent in February; median price of new home rose 3.1 percent, to $165,000 from $160,000 in February; Conference Board reports index of leading economic indicators rose 0.1 percent in March after 0.3 percent decline in February; graph on leading indicators (M)

headline: 15 Radio Stations Sold
abstract: Triad Broadcasting Co agrees to buy 15 radio stations from Adventure Communications Inc for $25.6 million; is buying 9 radio stations in Bluefield, W Va, and 6 stations in market covering Hilton Head, SC, and Savannah, Ga (S)

headline: Habib Bourguiba, Independence Champion and President of Tunisia, Dies at 96
abstract: Habib Bourguiba, who was president of Tunisia from 1957 to 1987 after leading country to independence from France, dies at age 96; photo (M)

headline: HEALTHEON TO PAY MORE SHARES FOR MEDICAL MANAGER
abstract: Healtheon/WebMD Corp increases by 52 percent number of shares it will exchange for Medical Manager Corp, parent of rival, CareInsite Inc, amid speculation that transaction could unravel; Healtheon shares have plunged 70 percent since it announced $5.4 billion purchase of both companies Feb 14, cutting value to about $1.68 billion (S)

headline: A New Service on the Net That Will Take Dictation
abstract: New Internet dictation service, iDictate.com, promises to turn spoken words into polished document in about hour, 24 hours a day; service uses typists based around world (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: DATEK ONLINE HOLDINGS, Iselin, N.J., named Thomas F. Robards chief financial officer. He had been chief financial officer, executive vice president and treasurer at Republic New York Corp., which was recently acquired by HSBC Holdings.    LEHMAN BROTHERS HOLDINGS, New York, named David Goldfarb, controller and chief financial officer at its broker-dealer unit Lehman Brothers Inc., to the post of chief financial officer. He succeeds John Cecil.

headline: The Joyful Noise Backlash
abstract: Lisa Belkin's Life's Work column on coping with noises such as barking, crying or humming while working from home; drawing (M)

headline: Downloading Some Life Back Into Downtown
abstract: Joel Kotkin, Grass Roots Business column, notes Iowa, like other states, has been promoting Internet as tool to help revive rural communities that have fallen into decline amid industrialization and consolidation of agricultural economy; finds rural Iowa continues to suffer 'Dakotaization,' while winners in state's emerging new economy have been larger urban centers that serve as telecommunications switching centers and enjoy best airport and highway connections; profiles town of Manning's reinvention itself as telecom center; photos, map (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: AFRICA    ETHIOPIA, ERITREA: POSSIBLE PACT  Eritrea said it had accepted cease-fire proposals from the Organization of African Unity to end its two-year border war with Ethiopia, which is expected to respond today. News of the proposals, after negotiations in Algiers, coincided with charges by Eritrea that Ethiopia had unleashed an all-out attack along the front close to Assab.    (Reuters)    NIGERIA: OIL PRICE STRIKE  A general strike over sharp fuel price increases halted all flights at Nigerian airports, and the action also spread to seaports and the oil industry, officials said. The commercial capital, Lagos, was paralyzed for the second day in what threatens to be the biggest disruption in Africa's biggest oil exporter since military rule ended a year ago. Unions rejected President Olusegun Obasanjo's offer to halve the 50 percent rise, instituted as part of a policy of ending government subsidies.    (Reuters)

headline: Clinton Urges United Europe to Include Russia
abstract: Pres Clinton, speaking in Aachen, Germany, urges America's European allies to invite Russia into their military and political unions; says that if Russia decides against becoming a member of NATO and European Union, those two organizations must make sure that their eastward expansion does not create barriers to trade, travel and security cooperation with Russia; receives Charlemagne Award for his contribution to European unity; photo (M)

headline: Taiwan's New Leader and Beijing Testing Each Other
abstract: China hastens to restate 'one China' principle a day after hinting at new flexibility in dealing with Taiwan and its new president, Chen Shui-bian; Chen, in May 20 inaugural speech, tried to reassure Beijing that he wanted reconciliation but did not satisfy Chinese leaders' demands that he unequivocally call Taiwan part of China; photo (M)

headline: Thomas Skutt, 69, Mutual of Omaha Chief
abstract: Thomas J Skutt, retired chairman of Mutual of Omaha Companies, dies at age 69 (S)

headline: Back Up To Beat The Bug
abstract: Peter Lewis column offers advice for computer users on protecting computers from I Love You worm and other computer viruses; cites importance of backing up files regularly; drawing (M)

headline: In Bleak Russia, a Young Man's Thoughts Turn to Hacking
abstract: Computer hacking is growing among Russian teenagers and young men, some of whom have grown quite skilled at it despite their primitive personal computers; their hacking is mostly confined to vandalizing Web sites and mild forms of online hooliganism, and Russian computer experts say American press has exaggerated the threat they pose (M)

headline: Oracle Leader Calls Microsoft Spying 'Civic Duty'
abstract: Oracle Corp chairman-founder Lawrence J Ellison defends his company's yearlong spying operation against Microsoft Corp as 'civic duty' similar to investigative reporting by the press, news conference; Ellison's remarks come a day after Oracle acknowledges hiring detective agency in Washington, DC, to document ties between Microsoft and advocacy groups Association for Competitive Technology, National Taxpayers Union and Independent Institute; Ellison asserts spying operation was justified by Microsoft's own business practices, which recently led Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson to rule that Microsoft should be broken in two; photo (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: THE AMERICAS    CANADA: FRENCH RULING  A Quebec court ruled that the government of the mainly French-speaking province has the right to limit use of English and to impose French as the dominant language on commercial signs. In reversing a lower court decision, Justice Paul-Marcel Bellavance of the Superior Court noted that Quebec's six million French speakers are surrounded by 300 million English speakers, saying, ''Quebec is in a unique linguistic situation in the world.''   James Brooke (NYT)    COLOMBIA: LIMITED TRUCE  The second-largest leftist guerrilla group, the Army of National Liberation, has announced a limited 10-day Easter truce and said it would release the four-member crew of an Avianca Airlines flight hijacked a year ago. The truce will apply only to civilian targets.   Larry Rohter (NYT)

headline: An Online Show That´s, Like, Funny
abstract: April 13, 2000

headline: Of Wedding Bells and Bills
abstract: Moet & Chandon's Matrimonial Matrix, which measures cost of 12 key elements of luxury wedding, has risen just 2.3 percent over last year, while five-year annual average is 3.6 percent; numbers of weddings in US is expected to be higher than annual average of 2.4 million, perhaps because it is year 2000 (M)

headline: Satellite Radio Channel Awards Its Account
abstract: XM Satellite Radio, which plans to introduce national satellite radio band with up to 100 channels of music, news, sports, talk and children's programming, names Playa del Rey, Calif, office of TBWA/ Chiat/Day to handle its account, with billings estimated at $100 milllion for an 18-month introductory period (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Top Fox Movie Executive Resigns
abstract: Bill Mechanic, top executive at 20th Century Fox movie studio, unexpectedly resigns; no replacement is named (S)

headline: Pearson Will Buy Dorling Kindersley In $496 Million Deal
abstract: Pearson PLC to buy Dorling Kindersley Holdings for 311 million pounds ($496 million) in cash (M)

headline: GAME THEORY; Lose the Seat Belts and Step on the Gas
abstract: Jeffrey R Young reviews Crazy Taxi, arcade game now available for Sega's Dreamcast; photos (M)

headline: Now, the Glass Is Half Empty; Microbreweries in the Slow Lane
abstract: Strong growth of microbreweries experienced in mid-1990's has fallen off sharply, forcing more of beer makers to close; more microbreweries in US closed last year than opened, and more bottles will head for clearance shelves this year; craft brewers that lived through shake-up are talking about leaner, more economical brewing, more conservative growth and more thoughtful business plans; they are taking breather before making another, more sober run on American beer market, which is dominated by Anheuser-Busch, Miller Brewing and Coors; graph; chart; photos (M)

headline: Government to Propose Breakup of Microsoft Today
abstract: Government to Propose Breakup of Microsoft Today

headline: GLOBESPAN GETS T.SQWARE FOR $200 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: GlobeSpan Inc agrees to pay $200 million in stock for privately held chip maker and software company T.sqware Inc (S)

headline: G.M. Executive Joins Lockheed Martin
abstract: General Motors says Louis Hughes, executive vice president for new business strategies, has left company to join Lockheed Martin as its president and chief operating officer; Hughes is replacing Peter B Teets, who resigned from Lockheed last fall (S)

headline: ATEC GROUP TO ACQUIRE COMPUTER EQUIPMENT BUSINESS
abstract: Atec Group agrees to acquire computer equipment seller IntelleSale.com, subsidiary of Applied Digital Solutions, for $375 million in stock; combined company will be called IntelleSale.com (S)

headline: Kosovars Changing Canadian Prairie
abstract: Refugees from Kosovo, Serbia, have received especially warm welcome in Canada, where federal government is trying to rejuvenate aging population with immigrants; country took in 173,011 immigrants including 7,200 Kosovars in 1999, or 75 percent of government's goal, and one in seven citizens in foreign born; members of Hoxha family, whom migrated in 1999 and live in city of Lethbridge, comment; map; photo (M)

headline: William Blair Value Discovery
abstract: William Blair Value Discovery Fund, $58.0 million small-cap value fund has returned 11.8 percent a year, annualized, for the three years through May, beating 4.8 percent average return of its peers; lead manager Glen A Kleczka attributes fund's success to its value philosophy; Kleczka invests in 'broken stocks, not broken companies'; seeks stocks that are 50 percent or so off their five-year highs and depressed relative to their three-year forward earnings potential; looks for companies with leading market share and management that is purchasing company shares or initiating stock buyback; photo (M)

headline: Ads as Drug Pushers
abstract: Leonard Klein, letter, responds to May 7 article that cited patients' demands for unnecessary drug treatment as one source of waste in health care system; blames drug company ads that tout expensive drugs, urging consumers to 'ask your doctor' (M)

headline: President Retiring From a BBDO Unit
abstract: Thomas H Carey, president of BBDO North America, part of BBDO Worldwide, is retiring, effective on July 1 (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Divining the Big Event: A Ray of Hope, at Least
abstract: News analysis: agreement signed at summit meeting between North and South Korea was brimming with words that heralded arrival of peace, yet the two countries are still technically at war, and no one wants to raise question of who would govern a unified nation; Clinton administration, scrambling to understand Kim Jong Il's apparent radical change of policy, is trying to balance caution over North Korea's missiles and arms trade with hope that North Korea is truly ready for change (M)

headline: APPLIED MICRO TO PURCHASE SEMICONDUCTOR DEVELOPER
abstract: Applied Micro Circuits Corp acquires YuniNetworks Inc in stock deal valued at $241 million (S)

headline: VF MAKES $40 MILLION BID FOR H.I.S. SPORTSWEAR
abstract: VF Corp offers to buy H.I.S. Sportswear AG, German jeans maker, for about $40 million; VF signs letter of intent with Chic by H.I.S. Inc to acquire its 56 percent stake in H.I.S. Sportswear; also offers other H.I.S. holders 9.25 euros ($8.87) a share for remaining 44 percent; VF acquires global trademark rights to Chic brand and rights to H.I.S. brand outside Europe for undisclosed price (S)

headline: For South African Whites, Money Has No Color
abstract: Article on growing confidence and increased prosperity of wealthy Afrikaners under black rule in South Africa; Afrikaners, descendants of 17th-century Dutch, German and French settlers, remained in South Africa when government finally changed hands; by contrast, many English-speaking descendants of British colonialists, who controlled much of economy under apartheid, did leave, enabling Afrikaners to fill gaps; between 1996 and 1999, Afrikaner businessmen have seen their share of Johannesburg Stock Exchange surge from 24 percent to 36 percent as they snap up companies shed by emigrating firms and begin dominating growing technology and electronics sectors; Afrikaner businessmen who once viewed black government with suspicion now believe their economic prospects will only improve under Pres Thabo Mbeki, who is taming deficit and reducing taxes, and has promised to relax tough labor laws and speed privatization of state enterprises; photos (L)

headline: Red Cross Says Three Diseases Kill Many More Than Disasters
abstract: Report issued by Red Cross says even though natural disasters receive most prominent news coverage, infectious diseases are claiming far more lives; says deaths from diseases such as AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria in 1999 were 160 times greater than those from natural disasters (S)

headline: Greeks Rally to Keep Religions on ID Cards
abstract: Thousands of Greek Orthodox clerics and followers rally in Athens to demand Greece retract decision to remove religious affiliations from citizens' identity cards; Abp Christodoulos says Greek Orthodox Church is indivisibly bound with nation's identity (M)

headline: Harwell Proffitt, 82, Executive
abstract: Harwell Webb Proffitt, retired executive of Proffitt's Department Store chain, dies at age 82 (S)

headline: ZIMBABWE TOBACCO SALES WANE
abstract: On opening day of this year's tobacco auctions in Zimbabwe, sales are down more than 50 percent, another symptom of country's economic and political problems; tobacco is Zimbabwe's biggest export and big source of foreign currency, but occupation of hundreds of white-owned farms by black protesters seeking land has caused havoc (S)

headline: New Offerings Delayed Amid Stock Turmoil
abstract: Cracks are starting to appear in stock market for new shares as stock prices sink fast, sending companies scrambling for other ways to raise capital; several young, technology-based companies have postponed their plans for initial public offerings and others are finding demand is weak for their second or third stock offerings; amid turmoil, some representatives of old economy are proceeding with initial offerings; investment bankers price first-time stock sales for two companies not related to Internet: Metropolitan Life Insurance Co and Krispy Kreme Donuts; at $2.88 billion, Metropolitan Life's initial offering is unusally large offering that is part of insurer's conversion from mutal company owned by its policyholders to public company; Krispy Kreme is niche offering raising $63 million for company with strong brand name but no connection to Internet, other than its Web site; Metropolitan Life's underwriters at Credit Suisse First Boston price 202 million shares at $14.25 each, near middle of expected price range; Deutsche Banc Alex Brown prices 3 million shares of Krispy Kreme's stock at $21 each, above projected range of $18 to $20 (M)

headline: Pentagon Urges Delay Of Arms Sales To Taiwan
abstract: Pentagon recommends deferring for year or more a decision on Taiwan's request to purchase four sophisticated American destroyers, as well as diesel submarines and surveillance aircraft; Taiwan officials also requested advanced arms, which they say are needed to defend against what they perceive to be growing threat from China; no final decision has been made on that request (M)

headline: Ahead of the Curve
abstract: To the Editor:     Re ''Beyond the Organizer: Handhelds Add Power and Peripherals,'' State of the Art, April 27): The combination of Psion hardware and EPOC software does everything that Palm and the Pocket PC claim to do, and even what they say they will do in the future. That means full Microsoft Office file compatability, wireless e-mail and Web access, etc.

headline: Kozmo Lays Off 24 Employees
abstract: Kozmo Lays Off 24 Employees

headline: One-Day National Strike Freezes Much of Argentina
abstract: Several million workers join or are forced to acquiesce to a one-day national strike in Argentina to protest Pres Fernando de la Rua's economic austerity policies and country's 14 percent unemployment rate; major cities and much of countryside are paralyzed; photo of trash-strewn street in Buenos Aires (M)

headline: Washington Braces to Handle Flood of Globalization Protesters
abstract: Law enforcement armada from half-dozen city and federal agencies prepares for mass rallies in Washington, DC, as organizers try to extend protest against globalization that plunged Seattle into violent street confrontations in November 1999 (M)

headline: Key Executives Shift Positions
abstract: GMO/Hill Holliday names Nancy Hill president, succeeding vice chairman Brian O'Neill; Darcia Joseph is leaving as president and chief operating officer of Young & Rubicam Advertising's Canadian operations; Jim Farquhar will become president and chief creative officer; C Raymond Werner is relinquishing duties as senior vice president and general manager of Bozell Kamstra Advertising and Public Relation's Pittsburgh office; will be named executive creative director and retire at end of year; Robert Bernardini succeeds him as general manager (M)

headline: Mossadegh: Eccentric Nationalist Begets Strange History
abstract: Biographical sketch of Mohammed Mossadegh, Iranian Prime Minister who was ousted in 1953 and died in 1967; Iran's Islamic leaders have tried to curb his popularity by ignoring him, but Mossadegh cult has been revitalized by resurgent nationalism and frustration with Islam's strictures; photo (M)

headline: OPEC President Predicts Decrease in Oil Prices
abstract: OPEC president Ali Rodriguez says he expects crude oil prices to fall because of group's agreement to raise production quotas by 708,000 barrels a day beginning July 1 in effort to lower prices; Rodriguez, who is Venezuela's energy minister, says oil prices should fall to range of $22 to $28 a barrel, which would be within price band set informally by OPEC (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Judge in Microsoft Case Hopes for Swift Conclusion  Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson told lawyers he wants to finish the remedy phase of the Microsoft case within 60 days.

headline: Korean Accord Fails to Stall Missile Plan
abstract: Clinton administration is resolved to move ahead with missile defense even after remarkable summit meeting between Korean leaders; North Korea has not stopped work on long-range missile program that has helped provoke proposals for United States to build defensive shield; highly classified intelligence report has reportedly concluded that North Korea could build missile capable of striking United States by 2005, if current pace of development remains unchanged; American officials say that it would not be prudent to back away from plans to build missile defense now without more concrete agreements and changes in North Korea's behavior, despite fact that American missile proopsal has roiled relations with Russia, China and even America's European allies (M)

headline: Putin's Plan to Centralize Power in the Kremlin Wins a Round
abstract: Russia's lower house of Parliament, ignoring misgivings of political analysts and democracy advocates, resoundingly endorses draft of Pres Vladimir V Putin's plan to concentrate state power in Kremlin; analyst says vote shows Putin firmly controls Parliament; plan seeks to curb power of governors who lead Russia's 89 regions by giving seats in Parliament's upper house to senators chosen by local legislatures in secret ballot instead of to governors and legislative leaders; Putin, in further step, suggests region's representation in upper house be proportional to its contribution to federal till (M)

headline: Taking a Warlord's Advice to Shake Up the Marketplace
abstract: Rakuten, Japan's largest e-commerce site, serves as gateway to some 2,800 merchants selling wide range of goods; offers established stores place to sell old inventory at bargain-basement prices without undercutting full-price sales; lets other vendors overcome Japan's notoriously layered distribution system; Hiroshi Mikitani, founder and president, comments (M)

headline: Students From Then and Now Pass On Painful Lessons of Kent State
abstract: Sense of history's turning is strong this spring at Kent State University as a campus meadow of 58,175 carefully planted daffodils bursts to life once more in memory of America's body count in the convulsive war in Vietnam; power of that memory is at a definitive point for nation; for it was generation ago--25 years--that the war was brought to an inglorious end, its meaning left to the encroaching forces of history; and it was 30 years ago that the home front of that war--confrontation between government authority and popular resistance--was made shockingly clear as civilians fell on prototypical America campus of Kent State; National Guardsmen, confronting students in one of countless protests of that time, unexpectedly wheeled and opened fire down a hillside, killing four students and wounding nine; photos (Article in series on Vietnam and impact of Vietnam War, 25 years after downfall of Saigon) (L)

headline: Division of Microsoft Gets Muted Reaction
abstract: Small software makers, who are supposed to benefit from any breakup of Microsoft, have offered muted reactions. Unified or divided, they say, Microsoft or its spinoffs will dominate any business they pursue. There was no sense of panic among people in Seattle, where many express strong faith in Bill Gates.    Articles, Pages A16 and C1.

headline: Napster Eyes New Business Models While Preparing Defense
abstract: Napster Eyes New Business Models While Preparing Defense

headline: PROXYMED TO CUT WORK FORCE 20% IN REVAMPING
abstract: ProxyMed Inc announces resignation of top management, major reorganization and dismissal of 20 percent of workforce (S)

headline: When Modems Fail to Stay Connected
abstract: Q & A: When Modems Fail to Stay Connected

headline: Putin Rebuked Over Chechnya Atrocity
abstract: Human Rights Watch challenges Russian government to seek out and try the Russian servicemen who went on a rampage near Grozny in Chechnya on Feb 5, kllling at least 60 civilians (S)

headline: Microsoft´s Position as to Future Proceedings on the Issue of Remedy
abstract: Microsoft's Position as to Future Proceedings on the Issue of Remedy

headline: SETTLEMENT AT BOMBARDIER
abstract: Tentative agreement is reached between Bombardier and 3,800 striking production and office workers at its Montreal aerospace unit; plant has been idle since June 22; union says three-year contract provides 2 percent wage increases in each year (S)

headline: Slate Holds Discussions About a Version for Britain
abstract: Slate, online magazine owned by Microsoft, weighs setting up a British-based clone; has been meeting with potential British partners; photo (M)

headline: Toysrus.com Reviewing Account
abstract: Toysrus.com, digital retail unit of Toys 'R' Us, is undertaking review for its creative and media account, with billings estimated at $25 million (S)

headline: In Illinois, China Trade Bill Pulls Congressman 2 Ways
abstract: Landmark legislation to normalize trade relations with China pulls Rep David Phelps, freshman Illinois Democrat, in opposite directions by diverse constituency in his sprawling district; farmers and agribusiness giants urge him to vote yes to help open rich new Chinese markets to American goods; longtime labor allies lobby hard against deal, saying it would cost hundreds of union jobs and reward repressive Communist government that has cheated on other trade pacts; Phelps and 39 other undecided House Democrats will probably control bill's fate; his silence on how he will vote has catapulted him into limelight; decision by House Democratic leader, Richard A Gephardt, to vote against measure weighs heavily on Phelps, who says he is torn between human rights and environmental concerns, and concerns about hurting America's economy; photo; map; chart (M)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Too Many High-Tech Visas Doled Out Last Year

headline: DISMISSALS PLANNED IN CONSUMER LONG-DISTANCE UNIT
abstract: AT&T Corp says it will lay off workers in consumer long-distance division after retirements and resignations failed to reduce staff sufficiently; company is seeking to cut $2 billion in costs this year (S)

headline: Unicef Issues Report on Worldwide Violence Facing Women
abstract: Unicef reports 'alarming' level of domestic abuse of women and girls around world, with problem often most acute in poorest nations; says up to half of female population comes under attack by those closest to them at some time in their lives; report, agency's first effort to establish global dimensions of such abuse, draws together previously published research from various nations; is part of aggressive drive to address root causes of problems of millions of world's children; Unicef executive director Carol Bellamy holds domestic violence has been given too low a priority, interview (M)

headline: Power to Protect
abstract: Letter by Peter Flynn responds to June 15 article on uninterruptrible power surge protection for computers; says article was correct in stating that the devices offer higher-quality surge protection than simple power strip

headline: Cisco and Nokia in Wireless Networking Deal
abstract: April 4, 2000

headline: Signs of Life in Japan
abstract: News analysis: huge victories by opposition Democratic Party in Japan's parliamentary elections awakens country to possibility of political change at time when many seemed willing to write off country's democracy as hopelessly moribund (M)

headline: Latest Style For Pruning Companies Lop the Top
abstract: Louis Uchitelle Economic View column notes sharp increase in turnover of corporate chief executives when company performance falters; notes one study found 40 percent of new chief executives lose their jobs within 18 months, while another study found that chief executive was three time more likely to be fired for poor performance in 1996 than in 1985; links trend to shift in balance of power between chief executive on the one hand and directors and shareholders on the other; notes critics of trend complain companies are substituting people for strategy; graph (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    NORWAY: 80,000 STRIKE -- More than 80,000 workers went on strike, disrupting construction, printing, freight hauling, maritime transport, hotels and restaurants, and sparking hoarding of consumer goods by people fearing an extended walkout. The strike was called after members of Norway's main umbrella trade union turned down wage and benefit offers negotiated by their leaders with the employers' association. No new talks are set.   Warren Hoge (NYT)    BRITAIN: POLICE ADMIT GUILT -- London's police force admitted in the High Court that some officers acted unlawfully when they confiscated flags and banners and otherwise blocked pro-Tibet demonstrators protesting a visit last October by President Jiang Zemin of China. The Free Tibet Campaign accused them of particularly heavy-handed tactics as Mr. Jiang rode in a carriage with Queen Elizabeth to Buckingham Palace. The Tibet group agreed to accept the police admissions and drop its legal challenge.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: TECUMSEH PRODUCTS SAYS IT WILL LAY OFF 1,500 WORKERS
abstract: Tecumseh Products Co, maker of engines for lawn mowers and snowthrowers, will cut 1,500 jobs, or about 8 percent of its work force, and close plant in Somerset, Ky; reductions will be made over 18 months (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Gains in European Stocks Being Swept Away by the Sinking Euro
abstract: Americans who have invested in European stock markets this year have been dealt cruel blow by the euro, which seems to be on relentless decline; on the surface, market news from Europe is good; while major American equity indexes are down, or flat for year, some prominent European stock indexes have posted gains; euro plunges more than 2 percent on April 25, bringing its decline for year to 8.5 percent and souring stock returns for Americans; graph; chart (Market Place column) (M)

headline: John Christian, 74; Headed B. Altman
abstract: John W Christi

headline: Intel Introduces New Processors for Notebook Computers
abstract: Intel Introduces New Processors for Notebook Computers

headline: Generation Gap Threatens Ruling Zimbabwe Party
abstract: Dominance of Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front, party of Pres Robert Mugabe that has controlled country's politics for past 20 years, is threatened by generation gap; old message to remember past and to stay true to party that liberated country from white rule is being delivered to changing nation; about third of population consists of young people who were either children in 1980, when majority rule was achieved, or were born shortly after; significant percentage of 5.8 million voters have registered since February, after party suffered its first major political defeat; maps; photos (M)

headline: Rome Journal; Dueling Festivals: Gay Pride and Vatican Collide
abstract: Italian politics are roiled in wake of Vatican's effort to block gay pride festival in Rome, center of Roman Catholic Church's Holy Year festivities; Mayor Francesco Rutelli withdraw's city's support for event, which he first welcomed, drawing fire from his center-left constituency without appeasing the church; photo (M)

headline: Let's Take a Flier: The Return of Mega-Leverage to Stocks
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on House and Senate Agriculture Committees' approval of bills that would allow futures markets to trade 'single-stock' futures; says once they become legal, person will be able to buy single-stock futures by putting up pennies on dollar, in sharp contrast to stock market, where one has to put up half purchase price; says legislators who are voting in favor of such futures may regret that decision if, before they choose to retire, public once again discovers that stock market really is risky, and that very high leverage can increase risks for both speculators and entire system; notes single-stock futures would be similar to similar to buying stocks at 'bucket shops' created by Jesse Livermore prior to 1929 stock market crash and Great Depression; photo (M)

headline: Hero of Versailles? It's New York
abstract: The best place to find businesspeople to support repairs to Versailles, where Louis XIV's gardens were blasted by storms last Christmas? Try New York. And so last week more than 100 guests including Richard and Kathy Hilton (as in the hotels); Lawrence Herbert, chief executive of Pantone Inc. and his wife, Michele; and the investor Peter Price and his wife, Judy, raised several hundred thousand dollars to mend the estate, as well as to keep up Claude Monet's Giverny. At the Carlyle hotel, this slice of mostly American royalty was welcomed by Prince and Princess Michael of Kent, sipped vintage Taittinger in the Versailles Room, then dined in the Trianon Room.

headline: Donald W. Davies, 75, Dies; Helped Refine Data Networks
abstract: Donald W Davies, computer security expert8

headline: Gauging the Effect Of Drug Warnings
abstract: Time Inc study finds consumers who say they would not take drug because of data about side effects offered in advertisements say they are influenced much more by such data in television commercials than by comparable data in magazine ads (M)

headline: Another Austin Internet Firm Announces Layoffs
abstract: Another Austin Internet Firm Announces Layoffs

headline: Thinking Defensively As the Bears Thrash
abstract: Interview with Douglas R Cliggott, US equity strategist for J P Morgan, on Nasdaq valuations and alternative stock investments; photo (M)

headline: Peru's Upstart: 'Chemistry With the People'
abstract: News analysis of Peruvian political scene, in which Alejandro Toledo is leading an exultant democracy movement that has mobilized hundreds of thousands of people across country; Toledo forces believe they stopped Pres Alberto K Fujimori from claiming fraudulent victory from April 9 voting; Toledo photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AMAZON.COM,  Seattle, the biggest Internet retailer, opened a lawn-and-patio store on the Web to sell a wider range of yard tools, furniture and decorations.    MEDIA GENERAL INC.,  Richmond, Va., the publisher of The Richmond Times-Dispatch, agreed to buy four Virginia newspapers from Community Newspapers of Southwest Virginia Inc. for an undisclosed price.

headline: ECONOMIC AID FOR PHILIPPINES
abstract: International donors pledged $6.2 billion in additional economic aid to Philippines, bringing to $10.3 billion total loans available to country's cash-short government; group, headed by World Bank and Japan, allocated $361 million to promote development projects on southern island of Mindanao (S)

headline: Divide and Conquer
abstract: Readers suggest silly names and ridiculous descriptions for Web sites; top entry is DigitalDivide.com, Web portal for those without Internet access; photo (M)

headline: Joining the Club: Like Others, China Will Try to Protect Its Own Industries
abstract: News analysis of China's possible entry into World Trade Organization, focusing on many loopholes behind promises of free trade (M)

headline: Serbian Government Seizes TV Station in a Drive to Crush the Opposition to Milosevic
abstract: Serbian government seizes control of main opposition television station, accusing it of advocating uprising; opposition politicians call immediate protest rally and talk of beginning of outright dictatorship under Pres Slobodan Milosevic; rally attracts 20,000 demonstrators in Belgrade, even though opposition media could not broadcast word of it; seized television station, Studio B, is controlled by Serbian Renewal Movement of Vuk Draskovic; its seizure is attack on him; he is said to be in Montenegro, for his safety; photo (M)

headline: After Rising Steadily, Productivity Slows in First Quarter
abstract: After rising spectacularly for six months, the productivity of American workers climbed more slowly in the first quarter, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. Once again, most of the improvement came in the manufacture of computers, machinery, autos, appliances and other durable goods -- particularly computers and the chips that go into them.    Labor productivity rose at a 2.4 percent annual rate. That was less than half the improvement in the two previous quarters and, indeed, one of the poorer quarterly performances in the last two years. But over the last four quarters, productivity is still rising at a very strong 3.7 percent, unchanged from December.

headline: American Topics : Kentucky Swaps Moonshine for Marijuana
abstract: In the rugged hills of eastern Kentucky, known more for poverty than for beauty, more than 40 percent of the U.S. marijuana crop is grown: a crop worth $3.9 billion annually in a region where the average household income has yet to surpass $8,000 a year

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: DIGITAL COURIER TECHNOLOGIES,  Park City, Utah, named Becky Takeda chief operating officer. She had been vice president for marketing and investor relations at Smart Modular Technologies.    EXODUS COMMUNICATIONS, Santa Clara, Calif., named Ellen Hancock, chief executive, to the post of chairman. And Don Casey was named president and chief operating officer. He had been president at Wang Global, part of Getronics N.V.

headline: Kiehl's Cosmetics Company Bought by France's L'Oreal
abstract: Kiehl's, after 149 years as small but intensely popular independent cosmetics company, agrees to be acquired by L'Oreal SA, French beauty products giant; price is undisclosed but people close to negotiations say it is between $100 million and $150 million; Kiehl's had revenue of about $40 million last year (M)

headline: Nissan Loses $6.3 Billion in Fiscal Year
abstract: Nissan Motor Co reports losses in fiscal year ended March 31 widened to record $6.3 billion; sales declined 10.5 percent amid painful overhaul; company has erased outstanding pension liabilities, adopted new accounting practices and moved to close plants and cut employees; photo (M)

headline: Will Managers Relate To This Gripping Tale?
abstract: Management consultant Dennis N T Perkins, author of Leading at the Edge, offers managers 10 rules for leadership distilled from Sir Ernest Shakleton's ill-fated 1914 Antarctic expedition; Perkins holds up Shackleton as model leader, a captain obsessed with the welfare of his men, cautious or daring as circumstances required, a man who shouldered the weight and made the decisions; principles Perkins espouses, stripped from adventurous context, seem mostly unexceptionable, if not routine; photo ( M)

headline: French Issue First Detailed Study of Wartime Thefts From Jews
abstract: Commission headed by Jean Matteoli finds Nazis and French collaborators seized $1.3 billion in assets from French Jews, far more than previously assumed; finds 90 percent was repaid in some form in 10 years after war; finds some Jews suffered from length and complexity of recovering assets; French Jewish leaders laud study; separate commission is dealing with claims from survivors and their heirs (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Gauging Attitudes About the Internet
abstract: If a group of grandmothers from Atlanta were running the Internet, there would be no chat rooms and absolutely no government involvement. And they would enlist William H. Gates, the church and the United Nations to help them oversee the global network.     College students, on the other hand, want the Central Intelligence Agency, the National Security Agency and the Internal Revenue Service involved, since, as they see it, ''these people pretty much run who we are.''

headline: The Tortoises and the Hares, in a Dead Heat
abstract: Mark Hulbert Strategies column reports his study of mailed versus telephoned, faxed or online investment newsletters over nearly 20 years since mid-1980's shows mailed newsletters produced 10.5 percent annualized return, while online and other newsletters produced 10.9 percent return, a difference so small as to be statistically insignificant; speculates advisers' ability to make near-instantaneous modifications in their model portfolios can tempt them into self-destructive actions, such as selling securities too soon; drawing (M)

headline: E*TRADE IS BUYING OWNER OF CANADIAN TRADING SERVICE
abstract: E*Trade Group, country's third-largest online broker, agrees to acquire Versus Technologies, owner of E*Trade Canada, for about $174 million in stock; deal will allow E*Trade to build cross-border electronic trading network and receive revenue from Versus trades (S)

headline: Romanian Playboy Article Draws Protests
abstract: Romanian edition of Playboy magazine, published by Romanian group under licensing accord with Playboy Enterprises, has outraged women's groups in Eastern Europe and caused stir at Playboy's corporate offices with 'satirical' article describing step-by-step procedure for wife beating; Christie Hefner, Playboy chairwoman, says article violates magazine's policy against editorial or visual depictions of violence against women; photos (M)

headline: Kunitachi City Journal; Japanese Trains Try to Shed a Gruesome Appeal
abstract: Article on rising number of railway suicides in Japan, especially on line operated by East Japan Railway Company near Kunitachi City has become favorite spot; efforts of company to discourage suicides discussed; maps; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA    SOUTH KOREA: NEW PREMIER  President Kim Dae Jung picked a conservative minority party leader as prime minister, a move expected to significantly widen his political base. The appointment of Lee Han Dong, 65, head of the United Liberal Democrats, left, is subject to approval by the 273-member National Assembly, which is expected to give its consent. Mr. Lee succeeds Park Tae Joon, who resigned in a tax evasion scandal. He is the third prime minister to serve in the Kim government, which was inaugurated in early 1998.   (AP)

headline: Equity Offerings Expected in the Coming Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    360networks Inc., Vancouver, Canada, an initial public offering of 46 million shares. Goldman Sachs and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

headline: Harcourt to Buy All of Medical Internet Site
abstract: Harcourt General will complete purchase of MD Consult, an Internet medical site, from Wolters Kluwer NV: says Wolters Kluwer bought Harcourts's professional-publishing business (M)

headline: Will dot-com advertisers turn to the infomercial to bring traffic to their Web sites?
abstract: Infomercial makers are courting dot-com advertisers; Tyee Euro RSCG has already developed two 28-minute, program-length commercials for Internet clients; infomercials are designed to generate immediate sales results that can be measured by volume of traffic to Web site or 800 number, capability that could prove attractive to dot.coms seeking to quickly build revenue and profits (M)

headline: Financier Maintains His Innocence in Jail Interview
abstract: Martin R Frankel, accused of masterminding largest insurance fraud in American history, insists his complex financial dealings were legitimate effort to feed world's hungry, interview from German jail with ABC News correspondent Brian Ross to air on TV program 20/20; Frankel portrays himself as victim, saying he had been brought low by charitable nature and tendency to trust others too much; prosecutors have charged him with bilking insurance companies of more than $200 million in scheme they say involved several priests, a high Vatican judge and fake charity; Frankel never directly denies charges against him, which include fraud, money laundering, conspiracy and racketeering; says life sentence, which he could receive, would violate 'human dignity and human rights'; photo (M)

headline: Herbalife's Afterlife Challenge; Charismatic Leader Left an Image Problem and Other Issues
abstract: Herbalife International, direct-sales giant of dietary supplements, faces several challenges, including recovering from death of its founder Mark Hughes on May 21; Hughes's death is serious blow for company--both because he was Herbalife's head cheerleader and because of possibility that his message of better life through herbal products might be diminished by the way he died; Hughes's death was ruled accident from combination of alcohol and prescribed antidepressant Doxepin; company is being run by chief executive Christopher Pair and Conrad Klein, chief business affairs officer; graph; photos (M)

headline: Public service campaigns try to catch the attention of the public and the media gatekeepers.
abstract: Article on ways advertising agencies try to catch attention of public when creating pro bono public service campaigns (Advertising column) (M)

headline: France Debates Parole, After 24 Years of Prison, for Killer of a Child
abstract: PARIS—  Can someone who has murdered a child be redeemed? Is there a prison sentence that is appropriate for such a crime, or a punishment that would allow a killer to change and become a productive member of society?

headline: Former Disney Studio Chief Gets Backing for Company
abstract: Joe Roth, former head of Walt Disney Studios, obtains backing for his new movie company, Revolution Studios, from Sony Pictures, Starz Encore Group and Fox Entertainment; three companies, plus other partners in Germany and Japan, have committed themselves to finance production and costs of at least 36 movies Revolution Studios plans to make in next six years; Roth will have autonomy to choose films and the budgets (M)

headline: First Amendment Lawyer Takes on Movie Studios in DVD Case
abstract: April 28, 2000

headline: THE HOUSE OPENS A SPIRITED DEBATE OVER CHINA TRADE
abstract: House opens spirited debate over bill to grant China permanent normal trading relations; undecided members demand wide range of favors for districts, leaving bill's supporters confident they will eke out victory; opponents hold vote is still too close to call; some dozen Democrats announce their support for bill; focus shifts to undeclared Republicans; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Cable Dispute Halts Service To Time Warner Customers  Millions of television viewers in major markets, including New York and Los Angeles, found themselves without access to ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' and many other popular TV programs as Time Warner and Walt Disney fought over how much Disney should be paid for its cable programming.    The dispute also involved issues concerning the distribution of news and entertainment programming, the growing competition between cable and satellite companies, and Disney's opposition to the proposed merger of America Online and Time Warner. ABC asked the Federal Communications Commission to restore programming. [Page A1.]

headline: TWO LAUNDRY DETERGENT BUSINESSES FORM PARTNERSHIP
abstract: Church & Dwight Co, Princeton, NJ, maker of Arm & Hammer baking soda, agrees to combine its laundry detergent business with USA Detergents Inc, North Brunswick, NJ, to cut costs and improve its supply chain (S)

headline: AT&T's ACQUISITION OF MEDIAONE WINS APPROVAL BY F.C.C.
abstract: Federal Communications Commission approves AT&T's acquisition of MediaOne after ordering companies to sell some of their assets, clearing final obstacle to merger that will create nation's largest provider of cable television, long-distance telephone service and high-speed Internet access; gives companies choice of which programming and cable subsidiaries and investments to sell to comply with rule that forbids corporation from having interests in more than 30 percent of nation's cable and satellite television market, or nearly 23 million subscribers; decision angers some consumer groups, which asked FCC to force AT&T to sell cable systems it co-owns with Time Warner and to force it to open Internet network to competiting service providers without requiring consumers to pay additional fees; Consumers Union weighs lawsuit; will ask Congress to pass law to narrow agency's authority to review mergers; agency chairman William E Kennard says decision strikes appropriate balance between promoting competition in local telephone service and protecting competition in cable and high-speed Internet service; AT&T executives laud decision; chairman C Michael Armstrong says it will mean real choice and lower prices in local phone service, faster Internet access and better cable television; photo (M)

headline: 300 New Jobs at Corning
abstract: Corning Inc says it will double manufacturing capacity at its plant in Bedford, Mass, to meet increased demand for fiber optic network components; more than 300 new jobs will be created and about $45 million invested; Corning also says its shareholders approved increase in shares of common stock to 1.2 billion from 500 million (S)

headline: U.N. Reports Rebels Now Hold 300 of Its Troops in Sierra Leone
abstract: United Nations and Clinton administration officials say rebels have taken more than 300 UN troops hostage in Sierra Leone, and that some peacekeeping units have lost contact with their command posts; 8,300-member UN force, composed mainly of African and Indian troops, is losing confidence as result of assault; entire mission said to be in jeopardy; parliamentarians in Kenya are calling for withdrawal of Kenyan contingent of peace force after reports that four of their soldiers are missing and presumed dead; talks are under way in Freetown between several commanders of insurgent forces and Western diplomats to try to stop fighting; photo; map (M)

headline: Digital Future Is Up for Grabs In Cable Battle
abstract: Time Warner-Disney dispute prompts analysis of whether pending America Online merger with Time Warner will give merged company and a few other giants control over ever-expanding array of media; such gatekeepers will have to fight for control with content providers and power of open Internet; table (M)

headline: New Disk Joins Crowded Field In Data Storage
abstract: DataPlay is set to offer portable computer memory disk about the size of half-dollar that can store digital images, audio and multimedia presentations; disk will have memory roughly equivalent of full-size CD-ROM (M)

headline: American Histories: Chasing Dreams And Nightmares; DREYFUS NATURAL GAS TO BUY COSTILLA ENERGY'S ASSETS
abstract: Louis Dreyfus Natural Gas Co to buy oil and natural gas assets of Costilla Energy Inc, which is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, for $100 million in cash (S)

headline: TELEFONICA BOARD TO MEET
abstract: Spain's largest telephone operator, Telefonica, said it would hold a special board meeting to consider a merger with the Dutch telephone company Royal KPN. Executives close to the merger talks said Telefonica was considering paying about $54.4 billion for Royal KPN.

headline: A Wary Welcome for the Net From Kentucky Artisans
abstract: Artisans working in Appalachian traditions in rural Berea, Ky, are slowly, fitfully moving online, in ways as individual as craftspeople themselves; many are unsure whether technology will help them maintain lives they have created or force them from cherished traditions; younger artisans are more comfortable with change; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Ready for Much Larger Security Council
abstract: US Amb Richard C Holbrooke tells General Assembly working group that after years of trying to hold 15-member Security Council to what it considers manageable size, US is prepared to drop its insistence that limit should be 20 or 21 seats in any expansion (M)

headline: Bush, Harvard Business School And the Makings of a President
abstract: George W Bush, Havard Business School Class of 1975, will be first president with a master's degree in business administration, if he is elected; though Bush has not made much of connection, his generalist, big-picture, highly delegative management style is in keeping with Harvard Business School training; classmates and professors remember Bush's relaxed attitude and unusual confidence; alumni scoff at suggestion that Bush is not smart enough to be president-- though theirs is not necessarily an impartial view; photo (M)

headline: For Vodafone, Saving Grace From French
abstract: France Telecom is expected to acquire Orange PLC from Vodafone AirTouch for more than $37 billion; Vodafone is required to sell Orange, Britain's third-largest wireless phone operator, as part of its acquisition of Mannesmann AG; photo (M)

headline: Company Brings Video Ads to Gas Pumps
abstract: Company Brings Video Ads to Gas Pumps

headline: Busy Times for Optical Sector
abstract: Dozens of companies are emerging to provide optical communications gear for optical networks, which convey millions or even billions of bits of digital information using pulses of light, rather than bursts of electricity (S)

headline: Credit Offerings Planned During the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and five-year and 10-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.78 percent and on the six-month issue, 6.01 percent. In when-issued trading, the five-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.72 percent, and the 10-year note, 6.51 percent.

headline: Movable Storage Device For Palm Users
