abstract: JKS Technologie, Germany, develops FlashPlug, small device that adds 8 megabytes of storage and enables users of Palm organizers to safely back up their data when no desktop is available; cost of device is about $120 (S)

headline: Honda Plans OnStar For Acura Sedans
abstract: Honda Motor Co, Japan, is planning to equip US versions of its Acura sedans with the General Motors Corp's OnStar satellite navigation and information devices starting in 2002; GM expects OnStar to sign up as many as 4 million customers and generate $1 billion in annual revenue by 2002 (S)

headline: Softbank Makes Deal for Nippon Credit
abstract: Group of investors headed by Softbank Corp signs an agreement to buy failed Nippon Credit Bank, Japan, from the government; Softbank will take stake of 40 percent to 50 percent in bank; along with its two main partners, Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance Co and Orix Corp, will invest some 80 billion yen ($752 million) in Nippon Credit; Softbank sees Nippon Credit as means of providing cash to young companies and new ventures that have traditionally found it difficult to find financing in Japan; photo of Softbank founder Masayoshi Son (M)

headline: Burmese Rebel Chief More Boy Than Warrior
abstract: God's Army, Karen rebel group fighting government of Myanmar, is led by 12-year-old twin boys, Luther and Johnny Htoo, who are believed by their followers to have magical powers; Jason Bleibtreu, American video cameraman allowed to film Luther and his followers, says God's Army guerrillas believe twins are reincarnations of heroes from past; says they treat boys with mix of deference and patient parenting; Thai political scientist, Dr Sunai Phasuk, says emergence of charismatic holy men with claims to magical powers is fairly common in Southeast Asia during times of trouble; brothers did not join God's Army's suicidal raid on Thai hospital in January, during which all 10 gunmen were shot dead; twins are now targets of stepped-up hunt by Burmese military, barred from potential sanctuary in Thailand and losing support of other Karen separatists; photos; map (M)

headline: HSBC'S SHARES DROP
abstract: Shares of HSBC Holdings PLC fall as investors express concern that its $10.5 billion offer for Credit Commercial de France is too high; HSBC chairman Sir John Bond comments; photo (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of June 18 roundup of experts' view on revitalizing Procter & Gamble; Ivory soap was invented in 1878, and Tide detergent was introduced in 1946 (S)

headline: PIVOTAL TECHNOLOGIES TO BE BOUGHT FOR $242.5 MILLION
abstract: Broadcom Corp acquires Pivotal Technologies Corp for $242.5 million in stock (S)

headline: War in Chechnya Swells the Ranks of Russia's Draft Dodgers
abstract: Col Gen Vladislav N Putilin says number of draft dodgers rose by almost 50 percent since fighting broke out in Chechnya, leaving Russian military without enough new conscripts; problem is so severe that government has cut from year to six months time soldier must serve in military before being sent to Chechnya; government has done little to advance pledge to create all-volunteer military (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Mindshare, combined media departments of WPP Group's Ogilvy & Mather and J Walter Thompson units, is formalizing structure of its new North American operations, to be based in New York with offices in nine other cities; chairman and chief executive Irwin Gottlieb names Peter Chrisanthopoulos, Jean Pool and Ray Simko to office of president; Larry Cole is named vice chairman (S)

headline: New York Board of Trade Is Named in Suit by Nymex
abstract: New York Mercantile Exchange files suit against New York Board of Trade to prevent it from using member funds to cover trading losses sustained by another member; class-action suit, filed in the Federal District Court, New York, seeks to prevent NY Trade Board from using member funds on deposit with Klein & Co Futures, clearing member, to meet margin requirements resulting from losses sustained in trading on New York Futures Exchange, division of board of trade; Nymex is joined in suit by 15 of its members that are customers of Klein & Co (M)

headline: Pork and beef producers are moving to freshen up their long-running consumer campaigns.
abstract: National Pork Producers Council and National Cattlemen's Beef Association want to get consumers interested not only in their meats, but also in their ads, which have been running for more than decade; pork association's ad agency is Bozell Worldwide; budget is estimated at $25 million for first year; beef campaign is being created by Leo Burnett Co; billings estimated at $10 million; some ads described (Advertising column) (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Kent Simons; Neuberger Berman Focus Fund
abstract: Interview with Newuberger Berman Forcus fund m

headline: SUPPORT FOR BANK EXECUTIVE
abstract: Deutsche Bank board chairman Hilmar Kopper, in memo to bank's employees, says bank's chief executive Rolf Breuer has 'total support' of bank's supervisory board; Breuer has been under pressure to resign after planned $29 billion takeover of Dredsner Bank collapsed last week; Breuer's counterpart at Dresdner, Bernhard Walter, has already resigned; photo (S)

headline: BRAZIL SLIGHTLY LOWERS INFLATION TARGETS
abstract: Brazilian government, in move intended to promote economic growth, sets inflation target of 3.5 percent for 2002, down only slightly from 4 percent target for next year; inflation is expected to be 6 percent this year; government also lowers long-term interest rate to 10.25 percent from 11 percent; photo of Pres Henrique Cardoso; photo (S)

headline: Some Promotions At Lowe Lintas
abstract: Top executives at US operations of Lowe Lintas are being promoted; Lee Garfinkel, chairman and chief creative officer, is named to additional post of chief executive, which has long been vacant; Gary Goldsmith, vice chairman and executive creative director, will share duties and titles of chairman and chief creative officer with Garfinkel (Advertising column) (S)

headline: The Internet Has a Reversal of Format
abstract: Number of Internet sites have recently begun publishing print magazines; photo (S)

headline: Amazon.com Hires Firm to Improve Supply Management
abstract: Amazon.com Hires Firm to Improve Supply Management

headline: YUAN RISES AGAINST DOLLAR
abstract: China's currency, the yuan, edges further beyond its tight trading band to close at 8.2764 to the dollar, its strongest level since China unified its foreign exchange rate in 1994 (S)

headline: Scholastic Is Planning to Buy Grolier
abstract: Scholastic Corp agrees to buy Grolier Inc from Lagardere for $400 million in cash (S)

headline: The Connection Gap
abstract: Letter from Alan S Kornheiser says May 18 article on difficulty of being connected to Internet in rural areas fails to appreciate how much of country is electronically underserved

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, GERALD L.
abstract: KAUFMAN-Gerald L. AMIT mourns the passing of the beloved president of the National Council of Young Israel. His financial expertise was always available to assist AMIT in its mission to save the ''Forgotten Children of Israel.'' May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Sondra Sokal, President Marvin Leff, Executive Director

headline: VITESSE SEMICONDUCTOR AGREES TO ACQUIRE SITERA
abstract: Vitesse Semiconductor acquires Sitera Inc for $750 million in stock (S)

headline: OPEC Agrees to 2.5% Increase in Output
abstract: OPEC ministers in Vienna decide to increase their production limits by about 708,000 barrels a day, or 2.5 percent, beginning July 1; increase is slightly higher than had been expected; analysts say it remains too modest to bring down gasoline prices that have reached more than $2 a gallon in some parts of US; oil ministers go out of their way to place much of blame for high gasoline prices on regulations and refining problems in US as well as extremely high gasoline taxes across much of Europe; crude oil prices on New York Mercantile Exchange jumps about 2 percent, or 72 cents, to $31.37 a barrel; chart on new OPEC quotas; graph; photo (M)

headline: Pooling Resources
abstract: Pooling Resources

headline: Dueling D.S.L.'s
abstract: George Dremeaux letter on May 4 article cites his positive experience with Bell Atlantic's DSL high-speed Internet access service

headline: Dealing With D.S.L.
abstract: Andrew Holliday letter on May 4 article lauds service he has gotten from small DSL provider

headline: Microsoft Is Seeking Government Records
abstract: Microsoft plans to ask the federal judge overseeing the antitrust case against it for authority to obtain hundreds of pages of government records and for permission to summon witnesses to argue that the proposed division of the software giant into two companies is unwarranted.    Government officials called the request a stalling tactic, possibly intended to delay the ruling until the next administration takes office.

headline: European Inquiry on Deal by Boeing
abstract: European Commission opens four-month probe into Boeing Co's proposed purchase of Hughes Electronics Corp's satellite unit, probe that could delay deal (S)

headline: Online Toy Retailer Raises $100 Million in Private Placement
abstract: Online Toy Retailer Raises $100 Million in Private Placement

headline: An Ageless Saigon Basks in Peace
abstract: Ho Chi Minh City celebrates 25th anniversary of Communist victory over US that ended Vietnam War; parades and other events described; photo; map (M)

headline: As Spring Comes to Kosovo, Search for the Dead Resumes
abstract: Teams from international war crimes tribunal in Hague resume digging in Kosovo, Serbia, as spring begins, searching for bodies and other clues to bosletr indictment of Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic and four other top allies in Serbia on charges of genocide, committed before and during NATO bombing in 1999; will examine 300 sites; has exhumed 160 bodies in past three weeks; map; photo (M)

headline: Opposition in Disarray as Belgrade Cracks Down
abstract: Leaders of democratic opposition in Serbia are divided about how to respond to government's seizure of main opposition television station, undercutting their credibility and damaging image of unity they are trying to project to voters and West; at issue are dangers of confrontation with Pres Slobodan Milosevic; some leaders favor program of civil disobedience, while others press for negotiated settlement with Milosevic that might bring early elections under fairer conditions; Vuk Draskovic, largest opposition party, reportedly opposes any plan of confrontation that would give Milosevic further pretext for general crackdown; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: Kathleen D Love is named to vacant post of president and chief operating officer at Mediamark Research Inc; Gail Ettinger is named to new post of executive vice president and general manager at Internet division of KSL Media (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Fuller's Dymaxion House To Be Rebuilt by Museum
abstract: Henry Ford Museum, Dearborn, Mich, is restoring and rebuilding only one of R Buckminister Fuller's futuristic Dymaxion houses that was ever erected; devotes part of its Web site to project; photo (M)

headline: Suharto Under House Arrest During Corruption Inquiry
abstract: Indonesian government, under intense public pressure to get tough, places former Pres Suharto under house arrest as its seeks to try him on charges of corruption and abuse of power; move comes two years after Suharto, who governed for 32 years, stepped down amid riots and student protests; carries powerful symbolism in nation struggling to convert from system of iron-fisted rule to open democracy; photo (M)

headline: Zimbabwe's Leader Reverses Call for Squatters to Leave
abstract: Pres Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe announces that his government will not ask black squatters to leave hundreds of white-owned farms despite escalating political violence that left three people dead; Vice Pres Joseph Msika had said squatters should abandon farms, and country's high court ordered police to evict them; Mugabe vows to defy court order, and distances himself from Msika; political analysts say Mugabe has revived land issue in effort to win rural votes in upcoming elections for Parliament; Mugabe has blamed whites for slow pace of land redistribution, even though his own government is partly responsible for slowdown in program; photo (M)

headline: CANADA'S INFLATION FALLS
abstract: Canada's inflation rate dips in April to eight-month low of 2.1 percent, down from 3 percent in March; inflation number is lower than expectations and could make it difficult for Bank of Canada to match any further interest rate increases applied by Federal Reserve Board in US (S)

headline: Equipping a Dorm Room: Fan, Pillow, LAN Card
abstract: Q. Many students entering college are being warned that their personal computers must have ISA/PCI Ethernet adapters and that networked PC's must be equipped with 10Base-T Ethernet adapter cards, cables and communications software. What do these terms mean?    A. Many of those terms relate to networking -- specifically, to getting the computer onto the university network.

headline: 'Games' Turn Deadly as Clash Quickly Spirals Out of Control
abstract: Fierce clashes between Israeli forces and Palestinians in Ramallah on West Bank described; Israeli Army says detachment of Palestinian military police initiated exchange, firing live ammunition from hilltop at troops battling stone-throwing youths with rubber bullets and tear gas (M)

headline: Disney Takes Its Case to City Hall
abstract: Executives from Walt Disney Co are meeting with dozens of city officials across America, urging them to make changes in franchise agreements with Time Warner when it merges with America Online; Disney advises local cable authorities to write specific language into agreements to ensure that combined AOL-Time Warner does no favor its own cable channels over those of rival programming providers; Disney wants to move its Disney Channel from premium service to basic lineup (M)

headline: Lucent Internet Deal
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc sells its ProxyMate Internet privacy technology to NaviPath Inc, CMGI Inc unit, in exchange for minority stake in unit (S)

headline: Web Surfers Want the News Fast and Free
abstract: Princeton Research Associates survey for Web content distributor ScreamingMedia.com finds 89 percent of respondents have never paid for news or data on Internet and 83 percent are not willing to pay; few news organizations have been able to sustain pure subscription model on Web (S)

headline: Media Talk; No More Dog Days of Summer in TV Land
abstract: The main thing that the latest television phenomenon, CBS's ''Survivor,'' has in common with the previous television phenomenon, ABC's ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' is not the $1 million ultimate prize.    The main thing is that both started out as answers to the question: What did you do on your summer vacation?

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Letters to the Editor

headline: Chief Executive Is Named at British Airways
abstract: British Airways announces appointment of Rod Eddington, former managing director of Cathay Pacific Airways of Hong Kong, as chief executive; Eddington replaces Robert Ayling; photo (M)

headline: Report Revives Criticism of General's Attack on Iraqis at End of the Persian Gulf War
abstract: Article by investigative reporter Seymour M Hersh in New Yorker magazine challenges conduct of Gen Barry R McCaffrey during 1991 Persian Gulf War in which he was top American commander; suggests Army division commanded by McCaffrey may have carried out unjustified attack against retreating Iraqi soldiers two days after cease-fire went into effect and it fired on unarmed Iraqi prisoners; McCaffrey rebuts allegations; says he is victim of journalistic attack; Hersh's allegations discussed; McCaffrey's current role as Clinton administration's drug czar noted; photo (M)

headline: Pit-Stop to Riches: A Monastery
abstract: August Turak, founder of software concern Raleigh Group International, has spent more than five months since 1996 at Trappists' Mepnik Monastery near Charleston (SC); says his time at monastery makes him realize 'how much energy we burn up everyday on unproductive activities'; sold his company earlier this year to MuTek Solutions of Israel for a sum rich 'enough to put a smile on my face' (M)

headline: Brown Brothers to End Brokerage Business
abstract: Brown Brothers, Harriman & Co, oldest privately held US bank, says it will quit brokerage business to focus on managing money for wealthy individuals; will dismiss 78 employees (S)

headline: Nasdaq Posts Its First Gain Of the Week
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes at 10,921.92, down 58.33 points, or 0.5 percent; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 10.66 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,498.58; Nasdaq composite index rallies for first time in week, gaining 114.94 points, or 2.6 percent, to 4,572.83; graph on Dow Jones industrial average; charts on stocks with large price percentage gains and losses and common stocks with largest gains and declines in percentage terms in first quarter of 2000, as calculated by Associated Press (M)

headline: A Gadfly, but One With a Difference
abstract: Andre Piazza, a former R & B Falcon employee and a familiar gadlfy at company meetings, disrupts annual meeting by brandishing hand grenade and pulling pin when asked to hold his questions until later; a company official wrestles grenade away from Piazza; the grenade turns out to be a harmless dummy, but Piazza is arrested on misdemeanor charge of making a terrorist threat (M)

headline: QUALITY DINING AGAIN REJECTS A HOSTILE TAKEOVER BID
abstract: Quality Dining Inc again rejects $54 million hostile takeover bid by investor group NBO LLC (S)

headline: Magazines Expect 12% Rise in Ad Revenue
abstract: Magazine publishers expect advertising revenue to increase by 12 or 13 percent this year despite the decline of many online companies and softness in some other categories, the trade journal Advertising Age said in its current issue.    According to the report, many magazine executives and media buyers say that a strong economy is pushing advertising spending higher than the increase of 8 percent to 9 percent they had expected. Automobile companies have spent the most on advertising so far in 2000, $512 million, followed by technology, telecommunications and communications networking systems businesses, the magazine said.

headline: Not Really a Stretch
abstract: News release by Sure Fit, slipcover maker, touting its 40 percent revenue growth as comparable to that of high-tech company reflects frustration of old-economy companies at ease with which Internet startups attract investor and media attention (S)

headline: SCIENTIFIC GAMES AND AUTOTOTE CONFIRM MERGER TALKS
abstract: Scientific Games Holdings Corp says it is discussing merger with Autotote Corp; Scientific Games says agreement has not been reached (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: EXXON MOBIL CORP., Irving, Tex., the No. 1 oil company in the world, said it had completed the sale of its California operations that regulators required before approving last year's merger of Exxon and Mobil.

headline: As Rate Fears Ebb, Treasury Yields Fall
abstract: Yields on Treasury securities fall to six-week lows on expectations that the Federal Reserve will not need to raise interest rates as much as forecast to slow the economy; 30-year bond's yield falls to 5.92 percent, from 5.94 percent, with price rising 12/32, to 104 21/32; chart; graph on 3-month Treasury bills (S)

headline: Israel's Withdrawal Is Certified by U.N.
abstract: UN certifies that Israel has withdrawn from southern Lebanon8

headline: Oldsmobile Head Joins Web Firm
abstract: General Motors Corp says Karen Francis, who is departing as general manager of its Oldsmobile division, will join Internet Capital Group; successor at GM has not been named (S)

headline: Hanna Batatu, 74, Authority On Politics of Iraq and Syria
abstract: Dr Hanna Batatu, expert on contemporary Arab world, dies at age 74; photo (M)

headline: WESLEY JESSEN VISIONCARE OPPOSES TENDER OFFER
abstract: Board of Wesley Jessen VisionCare recommends that shareholders refuse $35.55-a-share hostile offer from Bausch & Lomb Inc (S)

headline: Economic Scene; Equality in hiring remains the key to civil rights goals.
abstract: Alan B Krueger (Economic Scene) column on economic impact of Civil Rights Act of 1964; says since 1965, median earnings of black full-time workers have gained ground on earnings of their white counterparts; holds equality in hiring rmeains key to civil rights goals; says antidiscrimination policy works best when it opens doors and allows peopele to prove their mettle; graph (M)

headline: U.S. Condemns Peru Election And Fujimori Rule as Invalid
abstract: US and allies issue stern warnings to Peru that re-election of President Alberto K Fujimori without opposition risks serious harm to country's standing in international community; call handling of election undemocratic and its result illegitimate; election was boycotted by opposition and carried out despite objections from Organization of American States (S)

headline: In Japan, Start-Up and Risk Are New Business Watchwords
abstract: Focus on major shifts occurring in Japanese economy; changes in employer-employee relationship, liberalization of financial markets and explosion of new business models in freewheeling arenas of Internet and information technology have spawned new breed of entrepreneurs who care little for conventions that have dominated country for decades; many big companies are slowly realizing benefits of competitive procurement practices and cost of providing life support to many small partners; are struggling to pare work forces, largely by drastically cutting hiring of new employees; many that still dominate economy are adopting compensation programs based on performance and abolishing remuneration determined by seniority, fast diluting attractions of lifetime employment; evolution of financial markets is helping entrepreneurs, as new stock markets emerge designed to foster young businesses and flood of venture capital provides money that was once parceled out almost exclusively by big banks largely interested in corporate customers and real estate developers; at same time, barriers to taking young companies public have eased, making private capital less crucial in nursing them; previously, economic structure that evolved after World War II with its heavy emphasis on government-directed bank lending, its punitive tax structure, its ban on stock options and its lack of pension portability, had stifled entrepreneural spirit; photo; graph; chart (M)

headline: Time Warner and Disney Agree to End Dispute About Cable
abstract: Time Warner chairman Gerald M Levin says Time Warner and Walt Disney Co have reached agreement in principle that will end their dispute over cable transmission of television channels owned by Disney, address to shareholders; neither Time Warner nor Disney executives will discuss specific details of agreement, saying that it needs to be committed to contractual language first (M)

headline: AGCO WILL CLOSE MISSOURI PLANT AND DISMISS WORKERS
abstract: The Agco Corporation, the farm-equipment maker, said yesterday that it would close its plant in Independence, Mo., and dismiss about 500 workers, or 5 percent of its work force, because of a decline in demand for farm equipment. The company, the maker of Massey Ferguson equipment, said it would take a charge of about $20 million to close the plant, which is expected to cut production costs by about $10 million a year. Manufacturing will be moved to Agco's plant in Hesston, Kan., or will be contracted to third-party manufacturers.

headline: Vietnam's Napalm Photo Girl Forgives
abstract: LONDON—  Standing next to the museum display, the warm eyes, generous smile and smooth complexion of Phan Thi Kim Phuc make it hard to believe she is the same person as the girl in the picture.

headline: 3 Partners Plan Online Venture
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group, General Atlantic Partners LLC and Boston Consulting Group will create joint venture called iFormation Group to acquire and build online businesses for traditional companies (S)

headline: George E. Taylor, 94, Founder Of Key China Studies Program
abstract: George E Taylor, historian and political scientist who specialized in Asia, dies at age 94; photo (M)

headline: A Lego Webcam Turns a Toy Into a Robot That Stands Guard
abstract: Latest addition to Lego's popular Mindstorm line of programmable toy robots is Vision Command, $99 Web camera that is mounted on core unit of Lego's Robotics Invention System; using camera as pair of eyes, Mindstorm robot can detect color or movement, and react with any number of responses; photo (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Microsoft Hires Lobbyist To Curry Favor With Bush  Microsoft has hired Ralph Reed, a senior consultant to Gov. George W. Bush's presidential campaign and a former head of the Christian Coalition, to lobby Mr. Bush in opposition to the government's antitrust case against the software giant.   Microsoft's aim, the company says, is to curry favor with the apparent Republican presidential nominee, hoping he will speak out against the government's case -- and, perhaps, take a softer approach toward the company if he is elected president.   [Page A1.]

headline: SCOOT.COM TO BUY LOOT
abstract: Scoot.com PLC acquires British classified company Loot Ltd for $283.4 million in stock and cash; will assume $3 million in debt; Vivendi SA, French company, agrees to finance deal by buying some Scoot shares to increase its stake in Scoot to 22.4 percent from 11.5 percent (S)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Government and Business Leaders Discuss Ways to Fight International Cybercrime

headline: To Paleo Fans, a Dynamic Dino Site
abstract: Russell J Jacobson has emerged as Web celebrity with Dino Russ's Lair Web site, devoted to dinosaurs; has been putting dinosaur data online since early days of Internet; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   9.50   9.50   7.75       Discount rate   6.00   6.00   4.50       Federal funds   6.56   6.56   5.12       3-month T-bills   5.63   5.65   4.62       6-month T-bills   5.93   5.94   4.82       10-yr. T-infl.   4.09   4.08   4.01       10-yr. T-note   6.10   6.08   5.78       30-yr. T-bond   5.95   5.94   5.96       Telephone bd.   8.32   8.19   7.70       Municipal bds.   5.94   5.93   5.53        (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Hyundai Chief Quits to Allow Restructuring
abstract: On the 15th floor of his headquarters in downtown Seoul, Chung Ju Yung, the 84-year-old honorary chairman of Hyundai Group, announced the unthinkable Wednesday: He and the two sons he had chosen to take over most of the sprawling but troubled industrial empire would resign to make way for professional management.

headline: A Historian Presents the Civil War,Online and Unfiltered by Historians
abstract: A Historian Presents the Civil War, Online and Unfiltered by Historians

headline: The Search Engine as Cyborg
abstract: Web search engines are becoming more dependent on human judgment because computers and software cannot find and index all the new sites in the ever-expanding Web and because they are not yet at the point where they can analyze a Web document and, without any human interference, instantly understand what that document is about; librarians at Northern Light constantly fine-tune their directory structure and come up with names of categories for sorting Web sites; Google and other system may evaluate sites according to how frequently they are visited or the paths by which they are visited; information scientists see danger of human bias and 'tyranny of the majority' in such approaches; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Business; State Castoffs Are Going, Going, Gone, on the Internet
abstract: Number of states are finding that surplus property fetches much more when offered on online auction sites than through traditional channels; Oregon is leader in online sales; photo (M)

headline: MYPOINTS.COM TO BUY CYBERGOLD FOR $157 MILLION
abstract: MyPoints.com Inc will pay roughly $157 million in stock for Cybergold Inc (S)

headline: Lighting Up A Lesson In China Trade
abstract: Debate over bill to normalize trade with China turns on conflicting views of how best to induce change in China's authoritarian regime; those opposed to normalized trade contend annual Congressional reviews of China's trade status maintain pressure on Beijing to respond to complaints about human right abuses; those who favor normalized trade contend forces opened up within China by liberalized trade can exert greater leverage for reform than any diplomatic pressure; recent changes visible on streets of Shanghai seem to support latter argument; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Rapid Growth Makes Cisco A New Leader
abstract: Cisco Systems, which makes much of equipment that powers Internet, has become leader in computer industry, replacing Microsoft Corp; shift took place between March 1999 and March 2000, as Cisco's stock tripled, swelling company's market capitalization by $380 billion, to $560 billion; chart (Market Place column) (M)

headline: MORE ON THE DECISION
abstract: OLD RULES IN NEW ECONOMY  The legal principles that led to the breakup of Standard Oil in 1911 and AT&T in 1984 are not obsolete.   PAGE C1

headline: London Journal; Queen Breaks the Ice: Camilla's Out of the Fridge
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II, in noteworthy and unexpected warming of relations, meets Camilla Parker Bowles, mistress to Prince of Wales, for first time since their affair began; encounter was at 60th birthday party for exiled King Constantine of Greece at Charles's Highgrove estate in Gloucestershire; photo (M)

headline: A Brazilian Convict's Path From Poverty to 'a Very Dark Place'
abstract: Article on young killer, Leandro Luis Bernardo Dias, and Sao Paulo's Carandiru prison as ugly underside of Brazil's startlingdevelopment over past decade; Dias's slum life and crimes and frightening conditions in crumbling prison reflect Brazil's abject poverty, social crisis and unmistakable message that life is cheap; photos (M)

headline: Microsoft Offers A Dictionary That Talks
abstract: Microsoft's online Encarta World English Dictionary site offers audio clips of most common United States pronunciation of many words; photo (M)

headline: THE BOSS; Always Trying Harder
abstract: The Boss column profiles Marguerite McLeod, chief executive of MyShopFactory.com; her photo (M)

headline: Steel Curbs by U.S. Said to Cost Buyers $150 Billion
abstract: Report, written by lawyers for foreign steel makers and supported by American Institute for International Steel, says American trade restrictions on imported steel have cost customers in US as much as $150 billion in last three decades; report is dismissed by Clinton administration as biased; study takes aim at US antidumping laws that it says protect domestic companies against more efficient competitors in Japan, South Korea, Brazil and other nations (M)

headline: 'I Love You' -- So Hard to Resist, So Ripe for Evil
abstract: 'I love you' message attached to destructive computer virus proved success as act of applied psychology; induced people aware of threat of viruses spread by e-mail to open attachment; photo (M)

headline: CANADA JOBLESSNESS FALLS
abstract: Canada's unemployment rate dips to 24-year low of 6.6 percent in May, 2/10 percent below April (S)

headline: NEWMONT MINING TO BUY BATTLE MOUNTAIN GOLD
abstract: Newmont Mining Corp, North America's largest gold producer, acquires Battle Mountain Gold Co for $557 million in stock; also will assume $199 million of Battle Mountain's long-term debt, along with 2.3 million convertible preferred shares worth about $110 million (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PENN OCTANE CORP., Palm Desert, Calif., which supplies cooking gas to northeastern Mexico, said it had hired the investment bank CIBC World Markets Corp. to help review options, including a sale or merger.

headline: America Online to Appeal Subscribers´ Suit
abstract: America Online to Appeal Subscribers' Suit

headline: Opening Further, Japanese Are Buying More Corporate Bonds
abstract: Demand for corporate bonds denominated in yen has exploded this year, result of some far-reaching changes that have helped make Japanese economy less insular; IBM is latest company to tap market, selling 140 billion yen, or $1.31 billion at current exchange rates, of so-called Samurai bonds and setting record for corporate fund-raising in yen by foreign company; other recent corporate bond trading noted (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICAN INFLATION DOWN
abstract: Banco de Mexico head Guillermo Ortiz says Mexico's inflation fell in first quarter to 2.8 percent, lowest rate since 1994 peso crisis; predicts inflation decline will continue throughout 2000; central bank survey of private sector analysts shows they predict 9.67 inflation rate for this year, below Mexico's goal of 10 percent (S)

headline: Advertising; Eloise, the Grinch and Friends Taking a Page From Harry Potter
abstract: Hollywood was stunned last summer when Kenn Viselman's Itsy Bitsy Entertainment Company beat out several big studios for the merchandising and film rights to the Eloise books, the classic 1950's children's series about a cheeky little girl who lives in Manhattan's Plaza Hotel. Variety called it ''not just an itsy bitsy surprise: it was a shock.''    But while Mr. Viselman loved Eloise's comic antics, it wasn't just the appeal of the character that turned his head. As the man behind the marketing of ''Teletubbies,'' Mr. Viselman saw in the Eloise books a long-term brand franchise that could be transformed into everything from dolls to a television series to a string of feature films.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: A Lost Generation Seeks Its Due
abstract: Article on overlooked 'silent generation,' people who are in their mid-50's to mid-70's; says as 'silents' age, many are beginning to panic, because they have never had great adventure; they were not called on to save the world, as the GI generation was, and they have not been as wrapped up in satisfying themselves as baby boomers have been; says 'silents' want more out of life and that now-or-never feeling is one reason that many workers in their late 50's and early 60's are choosing to retire early and to proceed on their own terms; drawing (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: NASHUA CORP., Nashua, N.H., an office copy and computer products company, said its shareholders had re-elected its current directors, fending off a challenge by Newcastle Partners, Dallas, an investment group holding about 2 percent of Nashua's stock.    AMERICAN TOWER CORP., Boston, an owner of broadcast and wireless-communications towers, has agreed to buy General Telecom, New York, a telephone switching company, for $30 million.

headline: Fear of Failure? Back Up
abstract: Letter from Stephen L Javna comments on State of the Art column on May 18 on creating backups for when hard disk crashes

headline: MOTOROLA AWARDS CONTRACT TO FLEXTRONICS
abstract: Motorola Inc says Flextronics International Ltd of Singapore will make some of its phones, pagers and electronics equipment under five-year, $30 billion contract; Motorola will also buy 11 million Flextronics shares, or about 5 percent of company, for approximately $100 million (S)

headline: FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN KOREA RISES
abstract: South Korea's Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Energy says foreign direct investment in South Korea rose 34.9 percent in March from year earlier; investment totaled $981 million, and amounted to $2.73 billion in first three months of 2000, up 36.2 percent from year-earlier period (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: THE AMERICAS    PARAGUAY: ARGENTINA TO EXTRADITE TWO  An Argentine court ordered the extradition of two Paraguayans accused in the assassination of Vice President Luis Maria Argana of Paraguay last year. The men, arrested in January, were named by a man who confessed to being an accomplice in the killing, which led to the overthrow of Paraguay's president and forced its armed forces chief, who was accused of ordering the crime, into exile. Lawyers said the two men would appeal.    Larry Rohter (NYT)

headline: BAUSCH & LOMB PLANS TENDER OFFER FOR WESLEY JESSEN
abstract: Bausch & Lomb Inc will make tender offer for all outstanding shares of Wesley Jessen VisionCare Inc, after the company rejects unsolicited $666 million buyout offer; Bausch & Lomb will offer Wesley Jessen shareholders $34 a share in cash; Bausch & Lomb wants Wesley Jessen to drop its proposed purchase of Ocular Sciences Inc, which would create large competitor for Bausch & Lomb (S)

headline: In Silicon Valley, Ruling Won't Change Culture
abstract: Industry executives say even if Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's order to break up Microsoft survives appeal unscathed, potential competitors will not feel impact of antitrust trial for at least year; say culture in software industry will take time to change; say it may be year or more for investors like venture capitalists to begin financing potential competitors to Microsoft; y former Netscape chief James Barksdale comments; photo (M)

headline: Text of Fed's Statement
abstract: Text of statement by Federal Open Market Committee, Federal Reserve's monetary policy panel, after its decision to leave short-term interest rates unchanged

headline: MP3.com Soars on Talk of Settlement
abstract: June 7, 2000

headline: Road Warriors
abstract: As cities continue to sprawl, the trip to work, by whatever means, consumes more and more of the day. And that leaves more room for all manner of mishap and adventure. What has been your own most extraordinary, or annoying, experience in commuting, and what was the response when you dragged into work? Send your stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to onthjob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: Serbia's Detroit That Was: In Distress and Angry
abstract: Article describes conditions in Kragujevac, Serbia, city of nearly 200,000 which lies devastated after nearly decade of war but remains one of most important towns for Serbia's democratic opposition; approximately 60 percent of those of working age are out of jobs; while there is much anger, there is less sense of revolution than of passivity, anxiety and alienation; map (M)

headline: From Mirabella to U.S. Edition of Elle
abstract: Hachette Filipacchi Magazines said yesterday that it had named Roberta Myers, former editor in chief of Mirabella, to the top slot at the United States edition of Elle.     Ms. Myers will assume her new position on June 5, replacing Elaina Richardson, who is leaving to become president of Yaddo Inc., an artists' community in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

headline: MAVERICK TUBE TO BUY PRUDENTIAL STEEL FOR $483 MILLION
abstract: Maverick Tube Corp acquires Prudential Steel Ltd for $483 million in stock (S)

headline: Dot-Coms: A Way to Burn Money, or to Fuel the Future?; Winners Always Get Out in Time
abstract: Article by Serge Wilson, Internet startup executive, holds many such companies are doomed to flame out after early backers cash out because they have no incentive to run efficiently; holds venture capitalists encourage startups to burn through cash to win market share and get to initial public offering faster; photo (M)

headline: Fight Brews Over Swiss Bid to Block Web Sites
abstract: Fight Brews Over Swiss Bid to Block Web Sites

headline: A New Breed of Virus Targets Handheld Devices
abstract: A New Breed of Virus Targets Handheld Devices

headline: Swiss Holocaust Sentence
abstract: Gaston-Armand Amaudruz, who denied in books and magazines that Nazi gas chambers existed, is sentenced to year in jail for violating 1995 Swiss law that makes it crime to deny, grossly minimize or seek to justify genocide (S)

headline: Brazil Planning Early Payments to International Lenders
abstract: Brazil's central bank will repay early a large part of $41.5 billion emergency loan package provided by International Monetary Fund and other lenders; move would redeem $10.3 billion of loans due in October to IMF, Japanese central bank and Bank of International Settlements; of $32 billion offered by these institutions, Brazil has drawn $20 billion (M)

headline: GUARDIAN FIBERGLASS MAKES NEW BID FOR CAMERON ASHLEY
abstract: Cameron Ashley Building Products Inc receives unsolicited bid to be acquired by Guardian Fiberglass, subsidiary of Guardian Industries Corp, for $18.50 a share, total of $161 million; offer tops bid Cameron Ashley acccepted last week from investment group led by members of Cameron Ashley's management, which was for $18.25 a share (S)

headline: Revenge of the Tuna Salad
abstract: Readers relate stories about food in the workplace; cartoon (M)

headline: INTERNET SERVICES CONCERN MARCHFIRST SPINS OFF UNIT
abstract: MarchFirst Inc will spin off its MarketsWork company (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ENRON CORP., Houston, the world's largest energy trading company, and Peoples Energy Corp., Chicago, said they planned to spend about $360 million to build power plants in the Chicago area.

headline: WISCONSIN PLAYGROUND EQUIPMENT MAKER TO BE ACQUIRED
abstract: PlayCore agrees to be bought for $106 million by investment group affiliated with Chartwell Investments II, which will also assume $53.5 million in debt (S)

headline: No Clear Winner in Decision In Isuzu vs. Consumer Reports
abstract: Jury in Los Angeles rules that Consumers Union, publisher of Consumer Reports magazine, made several false statements in article and at news conference in which it branded Isuzu Motors Ltd's Isuzu Trooper sport utility unsafe because of tendency to tip over when swerving to avoid an object in the road; despite ruling, Consuemrs Union wins defamation case because jury either finds false statements were not made maliciously or had not damaged Isuzu; analysts say verdict is one that allows both sides to claim share of victory, with real victor being freedom of the press (M)

headline: Agency Group Shuffles Overseas Units
abstract: Units of the B Com3  Group are merging and acquiring abroad.    B Com3  in Chicago is merging the Japanese operations of two of its agencies -- the Leo Burnett Company and D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles. The new agency, to be called Beacon, will have 300 employees and billings estimated at $430 million from clients like Kellogg, Polaroid and Procter & Gamble.

headline: Barak Shifts Focus to the Palestinians
abstract: Prime Min Ehud Barak of Israel turns his attention to impending deadlines on Palestinian peace track; indicates he will offer some sweeteners to break ice with Palestinians, who have felt insulted and neglected by his nearly exclusive focus on Syria; pledges publicly, for first time, that Israel will not seek to annex Arab villages near Jerusalem; Palestinian leaders are unimpressed, noting Barak's failure to voice readiness to withdraw from all of West Bank, to dismantle Israeli settlements, or to acknowledge right of return of Palestinian refugees; map (M)

headline: AMERICAN GREETINGS WITHDRAWS PLANS FOR OFFERING
abstract: American Greetings Corp drops plan to sell minority stake in its online unit in initial public offering, citing financial market conditions (S)

headline: Justice Department Approves AT&T's Bid for a Cable Giant
abstract: Justice Dept approves AT&T's proposed acquisition of MediaOne Group, giving telephone giant control over more than third of nation's cable network for television, high-speed Internet access and online telephone service; companies now await decision by Federal Communications Commission, whose staff has raised concerns about companies having too much control over both cable systems and programming; Federal regulations prohibit company from owning more than 30 percent of nation's cable systems; by some estimates, AT&T would control more than 40 percent after merger; Justice Dept decision requires companies to sell their interest in Road Runner, cable Internet service, but competitors and consumer groups ask FCC to force sale of more assets to ensure competitive marketplace; Justice's decision continues Clinton administration policy of putting few obstacles in way of consolidation of telecommunications market since it was deregulated in 1996 (M)

headline: CATALINA LIGHTING WILL PURCHASE RING, A BRITISH RIVAL
abstract: Catalina Lighting Inc, maker of residential and office lighting products, agrees to buy British rival, Ring PLC, for $33 million (S)

headline: Through the Looking Glass: Europe Raises Interest Rates
abstract: Floyd Norris article discusses decision by European Central Bank to raise interest rate by half-point at time when European inflation, in this case figures are for Germany, is running at about 2 percent and unemployment rate is 9.6 percent; says bank, eager to prove its credibility as inflation fighter, has confounded forecasters by its action; says sad thing about Europe now is that it seems to have accepted high unemployment as virtually permanent thing; notes latest report for countries in eruo zone is 9.2 percent; says conventional wisdom is that unemployment is high because of structural problems like high wages and restrictive labor laws and that stimulative monetary policy will only revive inflation without doing much for growth; graph on German unemployment (M)

abstract: Robert C Bassett, former lawyer, labor negotiator and publisher, died May 2 at age 89 (M)

headline: Genetics Offers Denouement To Mystery of Prince's Death
abstract: Two scientists say they have proof that disease-riddled boy who died in 1795 after years alone in prison cell in France really was Louis XVII, son of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette; more than 500 books have been written about young dauphin, and many theories have emerged about his possible escape and presumed exile after his parents were sent to guillotine at height of French Revolution; would-be heirs have popped up all over Europe through the years; scientists, Jean-Jacques Cassiman and Bernd Brinkmann, both specialists in human genetics, examined remains of boy--a dried heart--and claim they matched his DNA with that of other members of royal family, including DNA from lock of Marie Antoinette's hair; photo (M)

headline: Iranian Students Protest Crackdown on Newspapers
abstract: Students at two Tehran universities hold peaceful demonstrations to denounce widening crackdown on independent press; courts close down 13th newspaper and issue arrest warrant for popular moderate cleric accused of insulting Islam by attending Berlin conference on democracy; perilous war of words between reform forces and hard-line opponents reviewed (M)

headline: Three Who Thrived on Technology
abstract: Interviews with managers of three high-performing aggressive, technology-oriented mutual funds: Lee Kopp of Kopp Emerging Growth Fund, Robert Zuccaro of Grand Prix fund, and Jim D Oelschlager, manager of Pin Oak Aggressive Stock Fund; photos (M)

headline: Museums Find Many Eager to Help Them Sell Online
Newspaper Reports Kremlin Push for Stronger Central Control
abstract: Moscow newspaper, days before Vladimir V Putin's swearing-in as Russia's second president, publishes what purports to be Kremlin proposal to use KGB's successor agency as weapon against political foes, journalists and others who stand in way of 'real control' of Russian politics and society; among other things, proposal speculates that government's special services could smear opponents who have damaging information about Kremlin leadership and gather 'special information' about potential candidates for high office (M)

abstract: The Boss column profiles Dave Thomas, founder and chairman of Wendy's International; Thomas comments (M)

headline: Big Chinese Web Portal About to Issue Stock in U.S.
abstract: Sina.com, first of China's leading Internet companies, is set to go public in US later this week--sort of; investors who buy stock will not actually own stake in Sina.com; instead, they will own piece of Sina.com's offshore Web site--a fraction of its core business; investors will be buying stake in company's marginal Hong Kong, Taiwan and North American portals (M)

abstract: Dollar is little changed as consumer price report shows tame inflation; in New York, the euro settles at 95.96 cents, down from 96.07 cents; dollar trades at 106.65 yen, down from 106.89; graph (S)

headline: Big Companies Back New Intel Chip Rival
abstract: Transmeta, which aims to take on Intel Corp in processor market, announces that it has received $88 million in financing from America Online and other large companies; Gateway, Compaq, Sony and several major Taiwan electronics manufacturers joined with AOL to invest $72 million; further $16 million came from existing investors, including Soros Fund Management and Vulcan Ventures Inc, headed by Microsoft co-founder Paul G Allen (S)

headline: Czech Gypsies Knock Harder on the Closed Doors
abstract: Czech Republic has 200,000 Gypsies, many of whom say they are treated poorly, discriminated against and have little legal recourse; Monika Horakova, only Gypsy member of Czech Parliament, says she has been refused entry to club in her hometown, Brno, for years, but only recently, as country moves toward European Union, was she encouraged to sue; recent wave of criticism from United States Congress, State Dept and European Union about Czech Republic's Gypsy policies have prompted government to begin to deal more seriously with worsening situation; photo; map (M)

headline: IRISH MERGER TALKS END
abstract: Irish mortgage lender First Active, resisting 'low-price takeover,' ends merger talks with Anglo Irish Bank (S)

headline: Conseco to Increase Provision for Loans
abstract: Conseco Inc, in filing with Securities and Exchange Commission, says it will have to raise provision related to guarantees on loans to certain officers and directors by $65 million after tax; disclosure puts more pressure on Conseco and its ability to pay its debts (S)

headline: Coke Executive to Become Chief of Motley Fool
abstract: Motley Fool, popular personal finance site on the Internet, is expected to announce that Coca-Cola president C Patrick Garner will become its new chief executive (S)

headline: Ethiopians and Eritreans Sign Cease-Fire
abstract: War between Ethiopia and Eritrea officially ends with signing of preliminary cease-fire in Algiers and agreeing to work toward final settlement; Eritrean foreign minsiter, Haile Woldensae, and Ethiopian counterpart, Seyoum Mesfin, comment; terms of cease-fire noted; photo; map (M)

headline: Combining the Tube and the Chat Room
abstract: America Online to introduce AOLTV, centerpiece of its strategy to move beyond personal computer; is marketing service, which enables people to surf Internet on television screens, to its existing members who want to access to e-mail, chat rooms and list of friends available for instant online conversation while watching television; photos (M)

headline: Kellogg Realigns Creative Duties
abstract: Kellogg Co realigns creative duties for five global brands between two roster agencies, J Walter Thompson and Leo Burnett Co (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Details Magazine Has New Publisher
abstract: Advance Publications, restaffing and refocusing its Details magazine, names Bill Wackerman publisher; shifts magazine from its Conde Nast unit to its Fairchild Publications unit; will resume magazine's publication with Oct issue (S)

abstract: Smith Introduces Broader High-Tech Visa Bill
