headline: EQUITY OFFICE SELLS PARKING OPERATIONS IN 5 CITIES
abstract: Equity Office Properties Trust sells 11 parking operations in Boston, Indianapolis, Milwaukee, Pittsburgh and Philadelphia to Urban Growth Property Trust, affiliate of Security Capital Group Inc, for $180 million (S)

headline: Popularity of Microsoft Products Contributes to Virus Spread
abstract: Popularity of Microsoft Products Contributes to Virus Spread

headline: Furor Over Bill Obscures Crucial Emigration Issue
abstract: Supporters and opponents of controversial bill to grant China permanent normal trade relations make little mention of current law that requires annual review of trading rights based on whether China allows free emigration; 1974 law was aimed at securing release of people who wanted to escape Communist bloc for religious reasons; Congress has granted China full trading rights ever year since diplomatic ties were established in 1979 (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE; VOLKSWAGEN BUYS REST OF SKODA
abstract: Czech government approves sale of its remaining 30 percent stake in carmaker Skoda to Volkswagen for $300 million; Volkswagen already owns 70 percent of Skoda; photo (S)

headline: For Job Hunters, Networking Beats the Net
abstract: Trends column finds networking and referrals remain chief way people find work, despite increasing popularity of Internet as job-search tool; graph; charts (S)

headline: LOSS NARROWS AT THOMSON
abstract: Thomson Corp says first-quarter loss narrowed to $22 million from $72 million a year earlier (S)

headline: Farafenni Journal; Soldier's Tale: How War In Burma Altered Africa
abstract: Interview with Bakary Dibba, resident of Farfenni, Gambia, who was among hundreds of thousands of African men drafted to fight for Britain during World War II against Japanese Royal Imperial Army in Burma and other places they never knew existed; conscription changed face of Africa since participation of Africans in liberating Europe from Nazis and Asia from Japanese Army strengthened continent's push for independence; map; photo (M)

headline: CDNow Says Search For Partner Goes On
abstract: CDNow Inc, Internet music seller, says its search for an investment or merger could produce offers that are below its share price; CDNow has lost $212 million since starting business in 1994 (S)

headline: U.S. Vulture Investor Expected To Lead Japan Bank Takeover
abstract: Japan is expected to announce that W L Ross & Co, an investment concern run by the bankruptcy specialist Wilbur L Ross, has been chosen to take over Kofuku Bank, regional bank in Osaka that failed in May 1999; sale indicates that contrary to recent speculation, government has not closed door to potential acquisition of banks by foreigners; banking industry analysts say Japanese regional banks badly need to consolidate and lower costs (M)

headline: A Fund Is Planned By U.S. Companies For Nazis' Victims
abstract: Several American companies that had factories in Nazi Germany will set up fund under auspices of US Chamber of Commerce to aid people who suffered persecution under Hitler; aim is at least in part to head off lawsuits; Clinton administration has pressed for fund to help aging survivors; Deputy Sec Stuart Eizenstat comments; at least 50 American companies operated factories in Nazi Germany; most were nationalized after 1941, but were returned just after war; some companies received dividends or benefited from forced labor (M)

headline: Media Talk; 'World News Tonight' Gets New Producer
abstract: Paul A Slavin, newly named executive producer of ABC News's World News Tonight, comments on plans to expand audience; photo (M)

headline: Time Warner-ABC Cable Dispute Extended
abstract: ABC and Time Warner Cable agree to another extension in negotiations in their dispute over rights for Time Warner to carry ABC's stations on its cable systems (S)

headline: General Motors Hires Away A Top Renault Designer
abstract: General Motors Corp, which has been struggling for years to make its cars less boring, hires Anne Asenio, star designer who helped transform Renault from also-ran in European auto industry into one of industry's most feared competitors (M)

headline: Belgrade Stepping Up Intimidation Of Journalists
abstract: Yugoslav government steps up campaign to intimidate and impoverish independent press as hundreds attend rites honoring Slavko Curuvija, journalist gunned down on Belgrade street year ago after turning against Pres Slobodan Milosevic's regime; has been using courts to impose heavy fines on media to spur self-censorship (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: AFRICA    ZIMBABWE: PROTESTING MUGABE  An opposition group vowed to begin 100 days of prayer meetings and peaceful demonstrations to protest the policies of President Robert Mugabe and his governing party. The decision by the National Constitutional Assembly came after thugs attacked its peaceful march over the weekend, injuring several people. The group, which blamed the police for failing to prevent the violence, has criticized official corruption, the unraveling economy and Mr. Mugabe's support of black squatters on white-owned farms.    Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)    AFRICANS AND EUROPEANS MEET  African leaders pleaded in Cairo for sweeping relief of their continent's crippling debt at the start of the first Africa-Europe summit meeting. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, left, opened the talks between the 15-nation European Union and the 52-nation Organization of African Unity with a call for a radical solution to the debt problem. Despite economic reform and efforts to spread democracy and human rights, he said, Western aid had slumped in the last two decades and Africa's share of trade had shrunk.    (Reuters)    SOUTH AFRICA: UNIONS' GLOBAL VIEW  The world labor union movement said it would muster all its strength to fight the social and economic fallout of globalization, which it said was widening the gap between rich and poor nations. Labor leaders addressing the start in Durban of the 17th World Congress of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions said globalization needed to pay attention to social rights for it to be a sustainable economic system.    (Reuters)    MIDDLE EAST    IRAQ: TURKS STRIKE AT KURDS  Turkish F-16 jets struck Kurdish rebel bases in northern Iraq, as more than 1,000 troops penetrated some six miles into the region in a new campaign to hunt down the guerrillas, a military official said. Cobra helicopter gunships were reported reinforcing the troops and armored units. No serious clashes with the guerrillas were reported.    (AP)    ASIA    INDONESIA: SUHARTO QUIZZED  A five-member team from the attorney general's office questioned former President Suharto at his home about corruption during his 32-year rule. The session ended after 90 minutes when Mr. Suharto said he was tired. He has defied summonses to appear at the attorney general's office for questioning, saying he is too ill.   Seth Mydans (NYT)    LAOS: BLAST TIED TO TERRORISTS  Authorities blamed unspecified terrorists for an explosion at the Thank You Very Much Restaurant in the capital, Vientiane, that it said wounded six Western tourists and two Laotians. Such acts are rare in the capital but bandits and the remnants of anti-Communist Hmong insurgents do operate in the countryside.    Seth Mydans (NYT)    AFGHANISTAN: CURRENCY WEAKENED  Reported drought damage to opium crops has further battered Afghanistan's weak currency and driven money changers in Kabul to try to dump the local currency in favor of hard currencies. A bumper harvest last year established Afghanistan as the world's leading source of opium, the United Nations estimates. Afghanistan relies on opium, the raw ingredient for heroin, as its primary export.    Christopher S. Wren (NYT)    THE AMERICAS    MEXICO: VOTE SPLITS PARTY  A primary in the race for governor of Tabasco State has revived bitter divisions in the governing party, known as the PRI, with complaints that the departing governor, Roberto Madrazo, rigged the vote to favor a longtime aide, Manuel Andrade, over Congressman Arturo Nunez, who has spent years as a senior official in the government and the PRI. Partial results showed Mr. Andrade with 57 percent of the vote and Mr. Nunez with 38 percent. In the presidential primary last year Mr. Madrazo challenged the PRI establishment, losing to Francisco Labastida.    (AP)    EUROPE    SWITZERLAND: HOLOCAUST TRIAL  A Swiss man who denies that Hitler's gas chambers existed has gone on trial on charges that he violated Switzerland's anti-racism law. Gaston-Armand Amaudruz, 79, is being tried in Lausanne for writing that there is no evidence of the Holocaust's gas chambers. A 1995 Swiss law makes it illegal to deny or justify genocide. Mr. Amaudruz, a spokesman for a far-right group, faces up to three years in jail and a $25,000 fine.    Elizabeth Olson (NYT)    IRELAND: EX-PREMIER PAYING BACK TAXES  Former  Prime Minister Charlie Haughey, 74, will sell off family properties to pay more than $1.2 million in back taxes, including interest, on gifts received while in office from a supermarket executive. Mr. Haughey's fall from grace reached a low last year when he was booed by spectators at the funeral of a previous Fianna Fail party leader. He is also facing charges of obstructing a 1997 tribunal looking into payments to politicians.    Brian Lavery (NYT)    GERMANY: RIGHTIST DATA  The number of neo-Nazi and right-wing extremists declined from about 54,000 in 1998 to around 51,000 in 1999, the Federal Agency for the Protection of the Constitution said in an official report. The number of rightists deemed likely to commit acts of violence, however, grew by about 10 percent to 9,000, the agency said, adding that recorded violent attacks by far rightists reached 746, up from 708 in 1998. Germany's seven million foreigners are considered particular targets of those attacks.    Victor Homola (NYT)    GERMANY: SPYING ON KOHL  The former head of East Germany's foreign espionage service, Markus Wolf, said in an interview with Reuters that his agents had known for a long time about the illegal slush fund set up by the Christian Democrats under former Chancellor Helmut Kohl. But he said he made little use of the information because he considered all capitalists to be corrupt.    Victor Homola (NYT)

headline: For Want of Safer Glue, Chinese Shoemakers Get Sick
abstract: As China prepares to join World Trade Organization, international concerns are being directed at sometimes unpleasant or dangerous working conditions in country's export industries; problems abound in industries owned by foreign companies, but Chinese and foreign experts say health and safety conditions are generally far worse in smaller factories that have sprung up across country during economic reforms of last two decades, mainly producing goods for domestic market; such factories are run by private owners and local governments often under 19th-century safety conditions; health problems in mom-and-pop shoe factories in 'shoe town' district of Bishan described; map; photo (M)

headline: Europe Regulators Raid Coke Offices in Brussels and London
abstract: European Commission investigators raid Coca-Cola Co's office in Brussels as well as Coca-Cola Beverages in London, expanding inquiry into Coke's marketing practices that began last summer; at issue are many of methods Coke uses to bolster sales of its soft drinks: contracts that prohibit competitors' products, sales incentive programs and discounts for certain customers; by bringing Coca-Cola Enterprises into investigation, regulators seem intent on examining entire European operation; Coca-Cola says it is cooperating with authorities (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Court Rules in AT&T's Favor Over Sharing of Cable Lines  A federal appeals court ruled that local governments may not force companies that offer Internet access to share their telecommunications lines with rival cable modem providers.

headline: For Now, Microsoft Can't Save Itself
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column says rebound of Microsoft stock now that government has formally proposed its breakup will be slowed by fact that Microsoft itself is barred from buying its own shares until June 8 under terms of its $1.5 billion purchase of Visio in January, which used Microsoft stock in a pooling-of-interests transaction; says some Microsoft investors are beginning to worry about dilution of earnings presented by the 1.1 billion shares Microsoft has issued since 1990 under stock option and purchase plans; graph (M)

headline: MICROSOFT INVESTS IN JAPAN
abstract: Microsoft Corp acquires majority stake in Japan's second-largest cable television operator, Titus Communications, as it expands into networks offering high-capacity Internet access; Microsoft buys entire 60 percent stake held by MediaOne Group; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Interest Rates Move Upward As Fed Cites Wage Gains
abstract: Interest rates shot higher yesterday after the Federal Reserve reported that wages were rising across the country and investors wondered if that news would make the central bank more aggressive in its effort to slow economic growth.    The report on economic conditions in Federal Reserve Districts around the country said that ''there were more frequent reports of intensifying wage pressures as shortages of workers persisted in all districts.''

headline: Internet Authority Proposes Rules for New Domains
Vote in Zimbabwe Shows Opposition Making Big Gains
abstract: Supporters of Zimbabwe's fledgling opposition party, Movement for Democratic Change, are jubilant as results from parliamentary elections show it making unprecedented gains against Pres Robert Mugabe's governing party, which has dominated country for past 20 years; results show opposition winning 48 seats, claiming lopsided victories in urban districts where voters have been squeezed by skyrocketing inflation and deepening unemployment; governing party seems likely to maintain majority, carrying 51 mostly rural districts; photo (M)

headline: A Magazine Giant Weighs In on Internet Business
abstract: Interview with John Huey, who headed Time Inc's effort to create E-Company Now, monthly magazine about Internet business; graph compares magazines in field; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Plans to Shift Product Focus To the Internet
abstract: Microsoft Corp says it will retool its product line to shift focus of computing away from hardware devices and toward new generation of Internet-based software allowing people to interact with data and one another whether they are using computers, digital cell phones or interactive television; chairman Bill Gates and his top executives introduce what they portray as vision of new software platform--called .NET--in which users will be surrounded by range of devices providing access to universe of information, including business and personal data; Gates says new products will be rolled out in increments beginning next year, when Microsoft plans to introduce version of its Windows operating system to be called Windows.Net 1.0 (M)

headline: FRANCE TELECOM PLANS TO SELL ITS STAKE IN CROWN CASTLE
abstract: France Telecom will sell its $1.3 billion interest in Crown Castle International to buy cable company NTL Inc; France Telecom must sell its 20 percent stake in Crown Castle, provider of wireless services, to get antitrust approval in Britain to by 25 percent stake in cable company (S)

headline: Financial Issues and Microsoft Lead Indexes Lower; Dow Has Biggest Loss in 3 Weeks
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average declines 211.43, to 10,323.92; Nasdaq composite index falls 65.26, to 3,205.35; S&P 500 falls 17.53, to 1,381.52; forecast by Goldman Sachs Group for lower second-quarter profit is factor; graph on Dow Jones industrial average; key rates chart; graph on stocks with largest price percentage gains and losses (M)

headline: DataBank: April 10-14; A Flare of Inflation, Then a Meltdown
abstract: Graphs reviewing week's performance in stock and bond market

headline: Mirabella Told Summer Issue To Be Its Last
abstract: Hachette Filipacchi Magazines chief executive Jack Kliger announces that Mirabella magazine will close after it publishes its June/July issue; cites continuing lack of advertising support as reason for closing; magazine employs about 40 people; Hachette is offering severance packages that editorial employees describe as surprisingly generous; company is also trying to place employees in other Hachette magazines (M)

headline: Gerald J. Whitrow, 87, Author Of Philosophic Tomes on Time
abstract: Dr Gerald J Whitrow, mathematician and philosopher who devoted much of his life to pondering nature of time, died on June 2 at age 87 (M)

headline: Jiang's Cordial Visit to Turkey Overshadowed by Ethnic Dispute
abstract: Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin arrives in Turkey for long-awaited state visit; visit is overshadowed by dispute over jailings and executions of separatist Uighurs, ethnic Turks living in western China; Uighurs have broad support in Turkey, but are not allowed to openly agitate there against Chinese rule; Chinese are determined not to give further autonomy to Uighur region, which is believed to have vast oil and mineral reserves, and have moved several million Han Chinese into region (M)

headline: Wieden & Kennedy Wins Kelly Awards
abstract: Wieden & Kennedy takes top honors with two awards, including $100,000 prize for general excellence, at annual Kelly Awards, competition sponsored by Magazine Publishers of America; some other winners noted (Advertising column) (S)

headline: American Histories: Chasing Dreams And Nightmares; DOREL INDUSTRIES TO BUY SAFETY 1ST FOR $111 MILLION
abstract: Dorel Industries, Canadian manufacturer of home furniture, will buy Safety 1st Inc, maker of child safety products, for approximately $111 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro is little changed, as falling US stocks offset disappointment at European reluctance to support currency; euro trades at 89.70 cents, compared with 89.79 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: IMPERIAL PROFIT UP 15%
abstract: Britain's Imperial Tobacco Group PLC says first-half profit rose 15 percent; profit rose more than expected to 151 million pounds ($231 million) in six months ended March 25, from 131 million pounds a year earlier (S)

headline: Boys Will Be Boys, and Sometimes Girls, in Online Communities
abstract: Forty percent of participants in online communities have engaged in some form of gender switching, practice of pretending to be someone of opposite sex, according to study reported in journal Information, Communication and Society; finds that half of gender-switchers have given up practice, because it stopped being interesting or because their curiosity had been satisfied; authors of study say results show gender switchhing is far less popular than some social scientists had claimed; drawing (M)

headline: Conspicuous Consumption
abstract: Letter by Mike Mettler responds to June 15 article on increased use of entertainment devices for children in autos; says there is brave new world now on the open road

headline: After Attack by Hackers, AOL Tightens Data Access
abstract: America Online plans steps to fix flaws in its network that let hackers get access to personal data about some members last week; says it does not yet know how many accounts wer affected and what damage was done; estimates number at about 200 out of 23 million subscribers (M)

headline: VIRATA TO ACQUIRE EXCESS BANDWIDTH FOR $315 MILLION
abstract: Virata Corp, which sells semiconductors and software, acquires Excess Bandwidth Corp for about $315 million in stock (S)

headline: A Dwindling Few in Search of Value
abstract: Columbia University Business School's annual seminar on value investing draws only 16 participants this year, down from 60 in 1999, a reflection of investors' infatuation with high-priced technology stocks, many of which lack proven franchise power, obvious asset value or profits, key measures of value; Prof Bruce Greenwald leads faithful few in study of value factors; Greenwald defends value investing as an attempt to make intelligent use of all available data, though value stocks have underperformed growth stocks in recent years; photo; graph (M)

headline: GAS FIND IN INDONESIA
abstract: Joint venture of Lasmo PLC and Unocal Corp finds natural gas in Indonesia estimated at two to three trillion cubic feet; Lasmo shareholders approve plan to buy back up to 10 percent of its shares; photo (S)

headline: Two Record Labels Settle Copyright Suit With MP3.com
abstract: BMG Entertainment and Warner Music Group settle copyright lawsuit with MP3.com, signalling new era of cooperation in contentious online music distribution business; MP3.com will pay licensing fees and approximately $20 million each to BMG and Warner (M)

headline: Sites and Events This Week
abstract: Sites and Events This Week

headline: Britain Tries To Reassure Sierra Leone Before Pullout
abstract: British Foreign Sec Robin Cook tries to reassure anxious Sierra Leoneans of Britain's long-term commitment to its former West African colony, even as British troops prepare to withdraw and leave country's security in hands of United Nations peacekeeping force; on one-day trip to capital Freetown, Cook meets with Pres Ahmed Tejan Kabbah, leaders of fragile pro-government coalition, and military heads of a UN force that had teetered on edge of collapse in early May before British arrived; photo (M)

headline: An Aboriginal Star Carries Olympic Torch : A Symbolic Flame, a Symbolic Runner
abstract: MELBOURNE—  Walk through the modest front door of Nova Peris-Kneebone's Victorian home and you soon come face to frame with a picture of Muhammad Ali standing on a stage next to Peris-Kneebone's young daughter, Jessica.

headline: Classical Concerts and Recordings Seek an Audience on the Web
abstract: Sixty-six of most prestigious American symphony orchestras and operas and ballet companies reach agreement with musicians union that allows them to turn to Internet as prime distribution vehicle for their work; landmark agreement, reached after year of discussions between American Federation of Musicians and representatives from important organizations as New York Philharmonic, Cleveland Orchestra and Metropolitan Opera, will govern compensation to be paid to musicians for performances made available on Internet (M)

headline: Pseudo Programs Lays Off 58 Workers
abstract: Online TV network Pseudo Programs Inc lays off 58 workers from production department, approximately one quarter of its total staff (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: THE AMERICAS    CANADA: GUN LAW UPHELD  The Supreme Court has unanimously upheld the nation's gun control law, which is stricter than United States gun laws. Rejecting a challenge by 2 of Canada's territories and 6 of its 10 provinces, the court upheld the 1995 Firearms Act, which requires the licensing of all of Canada's gun owners by the end of this year and the registration of all guns by the end of 2002. Firearms owners had largely boycotted the licensing process, awaiting the outcome of the court challenge.    James Brooke (NYT)

headline: JOHNSON & JOHNSON SELLS CANADIAN CONDOM BUSINESS
abstract: Johnson & Johnson sells its Canadian business that makes Shields condoms to Pacific Dunlop's Ansell Healthcare Products unit for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: Plaintiff's Memorandum in Support of Proposed Final Judgment
abstract: Plaintiff's Memorandum in Support of Proposed Final Judgment

headline: ELECTRONICS BOUTIQUE WITHDRAWS FROM FUNCO BIDDING
abstract: The Electronics Boutique Holdings Corporation, a video game retailer, said yesterday that it would not increase its offer of $21 a share, a total of $135 million, to buy the rival Funco Inc. The bid was topped last week by the Babbage's Etc. unit of Barnes & Noble, which agreed to pay $24.75 a share, or $161.5 million. The bidding war started in early April, when Funco of Eden Prairie, Minn., agreed to be acquired by Electronics Boutique of West Chester, Pa., for $17.50 a share. Barnes & Noble, based in New York, followed with an unsolicited bid of $135 million, an offer Electronics Boutique matched. Electronics Boutique had until yesterday to increase its offer.

headline: Huge Losses Move Soros to Revamp Empire
abstract: George Soros, who has absorbed huge losses in recent weeks, will reorganize his investment empire and abandon many of high-risk techniques that made him a billionaire and rewarded wealthy investors handsomely; five funds run by Soros Fund Management have declined twenty percent this year on technology's crash, and are down about one third from $22-billion peak in August 1998; Quantum Fund manager Stanley F Druckenmiller and Quota Fund manager S Nicholas Roditi will retire; Soros will reorganize Quantum as group of smaller funds; adds that he wants to reduce his market exposure and be more conservative, accepting lower returns as result (M)

headline: FedEx Profit Increases 11% As U.S. Shipments Rebound
abstract: FedEx says profit in its fiscal fourth quarter rose 11 percent, more than forecast, on rebound in US shipments; net income rose to $245 million from $221 million in year-earlier period; revenue in quarter ended May 31 increased 11 percent, to $4.85 billion from $4.38 billion (M)

headline: Barclays Bank has kicked off a really big brand campaign, but there's just one small problem.
abstract: Barclays PLC has begun $22 million advertising campaign that claims it is a big bank as it continues big cost-cutting program that includes closing 172 branches; ad campaign was created by Leagas Delaney in London (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Chief Executive of Efdex Resigns Abruptly
abstract: Ellen R Marram abruptly resigns as chief executive of efdex, Internet start-up she joined nine months ago (S)

headline: Big Japan Contractor Asks Banks to Forgive Billions in Debts
abstract: Japan's Hazama Corp appeals to its banks to forgive billions of dollars in debts, intensifying pressure on Japan's stressed financial system; decision by Hazama Corp, general contractor, to request 400 billion yen, or $3.7 billion at current exchange rates, worth of debt forgiveness is yet another sign that bad-loan problems of Japanese banks are far from over (M)

headline: DDB Chicago Wins The Grandy Award
abstract: DDB Chicago is top winner at annual International Andy Awards ceremony, winning grand prize, known as the Grandy, as well as most Andy awards; other winners noted (Advertising column) (S)

headline: DEAL FOR SWEDISH COMPANY
abstract: Japan's Toyoda Automatic Loom Works Ltd agrees to acquire 25.1 percent stake in BT Industries of Sweden for $222 million; Toyoda, affiliate of Toyota Motor Corp, says it plans to spend $664 million to buy rest of BT Industries by mid-May; Toyoda plans to buy 16.8 percent stake from Nordico Invest and 8.3 percent stake from Banc of America Equity Partners (S)

headline: Paris Mayor's Troubles Grow as Fraud Investigation Widens
abstract: Web of scandal surrounding Paris Mayor Jean Tiberi grows more complicated as 15 city officials, including his top aide, are placed under formal investigation for election fraud; new development is blow for Pres Jacques Chirac's Gaullist party, which is maneuvering frantically to hold onto mayor's office, which is one of most prestigious posts in France; new investigations reach far beyond Tiberi and threaten even to taint Chirac since they involve fixing Paris elections while he was its mayor (M)

headline: Timberland Stock Split
abstract: Timberland Co will split its stock two shares for one; new shares will be issued July 17 to shareholders of record as of June 30 (S)

headline: St.-Tropez Journal; The Bikini's Habitat, a Fabled Beach, Is Endangered
abstract: Fierce battle is going on for control of St-Tropez's Pampelonne beach, major French tourist attraction; environmentalists have won two court rulings proclaiming that Pampelonne is 'remarkable natural preserve'; if designation sticks, it will halt all further construction; local officials, who want some decorum returned to beach, do not want total end to development; beach tourism is major source of income; photo; map (M)

headline: Investing; When the Phones Didn't Ring, Financial Advisers Smiled
abstract: Financial planners report getting a very few calls from anxious investors during the stock market's recent plunge; say relative calm validates their efforts at persuading clients to take a long-term view and to disregard market swings; photo (M)

headline: Homing In on 'Intelligent' Web Design
abstract: Web-design firm in Chicago puts up parody Web site, eNoricom.com, that takes e-clients through process of selecting name, logo and motto for their new business; site pokes fun at recent dot-com conformity in naming and branding of new technology companies; drawing (M)

headline: Humberto Gordon, 72, Leader Of Secret Police Under Pinochet
abstract: Gen Humberto Gordon, who commanded Chilean secret police for seven years in Gen Augusto Pinochet's dictatorship, died on June 15 at age 72 (M)

headline: Schwab Says Account Values Plunged
abstract: Clients of Charles Schwab Corp sustained $56.2 billion in market losses in April as declining stocks shaved value of holdings by 7 percent; decline in account values comes as company reports lowest level of monthly asset inflows since October 1999 (S)

headline: HOPE FOR BAAN
abstract: Shares of ailing Baan NV rise on optimism that the company will find new financing and benefit from new Internet-based products; Baan declines comment on whether it is in talks with potential buyer or financing partner; stock price graph (S)

headline: A Crumber for Every Household
abstract: Sampling of shopping Web sites offering goods available only on Web (M)

headline: Hughes Picks President for DirecTV
abstract: Hughes Electronics Corp names Odie Donald to be president of its DirecTV unit, succeeding Eddy Hartenstein, who was promoted in January to be senior executive vice president of Hughes Consumer Sector (S)

headline: Auto Sales Declined 2% Last Month
abstract: Auto sales dropped 2 percent in May from May 1999, first year-to-year drop since summer of 1998; dismal results at DaimlerChrysler and General Motors entirely accounted for decline as other manufacturers posted record sales, leaving it unclear whether long-expected decline in sales had begun; Ford Motor, Toyota, Nissan, Honda and Mitsubishi announce increases in sales, with Toyota and Mitsubishi reporting their best months ever (M)

headline: Russian Officials Flesh Out Alternative Antimissile Proposal
abstract: Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin and Defense Min Igor Sergeyev describe for Defense Sec William S Cohen system Russia develops that could protect both Russia and United States by shooting down missiles soon after they are launched; also propose use of 'theater' anitimissile systems to protect Europe; these systems, used to shoot down short- and medium-range missiles, are allowed by 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty (M)

headline: Japan Unsettles Returnees, Who Yearn to Leave Again
abstract: Many Japanese returning after living in West for years are discovering freedoms they reveled in abroad, such as making own decisions and expressing opinions, are major handicaps back home; say taint of other cultures, in country already famous for keeping foreigners at arm's length, is often enough for them to be regarded as no longer fully Japanese; phenomenon, long experienced by expatriates, is perhaps most dramatic measure of challenge monoethnic nation faces in struggle to come to terms with pressures of globalization; many expatriates, frustrated by reception back home, are no longer willing to tolerate strictures and are returning overseas as fast as possible; say adjustment required to fit back into society is often more traumatic than adaptations required in moving abroad; photo (M)

headline: Business Travel; It's summer, and air traffic delays are starting to pile up as the nation's airport traffic increases.
abstract: Summertime airplane flight delays are starting to pile up as traffic increases at domestic airports; despite new strategies for better-coordinated air traffic control responses to weather-related delays that cause most of problems in overtaxed system, industry is worried that this summer is going to be a lot like last summer: worst period ever for domestic flight delays (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Weak Demand Prompts Ford To Produce Fewer Excursions
abstract: Ford Motor Co says it will produce fewer Ford Excursion sport utility vehicles during the 2001 model year, but attributes cutback to weak consumer demand for the vehicle rather than the company's concerns about its safety and environmental problems; company spokesman says Ford will cut production rate for the Excursion to 52,000 a year this summer, from 69,000 a year now (M)

headline: Kodak Net Up 15% For First Quarter
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co says first-quarter profit rose 15 percent; profit from operations rose $297 million from $259 million a year ago; revenue was little changed at $3.1 billion (S)

headline: MEDIA: Updating a Paperback Heroine; Can Mary Higgins Clark Lure Her Faithful to E-Books?
abstract: Mary Higgins Clark's latest contract with Simon & Shuster is believed to be record-breaker--five books for total advance of $64 million; company prepares to release electronic version of her newest best seller, Before I Say Good-Bye, and nine of her other books in electronic versions for use on laptops and desktop computers, electronic reading devices and personal digital assistants; it is not clear if mass market will find e-books approachable, but Clark is proven weapon; her 22 hardcover books have all been best sellers; book deal outlines; photos (L)

headline: INQUIRY ON WORLD ONLINE
abstract: Dutch regulators will begin investigation into initial public offering of World Online International NV, whose chairwoman, Nina Brinks, sold her stock before offering; value of company has fallen to 3.8 billion euros from 12 billion euros when shares were first offered to public (S)

headline: Britain Plans a Public Offering of Its Military Research Unit
abstract: British government, risking breach with US military establishment and braving swings of uncertain stock market, will sell 75 percent stake in secret military research unit, Defense Evaluation and Research Agency, in public offering; Defense Min Geoff Hoon says timing of sale will depend on likely valuation of an offering and could be delayed; plan provokes uproar among labor unions worried about impact on agency's 12,000 employees, and among legislators who, like US Defense Department, fear that sale will allow military secrets to fall into hands of private business (M)

headline: An Unsentimental Horse Whisperer
abstract: My Job column profiles Sam Brown, horse trainer and riding instructor; Brown comments; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Corn plunges after new forecasts predict showers in part of US Midwest where long drought has threatened crop production; in Chicago, corn for July delivery falls 7 cents, to $2.3875 a bushel; graph; chart (S)

headline: MANOR CARE SHARES DROP AFTER TAKEOVER REJECTION
abstract: Manor Care Inc. said yesterday that it would stay independent and publicly owned, two months after the company, a nursing home management concern, announced it was weighing competing offers from a management-led investment group and from its chairman, Stewart Bainum Jr. The decision, which accompanied an earnings report that fell below expectations, sent the company's stock tumbling. The stock closed at $7.50, down $4.625 a share. Manor Care, which is based in Toledo, Ohio, said its board had concluded that no proposal adequately reflected the company's long-term value. Manor Care operates about 300 nursing homes, along with about 200 assisted-living and outpatient facilities.

headline: Shares Rally on the Hope the Fed Will Hold Steady
abstract: Stock prices rose on major US exchanges on June 7, paced by technology issues; Dow Jones industrial average gained 77.29 points, to close at 10,812.86 on volume of 38.2 million shares; Nasdaq gained 82.89, to 3,839.26; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 13.52 points, to 1,471.36; graph (M)

headline: Ben & Jerry's To Unilever, With Attitude
abstract: Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc agrees to be acquired by Unilever for about $326 million, or $43.60 a share; Ben & Jerry's will be wholly owned subsidiary of Unilever, with separate board that will include Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield, founders of ice cream company; Ben & Jerry's says employees will be protected; current social mission of company will be encouraged and well-funded, which will lead to improved performance in this area, and opportunity has been offered for company to contribute to Unilever's social practices worldwide; photo (M)

headline: REYNOLDS & REYNOLDS TO BUY HAC GROUP FOR $200 MILLION
abstract: Reynolds & Reynolds Co acquires HAC Group for as much as $200 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: PaineWebber's Timely Warning
abstract: PaineWebber is running ads warning about risks of 'skyhigh valuations of 'new' new-economy stocks' (S)

headline: Cuddly Isn't Everything
abstract: Prof Lee Spector reply to Ingrid Newkirk's May 4 letter warns future robots may be able to feel pain and fear

headline: Sotheby's to Delay Meeting At Urging of Shareholder
abstract: Sotheby's Holdings postpones its annual meeting as Baron Capital Group, company's largest outside shareholder, pushes company's board to distance itself from its former chairman, A Alfred Taubman; Sotheby's and Taubman are subjects of federal investigation into allegations of price-fixing in art auctions (M)

headline: ELECTRICITY INCREASE SUSPENDED
abstract: Itamar Franco, former president of Brazil who is governor of Brazil's state of Minas Gerais, suspends federally authorized 12 percent rate increase by state's partly private electric utility, Companhia Energetica de Minas Gerais; Franco has opposed privatization of electric power in the country; under suspension order, state utility must first study how higher charges would affect poor (S)

headline: Trade Shows Suffer The Pangs of E-Tail
abstract: Shakeout and consolidation that is sweeping Internet retailing is also affecting Internet retailing trade shows; Faulkner & Gray has canceled its Internet Retail World 2000 conference, set for Chicago; show had planned to feature some companies that are now in deep trouble, or defunct (M)

headline: Berkeley Law School Plans Clinic on Technology Issues
abstract: Compressed Data: Berkeley Law School Plans Clinic on Technology Issues

headline: Hewlett Wins Amazon.com Contract
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co wins contract to supply 90 percent of computers that run business of Amazon.com Inc, replacing machines from Sun Microsystems Inc and Compaq Computer Corp; analysts value agreement at about $500 million (S)

headline: Change of Power in Taiwan Is Meeting a Moderate Response From Beijing
abstract: Chen Shui-bian is inaugurated as president of Taiwan; promises that he will not take steps to establish independence unless mainland China attacks Taiwan; Beijing response, accusing Chen of a lack of sincerity, is surprisingly temperate when compared with the dire threats and invective of recent weeks; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    UKRAINE: PRESIDENTIAL POWERS  A constitutional court ruled that President Leonid Kuchma's plan to strengthen his powers over Parliament do not violate the Constitution. The ruling paves the way for Mr. Kuchma to submit the changes to Parliament, which must pass them by a two-thirds majority. Some opposition leaders want to water down the proposals, fearing Mr. Kuchma's executive powers will too easily override the legislature. Ever since Mr. Kuchma won re-election last November, he has been campaigning for stronger powers to break the many deadlocks that have snarled economic reform plans.   Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

headline: AOL Pays a Fine to Settle a Charge That It Inflated Profits
abstract: America Online Inc agrees to pay fine of $3.5 million and to restate its books from 1995 and 1996 after Securities and Exchange Commission charged that company improperly inflated profits by hundreds of millions of dollars; America Online neither admits nor denies wrongdoing (M)

headline: Long Arm of the Law Gropes in Cyberspace
abstract: PARIS—  Technology continues to outpace the law. The Internet knows no national boundaries, and last week, a U.S. judge in Massachusetts issued an injunction regarding the Internet to the world at large.

headline: Correction
abstract: Correction of April 2 chart with front-page articles (Sec 3) about executive pay

headline: TELECOM ITALIA BID DEFENDED
abstract: Deutsche Telekom chief executive Ron Sommer defends company's failed $95 billion bid to acquire Telecom Italia in 1999; says he still sees logic in acquisition; lost out to Olivetti; photo (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Berkeley Law School Plans Clinic on Technology Issues
abstract: University of California at Berkeley law school will form high-technology law clinic that will work on civil liberties and public policy issues involved in areas like Internet privacy, encryption and free speech; founder, Prof Pamela Samuelson, comments; photo (M)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Econnect Unsure About Financial Future

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Graph plots rise of euro against dollar on June 7 on expectations European Central Bank will raise interest rates on June 8

headline: Billions of Pages? That's the Job for Software Reading Census Forms
abstract: Richard Taylor, information technology expert with diverse business experience, comments on his current task: equipping computers to make sense of writing on 1.5 billion pages from United States census forms, which were sent to more than 121 million households; current census will be first to use computer software to decipher and record information rather than human eyes; Taylor photo (M)'

headline: A magazine intends to grow along with the Internet economy.
abstract: Industry Standard, magazine devoted to e-commerce, opens $10 million advertising drive to attract broader range of readers; campaign, magazine's first, comes when circulation growth is already strong; photo (M)

headline: Coup Talk Empties Beaches And Fiji's Cash Registers
abstract: Fiji's tourism industry is drying up during attempted coup by rebels who occupy Parliament and hold three dozen hostages; map; photo (M)

headline: Innovators Looking to London
abstract: Chicago's financial exchanges may have spread the notion of hedging by buying futures on stocks, bonds and currency, but two men who helped pave the way for all this in the 1980's are now turning to London to promote further innovations. They are Richard L. Sandor, the former Berkeley economics professor who helped introduce financial futures at the Chicago  Board of Trade, and Leslie Rosenthal, the exchange's former chairman. They said they were behind the recent announcement that Battery Ventures, a venture capital fund, and the Blackstone Group would invest $91 million for nearly 40 percent stake in the London International Financial Futures Exchange, or Liffe.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Platinum declines on expectations that Russia will resume exports after more than yearlong halt; platinum for delivery in July falls $29.60, to $462.90 an ounce, on New York Mercantile Exchange; graph; chart (S)

headline: Smart Appliances
abstract: Letter by Dr Nevin Cohen on April 13 article on smart appliances; says use of such devices will help in water and energy conservation

headline: Nasdaq's Japanese Cousin Off to Slow Start
abstract: Japanese offshoot of Nasdaq begins trading eight stocks in technically smooth but low-volume start to what represents first time stock exchange has tried to go global; volume was mere 660,000 shares; photo (M)

headline: New Economy, Old-School Rigor; G.E.'s Management Methods Are Put to Work on the Web
abstract: It seems intuitively obvious: anyone who is buying a new refrigerator or washer wants it delivered as soon as possible. So, an appliance manufacturer setting up a Web-based order-and-delivery system would put next-day delivery high on the list of lures, right?    Right -- if the Web designer was trusting to intuition. But one thing that the folks at General Electric have had drummed into them the last four years -- or, ever since the company embraced the quality-control regimen known as Six Sigma -- is that they act on gut instinct at their peril.

headline: Echoes of a Closing Door
abstract: Julian H Robertson Jr's decision to shut Tiger Management reverberates in his hometown, Salisbury, NC, which has been recipient of $3.5 billion from foundation set up by Robertson with money from his hedge fund; photo (S)

headline: How Pixels Add UpTo a Good Picture
abstract: How Pixels Add Up To a Good Picture

headline: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
abstract: May 4, 2000          The Dynamic Duo

headline: Tokyo Journal; The Little White Ball That Put Japan in the Red
abstract: At least 1,700 golf courses in Tokyo, Japan, built during speculative boom of 1980's are in financial difficulties from collapse of nation's economic bubble 10 years ago, and bankers and others who lent freely to finance them are desperately trying to contain crisis; problems underscore bad-loan problems affecting Japan's economy and comes at time when country is having some success in whittling down other types of unconventional debt; photo (M)

headline: UAL DECLARES FIRST CASH DIVIDEND IN 13 YEARS
abstract: UAL Corp declares it first quarterly cash dividend in 13 years; dividend of 31.25 cents will be paid on June 13 to shareholders of record May 30 (S)

headline: Broad Rally Lifts Nasdaq To 6.6% Gain
abstract: Nasdaq composite index gains 228.75 points, or 6.6 percent, to close at 3,711.23; Dow Jones industrial average rises 218.72 points, or 2 percent, to 11,124.82; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 47.58 points, or 3.3 percent, to 1,477.44; graph; charts (M)

headline: Surge in Worker Productivity Is Recorded for First Quarter
abstract: Labor Department reports worker productivity grew in first quarter at fastest pace in seven years, helping businesses contain labor costs and keeping inflation in check; says compared with fourth quarter, productivity increased at 2.4 percent rate in first quarter, while unit labor costs rose 0.6 percent from those in quarter year earlier (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Nicholas S. Battelle; Standish Small Cap Tax-Sensitive Equity Fund
abstract: Investing interview with Nicholas S Battelle, portfolio manager of Standish Small Cap Tax-Sensitive Equity Fund; photo; chart (M)

headline: Cloud on Fujimori's Future Shadows Voting in Peru
abstract: Pres Alberto K Fujimori of Peru faces his most serious political crisis since he shut down Congress and Supreme Court at height of guerrilla war in 1992; 14 million voters will decide whether he should serve third term in office, and seveal leading pollsters say first-round victory for him is unlikely unless he resorts to fraud; diplomats and experts say campaign has been so marred by dirty tricks and legal irregularities that Fujimori will emerge weakened leader, even if he wins; challenge to Fujimori is lead by Alejandro Toledo, who has capitalized on growing concerns about campaign as well as grumbling over three years of particularly bad economic hardship; photo (M)

headline: Ugandans Vote on Type Of Politics They Want
abstract: Ugandans vote in unusual referendum on how they want to be governed, question tied deeply to violence of country's past and popularity of Pres Yoweri Museveni, who has, in large measure, ended that violence; referendum offers choice between current essentially one-party system and a multiparty system; Musevini's opponents say relatively light turnout shows success of their call for boycott, but voters may also being staying away from polls because result in Museveni's favor has never seemed in doubt; photo (M)

headline: VODAFONE NAMES CHAIRMAN
abstract: Vodafone AirTouch appoints Lord MacLaurin chairman of company; move follows resignation of Sam Ginn (S)

headline: 40 China Experts Ask Delay on Antimissile Plan
abstract: Over 40 American scholars on China and former diplomats are urging Pres Clinton to delay decision on whether to build national missile defense, warning of negative impact on ties with China; Council for a Livable World gathered their signaturees on letter to Clinton (M)

headline: VIRTUALFUND AGREES TO SELL ITS DIGITAL-GRAPHICS UNIT
abstract: VirtualFund Inc sells its digital-graphics unit to MacDermid Inc for $50 million (S)

headline: Digital Signatures Headed for a Vote
Combining Offices, Acquiring Agencies
abstract: Interpublic Group of Cos is combining three of four offices of its Ludgate Communications unit with offices of its Golin/Harris International unit; BSMG Worldwide acquires Scotchbrook Communications, which will be renamed Scotchbrook/BSMG Worldwide; acquires GJW and Lyons Waddell, which will be merged with BSMG's London operation; BSMG renames its Bozell Eskew unit Sawyer Miller & Co (M)

headline: Microsoft Accuses Its Rivals Of Garbage-Can Tactics
abstract: Microsoft Corp accuses rivals of trying to buy office trash of Association for Competitive Technology, Microsoft-backed lobbying group, to obtain data about company; is unsure which rivals were behind effort; charge comes as Justice Department files another brief in antitrust case against Microsoft (M)

headline: Top Internet Art Prize Goes to Science-Fiction Writer
abstract: April 27, 2000

headline: GERMAN POWER MERGER
abstract: European Union approves $14 billion merger of two major German power companies: Veba AG and Viag AG (S)

headline: Results at Goldman Sachs Beat Forecasts
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group reports 21 percent increase in net income in its fiscal second quarter ended May 26 from year earlier; company earned $755 million; investment banking revenue of $1.59 billion is 29 percent higher than in first quarter, which was Goldman's most profitable since it became public company a year ago, and 59 percent higher than in second quarter of 1999 (M)

headline: With Special E-Fares, Online Bookings Soar
abstract: Airlines are going after potential customers by adding more Web sites and forming partnership with online retailers as online ticket sales soar; face delay in plan by alliance of 27 domestic and international airlines for one-stop shopping site for low fares while Justice Department probes American Society of Travel Agents antitrust complaint; are finding e-mail sales of steeply discounted seats for weekend travel on planes that would otherwise fly with many empty seats provide big source of incremental revenue; photo (M)

headline: To Prepare For Worst, Back Up
abstract: Peter Lewis column offers advice on ways to backup computer data; cites magnetic, optical and online devices; drawing (M)

headline: Excite and Yahoo E-Mail Interrupted
abstract: Excite and Yahoo E-Mail Interrupted

headline: Hunt Oil Is Thwarted in a Canadian Hostile-Takeover Attempt
abstract: Ulster Petroleums Ltd of Calgary foils hostile takeover attempt by Hunt Oil Co of Dallas, agreeing to richer offer from Anderson Exploration; Ulster accepts $45 million offer in cash and stock from Anderson, one of Canada's largest and most profitable independent oil-exploration companies; price is 19 percent higher than $350 million in cash that privately owned Hunt had offered on April 5 (M)

headline: AT&T Paying $3.3 Billion To Add Wireless Systems
abstract: AT&T Corp agrees to pay $3.3 billion in cash for wireless systems in Houston, San Diego and San Francisco to expand its fast-growing wireless telecommunications business; as result of transactions, AT&T Wireless Group will add 1.3 million customers and 1,400 employees; AT&T will acquire operations in San Francisco from Vodafone AirTouch PLC, in San Diego from GTE Corp and in Houston from PrimeCo PCS (M)

headline: Williams Controls in Deal
abstract: Williams Controls Inc to sell its Premier Plastic Tec

headline: Renting Software and the Skills to Go With It
abstract: Small businesses are 'renting' business software from growing number of Internet companies known as ASP's--application service providers; ASP's use Internet to offer range of software and technology-related services that would otherwise be performed by internal departments at customer's company; big corporate computing departments are also striking deals with ASP's to shed at least some of their applications; photo; graph (M)

headline: Newspapers Bring Threat Of Web Into Perspective
abstract: Newspaper Assn of America holds its annual convention in New York; publishers are no longer terrified of being destroyed by Internet; they see new breed of competitor, but they also see themselves; newspaper companies are assembling their own Internet assets; latest measurement shows newspaper sites holding their own against other general-news sites; Itnernet, in form of dot-com advertising, is driving revenue streams of newspapers to new heights (M)

headline: U.N.'s Unlikely Ally for Sierra Leone
abstract: Release of 139 UN peacekeepers by rebels in Sierre Leone was facilitated agency's unlikely ally, Pres Charles Taylor of Liberia, former warlord who terrorized population into making him president; Taylor has been for years principal ally of Foday Sankoh, leader of Sierra Leone's Revolutionary United Front, and has allowed rebel group to smuggle diamonds through Liberia and made arms available to it; map; photo (M)

headline: Havens for Investors, On Edge and on Guard
abstract: Interview with four investment analysts and portfolio managers who discuss current sectors of marketplace where investors are least likely to suffer; photos (M)

headline: Tsakane Journal; Apartheid Still Burdens A Girl Who Didn't Fit
abstract: South Africans are reminded of the pain that apartheid caused ordinary people by a television documentary on Sandra Laing, now 44, who grew up a black child in a white family; she was expelled from her white school and classified as black in 1966; her parents had her reclassified as white, but then disowned her when they caught her dating a black man; Laing recently visted her mother for the first time since then in her nursing home; her brothers refuse to see her; photos; map (M)

headline: The Fund Flies, Then Flops. The Investors Still Believe.
abstract: Floyd Norris column on investors' confidence in PBHG New Opportunities fund and PBHG Select Equity fund despite huge losses; says New Opportunities fund has lost 42 percent of its value in less than four weeks and Select Equity fund is down 37 percent; holds vast majority of investors are holding on to the funds, which accounts for the 9 percent rise for New Opportunities and the 10 percent gain for Select Equity in last two days; says people who made a lot of money buying highflying technology stocks over last year, and particularly over last six months, are not convinced that anything has changed in stock market; says volatility may have shaken out some speculators, but many still believe; Frank P (Quint) Slattery V, who manages funds, comments; graph (M)

headline: Congo Grudgingly Accepts Ground Rules for Peacekeepers
abstract: Congo pres Laurent Kabila watches as his government signs agreement that he had long resisted, opening way for an international peacekeeping force to be stationed in his country; half of United Nations Security Council is present for signing of agreement, in Kinshasa, which guarantees free access to areas of country where UN officials will need to work and promises that government will do all it can to protect UN personnel, military and civilian (M)

headline: Privacy Advocates Condemn White House Drug Policy Office for Internet Tracking
abstract: Privacy Advocates Condemn White House Drug Policy Office for Internet Tracking

headline: Celebrating a New Company With Some Accidental 'Spam'
abstract: Everypath, Silicon Valley start-up, accidentally sends unrelated e-mail to hundreds of business reporters and editors it planned to invite to its launch party; many of recipients ignore plea on apology message not to reply and are inundated with junk e-mail; photo (M)

headline: The Advantages of Indexing
abstract: Richard E Evans letter disputes April 9 Mutual Funds Report on stock indexing (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of advertising account changes (S)

headline: House Shortens Computer Reviews
abstract: House Shortens Computer Reviews

headline: Israelis Struggle to Regain Stalled Peace Momentum
abstract: Prime Min Ehud Barak of Israel will fly to Washington for previously unplanned meeting with Pres Clinton on Apr 11; Israelis seek to pick up momentum for peace initiatives and help Barak's sagging profile on national stage; Barak faces widespread criticism at home for putting too much energy into Israel-Syrian peace and not enough into anything else, not even Palestinian peace; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ford Acknowledges Risks Of Sport Utility Vehicles  Ford Motor, which depends on sport utility vehicles for much of its profits, acknowledged that they cause serious safety and environmental problems. Ford said that the vehicles contributed more than cars to global warming, emitted more smog-causing pollution and endangered other motorists.    Ford said that it would keep building them because they are so profitable but would seek technological solutions and look for alternatives to the big vehicles. William C. Ford Jr., the company's chairman, depicted the company's statements as a combination of altruism and long-term business planning. [Page A1.]

headline: Internet Software Deal
abstract: Internet Commerce Corp acquires closely held BTrade.com for about $43 million in stock (S)

headline: Gateway Buys Stake in Hispanic Web Site Quepasa.com
abstract: Gateway Buys Stake in Hispanic Web Site Quepasa.com

headline: Talking Trash
abstract: Sue Tarlton letter lauds Apr 6 article on how plastic-bottle recycling equipment works

headline: Inquiry in 1945 Marine Deaths in Japan
abstract: United States Navy is investigating deaths of three American marines whose remains were concealed in cave on Okinawa from end of World War II until 1998, when police in town of Naha, acting on tip, discovered their remains; Japanese news media reports town residents and Japanese soldiers killed three marines for raping Okinawan women (S)

headline: American Topics : French Consulate Buffs Up Its Louisiana Connection
abstract: Rumors of a decline in the French presence in Louisiana have been greatly exaggerated.

headline: ABC Goes Off Cable Systems In Key Markets
abstract: ABC television network goes dark on Time Warner Cable systems in New York, Philadelphia and Raleigh-Durham after talks between parent Walt Disney Co and cable operator, allowing Time Warner to continue carrying ABC stations, break down; both sides blame each other; dispute began in 1999 after Disney requested several concessions from Time Warner in return for allowing cable operator to continue carrying seven of its ABC stations; demanded that Time Warner not only feature its new Toon Disney and Soap Channel, but also make it part of basic service packages with payment of $300 million; Time Warner agreed to carry channels, but balked at payment Disney is seeking; blackout could ultimately effect 3.5 million Time Warner subscribers in major markets nationwide (M)

headline: Japan Assailed For Omitting Data in Growth Calculations
abstract: Japan's official economic statistics became suspect recently when government omitted important piece of information on quarterly growth, apparently for first time; that information reflected startling weakness, suggesting that Japan's financial institutions were spending little or nothing on upgrading their businesses; inclusion of information would have pushed gross domestic product for October-December 1999 quarter signficantly lower than what had been announced; conscious omission of data has been acknowledged by Economic Planning Agency, though it has not been reported by Japanese press; its omission has invigorated critics, who have long contended that ruling Liberal Democratic Party manipulates economic data for political reasons, papering over harsh realities to create impression that economy is recovering from its prolonged malaise; criticism of data omission comes at particularly awkward time for government of Prime Min Yoshiro Miro, who is calling elections in a month; photo (M)

headline: Intel Introduces Faster Celeron Processors for Low-Cost PC's
abstract: Intel Corp offers faster versions of its Celeron processor for low-cost computers; again plays catch-up with new Duron process from Advanced Micro Devices (S)

headline: Divided Plaintiffs Must Now Cooperate
abstract: With the collapse of talks between the government and Microsoft, the Justice Department and the 19 state attorneys general who brought the antitrust case must now cooperate to devise a single remedy proposal.

headline: Confessions of an Online Applesauce Thief
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column notes supermarkets and Priceline are tolerating for now consumers who substitute brands when getting prearranged Priceline discounts to buy specific brands; quotes experts on why people like her who would never cheat a real merchant might occasionally cheat Priceline; drawing (M)

headline: Malaysia Leader Urges Modernization to Foil Muslims' Oppressors : Mahathir Tells IslamTo EmbraceTechnology
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  Exhorting Muslim leaders to reduce divisions among themselves, Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad of Malaysia urged government officials and diplomats from around the world Tuesday to embrace science and technology and combat those who "oppress" Muslims.

headline: AIDS Is Moving Into Rural Areas, U.N. Study Says
abstract: Unaids and Food and Agricultural Organization reports that global AIDS epidemic, long thought of as an urban phenomenon, is shifting strongly to rural areas in the third world, where there are even less in the way of social services for people with AIDS and their families; says situation is particularly serious in Africa (M)

headline: This Call's for You
abstract: Alan Peres letter on using cell phone earbuds (S)

headline: Not for Golfers
abstract: To the Editor:    ''A Tool for Taking the Lay of the Land'' (News Watch, April 27), about the Leica LRF 800 Rangemaster, which measures distances between 33 feet and a half-mile, suggests that the device will be a boon to ''hunters, golfers or gardeners.'' But Rule 14.3 of the United States Golf Association's ''Rules of Golf'' states that ''the player shall not use any artificial device or unusual equipment'' for gauging or measuring distance. Good luck, hunters and gardeners.    DAVID S. SUTTON  Olympia, Wash.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Mexico's Debt Situation Takes a New Twist
abstract: Mexican government is once again embroiled in borrowing problem with Citibank; but this time Mexico is not late in its payments; Citibank says Mexico paid too early; Mexico's prepayment of $2.5 billion loan means Citibank loses hundreds of millions of dollars in interest income it had assumed would flow over next six years; Citibank has insisted prepayment is illegal and has gone to Mexican court to press its case, essentially arguing that Mexico is not permitted to pay off debt yet; Mexican government says it decided to prepay now and save taxpayers at least $300 million; time of dispute, coming just days before Mexico's presidential elections, has been made it sensitive political issue (M)

headline: Officials Seek Student in ´Love Bug´ Case
abstract: Officials Seek Student in 'Love Bug' Case

headline: U.S. Judge Says MicrosoftViolated Antitrust LawsWith Predatory Behavior
abstract: U.S. Judge Says Microsoft Violated Antitrust Laws With Predatory Behavior

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CORNING INC., Corning, N.Y., which makes glass and fiber optic products, and PPG Industries Inc., Pittsburgh, which makes glass and coatings, said they would take $35 million charges to write off their investments in a joint venture, Pittsburgh Corning Corp., which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Sunday.

headline: Publicis Said To Be Ready To Buy Saatchi In Stock Deal
abstract: Puiblicis SA is expected to buy Saatchi & Saatchi, British advertising agency company, for at least $1.5 billion in stock (Advertising column) (M)

headline: As Europe Tenses, England Moves to Leash Soccer Thugs
abstract: England is trying to cut down on ugly behavior by its soccer fans in biennial Europe-wide competition being held this year in Belgium and Netherlands; responsibility for combating soccer hooliganism has been assigned to team of crack English police officers; photos (M)

headline: Genesis Health Ventures Fils for Bankruptcy
abstract: Genesis Health Ventures Inc files for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of Bankruptcy Code; shares of Genesis are suspended on New York Stock Exchange, where they will be delisted; Genesis says it is faced with huge cuts in Medicare reimbursements; 197 units of skilled managed care provider Multicare Companies--about 43 percent owned by Genesis--file Chapter 11 petitions in Delaware (M)

headline: Bolstering Its Emphasis on Data, Thomson Will Buy Primark
abstract: Thomson Corp, which is selling most of its newspapers to focus on electronic distribution of legal and financial information, agrees to buy the Primark Corp for $842 million; like Thomson, Primark has been focusing on electronic services; Joseph Kasputys, chairman and chief executive of Primark, will become chairman of Thomson Financial; boards of both companies have approved acquisition (M)

headline: Eastern Europe First Needs to Build Up Business : The Next Step:Charting E-Commerce's Future
abstract: NEW YORK—  Some years ago, a software company in Russia called Trio-Plus did a great business selling its products through mail order to the remote regions outside Moscow and St. Petersburg.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Today's Opening Bell Could Be A Test Case for the Lessons of 1987
abstract: Floyd Norris Market Place column on whether last week's sharp stock price slide will continue; notes many investors have come to view Oct 1987 stock crash as great buying opportunity and subsequent dips have been quickly followed by rebounds; cites similarities between 1987 crash and current situation (M)

headline: Questions About Civil Rights Follow Government Confrontations With Critics
abstract: Pres Clinton openly raises concerns about state of democracy in Russia and government's efforts to muzzle free speech in meeting with Pres Vladimir V Putin in Moscow; is reportedly assured by Putin that building civil and democratic society is one of his priorities; gives exclusive hour-long interview on all-news radio station Echo Moskvy, harsh critic of government that was recently raided by police; photo (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: ADOBE SYSTEMS INC., San Jose, Calif., named Bruce Chizen, executive vice president for worldwide products and marketing, to the additional post of president, succeeding Charles M. Geschke, who is retiring.     CBS CORP., New York, named Lisa Simpson chief operating officer at its Internet unit. She was head of Sony Corp.'s online entertainment unit.
