headline: Eager Buyers Lift Nasdaq as Dow Ekes Out Small Gain
abstract: Nasdaq composite index rises 81.38 points, or 2.1 percent, to 3,940.34; Dow Jones industrial average gains 23.33 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,527.79; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbs 4.27 points, to close at 1,454.82; graph; chart (M)

headline: NATURAL MICROSYSTEMS TO ADD CANADIAN CONCERN
abstract: Natural MicroSsystems Corp will acquire privately held InnoMediaLogic Inc of Canada for $155 million (S)

headline: Trial of Jews: Clue to Iran's Direction?
abstract: Iran's pending trial of 13 Jews on espionage charges is monitored as gauge of evolving balance of power between forces of tolerance and Islamic zealotry; charges have generated sharp questions from officials of US, Western Europe, Japan and even Russia, where Jews long suffered from discrimination; three defendants are free on bail; photos; accused are charged with spying for Israel but no evidence has been made public (M)

headline: The patent office is fighting once again to hold onto its own revenue in the budget battle.
abstract: Patent and Trademark Office battles House subcommittee proposal to keep its budget flat and divert any office revenue above $905 million to other agencies; warns of increased delays in patent processing and approval; proposal comes as office gears up to accept patent applications via Internet (M)

headline: Microsoft Leads Slide
abstract: Reports about the Justice Department proposal compounded trouble for Microsoft, whose shares fell more than 15 percent. Investors digested the company's earnings report for the quarter ended in March, which was released on Thursday, and realized that operating profit and revenue were short of analysts' estimates. Microsoft was the leading contributor to a 4.4 percent decline in the Nasdaq composite index.  Business Day, Page C1.

headline: Lehman Brothers' Profit Rises 15 Percent From Prior Year
abstract: lehman brothers' profit rises 15 percent from prior yü

headline: Molybdenum Cutback
abstract: Climax Molybdenum Co, subsidiary of Phelps Dodge Corp, says it will reduce production by about 20 percent and lay off 130 workers at its mine in Henderson, Colo; company says cutbacks are response to oversupply of molybdenum--metallic element used to strengthen and harden steel and iron--and continued low prices on market (S)

headline: Zimbabwe Talks Tough but Steps Softly in Battle Over Land
abstract: Zimbawe Pres Robert Mugabe who takes tough public stance over issue of land reform, with threats to seize without remuneration land of white farmers who he blames for slow pace of land redistribution, privately adheres to pragmatic and even conservative approach; despite repeated threats over 20 years, and bitter campaign for constitutional amendment on issue, government has never seized any property without paying for it and has rarely used tough law that lets it delay payments up to five years (M)

headline: BRUNSWICK TECHNOLOGIES REJECTS TAKEOVER OFFER
abstract: Brunswick Technologies Inc., a maker of industrial and construction materials, rejected a $45.9 million takeover offer from Compagnie de Saint-Gobain, Europe's biggest building-materials distributor. Brunswick said the $8-a-share offer, which was made last month by the Vetrotex CertainTeed Corporation, a unit of Saint-Gobain, undervalues the company and said it would immediately begin exploring other options to improve shareholder value. Brunswick's composite materials are used in boat, snowboard, railcar and offshore oil and gas production. Shares of the company, which is based in Brunswick, Me., rose 12.5 cents, to $8.875, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: Cries of racism in the filming of a commercial ensnare Ford in actors' strike against ad agencies.
abstract: Ford Motor Co, stung by accusations of racism for having used makeup to darken face of white stunt driver in filming of television commercial, says it will postpone making new commercials until after nationwide strike against advertising agencies is resolved; Ford also says it will review its makeup policies; Ford acknowledges criticism by actors' unions that its advertising agency, Young & Rubicam, darkened nonunion driver's face during filming of commercial (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Treasury's Planned Debt Buyback Helps to Lift Bond Prices
abstract: US bond prices are mostly higher, with price of 30-year bond rising 11/32, to 104 26/32; yield falls to 5.91 percent from 5.93 percent; graph on yields of selected Treasury securities; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: A Universe Where Ideas Can Trump Actions
abstract: Seth Schiesel assesses Interplay Productions computer game Planescape: Tormen; photos (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICAN BANKING RESCUE EFFORT
abstract: Mexico's bank bailout agency cuts its debts by $2.4 billion this year, beating by $300 million target set by Mexico's congress for all of 2000; agency official Vicente Corta says it was helped by sale of Banca Serfin, Mexico's third-largest bank, for $1.56 billion (S)

headline: APPLIED DIGITAL TO ACQUIRE ATEC GROUP FOR $55.4 MILLION
abstract: Atec Group, computer hardware and software developer, agrees to be acquired by Applied Digital Solutions Inc for $55.4 million in stock, significantly revising transaction announced last month (S)

headline: Ventures Started At Two Agencies
abstract: Mediacom, media services unit of Grey Advertising, and CBS Broadcast International are teaming up to form Eyeventure Media and Entertainment, with offices in Hong Kong, London, Miami and New York; terms undisclosed; William Kunkel is named president and chief executive of Eyeventure; Omnicom Group acquires Eden Communications Group; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: In Australia, Slowly Developing E-Commerce

headline: U.S. SAID TO WANT MICROSOFT BROKEN INTO 2 COMPANIES
abstract: Justice Dept reportedly intends to ask Federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson to break Microsoft Corp into two companies to bring about competition in software industry; proposal comes less than month after settlement talks between government and Microsoft broke down and Jackson found Microsoft in violation of federal and state antitrust laws; department's plan calls for one company to retain Windows operating-system business and other to take rest of Microsoft's operations; result would be about 60-40 split of Microsoft's estimated $23 billion in revenue this year (M)

headline: People
abstract: Bradley K Clark is named to new post of principal and general manager at Gardner, Geary, Coll, San Francisco, formerly known as Gardner, Geary, Coll & Young; Mike Lotito, president and chief operating officer at Initiative Media North America, NY, is named to handle additional duties of new unit, IM.com; Jim Hood, executive with two Greenfield Cos units, is named to new post of group chief executive at parent (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Iran Sends Mixed Messages, One Bad, One Good, to Reformers
abstract: Iranian authorities, torn between conservatives and reformers, act in ways that could both provoke and placate reformers who have been under severe attack by hard-line clergy over last three months; Tehran court jails reformist lawyers Mohsen Rahami and Shirin Ebadi without trial on charges of insulting public officials; Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, nation's supreme leader, abruptly dismisses Brig Gen Hedayatollah Loftian, who was blamed by pro-democracy students for attack on Tehran University that spurred riots last year (M)

headline: U.S. Trade Representative May Take Action Against Mexico
abstract: US trade representative Charlene Barshefsky says Mexico is failing to support competition in telecommunications and warns that she might take action against Mexico before World Trade Organization; US will decide by July 28 whether to lodge formal grievance against Mexico with WTO; AT&T and MCI Worldcom have pressed Barshefsky to take Mexico to WTO, arguing that Telefonos de Mexico has abused its advantages as former monopoly to suppress competition in Mexican telecommunications industry (M)

headline: Placing Hopes In the Net; Indonesia Entrepreneur Tries To Redeem Business Dynasty
abstract: Indonesian entrepreneur Edward Suriadjaya has returned to corporate stage as high-technology entrepreneur planning to build stable of dot-coms and turn Jakarta's old airport into Indonesia's Silicon Valley; Suriadjaya is famous as scion who broke his family's bank and cost his family the car company his father, William, founded in 1957, Astra International; Suriadjaya wants to prove at last that he was unwitting pawn of politics and to help restore his family's position; Suriadjaya's vehicle is PT CyberCity Indonesia, holding company; business experts are split over whether Indonesia, which is far behind much of Asia, presents fertile opportunity or fool's mission; graph; photos (M)

headline: Globalization: Unspeakable, Yes, but Is It Really Evil?
abstract: Economic View column by Joseph Kahn says protesters who ring alarm about global economics have made globalization naughty word; says while growing body of evidence does suggest that 1990's-style global integration has done far less to relieve poverty and inequality than its early supporters predicted, record also shows that process is probably less eocnomically harmful than some critics maintain; graph (M)

headline: Ad agencies are warily sizing up their dot-com clients after the market maelstrom.
abstract: Recent abrupt shift in how Wall Street and Main Street perceive prospects of Internet companies is having significant effect on advertising industry; as dot-com shakeout proceeds with gyrations of stock markets, agencies are warily watching to see how they will be affected as winners and losers of cyberspace are decided (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Apr 30 Market Watch column about Microsoft's purchase of its own shares

headline: Missing the Basics
abstract: Jump$tart Coalition for Personal Financial Literacy finds that only 51.9 percent of high school seniors are financially literate; University of Buffalo dean Lewis Mandell, who conducted tests, says students are not taught crucial practical problem-solving skills (S)

headline: In a Search for Hot Wheels, Buyers Hit a Dead End
abstract: Automobile buyers are likely to have to wait long time--and, at some dealers, pay more than sticker price--to get hold of some especially hot car models, including Honda Odyssey, Mercedes S500, Chrysler PT Cruiser, Toyota MR2 Spyder and BMW XS; Memphis car dealer Corky Jones comments; chart; photo (M)

headline: Uzbeks Are Said to Seize Radioactive Cargo
abstract: US State Department reports that border guards in Uzbekistan have seize radioactive cargo on Iranian truck bound for Pakistan last week; meterial is being tested in Kazakhstan, where it originated, to see if it could have been used to make weapon (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CARORDER.COM INC., Austin, Tex., a car seller on the Internet, has laid off 100 workers, or nearly one-third of its work force, as it struggles with competition in the online auto sales industry.    GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP., Falls Church, Va., the fourth-largest military contractor in the United States, agreed to buy a unit of New Colt Holding Corp., West Hartford, Conn., that makes machine guns and grenade launchers. The price was not disclosed.

headline: Muted Comments Avoid Criticizing the Defendant
abstract: Gov George W Bush of Texas and Vice President Al Gore, presumptive presidential nominees, decline comment on decision by federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson to break up Microsoft for violating antitrust laws; Congressional Republicans condemn ruling (M)

headline: The Inclining Laptop
abstract: Letter by Erik Engquist responds to Frederick Willman letter on lack of laptop with an inclining keyboard (June 1 article); says IBM does offer model with such feature

headline: DEAL FOR COAL MINER
abstract: Anglo American, one of world's largest mining concerns, reaches agreement with Shell Petroleum Co Ltd to acquire Shell Coal Holdings for $850 million to $900 million (S)

headline: Dealing With D.S.L.
abstract: Barbara Michalak letter on May 4 article questions high cost of DSL phone service for Internet use

headline: New York Times Appoints A Chief Financial Officer
abstract: The New York Times has appointed Liam J. Carlos as vice president and chief financial officer effective July 1.     Mr. Carlos, 47, has been assistant controller in the newspaper's financial department since June 1999. He will succeed James L. Terrill, who is retiring next month.

headline: PeoplePC to Provide PCs to Singapore Union Workers
abstract: PeoplePC to Provide PCs to Singapore Union Workers

headline: LYCOS AGREES TO BUY METROSPLASH.COM FOR $44 MILLION
abstract: Lycos Inc, Internet-search service being bought by Terra Networks SA, agrees to buy Metrosplash.,com for $44 million in cash to add Matchmaker.com's online personal ads to its network of Web sites; in buying Metrosplash.com, Lycos adds a Web site ranked number 1 among online dating sites in terms of how much time users spend at the site (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Calvin Klein Battles Maker of Its Jeans
abstract: Calvin Klein Inc files suit to break licensing pact with Warnaco Group Inc, which makes its underwear and jeans brands, in what many industry insiders say is act of vegeance against Warnaco chief executive Linda J Wachner; suit seeks to terminate Warnaco's long-term license to make Calvin Klein jeans on ground that company has breached its fiduciary duty by 'diluting' quality of Klein's image; among specific infractions cited is selling new products through unauthorized mass marketers; whatever the merits of suit, timing could not be more devastating to Wachner, who is already target of irate Warnaco shareholders; photos (Market Place column) (M)

headline: In Britain, Putin Finds Reform Popular, but Not Chechen War
abstract: Russian Pres-elect Vladimir V Putin visits Britain; courts businessmen and meets with Prime Min Tony Blair and Queen Elizabeth II as he seeks to restore Russia as world power; reassures anxious Westerners that Wall Street stock market rout is temporary, news conference with Blair; defends fight against rebels in Chechnya; cites establishment of yet another commission to probe charges of human rights abuses by Russian troops there; photo (M)

headline: Fashion Victims
abstract: Two stores in Jonesboro, Ark, sell close copies of local prison garb to fashion-forward teenagers, spurring rash of calls to police about escaped prisoners seen roaming city (M)

headline: Digital Distribution of Movie Is Planned by Fox and Cisco
abstract: Twentieth Century Fox and Cisco Systems plan to digitally transmit animated film Titan AE via Internet and digitally project film for its world premiere at Supercomm trade show in Atlanta; seek to show potential of digital distribution, which may evenutally supplant film; digital projectors have been used sporadically in last year to exhibit few films in handful of theaters around nation (M)

headline: Uncertain Market Appetite For Dean & DeLuca Offer
abstract: Dean & DeLuca, high-end food and kitchenware retailer, has not turned a profit in seven years, but hopes to raise about $69 million through planned initial public offering to finance a major expansion; company, which operates flagship stores in New York City and four stores across US, wants to open one or two specialty stores in 2001 and three or four stores each year in 2002 to 2006; had loss of $8.9 million on sales of $59.6 million in 1999; IPO, which has not yet priced, is expected in five to six weeks; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil futures prices fall; crude oil for July delivery falls 62 cents, to $32.33 a barrel, after United States agrees to supply 500,000 barrels of oil from Strategic Petroleum Reserve to prevent gasoline shortage in Northeast; graphs; table (S)

headline: Austin Internet Car Seller Lays Off 100 Workers
abstract: Austin Internet Car Seller Lays Off 100 Workers

headline: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; Lessons of Job Burnout, at 16
abstract: M Susan Hamilton describes how her 16-year-old son suffered job burnout after working four months as sneaker salesman at local mall store (M)

headline: McCORMICK, SPICE MANUFACTURER, SEEKS HERB BUSINESS
abstract: World's largest spice maker McCormick & Co announces negotiations to purchase herb business of French firm Eridania Beghin-Say (S)

headline: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
abstract: April 20, 2000          Joyce Dopkeen / The New York Times

headline: CRESTLINE CAPITAL AND BEDROCK PARTNERS TO BUY HOTELS
abstract: Crestline Capital Corp signs letter of intent to form joint venture with Bedrock Partners II LLP to buy hotels worth $250 million in coming two or three years (S)

headline: Guatemalan Squatters Torching Park Forests
abstract: Guatemalan peasants are setting fires to clear forest land in El Ceibal national park, which is home to Mayan ruins but is protected only on paper from squatters and loggers who have cut down best trees; photo; map; region is shrouded in smoke during spring dry season; more than 200 squatters have lived since 1998 in shacks in two settlements in park; unending internal migration affects Peten region, which includes environmentally sensitive jungles of Maya Biosphere Reserve, rich with wildlife, forests and majestic temples; population has increased from 20,000 in 1960 to almost half million; government is trying to fight slash-and-burn fires all around country (M)

headline: Reading the News in the Inkless World of Cyberspace
abstract: Essay by Mike Wendland reports on his experiment to see how well he could stay informed by reading news only online, on his handheld Palm organizer or 'Web enabled' wireless phone; says he was frustrated without his printed newspaper, but on objective level, he can say with certainty that after five months of consuming only online news, he did not miss very much news; says what he could not get online was local news, local advertising, convenience and various subjective things; says he has resubscribed to his old newspapers; photo (M)

headline: KOREA TRADE SURPLUS NARROWS
abstract: South Korea's April trade surplus of $225 million was sharply lower than $2.4 billion a year ago, and cumulative trade surplus in first four months of year to $773 million, from $7 billion a year earlier; exports increased 18.6 percent, to $13.64 billion, while exports surged 47.4 percent, to $13.42 billion (S)

headline: The Color of Profits
abstract: Color Marketing Group, nonprofit association of 1,600 color designers, predicts 'spiritual, meditative' colors will be popular for manufactured goods in 2002, though high-technology products will favor bold colors (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar falls against Japanese yen on expectations that Japanese central bank will soon raise interest rates; in New York, dollar settles at 104.44 yen, down from 105.55 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: Find Old Books on the Web, Then Prepare to Pay the Price
abstract: Survey by Professors Phyllis Bernt and her husband, Joseph, of 189 booksellers who list their products with Advanced Book Exchange, finds that while Internet has made it easier to track down used books, 34 percent of sellers charged higher prices to buyers using Internet than to those buying in a bookstore (S)

headline: AMERICAN TELESOURCE BUYS TELEPHONE SERVICES PROVIDER
abstract: American TeleSource International Inc to acquire privately held Genesis Communications International Inc, San Diego, for about $37.3 million in stock; Genesis, which provides telephone services to Hispanic markets in US, has 65,000 long-distance customers and 10,000 local-service customers (S)

headline: NewMil Bancorp in Deal
abstract: NewMil Bancorp acquires Nutmeg Federal Savings and Loan Association for $20 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: BRAZIL'S TRADE SURPLUS
abstract: Brazil reports trade surplus of $183 million in April despite strike that paralyzed commerce at beginning of month; Brazil closes out first four months of year with surplus of $209 million, compared with deficit of $782 million a year earlier; average daily exports increased 18.7 percent over April 1999 (S)

headline: Colle & McVoy Wins Best of Show Award
abstract: Business Marketing Association gives its top Ace Award to Colle & McVoy Marketing Communications; Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide wins four Aces (S)

headline: Nike Web Site Taken Over
abstract: Nike Web Site Taken Over

headline: Final Ruling in Microsoft Antitrust Case Is Unexpectedly Delayed for About a Week
abstract: US Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who is trying Microsoft Corp antitrust case, unexpectedly agrees to delay his final ruling for about a week, giving Justice Department time to reply to Microsoft's proposal to water down government's breakup plan (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ADAPTEC, Milpitas, Calif., a designer of cards that speed computer communications, said it planned to make its software unit an independent company and make a public offering of shares for part of the unit.

headline: Horse-Trading (and Pork) on Trade Bill
abstract: Various members of Congress are making special requests on purely local issues in exchange for their support of bill extending permanent trading rights to China; 30 lawmakers on both sides of aisle are being coy about how they will vote on trade issue, holding out for pledges on their special requests; photos (M)

headline: China Suspends Web Site for ´Spreading Rumors´
abstract: China Suspends Web Site for 'Spreading Rumors'

headline: Logging On and Staying On
abstract: Michael Spielman letter says June 22 Q&A column gave incomplete answer to the reader who was often disconnected while trying to download Web files; suggests disabling the antivirus program

headline: Oxford-Cambridge Rivalry Is Complicated by Harvard
abstract: Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is considering a request from Cambridge University for a $200 million scholarship endowment to bring 230 foreign graduate students to Cambridge each year; meanwhile, controversy over Britain's elite universities is rekindled after Laura Spence, a high school student from a public state-run school, applies to study medicine at Oxford, is rejected after an interview, despite high grades, and goes on to receive a $100,000 scholarship to Harvard University (M)

headline: J.C. Penney Bosses in Stock Bind
abstract: Management experts and institutional investors lobby American executives to own more stock in companies they run; unlike options, ownership of actual shares brings downside: when investors lose money, so do people running the company; in year when many old-economy stocks declined, danger became real for top executives at Coca-Cola, Eastman Kodak, Sara Lee and Sears, Roebuck, all of which have stock ownership policies, and saw their prices drop in 1999; worst hit are executives at J C Penney, whose stock lost more than half its value during 1999; photo; graph (M)

headline: A. H. BELO WILL SELL PROPERTIES TO LIFT ITS STOCK PRICE
abstract: A H Belo Corp will sell its stake in Dallas Mavericks basketball team, and three smaller newspapers and repurchase some of its stock to push up company's stock price; reaches oral agreement to sell its minority interest in Mavericks and its related stake in arena to team's majority owner, Mark Cuban, for about $34.5 million; also says it will sell The Messenger-Inquirer in Owensboro, Ky, The Gleaner in Henderson, Ky, and The Eagle in Bryan/College Station, Tex (S)

headline: Pouring New Money in Old Bottles
abstract: Napa Valley Wine Auctions raises record $9.5 million for local charities, nearly doubled from $5.5 million last year; Chase Bailey, retired Cisco Systems executive, paid $500,000 for six-liter bottle of 1992 Screaming Eagle Cabernet Sauvignon, a single-bottle record, and paid more that $1.7 million for five lots (M)

headline: Sony to Unveil Plan for Digital Music Distribution
abstract: Sony to Unveil Plan for Digital Music Distribution

headline: PEREGRINE SHARES DROP ON HARBINGER DEAL
abstract: Stock of Peregrine Systems Inc drops more than one-third of its value after company agrees to acquire Harbinger Corp in stock-swap deal valued at about $2.1 billion; several analysts downgrade stock on news of deal; shares of Peregrine fall $21.25 each to $36.75 (S)

headline: Modern Note-Passing 101
abstract: Letter from Jared Sheer, age 16, on Mar 23 article discusses communicating with friends in school via wireless network

headline: Putting Technology Jobs On Women's Career Radar
abstract: Career opportunities for women open in high technology sector; many information technology companies are scrambling to fill jobs they have created and are tapping ready supply of workers, women who have been out of work force; drawing (M)

headline: RJB MINING MAY GET OFFER
abstract: Shares of Britain's biggest coal producer, RJB Mining PLC, surge after company says it is in talks that may lead to bid being made for the company (S)

headline: Agent's Role In Music Site May Be Shift In Rights War
abstract: Pop culture hub on World Wide Web, latest endeavor of Michael Ovitz, superagent, has potential to drain income from some of his own clients by enabling users of site to copy music, media and other files from one another; Ovitz and business partner are majority owners of Scour.com, entertainment site and search engine which recently added feature, Scour Exchange, that lets users exchange one another's multimedia files online, including copyrighted material by artists who are clients of Ovitz's talent agency, Artists Management Group; Ovitz's backing of Scour.com's file exchange mechanism suggests opposition may be eroding to technology that, by many accounts, will force development of new business models for entertainment industry, changing how artists are compensated for their work and how their work is protected; photos (M)

headline: Springing Forward With New Stock Issues
abstract: Steve Galbraith, analyst at Sanford C Bernstein, answers questions about fate of new 'old' stock in competition with new, new issues on Nasdaq; photo (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: FEDERAL-MOGUL CORP., Southfield, Mich., named G. Michael Lynch chief financial officer, succeeding Tom Ryan, who resigned. Mr. Lynch had been vice president and controller at Dow Chemical Co.    KLA-TENCOR CORP., San Jose, Calif., named John Kispert, vice president for corporate finance, to the post of chief financial officer. He succeeds Bob Boehlke, who is retiring.

headline: Banks Are Slow to Move Online, but So Are Their Customers
abstract: Big commercial banks have been struggling with offering online banking services for years, with results ranging from modest success to spectacular failure; consumers have been slow to accept Internet banking, with fewer than 10 percent of Americans banking online; real challenge to established banks may just be arriving, in form of companies that combine banking with other services online; drawing (M)

headline: Sophistication of Chinese Counterfeits Makes Them Harder to Detect : Can You Tell the Fake From the Real?
abstract: Counterfeiters in southern China are producing copies of 2,000-year-old pottery soldiers, horses and dancing ladies with such skill and sophistication these days that experts say they are finding it increasingly difficult to detect the fake from the real.

abstract: Percent           Yesterday   Day Ago   Year Ago       Prime rate   9.00   9.00   7.75        Discount rate   5.50   5.50   4.50        Federal funds   5.94   6.17   4.71        3-month T-bills   5.73   5.77   4.48        6-month T-bills   5.93   5.93   4.50        10-yr.
