headline: Equity Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    ASM Lithography Holding N.V., the Netherlands, 60 million ordinary shares. Credit Suisse First Boston and Goldman, Sachs & Co.

headline: Profit Up at Citigroup, Merrill and Schwab
abstract: Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and Charles Schwab all report their most profitable first quarters ever; Citigroup's net income was $3.59 billion, 52 percent higher than $2.36 billion in year-earlier quarter; chairman Sanford I Weill comments; Merrill Lynch earned $1.04 billion compared with $609 million in period a year earlier; Schwab's net income nearly doubled, to $284.2 million compared with $142.9 million; revenue rose 65 percent, to $1.57 billion, and after-tax profit margin increased to 18.1 percent from 15 percent; photo (M)

headline: French McDonald's Bombed; Breton Terrorists Suspected
abstract: Bomb explodes beside McDonald's in Dinan, small town in Brittany, killing restaurant worker; second bomb, outside post office in Rennes, 35 miles away, is defused; police arrest members of obscure Breton separatist movement, Brittany Combat Group, and of Basque separatist movement, ETA; police say three sticks of dynamite found in Rennes are from cache of eight tons stolen at gunpoint from industrial depot last September (M)

headline: British Troops' Success Fosters Pride and Worry
abstract: Britain greets its troops' success in bringing stability to Freetown, Sierra Leone, with mixture of pride and concern that it is becoming too deeply involved; Defense Sec Geoff Hoon assures Parliament that Britain will not take over United Nations mission or be drawn into civil war; Britain sent forces to capital to secure airport for evacuation of Britons and other foreigners and to enable UN to fly in reinforcements for its besieged peacekeepers; Gen Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of staff, ends visit to Freetown, warning that restoring peace could be 'long haul' (M)

headline: A Model Partnership for Inner-City Renewal, Derailed
abstract: Burger King franchisee La-Van Hawkins sues company, alleging racial discrimination, and contends that it reneged on promise to help him open 225 restaurants; Burger King claims that Hawkins owes $6.5 million in delinquent royalties and loans; his portrait (M)

headline: CACHEFLOW BUYS SPRINGBANK FOR $180 MILLION
abstract: CacheFlow Inc buys closely held Springbank Networks, Sunnyvale, Calif, for about $180 million in stock (S)

headline: Personal Business; Road Warriors
abstract: Readers are asked to submit accounts of their most extraordinary or most annoying experiences commuting to work

headline: Web Sites Make It Hard To Peddle Hot Renoirs
abstract: Number of Internet sites are available that list details and photographs of lost or stolen art and artifacts; among them are Antique Tribal Art Dealers Assn, Art Loss Register and Federal Bureau of Investigation's National Stolen Art File; photos (M)

headline: BP Amoco's Profit Rose in First Quarter
abstract: BP Amoco PLC says its first-quarter operating profit more than tripled and that further cost cuts will increase income for rest of year; profit from operations rose to $2.7 billion, compared with $761 million in year-earlier period (M)

headline: Taking the Sea's Pulse
abstract: Owners of several super yachts are paying $40,000 each to add equipment to their boats to monitor ocean water quality and weather; effort is spearheaded by nonprofit International SeaKeepers Society (S)

headline: AOL OFFERS CONCESSIONS ON BID
abstract: European Commission says America Online has offered concessions to try to win approval for its $146 billion purchase of Time Warner Inc; commission has until June 19 to decide whether to approve transaction, which would form world's largest media and Internet company or examine it for another four months (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (Advertising column) (S)

headline: JDS Uniphase to Buy Cronos
abstract: April 4, 2000

headline: INVENTOR OF BUBBLE-WRAP PLASTIC TO EXPAND IN EUROPE
abstract: Sealed Air Corp, protective packaging maker and inventor of bubble-wrap plastic, agrees to buy Dolpin Packaging for 79 million pounds ($119 million) in cash to bolster its product line and better serve its European customers (S)

headline: U.S. Fines Lockheed $13 Million in China Satellite Case
abstract: Lockheed Martin Corp agrees to pay $13 million fine, largest civil penalty ever under Arms Export Control Act, to settle case involving 1994 sale of satellite technology to China; accord does not call for suspension of company's right to export satellite technology; settlement may put pressure on Loral Space & Communications Corp to settle separate case (M)

headline: Crime Book May Become a Page in Canadian Law
abstract: Canadian press freedom advocates hope case of Stephen Williams, author of crime book Invisible Darkness, will set precedent for kind of reporter's shield legislation adopted by many states in US; Williams expects to be jailed for refusing to reveal source of details of gory sex murder scene in book; faces charges of disobeying judge's order; photo (M)

headline: Metropolitan Mortgage
abstract: Metropolitan Mortgage, subsidiary of Transamerica, says it will cease operations and sell its loan portfolio; 194 employees will lose their jobs (S)

headline: Quarter Books Add Up to a Publishing Hit
abstract: St Martin's Press reports that sales of its classic Whitman series of coin collecting albums and guides quadrupled in 1999, fueled by collecting frenzy over newly minted quarters that are being issued for each of 50 states; photo (M)

headline: On a Visit to Moscow, Monetary Fund Official Is Bullish on Putin's Program
abstract: International Monetary Fund acting managing dir Stanley Fischer, after meeting Pres-elect Vladimir V Putin in Moscow, says fund is ready to pursue new relationship with Russia as soon as Putin acts on his promise to build better foundation for country's still shaky market economy (M)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Bar Codes Allow Readers to Link to Web From Newspaper

headline: Profit at Tommy Hilfiger Drops 25%
abstract: Tommy Hilfiger reports fiscal fourth-quarter profit from operations fell 25 percent, to $34.8 million, compared with $46.2 million in same period year earlier (S)

headline: Congratulations! Remember Me?
abstract: Dot-com millionaires and other sudden celebrities must cope with sudden rush of calls from people soliciting money, selling something, pitching business deals or otherwise working an angle; drawing (M)

headline: Cuzco Journal; To Get to the Disco, Just Follow the Llama Tracks
abstract: Cuzco, Peru, onetime Incan capital, has become one of South America's prime tourist destinations in last seven years, since terrorist Shining Path insurrection began to wind down; city of 300,000 inhabitants welcomed 283,000 tourists in 1999, twice the nunmber who came in 1995, and hotel managers say boom is accelerating this year; Cuzco now has 15 discotheques and two Irish pubs, and McDonald's is scheduled to open its first restaurant by end of year; Lorena Tord Velasco, anthropologist who works in Cuzco, says tourism has made many Peruvians realize wonders of their culture, but she is bothered by their re-creation of Andean culture for tourists; photo of Indian woman, posing in tradition dress, asking tourists for tips; map (M)

headline: METROMEDIA TO BUY A FIBER OPTIC NETWORK IN MOSCOW
abstract: Metromedia Internationa

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Unless stocks take another severe dive, overall damage to the economy is likely to be minimal.
abstract: Stock prices have regained some of their lost ground, but enormous hit to wealth last week is likely to knock nation's economy only partly off its stride--unless rout on Wall Street resumes in earnest; from early January through April 14, sell-offs have destroyed estimated $2 trillion to $3 trillion in total wealth, including $1.5 trillion in household savings; most of that was wiped out in last week's steep decline; loss averaged more than $12,000 a person; Macroeconomic Advisers says if market merely fails to rebound, growth rate of economy should slow by this summer to about 3.6 percent, compared with last year's growth of 4.6 percent (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Stock Offerings Planned This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Activeworlds.com Inc., Newburyport, Mass., 1.2 million units, each consists of 1 share and 1 series B warrant. Brous (H. D.) & Co.    AT&T Corp., Wireless Group, New York, an initial public offering of 360 million shares, 306 million in the U.S. and Canada. Goldman, Sachs & Co., Merrill Lynch & Co. and Salomon Smith Barney.

headline: The Connection Gap
abstract: Letter from Ronald Rettig says small town he lives in has Internet access available through multiple dial-up ISP's as well as DSL and cable modem service

headline: Judge Dismisses Suit Against Magazine
abstract: Federal Judge Virginia A Phillips says she intends to dismiss lawsuit against Rolling Stone magazine over article it published in March 1998 about antidrug program DARE, for Drug Abuse Resistance Education, that contained fabrications by its author, Stephen Glass; Phillips says there is no evidence that Rolling Stone knew of Glass's fabrications before article was published and that DARE will not be able to prove Rolling Stone acted with malice or reckless disregard for the truth (S)

headline: Some experts of spin offer advice to Microsoft on how to reach consumers' hearts and minds.
abstract: Advertising column examines advice from advertising experts on how Microsoft can repair image in wake of decision by federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson that company should be broken up because of violations of antitrust laws (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Executives Leaving At Several Agencies
abstract: Senior executives are leaving advertising agencies for new jobs; Joe Hemp is leaving TBWA/Chiat/Day to join Siltanen/Keehn as group creative director; Steve Soldano is leaving Deutsch Inc, where he is partner and media services director, to join American operation of Optimedia International as president and chief operating officer; Eric Steinhauser has left Young & Rubicam Advertising to join J Walter Thompson as senior partner and executive creative director; Bartle Bogle Hegarty deputy chairman Martin Smith is leaving to become partner and chief executive of Grey Advertising's London office, succeeding Steven Blamer, who will be New York office president (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PENN VIRGINIA CORP., Radnor, Pa., a crude petroleum and natural gas company, said it had acquired rights to natural gas and oil drilling prospects in West Virginia, Virginia and Kentucky for $35.7 million from an undisclosed seller.

headline: Buying Tupperware Online Lets You Skip the Party
abstract: Do you covet a Tupperware Egg-ceptional Server set (''a stylish server for deviled eggs and more'') but can't bear the thought of sitting through an actual Tupperware party to buy one? Tupperware now has a Web buying option. With a new service called My.Tupperware.com, you can do business with your neighborhood Tupperware representative while keeping your evenings free.     At the company's new site, 75,000 United States sales representatives can create personal home pages using preformatted designs. Besides listing Tupperware parties and Tupperware bingos, the personal pages can include Tupperware testimonials and recipes.

headline: The summer movie Web sites look like, well, sequels.
abstract: Survey of motion picture Web sites suggests that the summer with be thick with sequels and formulaic rehashes of earlier blockbusters; photo (M)

headline: WILLIAMS TO SELL PAINT UNITS FOR $453 MILLION
abstract: Williams PLC sells its North American paint companies and its Masterchem Industries unit for $453 million; Williams is selling Frazee Industries, Kwai-Howells, Parker Paint and General Paint of Canada through leveraged buyout with Jordan Co; will sell Masterchem to Masco Corp (S)

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: AVISTA CORP.,  Spokane, Wash., a utility owner in the Pacific Northwest, said it hired Merrill Lynch & Co. to help it consider alternatives for Avista Labs, its fuel cell unit, including an initial public offering.    TLC LASER EYE CENTERS INC.,  Ontario, Canada, an eye care company, said its eyeVantage.com unit had agreed to acquire Oregon Optometric Group Provider, one of the largest buyers and distributors of eye care products in the United States. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Microsoft's Future
abstract: Executives at Microsoft say they have not yet discussed how to carry out a judge's order to split the company. But consultants warn that Microsoft runs risks if it fails to lay plans quickly.    Money & Business

headline: Toys 'R' Us Earnings Increase For First Time in Two Years
abstract: Toys 'R' Us Inc says its earnings in quarter ended April 29 rose for first time in more than two years; profit rose 41 percent, to $24 million, compared with net income of $17 million in quarter a year ago; sales rose 7.1 percent, to $2.32 billion from $2.17 billion (M)

headline: INTERNET COMMERCE PURCHASES PRIVATE WEB CONSULTANT
abstract: Internet Commerce Corp, which allows companies to exchange invoices and purchase orders over the Web, to buy Research Triangle Commerce Inc for $42 million in cash and stock; Research Triangle helps companies link electronic-commerce systems with Internet (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Judge Sets Deadline in May For Microsoft Penalty Plan  The next phase of the Microsoft antitrust case should be wrapped up by late May under a schedule set by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who is presiding over the case.    The timetable calls for the Justice Department to propose remedies by April 28 and for Microsoft to make its proposal on May 10. State Attorneys General, meanwhile, appeared to be giving up any attempt to force the breakup of Microsoft.   [Page A1.]    'Yield Burning' Case Is Settled  More than a dozen Wall Street investment banks, led by Citigroup's Salomon Smith Barney unit, have agreed to pay more than $120 million to end federal investigations into whether they overcharged state and local governments nationwide for Treasuries.   [C8.]

headline: White Political Opposition Joins Forces in South Africa
abstract: Leaders of National Party, political party that created apartheid in South Africa, will dissolve organization and merge with rival Democratic Party to form New Democratic Alliance, which is likely to attract most of country's white, Indian and mixed-race voters; Tony Leon, leader of alliance, comments; photo (M)

headline: WARWICK OFFERS TO BUY THE REST OF GSB FINANCIAL
abstract: Warwick Community Bancorp is prepared to pay $18 apiece for 1.8 million shares of GSB Financial Corp it does not already own (S)

headline: Backflip Lets Web Users Store and Share Bookmarks
abstract: Backflip is one of several companies that let users store their Web browser bookmarks or favorite lists on company's Web site rather on their employers' hard drives; offers service that automatically informs others on user's e-mail list of directory updates (S)

headline: One More Africa Mediating Effort for U.N. Traveling Mission
abstract: United Nations Security Council delegation visiting Africa has abruptly shifted its attention from Congo crisis to Ethiopian-Eritrean border, where hundreds of thousands of troops on both sides reportedly prepare for war; council members, shuttling back and forth between two capitals, are urging Ethiopian Prime Min Meles Zenawi and Eritrean Pres Isaias Afwerki to avoid renewed fighting; Amb Richard C Holbrooke says they seek to restart Organization of African Unity peace talks; scores threat of war over disputed border territory in midst of famine; map (M)

headline: Agency Clears An Internet Bank
abstract: Marsh & McLennan Companies, world's largest insurance broker, wins clearance from regulators to start Internet-based bank that will offer savings accounts (S)

headline: New Homes Are Now Wired For a Lot More Than Lights
abstract: New-home buyers want high-speed Internet connections in their houses, prompting some developers and builders to jump into telecommunications business; builders are offering Internet access, bundled with cable and phone service, either by building and owning neighborhood networks, or joining with telecommuncations companies; costs to homeowners are up to $20 a month below typical cost; these efforts are in early stages, with most wired developments sprouting only in last year; how developers eventually fare against regional phone companies, cable companies and other providers is not known; builders see way to have continuing revenue from these services, income that is welcome in business that has its ups and downs; consumers used to speedy connections at work have been frustrated about not having same high-speed, or broadband, access in their homes (M)

headline: FORD PLANNING TO SPIN OFF AUTO PARTS DIVISION
abstract: Ford Motor Co will announce it is filing paperwork with Securities and Exchange Commission for spinning off Visteon Automotive Systems, its auto parts division; Ford plans to distribute 100 percent of Visteon's shares to Ford shareholders in deal that is likely to be completed by midsummer; Ford vice chairman Peter J Pestillo will run Visteon as its chairman and chief executive (S)

headline: Good Times Add Ring of Truth to TV Networks' Spring Celebration
abstract: Network television executives and programmers begin annual 'up front week,' in which year's new comedy and drama models will be unveiled; in coming week, six networks will introduce between 30 and 40 new series to television world; six networks as whole set record this season for total advertising revenue, taking in $16.8 billion, even with flops rampant; TV executives are heartened by success of ABC game show, Who Wants to Be a Millionaire, which provided evidence that network can still command attention of much of viewing audience on regular basis; graph (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Earth Day Special Is No Hit Despite Its Leading Man  Despite a spate of unintended preshow publicity surrounding the participation of Leonardo DiCaprio, ''Planet Earth 2000,'' the hourlong ABC Earth Day special program shown on Saturday night, did not qualify as a hit.    According to preliminary Nielsen Media Research figures -- which are based on viewing in the 47 largest markets and are subject to change -- the special came in last among its major network competitors. ABC News executives said they were standing behind the program despite its ratings. [Page C15.]

headline: A Call to Put Social Issues on Corporate Agendas
abstract: Amnesty International report says a multinational company's stance on human rights will be considered part of its performance and that companies must be prepared to confront governments that play host to them about issues ranging from political repression to child labor; Amnesty International wrote report along with Prince of Wales Business Leaders Forum, advocacy organization supported by Prince Charles of Britain to promote socially responsible business practices; report signals beginning of new campaign by advocacy groups to hold corporate behavior to standards that many multinational companies have once sought to dismiss (M)

headline: World Red Cross Movement Takes Step Toward Admitting Israel
abstract: Red Cross moves to adopt new emblem, in addition to its red cross and red crescent, partly to clear way to admit Israel as member after 50 years of exclusion; action follows pressure from American Red Cross to admit Israel's equivalent relief services organization, Magen David Adom, or Red Shield of David, whose symbol is red six-pointed star; organization has considered adopting symbol not linked to religion or nationality (M)

headline: UNIONS DENY STAND OVER TRADE POLICY IS PROTECTIONISM
abstract: American labor movement seeks to fend off charges from many economists, business executives and members of Congress that its stand against trade expansion measures is protectionism; critics call labor's across-the-board fight against trade expansion crass effort to protect American jobs by preventing imports from increasing; union officials insist they have jettisoned their past protectionism; say they oppose trade initiatives because they fail to protect rights of foreign workers; AFL-CIO has been most powerful voice against China trade bill, helping sway scores of Democrats, including Richard A Gephardt, House Democratic leader, to oppose it; lawmakers say vote in House is too close to call, largely because of labor's aggressive opposition; labor's outspoken opposition is also complicating matters for Africa trade bill, which would reduce tariffs and quotas on imports from some of world's poorest countries; for three years, labor has blocked Congress's efforts to make it easier for Clinton administration to negotiate extending North American Free Trade Agreement to other countries (M)

headline: Thieves Looting Russia of Its Power Lines
abstract: Thieves, among them desperately poor and criminal gangs, are stripping Russia's networks of electric transmission lines and other cables for sale as scrap metal; thefts have led to 700 electrocutions nationwide and over 500 deaths from electric shock in 1999; engineers estimate over 15,000 miles of power lines have been pulled down in recent years, leaving millions of households without electricity for weeks at time; photos (M)

headline: Rwanda and Uganda, Supposedly Allies, May Stumble Into War
abstract: Rwanda and Uganda, whose troops have been fighting to oust Pres Laurent Kabila of Congo, are threatening to turn their well-trained armies on each other if they cannot resolve tensions that have flared in recent days into small-scale skirmishes; dispute puzzles many experts because until last summer two countries and their leaders were close friends with common goals in Congo; their dispute is troubling because cooperation of both Rwanda and Uganda is essential to success of larger cease-fire agreement in Congo (M)

headline: Study Says Combating Malaria Would Cost Little
abstract: Study by Harvard University Center for International Development and London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine concludes that malaria hurts African economies more than has been recognized but could be better controlled for relatively little money; will be presented in Nigeria at first conference at which African heads of state will meet to discuss malaria; conference is sponsored by World Health Organization and begins on April 25; photo (M)

headline: Fear of Failure? Back Up
abstract: Letter from Ted M Hopes says he shares Peter H Lewis's feelings of insecurity about using compressed files in his backup routine (May 18 article)

headline: CIRCUIT CITY SHARES PLUMMET ON PROFIT WARNING
abstract: Shares of Circuit City Group decline 24 percent, to $39.625, after the company says it expects lower profit margins and that earnings will fall short of analysts expectations by about 4 cents a share for the first quarter (S)

headline: Assessing the Online Exchanges: From One Expert, a Mixed Grade
abstract: Interview with Prof Eric K Clemons on boom in Internet business-to-business exchanges; he compares new industrial exchanges with earlier online financial exchanges and holds they are doomed to repeat many of same mistakes; photo (M)

headline: Three Roads in China: B2B, B2C and C2C
abstract: State of e-commerce in China for business-to-business, business-to-consumer and consumer-to-consumer sites discussed; many barriers, both cultural and technical, slow spread of e-commerce; chief concern among consumers is security of online transactions; photos (M)

headline: Broadcaster in Deal For 9 TV Stations
abstract: Hispanic Television Network Inc. Spanish-language broadcaster, buys nine TV stations, including new flagship station, KLDT, in Texas, and signs up three more affiliates as it expands in important Hispanic markets (S)

headline: Wire-Distribution Deal
abstract: Kent Electronics Corp sells most of its redistribution business to Houston Wire and Cable Co; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Team Links Brain Cells With a Robot
abstract: Dr Sandro Mussa-Ivaldi of Northwestern and researchers from other universities report they have controlled motion of two-wheeled robot by connecting it to brain stem of sea lamprey (S)

headline: Senator Proposes Tax Credit for Telecommuters
abstract: Senator Proposes Tax Credit for Telecommuters

headline: Diamond Miner Halts Stock Listing Plans
abstract: Oryx Natural Resources, diamond-mining company with ties to governments of Congo and Zimbabwe, is forced to shelve plans to list its shares on London Stock Exchange less than 24 hours before stock is to begin trading; decision follows threat by Oryx's London financial adviser, accounting firm Grant Thornton, to resign if company, which is registered in Cayman Islands, proceeds with all-stock, $75 million merger with Petra Diamonds Ltd, Bermuda-registered concern run from Johannesburg; deal was intended as way for Oryx to take over Petra's listing and change company's name to Oryx Diamonds Ltd; shareholders vote to delay transaction indefinitely; Petra's chairman-chief executive Adonis Pouroulis says he does not understand why Grant Thornton threatened to quit; merger had been intended to enable company to sell stock in venture to exploit $1 billion, 25-year diamond concession in Congo, awarded to Oryx in area guarded by Zimbabwean soldiers allied to Congolese government in its battle with rebel forces; plan had been opposed by British government, which is leading campaign to outlaw sale of 'conflict diamonds' that help fuel African wars; map; photo (M)

headline: GERMAN BUSINESS CONFIDENCE WEAKENS
abstract: German research institute IFO's monthly index of business confidence shows unexpected drop that helps depress euro; analysts had expected business confidence to strengthen; Germany's six leading economic research institutes raise prediction for economic growth for this year to 2.8 percent from 2.7 percent; growth was only 1.4 percent in 1999; euro slips from 94.5 cents to 94.45 cents, less than penny above all-time low of 93.9 cents (S)

headline: A Long-Distance Look at Life in Turkey
abstract: Salih Memecan, one of Turkey's most influential political cartoonists, lives in affluent New York suburb; his cartoons, appearing in Turkish newspaper Sabah, use deft humor to skewer politicians and politics of his native country seven time zones away; Memecan says he moved to United States to gain perspective on Turkish politics; says Internet has enabled him to file his work on time, and to maintain his essential contact with his native country; Memecan is among segments of mainstream Turkish press engaging in robust debate on sensitive social and political topics, as government eases restrictions on news media somewhat; photos (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   9.00   9.00   7.75       Discount rate   5.50   5.50   4.50       Federal funds   5.97   5.97   4.62       3-month T-bills   5.60   5.63   4.20       6-month T-bills   5.71   5.78   4.36       10-yr. T-infl.   4.00   4.04   3.91       10-yr. T-note   5.85   5.91   5.21       30-yr. T-bond   5.78   5.79   5.57       Telephone bd.   8.10   8.08   7.24       Municipal bds.   5.93   5.92   5.23        (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Factory Turnaround Reflects Economic Glimmer in Russia
abstract: Russia's economy shows signs of resurgence, with industrial production through April up 10.3 percent over same period in 1999; exports jumped 50 percent, and average worker's salary increased 7 percent in March over year ago; companies and government have started paying workers months and even years of back wages; inflation in current year is expected to run about 13 percent, or far below 1999 rate, and budget now runs a primary surplus; Prime Min Vladimir Putin warns growth cannot last without basic economic reforms; already has proposed wholesale changes in taxes, including flat income tax and corporate tax cuts, that appear to have strong support despite concerns that wealthy will benefit most; Eduard F Baranov, first deputy chief of government's Economic Research Center, and other Russian officials comment; photo; map; graph (M)

headline: At Libyans' Trial, Lockerbie's View of Horror From Sky
abstract: A noise that kept growing louder. A dark mass just clearing the rooftops. A fireball like a mushroom cloud. The Flannigans' house not there anymore, replaced by a pile of rubble as high as a kitchen window.  Great gouts of fire raining down, the reek of jet fuel, and things lying in the street that, in the light of the flames, slowly became recognizable as bodies.

headline: Swiss Refusal Of Citizenship To Immigrants Raises Debate
abstract: Rejection of 48 naturalization applications in Emmen, a suburb of Lucern, stirs debate across Switzerland and charges that local government's vote on issue amounted to racist selection; all those turned down are Turks or people from former Yugoslavia; Emmen vote makes clear that foreigners must virtually become more Swiss than the Swiss--pass what the media call the 'fondue test'--to stand a chance of holding a passport (M)

headline: J. P. Morgan Accepts Fine In Case About Limit Orders
abstract: J P Morgan agrees to pay $200,000 fine after NASD Regulation, regulatory arm of National Association of Securities Dealers, finds that the firm had repeatedly violated rules requiring that customer limit orders be displayed to the market; NASD Regulation says that in several cases Morgan failed to execute limit order while trading at same price for its own account; after problem was discovered in 1998, Morgan put in an automatic compliance system but it was immediately disconnected by Morgan's head trader, who is not identified; Morgan told regulators that trader believed system was not working correctly and it remained off for five months (M)

headline: Napster Has a New Interim Chief and Gets a $15 Million Investment
abstract: Hummer Winblad Venture Partners leads $15 million round of investment in Napster, Internet music site involved in copyright dispute with recording industry; places one of its partners, Hank Barry, as company's interim chief executive; investment suggests technology that lets Internet users exchange music files kept on their own computers is attracting mainstream backing (M)

headline: Trying to Gauge, and Bridge, Europe´s Gap in Net Access
Staying in Sync: All the Data, Up to Date, All the Time
abstract: Advice on various ways to synchronize data between home and office computers; photos (M)

headline: Wounded Serb Opponent Blames Milosevic
abstract: Vuk Draskovic, Serb opposition leader returns from Montenegro after shooting attack for which he blames Pres Slobodan Milosevic; photo; attack in seaside town of Budva causes grave concern among Montenegrin officials who fear Belgrade is trying to destabilize smaller partner (M)

headline: A New Blackberry Pager Allows Longer E-Mail
abstract: Research in Motion, maker of popular Blackberry pager, small, wireless e-mail device with keyboard, unveils larger device intended to let people on move get longer e-mail messages; photo (M)

headline: Web Site Buys Veterans´ Newspaper
abstract: Web Site Buys Veterans' Newspaper

headline: Vivendi Will Retain Management at Universal
abstract: Vivendi SA, French company that is buying Seagram Corp, says it plans to make no significant changes in top management at Seagram's Universal film and television operation; after acquisition, Vivendi will control 43 percent of USA Networks Inc (M)

headline: KEYNOTE WILL BUY VELOGIC SERVICES FOR $50 MILLION
abstract: Keynote Systems Inc acquires Velogic Inc for about $50 million (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, GOLDA
abstract: SCHWARTZ-Golda. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Men's Club mourn the passing of the beloved mother of their devoted member Bernard Schwartz and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

headline: United Way Leader Announces Retirement
abstract: Betty S Beene, president of United Way of America since January 1997, says she plans to retire in 18 months; says she announced her plans far in advance partly to win support for her efforts to give United Way of America greater control over use of organization's name and logo by 1,400 local United Ways (S)

headline: Microsoft Launches New Windows for Smaller Devices
abstract: Microsoft Launches New Windows for Smaller Devices

headline: LOWEST SINCE 1970
abstract: Nation's unemployment rate in April is 3.9 percent, falling below 4 percent for first time in 30 years; employment numbers from Labor Dept show little evidence that nine-year-old expansion might be weakening in response to Federal Reserve's attempt to slow economy by raising interest rates; Fed's great fear, as expressed by chairman, Alan Greenspan, is that job shortages will eventually give workers enough bargaining power to push up labor costs ahead of productivity gains; although wage gains remain relatively modest and many of latest jobs are temporary, employers may still respond to tight labor by raising prices to cover higher costs--or simply because strong economy allows them to; graphs (M)

headline: The Microsoft Matter
abstract: Mike Kelly letter on May 4 article notes users of Microsoft's popular word processing program were able to open Justice Department's proposal to break up Microsoft, even though department posted proposal in another format

headline: Foe's Strength Forces Putin Into a Humbling Reversal
abstract: Russia Pres-elect Vladimir V Putin asks Valentina Matviyenko, his first deputy prime min, to pull out of race for governor of St Petersburg, race she had entered with Kremlin's blessing less than month ago; Putin move is seen humbling concession to political strength and popularity of incumbent governor, Vladimir Yakovlev; it is seen galling retreat for Putin; analysts say that Putin cannot afford battle with strong regional leader like Yakovlev while preparing to undertake economic reforms; photo of Putin aboard nuclear submarine (M)

headline: Missile Defense May Have Price Of $60 Billion
abstract: Congressional Budget Office estimates cost of building national missile defense system would be nearly $60 billion; graph; Pentagon, which does not dispute figure, has only one more chance to prove that technology works before Pres Clinton makes decision this summer; one of two tests of full system has succeeded so far (S)

headline: AETHER SAYS IT WILL PAY UP TO $90 MILLION FOR NETSEARCH
abstract: Aether Systems is acquiring NetSearch for $25 million in cash and additional $65 million payable over 13 months if company meets specified revenue targets (S)

headline: Dutch Phone Group Puts I.P.O. on Hold
abstract: UN Security Council delegation winds up visit to Kosovo, with reactions somewhat muted by complexities of situation on ground; photo of members on tour of ethnically divided Mitrovica (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: MIDDLE EAST    IRAN, EGYPT: DIRECT TALKS  Presaging a possible warming of relations between two mutually suspicious nations, the presidents of Egypt and Iran spoke by telephone in what may be the first direct top-level contact since their countries broke off ties after Egypt's peace treaty with Israel in 1979. The occasion for the conversation was Iran's bid to join the so-called G15 group of developing nations, which ended a two-day meeting in Cairo.    Susan Sachs (NYT)

headline: 2 Beer Campaigns Honored at Festival
abstract: DDB Worldwide's Chicago office wins top honor in television and cinema category at International Advertising Festival, Cannes, France; Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide's London office wins top honor in print and poster category (M)

headline: U.N. Aide Wants Web Drug Crime Pursued Like Genocide
abstract: U.N. Aide Wants Web Drug Crime Pursued Like Genocide

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Platinum falls after Russian mining company RAO Norilsk Nickel says it has resumed exports after yearlong halt; in New York, platinum for July delivery falls $22.50, or 4.9 percent, to $440.30 an ounce; graph; chart (S)

headline: Big Board Reports 4.4% Rise In Uncovered Short Sales
abstract: Open short positions on New York Stock Exchange rise 4.4 percent; on American Stock Exchange, increase is 2.2 percent (S)

headline: Americans Enjoy 70 Healthy Years, Behind Europe, U.N. Says
abstract: Report by World Health Organization says US is behind almost every country in Europe, as well as Canada, Australia and Israel in what organization calls 'healthy life expectancy;' report measures life expectancy in new way by factoring in diseases and disabilities likely to rob people of lifetime of good health; says Japan leads world in healthy life expectancy, at 74.5 years; Sierra Leone is last; child born in 1999 will live healthy life of fewer than 26 years (M)

headline: Britain and Ireland Agree On a New Start for Ulster
abstract: British and Irish governments announce agreement on new formula to restart suspended power-sharing government in Belfast and they urge Ulster's Roman Catholic and Protestant leaders to endorse it; new plan envisages resumption on May 22 of government that was suspended in February; it sets new date of June 2001 for putting in place all steps of flagging Northern Ireland peace accord; outline of new blueprint indicates that governments have dropped demand for disarmament itself and instead seek declaration from Irish Republican Army and Protestant paramilitary groups that they would rule out acts of violence in future (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   9.00   9.00   7.75       Discount rate   5.50   5.50   4.50       Federal funds   6.00   6.00   4.91       3-month T-bills   5.57   5.58   4.39       6-month T-bills   5.79   5.74   4.41       10-yr. T-infl.   3.97   3.97   3.87       10-yr. T-note   6.22   6.13   5.20       30-yr. T-bond   5.98   5.94   5.52       Telephone bd.   8.20   8.03   7.28       Municipal bds.   6.01   5.98   5.24          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Reports Rattle Shares of Coke And Its Bottler
abstract: Coca-Cola Enterprises, Coca-Cola Co's largest bottler, says it will not meet its growth target in US this year and that it is facing even bigger hurdles in another major market, Britain; shares of Coca-Cola Enterprises drop 30 percent, or $6.9375, to $15.625, a 52-week low; shares of Coca-Cola fall $3, to $48.9375; bottler's president and chief operating officer, John R Alm, in conference call with analysts, says that domestic volume will grow only 1 percent to 2 percent this year; in Britain, bottling company's difficulties will lead to shortfall in operating profit for year; cheaper Coke products are being shipped into Britain from European Union countries outside bottler's territory; flood of imports is being encouraged by weak euro, which makes foreign-made products cheaper; separately, Coke says it will spend $1 billion over five years on programs for minorities and women and $1 billion over three years on bottling plants and other efforts to build business in Africa (M)

headline: Measuring the Value of an Old Friend
abstract: I HAVE a history of addiction. I have never been able to pass a used-book store without feeling compelled to buy an armload. So I felt very virtuous about my ability to withstand the wiles of the flashy ad campaign staged last year by Alibris, an ambitious online bookseller.     Perhaps you have seen some of the full-page ads showing beaten-up classics; the ads have appeared in dozens of magazines since November. One showed a dog-eared paperback copy of Jack Kerouac's ''On the Road'' that looked identical to the one I owned in college. Another showed a vintage edition of ''Valley of the Dolls'' that brought back memories; its pill-strewn dust jacket looked so dangerous 30 years ago when my mother and her friends were passing it around.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MCDONALD'S CORP.,  Oak Brook, Ill., the biggest restaurant chain in the world, received approval from a bankruptcy court to buy the Boston Market business, which sells rotisserie chicken, from Boston Chicken Inc., Golden, Colo., for $176.2 million.    MELLON FINANCIAL CORP.,  Pittsburgh, said it would buy back up to 25 million shares of its stock, or about 5 percent of its stock outstanding.

headline: DONALDSON, LUFKIN AND ITS PARENT TO BUY BACK STOCK
abstract: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and its parent, AXA Financial, will combine to buy back up to 10 million D L & J shares for about $421 million; stock has lost 44 percent of value in past year (S)

headline: Vietnam Memorial Has a Virtual Twin
abstract: Each year, about two million people visit the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington, DC, while about one million visits are recorded at the memorial's Internet twin, the Virtual Wall (www.thevirtualwall.org), each month; online site includes information about the real wall and a traveling replica; is the result of connection between Jan C Scruggs, president of Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund, and Nathan Kantor, chief executive of Winstar Communications, wireless broadband company; some Web users comment on importance of site in their lives; photos (M)

headline: President Views Success of China Trade Bill as His Foreign Policy Legacy
abstract: Pres Clinton sees coming vote in Congress on granting China membership in World Trade Organization as probably the last hope of making deep imprint on foreign affairs in his second term; has reportedly confided to close friends and colleagues that he will not repeat past mistakes and will not allow politics of moment or even prospect of war within his own political party to pull him back from step he is convinced is best hope of keeping China from becoming adversary (M)

headline: ROYAL AHOLD BUYS ANOTHER CHAIN OF CONVENIENCE STORES
abstract: Royal Ahold NV acquires Golden Gallon Inc, chain of 134 convenience stores and gasoline stations in US Southeast; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: U.S. Clears Pfizer Deal for Warner-Lambert
abstract: Federal Trade Commission approves Pfizer Inc's acquisition of Warner-Lambert Co on condition that companies shed businesses in four categories; Warner Lambert is to end its arrangement with Forest Laboratories to co-promote antidepressant Celexa; Pfizer will sell its head-lice treatment business to Bayer Corp; Warner-Lambert's assets related to Alzheimer's drug Cognex are to be sold to First Horizon Pharmaceutical Corp; Pfizer will transfer its business under development for treating solid-tumor cancers to OSI Pharmaceuticals (M)

headline: Soros Fund Management Chief Steps Down
abstract: Duncan Hennes resigns as chief executive of Soros Fund Management, as George Soros's changed philosophies of business growth eliminated task Hennes was hired to accomplish (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil futures prices rise; crude oil for June climbs briefly above $30 a barrel, before falling to close at $29.62; graphs; table (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil edges higher by six cents to $32.25 per barrel; list of major commodities prices; graph (S)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Online Trading Volume Sinks After Market Turmoil

headline: SAFEGUARD SCIENTIFICS TO SHIFT TO INTERNET DEVELOPMENT
abstract: Safeguard Scientifics plans to shift its investments to Internet development companies from business-to-business ventures (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: BLAIR VOWS COOPERATION -- Prime Minister Tony Blair promised to work with Ken Livingstone, the left-wing maverick he tried to keep off the ballot but who won the race for London's first elected mayor with 58 percent of the final vote. Mr. Blair also acknowledged that Conservative success in winning back some 600 of the 3,300 local council seats across England represented ''some bad results.'' But Conservatives suffered a shock loss of a parliamentary seat in the one by-election, in Romsey, southeast England, where the winner was a Liberal Democrat.    Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: A Typical Day: Stocks Plunge, Then Rebound
abstract: Stock prices plunge early in day and then rebound, leaving market down only moderately; Nasdaq composite index closes down 26.19 points, at 3,364.21; Dow Jones industrial average drops 84.30 points, to 10,542.55; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 6.23 points, to 1,400.72; 30-year Treasury bond rises 8/32, to 100 28/32, to yield 6.19 percent; tables; graph; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FRESH DEL MONTE PRODUCE INC., Coral Gables, Fla., one of the top producers and sellers of fresh fruit and vegetables, agreed to buy the Graziano Produce Co., Portland, Ore., a regional supplier of fresh-cut produce, to gain market share in the United States Pacific Northwest. The purchase price was undisclosed.

headline: Microsoft Hires A Bush Adviser To Lobby Bush
abstract: Microsoft Corp quietly hires Ralph Reed, senior consultant to Gov George W Bush's presidential campaign, to lobby Bush in opposition to government's antitrust case; company says aim is to curry favor with apparent Republican nominee, hoping he will take softer approach toward company if elected president; Reed, former head of Christian Coalition who runs Century Strategies and is one of Bush's top consultants, declines comment; photo (M)

headline: Pepsi Plans to Offer a Competitor to Sprite
abstract: PepsiCo Inc will sell new lemon-lime flavored soft drink by year end to compete with Coca-Cola Co's fast-growing Sprite (S)

headline: You Can Paint This Corporate Benefit Gray
abstract: Number of American households that cared for parents or relatives afflicted with infirmities of old age tripled between 1988 and 1996, to 21 million from 7 million; Hewitt Associates survey shows forty-seven percent of large companies offered elder-care programs in 1999, up from 20 percent in 1993; most common forms of assistance, available at 40 percent of corporations, were resource and referral programs; graphs (M)

headline: Ford Is Selected as the Bidder to Enter Daewoo Talks
abstract: Ford Motor Co wins exclusive rights to negotiate purchase of South Korea's ailing Daewoo Motors Co with $6.9 billion offer that if successful would be Ford's largest foreign acquisition and could significantly strengthen its operations in Asia; David Snyder, head of Ford's Asia-Pacific operations, seeks to ease fears that there would be widespread layoffs at Daewoo factories; photo (M)

headline: In a Russian Region Apart, Corruption Is King
abstract: Entrenched corruption in Russian city of Kaliningrad described; former Konigsburg, seized from Germany during World War II, was closed Soviet city, and is now separated from rest of Russia by 300 miles of Lithuania and Belarus; Gov Leonid P Gorbenko is considered law unto himself, with personal control of lucrative dealings in cigarettes, liquor and autos; photos; map; city has deep harbor, well-educated labor force, amber deposits, rich farmland and endless beaches, but foreign investors have fled since Gorbenko's election in 1996 (M)

headline: With Foreign Aid Promised, Zimbabwe Calls Off Squatters
abstract: Zimbabwe government, after receiving renewed pledges of financing from Western donors for land redistribution, urges black squatters to abandon hundreds of white-owned farms they invaded over past two months; announces that World Bank has approved $5 million loan to support initial phase of program intended to redistribute more than two million acres of fallow farmland; photo (M)

headline: COUNTRYWIDE SOFTENS STANCE ON POSSIBLE TAKEOVER BIDS
abstract: Shares of Countrywide Credit Industries rise sharply after its chief executive Angelo Mozilo says company will listen to takeover offers (S)

headline: The New Economy As Wired Catastrophe
abstract: Alan Cowell Off the Shelf column discusses Age of Access, by Jeremy Rifkin; notes Rifkin foresees dismal future of hypercapitalism in which every activity outside the family will be based on commercial transaction and traditional reciprocal obligations and expectations will be replaced by contractual relations in form of paid memberships, subscriptions, admission charges, retainers and fees (M)

headline: Spills Are Not a Problem For a Flexible Keyboard
abstract: Flexboard, washable, flexible, rubber-covered computer keyboard, which has been available in Europe for several years, is being distributed in United States; Man & Machine, eastern US distributor, comments; photo (M)

headline: Limits of Speech Software
abstract: Jean Harrington letter on Mar 30 article notes speech-recognition software does not recognize speech of stroke victims like herself, who slur words

headline: FCB Combines Units And Adds Operation
abstract: FCB Worldwide, New York, part of True North Communications, to form new interactive customer-relationship management unit, by combining its FCB Direct and FCB Digital operations; new worldwide direct and interactive unit, to be called FCBi, will have 850 employees and offices in 27 countries and billings estimated at $775 million (Advertising column)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of advertising account changes (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Spain Tries Electricity Shaken, Not Stirred
abstract: Farmers in olive-growing hamlet of Benameji, Spain, for last three years have delivered residue from their Spanish olives to specialty designed power station, where it is burned to produce electricity and reduce Spain's reliance on Saudi Arabian oil; power plant produces 12 megawatts of electricity, roughly enough for four villages size of Benameji; it has been so successful that leading Spanish utility, Endesa, which built it together with Abengoa engineering group, is about to build two more, each costing $19 million, including one near Jaen, whose groves alone account for more than 20 percent of world's olive oil production; map; photo (M)

headline: A Hands-On Tour of Seattle´s High-Tech Playground
Dance Has Africans Shaking Behinds, and Heads
abstract: Mapouka, dance that includes suggestive gyration and wiggling, is latest craze in West Africa, spreading from country to country even as some officials seek to ban it; acknowledged queens of mapouka dance craze are group from Ivory Coast called Les Tueuses, or The Killers; trio has performed in neighboring countries and recently gone on foreign tours, including to New York and Montreal; photo (M)

headline: PrivateSector; From the Melting Pot, Perhaps With a Few Sparks
abstract: William Denis Fugazy, chairman of National Ethnic Coalition of Organizations, comments on this year's Ellis Island Medals of Honor; photo (M)

headline: Break Out the Rabbit Ears, Martha
abstract: Time Warner Cable subscribers who have lost Disney-owned WABC station in New York are installing A/B switch and antenna to watch station; some New Yorkers have switched from cable television to satellite dishes, and satellite providers like DirecTV and EchoStar Communications hope to capitalize on viewers' unhappiness; they say disrpution is likely to prove a bonanza, pushing many people who have been contemplating switching into finally acting (M)

headline: Bond Offerings for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.74 percent; a six-month bill was 5.99 percent.

headline: BRAZIL AUTO OUTPUT RISES
abstract: Brazil's automobile production climbed 14 percent in March; sales fell 14 percent from year-earlier period, largely because Carnival was celebrated in March this year, instead of February; sales in March rose 4.3 percent from February (S)

headline: Barnesandnoble.com to Offer Classes as Part of New Online University
abstract: Barnesandnoble.com to Offer Classes as Part of New Online University

headline: DIGITAL INSIGHT TO ACQUIRE 1VIEW NETWORK
abstract: Digital Insight Corp to acquire 1View Network Corp in cash-and-stock deal worth $56.3 million (S)

headline: Mall developers fight back against the Internet by moving there themselves.
abstract: Shopping mall developer have racketed up own e-commerce strategies in counteroffensive against suddenly more vulernable online retailers; are vying to fill gaps left by both traditional and Internet retailers, in areas like electronic ordering and customer service; Simon Property Group, most aggressive of developers in pushing e-commerce, has created two separate business units, Clixnmortar and TenantConnect.net, to enable shoppers to integrate e-commerce into mall trips; photos (M)

headline: Finding Deals, Small Businesses Buy More Online
abstract: Survey by Access Markets International Partners finds that small-business owners are going online in droves looking for deals, particularly on computer equipment, office supplies and travel reservations; graph (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; VIBRANT GROWTH IN MEXICO
abstract: Mexican economy grew by 7.9 percent in first quarter of 2000, fastest growth rate since second quarter of 1998; economy grew 3.7 percent in 1999 (S)

headline: Dreyfus to Pay $2.9 Million After Investigation of Fund
abstract: Dreyfus Corp agrees to pay $2.95 million to settle charges that it failed to inform investors adequately about risks of its Dreyfus Aggressive Growth Fund and that fund's early performance had been manipulated by its being loaded with inital public offerings; Michael L Schonberg, fund's former manager, agrees to nine-month suspension from investment management business and will pay $50,000 fine; neither Dreyfus nor Schonberg acknowledge any wrongdoing under terms of settlement with Securities and Exchange Commission and New York attorney general's office (M)

headline: China Cites Progress On Its Rights Record
abstract: China tells United Nations human rights panel that it has made progress in preventing torture and in prosecuting officials suspected of such abuse but concedes that it could do more (S)

headline: Beijing Jails Muslim Woman for Sending Newspapers Abroad
abstract: Newly available transcript of court verdict confirms that Muslim businesswoman, Rebiya Kadeer, was dealt an eight-year prison sentence mainly because she tried to mail her exiled husband back copies of local newspapers; Kadeer, 53, was convicted on March 10 in her home province of Xinjian in western China for 'revealing state intelligence' abroad (M)

headline: Sabri Tahir, 76, Slain; Cypriot in Durrell Book
abstract: Sabri Tahir, Turkish Cypriot businessman who was renowned for his friendship with novelist Lawrence Durrell, is shot dead in Cyprus at age 76;

headline: The Other Contenders
SCHLUMBERGER AND BAKER HUGHES FORM SEISMIC VENTURE
abstract: Schlumberger Ltd agrees to pay $500 million to rival, Baker Hughes Inc, for 70 percent stake in new joint venture to provide seismic services used to locate oil and gas; Schlumberger and Baker Hughes will combine their seismic divisions to form venture called Western GECO (S)

headline: U.N. Cool to Increase
abstract: UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan recommends to Security Council that agency not increase size of its peacekeeping force in Lebanon until Israel withdraws and Lebanon guarantees safety of troops (S)

headline: Digital Economy Has Arrived, Commerce Department Says
abstract: June 6, 2000

headline: I.B.M. and Start-Up Plan Small-Business Partnership
abstract: International Business Machines and start-up company Salesforce.com plan partnership aimed at helping small businesses transform themselves into e-businesses; Salesforce offers software for managing sales information as subscription service from Web site; IBM will make service available to customers of its Small Business WebConnections; two companies also plan to jointly develop new applications (M)

headline: South Lebanon Now Reaps a Harvest of Bitterness
abstract: Small villages in southern Lebanon's buffer zone that were occupied by Israeli soldiers for 22 years are reaping bitter harvest of Israel's withdrawal; occupation divided families and estranged neighbors; was enforced against Lebanese by Lebanese, corroding social relations; residents of Kafr Shuba comment; map; photo (M)

headline: Venezuelan Calls Tune In OPEC's Price Tactics
abstract: Ali Rodriguez Araque, Venezuela's energy minister and president of OPEC, faces daunting task of stabilizing prices at a level thatboth producers and consumers will find acceptable; Rodriguez's sudden emergence as OPEC's public face is just one sign of higher profile in international energy affairs that Venezuela is vigorously seeking; since Pres Hugo Chavez took office 14 months ago, nation of 23 million people, largest exporter of oil outside Middle East and leading supplier to United States in recent years, has gone from lamb to lion on oil matters; photo of Rodriguez (M)

headline: U.S. Pushes To Weaken World Court On Atrocities
abstract: The United States, isolated among the nations of the world, is going into a crucial conference Monday on the soon-to-be-established International Criminal Court still asking for changes in its charter.     The United States says it is trying to protect American soldiers and officials from falling under the court's jurisdiction. But all members of the European Union and other members of NATO support the court and have told the United States that there should be no attempt to reopen debate on how it will work.

headline: Personal Business; Road Warriors
abstract: As cities continue to sprawl, the trip to work, by whatever means, consumes more and more of the day. And that leaves more room for all manner of mishap and adventure. What has been your own most extraordinary, or aggravating, experience in commuting, and what was the response when you dragged into work? Send your stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: Murdoch's Son Gets Post
abstract: News Corp names John Murdoch, youngest son of News Corp chairman Rupert Murdoch, to be chief executive and chairman of Star TV; he replaces Gareth Chang, who resigned (S)

headline: Fund Manager Will Return To Duquesne in September
abstract: Stanley Druckenmiller, who quit Soros Fund Management in April and at same time told investors in his Duquesne Capital Management fund group that he was taking a break, says he will return in September to Duquesne (S)

headline: Xerox and Microsoft Create Digital Safeguard Company
abstract: Xerox Corp and Microsoft Corp say they will create company called ContentGuard to produce and market software that protects copyrighted material like books, music and video distributed over Internet; new company is being spun out of Xerox; public offering is anticipated; Microsoft will own minority stake in ContentGuard; Xerox president-chief executive G Richard Thoman and Microsoft president-chief executive Steven A Ballmer comment; photo (M)

headline: DE BEERS IMPOUNDS DIAMONDS
abstract: De Beers, armed with court order, begins seizing shipm

headline: Moves to restrict cell phones reflect a growing reaction against a vocal minority of users.
abstract: Moves to restrict cell phones on airplanes reflect growing reaction against vocal minority of users; while airlines and federal regulators still insist that in-flight cell phone use is safety hazard that can interfere with complex cockpit communications and navigation technology, some experts and cell phone industry officials have been publicly arguing that science supporting ban is questionable because cell phone use is routine on board private corporate aircraft; given general level of annoyance that many people show toward being subjected to someone else's cell phone conversation, airline industry might be willing to maintain status quo; airlines make money when passengers place expensive calls on existing on-board phones (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Ex-Bear Stearns Executive Is Barred From Securities Industry
abstract: Richard Harriton, former chairman of securities clearing subsidiary of Bear Steans Cos, will pay $1 million in penalties and be barred from securities industry for life under settlement disclosed by Securities and Exchange Commission; settlement, which ends civil fraud lawsuit brought by SEC last August, says Harriton may reapply to regulators after two years; Harriton settles suit without admitting or denying accusations; SEC's suit against Harriton followed three-year investigation into failure of A R Baron, New York brokerage firm, which defrauded investors of $75 million before it closed in 1996; Bear Stearns Securities Corp, subsidiary run by Harriton, cleared Baron's trades and provided it with capital it needed to operate; photo (M)

headline: Philippine ´Love Bug´ Investigators Question Former Computer Students
abstract: Philippine 'Love Bug' Investigators Question Former Computer Students

headline: Big Carmakers Extend Benefits To Gay Couples
abstract: sGeneral Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler division announce they will extend medical, dental and prescription drug benefits for same-sex partners of their 466,000 hourly and salaried employees; move is largest yet by corporate America to provide such benefits for gay and lesbian couples; gay and lesbian advocates say car makers' decisions dwarfs previous corporate moves and are particularly welcome because Midwestern companies have been slow to move on such benefits; Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit expresses dismay at automakers' decision (M)

headline: MERCK IS BUYING PROVANTAGE HEALTH FOR $222 MILLION
abstract: Merck & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy ProVantage Health Services, a pharmacy benefit management company, for $222 million in cash, or $12.25 a share. Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., said it would fold ProVantage, based in Waukesha, Wis., into its benefits services unit, Merck-Medco Managed Care. ShopKo Stores, which owns a 65 percent stake in ProVantage, has agreed to sell its holding. ProVantage's stock soared 55 percent, rising $4.25, to $11.875, on the New York Stock Exchange, while Merck's shares fell $1.125, to $67.1875, also on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Vodafone and Unicom Agree to Work Together in China
abstract: China Unicom signs agreement with Vodafone AirTouch to collaborate on mobile-telephone technology and services in China; deal is short on details (M)

headline: Untangling the Legal Maze by Surfing the Web
abstract: Advice on seeking legal advice on line; some dozen legal Web sites are aimed at nonlawyers, while many more present legal resources in less consumer-friendly manner; photos (M)

headline: Congo Leader Shuts Down Africa Mediation Effort
abstract: Pres Laurent Kabila says he shuts down Organization of African Unity effort to open talks among warring factions in Congo because group's mediator, Sir Ketumile Masire openly criticized government; says Masire's Kinshasa offices were sealed and his staff dispersed; is hopeful he can work out deal with Rwandan Pres Paul Kagame to end war; charges Ugandan troops seek only to loot Congo; State Department urges Kabila to end what it calls violation of 1999 peace accord; photo (M)

headline: AT&T MOVE MEANS MILLIONS WILL FACE HIGHER PHONE BILL
abstract: AT&T filed for increase in per-minute charges on basic accounts of millions of customers, even as company and Federal Communications agency were announcing with fanfare that millions of customers would see lower bills in savings from government-ordered reduction in fees long-distance companies pay local phone companies; company says it will also raise monthly fee for some popular One Rate plans, which charge single per-minute long-distance rates, by 66 percent; consumer groups accuse company, which controls 66 percent of residential long-distance market, and FCC with misleading consumers by failing to disclose rate increases when they announced rate cuts; agency says it knew of proposed rate increases but was not troubled by them since company agreed to send letter to customers urging them to consider switching to lower-priced plans (M)

headline: Forum on Torture Hears of U.S. Efforts to End Police Brutality
abstract: United States defends its efforts to eliminate torture, including police brutality and inmate abuse, in its first report on its compliance with United Nations Convention Against Torture; US, like 117 other countries that signed 1984 convention, is obliged to detail to body's review committee every four years incidents of torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment of its citizens and to describe steps taken to stamp out such practices; Amnesty International has filed its own 45-page report with torture committee, describing specific cases in US that it says violated international pact (M)

headline: SOROS FUND SELLS STAKE IN SATELLITE PHONE VENTURE
abstract: Soros Fund Management LLC liquidated its stake in satellite telephone venture Globalstar Telecommunications Ltd as of March 10 (S)

headline: The Temptation Of the Market Timers
abstract: Edward Kerschner, chief investment strategist at PaineWebber, says investors must learn to put up with volatility of technology stocks and stop trying to time the market; photo (S)

headline: Ex-Coke Workers Start Trip To Publicize Racial Dispute
abstract: About four dozen former Coca-Cola employees and activists begin five-day bus trip from Atlanta to Wilmington, Del, site of Coke's annual meeting, to call attention to suit charging company with discrimination against black workers; organizers threaten possible boycott (M)

headline: Israel Hurries Pullout Plans After Clashes Along Border
abstract: Israel speeds up preparations to withdraw forces from southern Lebanon following spate of border violence, in event Prime Min Ehud Barak decides to do so before self-imposed deadline of July 7; senior military officials expect to withdraw under fire; several indicate they may as well withdraw as soon as possible and cut losses they could sustain in next two months (M)

headline: Barak Declares End to 'Tragedy' as Last Troops Leave Lebanon
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak declares end to 'tragedy' of two-decade occupation of southern Lebanon as last remaining Israeli troops and pro-Israeli militias pull out of border security zone; security cabinet, in emergency session, authorized him to swiftly withdraw forces; Barak says Israel will hold Lebanon and Syria directly responsible for any attacks on Israel launched from Lebanon; Israel is pressing United Nations Security Council to delineate border that has never been fully marked or surveyed (M)

headline: West Exasperated by a Failed Intervention : In Sri Lanka, Eritrea and Sierra Leone, War Rolls On
abstract: PARIS—  Continuing Conflicts

headline: Legal Battles Have Little Effect on Microsoft Deals
Americans in Jordan Warned of Possible Peril
abstract: United States Embassy in Jordan warns of possible terrorist attack on embassy and on American citizens in Jordan (S)

headline: A Tool for Taking The Lay of the Land
abstract: Leica offers device for amateur surveyors that uses laser beam and optical rangefinder system to instantly measure distances between 33 feet and half-mile; photo (M)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Handspring Cuts I.P.O. Price

headline: A Role Model's New Clothes
abstract: Mattel Inc is trying to update Barbie's image, partly because of competition from more career-minded role models; in last couple of years, Mattel has been under increasing pressure from some parents to lay aside Barbie's trademark vagueness and make her more career-oriented to build credibility among primary-school set and their two-career parents; Mattel is packaging dolls with literature or CD-ROM's that emphasize education and other requirements for employability; shoppers can expect to see Jessica the Journalist, Get Real Girl and Barbie for President; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Hong Kong Phone Bid May Be Losing Appeal in Singapore
abstract: Singapore Telecommunications is leaning against making rival bid for Hong Kong's Cable and Wireless HKT; Singapore Telecom is balking at price it will have to pay for company to surpass existing offer by Pacific Century CyberWorks; Pacific Century has proposed acquiring Cable and Wireless HKT in stock-and-cash bid valued at $26.9 billion (M)

headline: ASPEN ACQUIRES ANOTHER PETROLEUM SOFTWARE COMPANY
abstract: Aspen Technology Inc acquires Petrolsoft Corp for about $59.6 million in stock (S)

headline: MARK IV IN TALKS TO BE ACQUIRED BY BC PARTNERS
abstract: Mark IV Industries, which put itself up for sale or merger in January, says it is in talks to be bought by British buyout firm BC Partners Ltd (S)

headline: Beijing Court Nullifies Conviction of Stanford Researcher
abstract: Beijing High People's Court, in unusual judicial reversal, nullifies conviction of Hua Di, Chinese-born Stanford University researcher who has been in prison for over two years for 'revealing state secrets'; Hua, former Chinese missile scientist, was sentenced to 15 years in prison for academic publications in US about China's military program; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Rogue Software Program Wreaks Havoc Worldwide  A rogue software program, borne by an e-mail message proclaiming ''I love you,'' wreaked havoc around the world, jamming and crashing e-mail systems and destroying data on hundreds of thousands of computers.    To defend themselves, thousands of corporations unhooked their computer systems from the Internet and began the slow process of purging the program internally. The program also hit government agencies, including the White House, the Pentagon, Congress and the British House of Commons. [Page A1.]

headline: Two inventors honored for seminal work on the balloon catheter and wireless communications.
abstract: Dr Thomas J Fogarty is awarded Lemelson-MIT Prize for his Fogarty Embolectomy Catheter, invention that revolutionized vascular surgery, which he first described in paper published in 1963; Lemelson-MIT Lifetime Achievement Award for Invention is awarded to Al Gross, pioneer in wireless communications, who received patents over the years for technologies that anticipated inventions ranging from garage door openers to cell phones and paging systems (M)

headline: ULSTER UNIONISTS BACK A JOINT ROLE WITH I.R.A.'S ALLIES
abstract: Northern Ireland's largest Protestant party, Ulster Unionists, vote by narrow margin to return to power-sharing administration with Catholic rivals in Sinn Fein, political representatives of Irish Republican Army; this means that government of province will revert to Belfast and that continually imperiled Northern Ireland peace accord will have survived another precarious lapse; motion deliberately drafted to be vote on Unionists' leader, David Trimble, wins support of 53 percent of delegates of party's ruling council; Trimble has been under attack by growing number of hard-liners; he had waged strenuous campaign to overcome resistance in his party to joint rule; photo (M)

headline: Two Big Companies Select Ad Agencies
abstract: Iomega Corp selects Publicis & Hal Riney in San Francisco, part of Publicis SA, to handle its advertising account, with billings estimated at $30 million to $35 million; Consumer Healthcare Division of Becton Dickinson Co names Bates USA, New York, to handle what is described as exploratory consumer branding and integrated marketing assignment for its Ace brand of bandage products (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Taiwanese Leader Hedges an Overture to China
abstract: Taiwan Pres Chen Shui-bian says he can agree with China's government that there is only 'one China,' but holds Taiwan and China must be able to intepret those words differently; stand is not acceptable to China (M)

headline: Stryker Plans Stock Split
abstract: Stryker Corp, surgical and medical products maker, will split its stock 2 for 1 on May 12 (S)

headline: Phone Giants Reconnoiter as Merger Stalls
abstract: Worldcom and Sprint Corp have not yet called off their merger, but already rumors are swirling about who might try to buy either company; telecommunications executives around world huddle with their advisers to figure out what Justice Department's opposition to WorldCom-Sprint merer might mean for them (M)

headline: African Diamond Concern To Sell Shares in London
abstract: Shares of diamond company, Oryx Diamonds Ltd, to be offered on London Stock Exchange, giving investors a stake in venture that includes embattled governments of Congo and Zimbabwe; deal is believed to be first overtly commercial venture involving two countries involved in one of Africa's most complex conflicts; Geoffrey White, deputy managing director of Oryx, says new company sought to avoid secrecy about its dealings in light of potential adverse publicity; company has enlisted Francis Cook, former United States ambassador in Oman, and Moses Anafu, high-ranking official of 54-nation Commonwealth, to join its board as nonexecutive directors; concern about stock offering stems from fact that for years diamonds from African war zones have fueled conflict; in this instance, Congo government has granted mining rights and mine is guarded by Zimbabwean soldiers, who are supporting Congo government along with other African nations against rebels; senior diplomats in London question impact of deal on efforts to bring peace to Congo (M)

headline: SOFTWARE MAKER E.PIPHANY ACQUIRES AN E-MAIL CONCERN
abstract: E.piphany Inc agrees to acqurie eClass Direct for $59.9 million in stock (S)

headline: Detected in Asia, Computer Affliction Moved Swiftly and Crippled Big Systems : 'Love' Virus Hits E-Mail Worldwide
abstract: NEW YORK—  An e-mail-based virus devastated computers around the world Thursday, stealing passwords, interrupting communications and destroying files for hundreds of thousands of users from the House of Commons in Britain to Ford Motor Co.

headline: Gannett-ZapMedia Venture Is Planned
abstract: ZapMedia.com Inc. said this week that it had formed a $270 million partnership with the Gannett Company to provide interactive entertainment. The specific terms of the deal were not disclosed.    ZapMedia, a privately held company based in Atlanta, plans to market a multimedia player that will connect television and stereos to its Internet site.

headline: Toyota Plans to Join Buying Exchange
abstract: General Motors Corp says Toyota Motor Corp plans to join Covisint, Internet exchange being formed by GM and other vehicle makers to cut purchasing costs (M)

headline: H & M PROFIT FALLS
abstract: Hennes & Mauritz, Europe's second-largest retailer, says first-quarter net income fell 12 percent on costs for expansion into US and Spain; says profit fell to 435.8 million kronor ($50.3 million) from 493.2 million kronor a year earlier; photo (S)

headline: The Chairman's Vision
abstract: Article on third of series of television commercials in which Microsoft Corp's leaders describe company's values and its importance to the economy; photo (Advertising column) (M)

headline: U.S. Growth of 4.5% Projected in 2000
abstract: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, in annual review of nation's economy, says it expects annual growth of 4.5 percent this year, above 3.5 percent pace that it said economy could grow without leading to higher inflation; says Federal Open Market Committee should raise short-term interest rates by at least 1 percentage point by end of summer to avoid sending inflation higher (S)

headline: Click by Click, Finns Build the World's Largest Online Bank
abstract: HELSINKI—  As head of electronic banking at the world's most successful Internet bank, Bo Harald uses a surprisingly old-fashioned metaphor to describe his strategy.

headline: PrivateSector; Executive Pay Gets a Second Look
abstract: Comment on decision by Computer Associates to have founder Charles B Wang and executives Sanjay Kumar and Russell J Artzt return 22 percent of millions of shares of stock they received following decision by Delaware Chancery Court, which ruled shares were given under plan that lacked clause adjusting their awards for splits (S)

headline: KOREA GAS MONOPOLY SALE
abstract: Korea Gas Corp negotiates sale of 15 percent ownership to one of four interested international oil and gas giants for $258 million; plans to decide among them by September (S)

headline: Shareholders at Warner And AOL Approve Merger
abstract: Shareholders of both America Online and Time Warner vote approval of merging into world's biggest media conglomerate; government regulatory bodies have yet to render their approval (M)

headline: Suzuki Expands Ties To Colby Effler
abstract: American Suzuki Motor Corp, Brea, Calif, says it will expand its relationship with Colby Effler & Partners, Santa Monica, Calif, by awarding the agency the Suzuki automotive account; billings are estimated at $33 million (Advertising column) (S)

headline: A Gardening Chore Without Any Blisters
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on garden supply Web sites; drawing (M)

headline: Despite Some Success, E-Commerce in Canada Faces Particular Hurdles
abstract: April 7, 2000

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of advertising account changes (S)

headline: 58 Bodies Discovered In a Truck in Britain
abstract: British customs officers searching a consignment of tomatoes aboard a Dutch truck in the port city of Dover found the bodies of 58 Asian men and women. It was suspected that the victims -- presumed to be poor migrants being smuggled into Britain -- had died of suffocation.

headline: Laser Power Bid Extended
abstract: II-VI Inc, maker of optical components used in welding, extends its offer for Laser Power Corp until noon June 16 after Laser's board says its $46 million bid is better than bid by Union Miniere SA (S)

headline: As the Odometer Turns: Photographs of the Nation, Mile by Mile
abstract: Eastman Kodak has posted on Web site mile-by-mile highway photographs taken by Matt Frondorf on cross-country auto trip (M)

headline: FOAMEX NEGOTIATIONS WITH POTENTIAL BUYER BREAK DOWN
abstract: Foamex International Inc says discussions between company and interested 'buying group' have broken down; hires investment bank J P Morgan & Co as adviser and is looking for another buyer (S)

headline: Market Economics; Chicken Shows the Difficulty of Exporting Food to India
