abstract: Deep ambivalence about foreign investment and trade remains in India, and nation has taken decidedly cautious approach to globalization; over last decade, it has let in ever more foreign goods and lowered barriers to trade, cutting average tariffs from 128 percent to 40 percent; still, Indian has some of world's highest tariffs; government hastily agreed last month to raise tariff on chicken legs from 35 percent to 100 percent, year before import limitations were to be removed; higher tariff would be setback for Perdue Farms, America's number 3 chicken producer; 100 percent tariff would sharply curtail Perdue's ability to compete on price in India; chicken is one of more than 1,400 goods that India is taking off its restricted list this year and next and allowing it to be freely imported, after tariffs are paid; India's volume of exports and imports has grown substantially, but its share of global trade remains at just 0.6 percent, same as it was more than 20 years ago; many Indians believe India must shield its small producers, even at expense of higher prices for consumers and lower-quality goods; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Trade Deficit For March Hit $30.2 Billion
abstract: Commerce Department reports US trade deficit widened to record $30.2 billion in March from $28.7 billion in February amid surging demand for imports; graphs (M)

headline: Chat-Room Millions, Real-Life Misery
abstract: Internet chat rooms have added new dimension to quest as old as stock market themselves: to make a killing on the next big thing; among chat rooms' most popular subjects are tiny stocks that most people never heard of; David L McCoy and his brother Douglas R McCoy rode such a stock, Wave Systems Corp, to paper fortunes of $2.34 million and $507,000, respectively, over three years, only to wiped out amid tech stock sell-off and margin calls that left them scrambling to keep their shirts; after the dust settled, both brothers bought back in and rejoined like-minded souls in 'Wavoid' chat rooms; photo, graphs, charts (L)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Letters to the Editor

headline: Changes at Fox Studio End Pax Hollywood
abstract: Bill Mechanic's unexpected resignation as head of 20th Century Fox movie studio ends period of relative calm in revolving-door world of top studio executives; Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corp owns Fox, reportedly is upset with dark tone and poor performance of studio's recent films; photos (M)

headline: 3 Admit Guilt In Falsifying CUC's Books
abstract: Cosmo Corigliano, Anne Pember and Casper Sabatino, former executives with CUC International, formerly Comp-U-Card International, appear in United States District Court, Newark, NJ, to plead guilty to federal charges in what authorities call largest and longest accounting fraud in history, covering at least 12 years and costing investors $19 billion; three executives say that for most of entire history of CUC, its top executives directed conspiracy to inflate profits in order to meet Wall Street forecasts and keep stock price high; Corigliano says he worked 'in culture that had been developed over many years'; says conspiracy was directed by his superiors, though he does not identify them; Henry R Silverman, founder of HFS and now chairman and chief executive of Cendant, attends hearing; says he will not be satisfied until all people responsible have been brought to justice; people fimiliar with Cendant's legal plans say company will take action against E Kirk Shelton, president and chief operating officer, and Stuart L Bell, former chief financial officer of CUC; Attorney General Janet Reno says case 'involves grave betrayal of public trust'; CUC grew through mergers into giant Cendant Corp; photo (L)

headline: Big Board Suggests Ending Links Among Exchanges
abstract: New York Stock Exchange calls for ending aging system that provides rudimentary links between Big Board, regional exchanges and Nasdaq stock market; exchange also declares its opposition to creating national 'limit-order book' that would closely link markets nationwide (M)

headline: Fortune Telling For Profit And Policy
abstract: Economic View column predicts Federal Reserve will raise interest rates once or twice by end of summer and will then call a time out; predicts upcoming federal budget surplus projections will rise substantially (M),

headline: After 40 Years, Israel May Be Losing Its Outsider Status at U.N.
abstract: Israel is invited to join Western European regional group in United Nations, ending its virtual disenfranchisement in organization; until now, voting bloc of Arab and third world nations has isolated Israelis in General Assembly and other bodies; United States has lobbied hard to get Israel into Western Europe group as start; Israel's real goal is membership in Asian group (M)

headline: Forced Smiles in Southeast Asia, as Relations Turn Sour
abstract: SINGAPORE—  Diverging levels of political stability and allegations of political interference in internal affairs are straining relations among Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines and Singapore — four of the five countries that formed the original core of the Association of South East Asian Nations.

headline: Battles Erupt Along Border Of Ethiopia And Eritrea
abstract: Heavy fighting erupts along disputed border of Ethiopia and Eritrea; Ethiopia may be pushing to end war that has worsened severe food shortages and claimed tens of thousands of lives in two years of sporadic fighting (S)

headline: MEDICINE MERCHANTS: A special report.; Drug Makers and 3rd World: Study in Neglect
abstract: Pharmaceutical industry is not developing drugs to treat ailments particular to the third world because it has no incentive to make the huge investment required when the potential customers cannot afford the drugs; industry executives concede the justice in the charge that they would rather develop a cure for a balding American than a dying African; many health policy makers say rich nations may either have to pay manufacturers directly to develop drugs for third-world diseases, offer them tax breaks, dangle before them the carrot of longer patents on their most lucrative drugs, or, in acute crises, simply allow poor countries to declare health emergencies and seize patents to make their own generic versions or buy them from India, Brazil or other countries that ignore Western patent law; problems with the four drugs known to work against sleeping sickness, human African trypanosomiasis, show how the open marketplace that works so well for Americans fails the world's poor; photos (L)

headline: Lawmakers Step Up Scrutiny Of Price Increases for Gasoline
abstract: Oil prices show no sign of retreating a day after OPEC decides to increase production, and lawmakers step up calls for investigations into 'price gouging' in gasoline market; lawmakers are especially concerned about high prices in Midwest; some officials say price of gasoline in Midwest may have finally leveled off; new supplies are coming on market, refiners have increased production of new gas and wholesale prices have fallen; Federal Trade Commission, which is investigating whether soaring prices could be result of industry collusion, expects to report its finding to Congress by third week of July; FTC is expected to begin issuing subpoenas within days, and some lawmakers want industry chief executives to be required to testify on matter; Pres Clinton, facing political firestorm over issue, says he believes there is 'no economic explanation' for high Midwest prices; Vice Pres Al Gore, presumed Democratic presidential candidate, reiterates his belief that industry collusion may be stoking problems; industry officials blame supply problems, low inventories of gasoline and June 1 switch to cleaner fuel, and they point to recent Congressional Research Service report suggesting that cleaner gas mandate and pipeline problems added 50 cents to price of gallon of gas in some parts of Midwest; graph; photo (M)

headline: In Mexico, Top Newsman And Network Part Ways
abstract: Jacobo Zabludovsky, Mexico's most influential television newsman, parts company with Televisa, extraordinarily powerful network he has worked for for decades; incoming prime-time anchor, Joaquin Lopez Doriga, says he will remain impartial in reporting on presidential campaign now under way; this marks sharp change from Zabludovsky's coverage of last presidential race, in which he was openly favorable to government; muted reaction to Zabludovsky's resignation is itself sign of times in Mexico, authoritarian one-party state that is making its way toward democracy (M)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: MP3.com Forms Retail Music Licensing Division

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, HARRIET MARILYN (NEE VOGEL)
abstract: ABRAMS-Harriet Marilyn (nee Vogel). Cherished wife of Dr. Abraham. Beloved mother of Gary and Joan, Janet and Louis and Ellen and David. Cherished grandmother of Bryan, Lindsey, Jason, Alexis, Kerry, Ryan, Elizabeth and Tracy. Dear sister of Sherman and Jeanette Vogel and Betty Hartenstein. Services today, 12:30 pm at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, LI.    ABRAMS-Harriet. The Board of Governors and members of Tam O'Shanter Club are saddened by the passing of their member Harriet Abrams. Our sincere condolences are extended to her husband Abe and the family. Frank Jacobson, President Arthur Kaufman, Secretary

headline: Smart Appliances
abstract: Letter by Rob Costin on April 13 article on smart appliances; says he was disappointed article did not consider social or environmental uses for the technology

headline: Russia Seizes Japanese Vessel In Maritime Boundary Dispute
abstract: Russian Coast Guard fires on and seizes Japanese fishing boat off coast of Hokkaido; photo; map; incident threatens to revive tensions over longstanding boundary disputes (S)

headline: Uganda Must Choose Popular Autocrat or Democracy
abstract: Ugandans are set to vote on whether to continue what Pres Yoweri Museveni champions as what he calls no-party state or switch to multiparty system, outlawed since Museveni fought way to power in 1986 after two violent decades; Museveni argues that political parties divide nation by ethnicity and religion; map; photo (M)

headline: A Peek at Your Credit Scorecard
abstract: Mickey Meece Personal Business column offers advice on maintaining a good credit score; some factors are obvious: borrow moderately and pay on time, but some idiosyncrasies of credit scoring and potential pitfalls may surprise consumers; Fair Isaac, which pioneered credit scoring 40 years ago and dominates field today, has published its general formula for scoring consumer credit on its Web site; loan-service Web sites such as E-Loan and pending legislation before Congress are also demystifying credit scores; chart (M)

headline: A New Role for a Gates Sibling
abstract: Avista, Spokane, Wash, gas and electric utility, names Kristianne Gates Blake, sister of Microsoft chmn Bill Gates, to its board of directors; Gates acquired 5 percent stake in Avista in November 1999 (S)

headline: Compaq Meets Forecast With Flat Revenue
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp reports first-quarter earnings that meet analysts' estimates, but revenue was flat; earnings were $325 million, compared with $281 million a year ago; revenue rose 1 percent, to $9.51 billion, from $9.42 billion in first quarter of 1999; graph (M)

headline: Pakistan Court Upholds Coup but Orders Reforms
abstract: Pakistan Supreme Court rules that military coup last October was legal, but sets three-year deadline for return to civilian government (S)

headline: Salon Dismisses 13 Workers In Effort to Fight Shortfall
abstract: Salon.com, one of highest-profile Web magazines, dismisses 13 employees in effort to make up an expected $7 million shortfall in its $35 million budget; similar layoffs at APBNews.com and CBS Internet division noted; layoffs underscore financial strain of producing original content for Web (M)

headline: SOFTWARE ACQUISITION
abstract: World Business Briefing: Software Acquisiti

headline: Nasdaq Plummets as Microsoft Leads a Selloff in Technology Shares
abstract: Nasdaq Plummets as Microsoft Leads a Selloff in Technology Shares

headline: Egyptian At Center On Rights Of Women
abstract: Interview with Suzanne Mubarak, wife of Pres Hosni Mubarak, who leads Egyptian delegation to United Nations conference on implementing rights for women drafted at 1995 Beijing conference; she says women must speak against false notions of Islam promoted by extremists who would deny women education and jobs; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft´s Memorandum in Support of Its Motion for Summary Rejection of the Government´s Breakup Proposal
abstract: Microsoft's Memorandum in Support of Its Motion for Summary Rejection of the Government's Breakup Proposal

headline: From Tres Chic to Internet Geek; A Purveyor of Prestige Bets His Own Money on the Web
abstract: Bernard Arnault, chief executive of luxury goods conglomerate LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, has invested hundreds of millions of dollars of his own money in Internet ventures in Europe and United States; his American investments include $115 million in Datek Online Holdings Corp, $90 million in MP3.com and $10 million in eBay; his most ambitious investment, $500 million, is in Europ@Web, which plans to make public stock offering of its shares in July; through his personal investments in Internet, via Europ@Web, Arnault is gaining experience that helps him assess online strategies for LVMH's brands; photos; graph (M)

headline: Eaton and Motorola in Auto Alliance
abstract: Eaton Corp, largest US maker of truck transmissions, and Motorola Inc say they will jointly develop and produce vehicle transmission-control systems combining their automotive and electronics technologies; financial terms and other details undisclosed (S)

headline: Hilversum Journal; Europe's 'Reality' TV: Chains and Big Brother
abstract: Article on Endemol Entertainment Holdings, Dutch entertainment group operated by John de Mol that develops and exports voyeuristic television game shows across Europe (Hilversum Journal); photo; map (M)

headline: 3 Dead Marines and a Secret of Wartime Okinawa
abstract: Some elderly Okinawans, who grew up near where remains of three American marines missing since near end of World War II were found, say Katsuyama villagers ambushed and killed men, thinking they were three black marines who villagers believed had repeatedly come to village to rape women; tale refocuses attention on widespread rape of Okinawan women by American servicemen, one of most widely ignored crimes of war; map; photos (M)

headline: Chinese Embassy Bombing: A Wide Net of Blame
abstract: Detailed investigation of missteps that led to bombing of Chinese Embassy in Belgrade last May finds wider circle of blame than government's explanation of simple error of judgment by few people at Central Intelligence Agency (special report: Fateful Choice); officials say bombing resulted from error piled upon incompetence piled upon bad judgment in variety of places--from frantic rush to approve targets to questionable reliance on inexpert officers to inexplicable failure to consult people who might have averted disaster; say bombing could have been avoided at several points along way; see no evidence that bombing was intentional; detailed chronology of events; photos; map; chart (L)

headline: Russian Media Executive, Freed From Jail, Finds New Pressure
abstract: Gazprom, Russia's biggest company, presses Vladimir A Gusinsky's Media-Most independent media conglomerate to repay large debt Gazprom paid for company in March; acts at urging of Pres Vladimir V Putin in wake of Gusinsky's release from jail pending trial on embezzlement charges; Media-Most seeks foreign investor to help ease pressure from Gazprom (M)

headline: Interpol Offers Information on Cybercrime
abstract: Interpol Offers Information on Cybercrime

headline: Chinese Town's Main Export: Its Young Men
abstract: Residents of Fuzhou, China, which is home to many of 58 illegal Chinese aliens found asphyxiated aboard tomato truck by British authorities in port of Dover, greet news of deaths with mixture of sadness and detachment; regard such trips as calculated risk, like those that rational people make; many say they similarly plan to join relatives already smuggled to West, despite high costs and dangers; for hundreds of thousands who have gotten through, journeys have generally proved satisfying and sound economic investment; many have prospered, sending money back home and smuggling more relatives over; relatively few attractive employment options in areas of southern China from which most of country's illegal aliens to West have come noted; maps; photo (M)

headline: Angry Election Monitor Leaves Peru 2 Days Before Runoff Vote
abstract: Eduardo Stein, head of Orgn of American States observation team, says he was deceived by Peruvian officials, and angrily leaves Peru, two days before presidential runoff election that he was supposed to monitor to guarantee against vote fraud (M)

headline: Fear of Failure? Back Up
abstract: Letter from Anthony Nero suggests installing second hard drive, so backup can be made primary if primary drive fails

headline: STATION CASINOS TO ACQUIRE SANTE FE HOTEL AND CASINO
abstract: Station Casinos Inc acquires Santa Fe Hotel and Casino from Santa Fe Gaming Corp for $205 million, gaining sixth property in Nevada; Station Casinos also agrees to lend as much as $36 million to Santa Fe Gaming's Pioneer Hotel Inc unit; loan will be credited against sale price (S)

headline: Real Books on Real Shelves
abstract: Lettrer by Joann Stolzar responds to June 15 article on library computerization; says despite many appeals of technology, she cherishes her memories of researching her first English term paper as high school junior in 1968

headline: CLARUS SAYS IT WILL PURCHASE AN IRISH SOFTWARE MAKER
abstract: Clarus Corp acquires Redeo Technologies Inc, Irish financial-services software maker, for $60 million; Clarus will incorporate Redeo's Web-based technology into its eProcurement and eMarket software; acquisition includes i2Mobile.com (S)

headline: Judge Builds Legal Argument Aimed at Surviving an Appeal
abstract: Judge Builds Legal Argument Aimed at Surviving an Appeal

headline: How Killer B-to-B's Went Into A Tailspin
abstract: Business-to-business Internet stock groups, which did so well this spring, turned into prime killing ground for overvalued technology stocks; one reason is outrageously high prices many of stocks had rocketed to; another problem is rising tide of skepticism that has engulfed sector; graph; photo (M)

headline: Wall Street Slept as Investors Were Fleeced of Millions
abstract: Floyd Norris column on how Mattel Inc investors lost of millions of dollars; Carnegie Investment Management obtained millions of shares in Mattel by promising to pay more than market price; it got shares, but did not pay for them; Carnegie Investment did that through tender offer that seemed legitimate; word of tender was distributed by Depository Trust Corp, backbone of country's share-trading network; shares would end up in account of Paine Webber; Jeffrey and Hubert Leach, who were behind the tender, borrowed $10 million against value of stock they had not paid for; they used money for what their broker described as 'day trading' in technology stocks; but that trading did not go well, and Mattel's stock price also slid; there were margin calls, and Paine Webber sold some of stock to cover losses in account, while Carnegie filed for bankruptcy; Norris suggests Wall Street institutions involved should step up and reimburse investors who have suffered because precautions were not taken; graph (M)

headline: U.S. and Microsoft Agree on Schedule
abstract: Microsoft Corp and government agree on expedited schedule for submitting briefs to Supreme Court that will enable court to decide whether to accept antitrust case as soon as late August (S)

headline: ANTEX HIRES FIRST SECURITY FOR FINANCIAL ADVICE
abstract: Antex Biologics Inc hires First Security Van Kasper to advise it on financial strategies; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Bush's Foreign Policy Tutor: An Academic in the Public Eye
abstract: Article profiles Condoleeza Rice, who refers to herself as 'quarterback' of disparate team of foreign policy experts who are advising and tutoring Gov George W Bush in international relations; Rice is professor of political science at Stanford University and was member of National Security Council in first two years of former Pres George Bush's administration; her specialty is Russia, its nuclear arsenal and America's defense posture; in series of interviews, Rice herself admits that there are vast swaths of world that are new to her; Rice photo; brief biographical sketches and photos of rest of Bush's foreign policy team: Richard L Armitage, Robert D Blackwell, Stephen J Hadley, Richard Perle, Paul D Wolfowitz, Dov S Zakheim, and Robert B Zoellick (M)

headline: Road Warriors
abstract: New York Times seeks stories on most extraordinary, or annoying, experience in commuting, and what was response when you dragged into work

headline: Nasdaq Firms Solidly Favor Sale of Market
abstract: Members of National Assn of Securities Dealers vote overwhelmingly to turn Nasdaq stock market into for-profit company; this clears way for association to raise $1.5 billion by making two sales of Nasdaq stock and warrants, in May and September, to brokerage firms, companies and institutional investors; sale will leave association with 22 percent stake in new Nasdaq firm (M)

headline: Mexican Billionaire Buys Stake in CDNow
Ethiopian Hunger: Another Disaster Ahead?
abstract: Chronic poverty and worst drought to hit Horn of Africa in nearly two decades combine to create hunger once again in southeastern corner of Ethiopia; no one is calling it famine yet, but children are dying, and ongoing war has hampered any solution; world's rich nations have pledged what experts say should be enough food to stave off far greater disaster: at least eight million Ethiopians face food shortage, same number affected in famine of mid-1980's that killed hundreds of thousands of people; photo; map (M)

headline: Despite a Stricken Leader, Japan Keeps a Level Head
abstract: Nikkei 225 stock index closes at 20,726.99 on April 3, its highest level in three years, despite news that Prime Min Keizo Obuchi has been hospitalized in serious condition (M)

headline: Inspired by Korean Peace Talks, Taiwan Makes Overture to China
abstract: Taiwan's new president Chen Shui-bian, emboldened by unexpectedly warm summit between leaders of North and South Korea, invites Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, to take part in similar peace-making effort across Taiwan Strait; does not concede on 'one China' issue that has kept both nations apart; reiterates that Taiwan will not accept Beijing's preconditions for negotiations, namely, that Taiwan acknowledge there is only one China, of which it is a part; challenges both sides to show 'wisdom' and 'creativity' in crafting new definition of 'one China' acceptable to both sides; China quickly rebuffs overture; says 'one China' principle is basis and precondition for peaceful reunification and on which it will not compromise; photo (M)

headline: Dell in Deal to Sell Office Printers by Xerox
abstract: Xerox Corp, copier maker, says Dell Computer Corp will begin selling its office printers in United States and in markets worldwide later this year; Dell will feature Xerox DocuPrint personal and network laser printers on its Web site as part of agreement (S)

headline: Biogen Chooses Chief Executive
abstract: Biogen Inc names its president, James C Mullen, to position of chief executive; succeeds James L Vincent, who will remain as chairman (S)

headline: Auction Dispute Centers on Question of Control Over Data
abstract: April 14, 2000

headline: CORPORATE PATRIARCH IS AILING
abstract: Enrico Cuccia, founder and honorary chairman of Mediobanca SpA, is in intensive care in Milan hospital; poor health of Italy's most powerful financier prompts speculation that company will be vulnerable to takeover (S)

headline: God Save the Queen, and All of Her Screens
abstract: Screen Grab column describes British monarchy's Web site; photos (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SAM
abstract: SCHWARTZ-Sam. Of Riverdale, N.Y. on April 12, 2000. Beloved husband of Frances. Devoted father of Jane Kent, John Schwartz and the late Peter Shaw. Loving grandfather of James, Michael, Deborah and Craig. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 402 Park St, Hackensack New Jersey on Friday, 12 Noon.

headline: Janus Is Closing 3 Rapidly Growing Funds to New Investors
abstract: Janus closes three funds, including $42 billion Janus Worldwide, nation's largest fund with international bent; other funds closed are Janus Global Life Sciences and Janus Olympus; move means that nearly half of Janus' 15 equity funds will be closed to new shareholders; such closings are common practice in industry to keep assets in any given fund from growing too large to be effectively managed (M)

headline: Telling the Truth, or at Least Most of It
abstract: Jeffrey L Seglin frets over ethics of withholding true information that you think will lead people to false conclusions, a gray area between heroic sacrifice of integrity and trimming the truth for personal gain; drawing (M)

headline: SEPRACOR SHARES UP AFTER LICENSING APPROVAL
abstract: Federal Trade Commission gives clearance to agreement by Sepracor Inc to license to Eli Lilly & Co improved version of Lilly's antidepressant Prozac; FTC action rejects recommendation from its staff lawyers, who argued agreement could undercut generic Prozac competition; action will let Lilly sell Sepracor's version of Prozac, which may have fewer side effects than original, and pay Sepracor royalties; Lilly could introduce new Prozac in 2002, two years before older drug faces generic rivals in US (S)

headline: SINCLAIR TO SELL 6 STATIONS TO EMMIS, SETTLING LAWSUIT
abstract: Sinclair Broadcasting Group sells six radio stations in St Louis to Emmis Communications for $220 million, settling lawsuit filed by Sinclair in January; suit challenged right of Emmis to buy radio stations and Sinclair's St Louis television station, KDNL-TV; Barry Baker, Sinclair's former head of television and radio, sold option to acquire properties to Emmis last year; Sinclair had also sued Baker (S)

headline: U.S. Report Says the U.N. Has Improved With Changes
abstract: GAO gives Congress surprisingly positive report on changes at UN, crediting Sec Gen Kofi Annan with making considerable progress on improving management; report to Senate Foreign Relations Committee differentiates between reform goals that secretary general can achieve alone, and those dependent on decisions by 188 member nations (S)

headline: Newspapers' New Hurdles
abstract: Larry Penner letter on challenges facing San Francisco Examiner and other newspapers

headline: New Curbs on Internet Pharmacies Sought
abstract: New Curbs on Internet Pharmacies Sought

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Stewart Information Svcs Corp    TUESDAY  Commerce Bancorp Inc N J  Culp Inc

headline: A Ceaseless War Leaves Trail of Death in Eritrea
abstract: Ceaseless war between Ethiopia and Eritrea, which has left trail of death in Eritrea, grows even more complex as Ethiopia continues to push southward; photos; map; Ethiopian officials make no secret of desire to punish Eritrea , and say they will not end war until final peace accord is signed and Eritrea has left all land claimed by Ethiopia(M)

headline: HOUSE, IN 237-197 VOTE, APPROVES NORMAL TRADE RIGHTS FOR CHINA
abstract: House, in stunning victory for Clinton administration and corporate America, approves bill to grant China permanent normal trading privileges, 237-197, by surprisingly wide margin; vote follows months of fierce lobbying that pitted business against organized labor; three out of four Republicans vote for bill, larger-than-expected majority; two out of three Democrats vote against; Pres Clinton hails vote; Gov George W Bush, presumptive Republican presidential nominee, hails vote; Vice Pres Al Gore voices more qualified support; trade graphs; photos (M)

headline: 3 African Leaders Urge Britain To Aid Zimbabwe Land Reform
abstract: Leaders of Mozambique, Namibia and South Africa, Zimbabwe's neighbors, rally behind Pres Robert Mugabe and call on Britain to follow through with financial support for land reform; say they are satisfied that Mugabe is moving to halt occupation of white-owned farms and end violence (S)

headline: AKZO NOBEL NET RISES
abstract: Akzo Nobel, Netherlands' biggest chemical maker, says first-quarter profit rose 30 percent; net income rose to 219 million euros ($206 million), more than expected, from 169 million euros a year earlier; Akzo Nobel says it expects to post profit growth of 10 percent to 20 percent this year (S)

headline: A Web Site to Analyze Analysts
abstract: BulldogResearch.com, new Web sir

headline: Nike Will Sell High-Tech Gear to Athletes
abstract: Nike Inc says it is branching out from athletic shoes and clothing by forming division for high-technology sports gear that will introduce five gadgets for athletes this year (S)

headline: Belgrade TV Shuts Out Milosevic Rival From Political Program
abstract: Yugoslav state television withdraws invitation for opposition politician, Zoran Djindjic, to appear on live discussion program on ground that another opposition politician, Vuk Draskovic, refuses to appear; incident makes government of Pres Slobodan Milosevic appear indecisive or even fearful of impact that Djindjic might make; Djindjic has not appeared on state television since 1994, and state television officials reportedly never expected him to accept latest invitation to appear; major opposition rally is scheduled in Belgrade (M)

headline: Rallying Round the China Bill, Hungrily: Agriculture; Poised to Become A Big Winner
abstract: Unusually wide range of US companies has banded together to lobby Congress in support of pending China trade bill; US agriculture could be among biggest beneficiaries of trade pact; China has already said it will lower tariffs on most US agricultural goods if pact is approved; tariffs could fall from average 31 percent at present to 14 percent in 2004; China has also promised to reduce its subsidies to its own farmers; nearly all agriculture officials foresee increased exports and better commodities prices if pact is approved (M)

headline: Judge Bans Web Site's Use of EBay Data
abstract: US District Court Judge Ronald M Whyte grants request by eBay to stop another Web site, Bidder's Edge Inc, at least temporarily, from compiling database of eBay's auction information without its consent; ban will remain until full trial, scheduled for next March (S)

headline: RANGER ACCEPTS SWEETER BID
abstract: Ranger Oil Ltd of Calgary, Alberta, accepts takeover offer worth about $748 million from local rival, Canadian Natural Resources Ltd; offer tops hostile bid worth about $680 million made April 6 by Petrobank Energy and Resources Ltd (S)

headline: Translate This
abstract: Ultan O Broin letter on Apr 20 article on computer-aided translation notes corporations that use machine translation invest heavily in terminology standardization to avoid ambiguity

headline: Industry Moves to Defend Biotechnology
abstract: Graphs and charts on how world stock markets fared in first quarter of 2000

headline: Micron Electronics Tops Estimates by 2 Cents
Connecting Rural India to the World
abstract: India is fast becoming laboratory for small experiments aiming to link isolated rural pockets to borderless world of knowledge through computer; local governments and nonprofit groups are testing new approaches to provide villages where barely anyone can afford telephone with computer centers that are accessible to all; there are many obstacles and there are critics who contend India would better spend its money on schools and health clinics than on computers; but supporters say computers must spread if developing nations like India are to close yawning technology gap with rich countries; photo; map (M)

headline: Trying to Transfer Niche Marketing From the Cable TV Industry to the Skies
abstract: Article on UAL Corp's proposed acquisition of US Airways focuses on origins of deal that gives Black Entertainment Television head Robert L Johnson, member of board of United Airlines, ownership of DC Air, spinoff from merger of two carriers; says most aviation experts believe Johnson will need to create distinct identity through innovative marketing and cut costs if he hopes to be success with DC Air; chart; photo (M)

headline: A Collapse of Airlines' Deal Would Not Be Too Painful
abstract: US Airways would have to pay $160 million to UAL Corp if it breaches merger contract, while UAL would be forced to pay $50 million to US Airways if it backs out of deal; either company can terminate agreement if merger is not completed by Dec 31; deal faces many regulatory hurdles, making it likely there will be delay; many in airline industry wonder if deal will ever be completed (M)

headline: Shrinking World Means Big Gains for the Little Guys, Too
abstract: Myriad of Internet companies are developing marketplaces and services to give small businesses same oppurtunities available to large corporations; Internet-based business exchanges, e-marketplaces and free and fee-based business services have proliferated over last year for small and midsize businesses; photos (M)

headline: ROSEMORE TO BUY CROWN CENTRAL PETROLEUM
abstract: Crown Central Petroleum Corp says its shareholder Rosemore Inc has agreed to buy rest of company for about $67 million, ending month-long bidding war with Apex Oil Co (S)

headline: EMMIS TO BUY 15 TV STATIONS FROM LEE ENTERPRISES
abstract: Emmis Communications acquires eight network affiliate and seven satellite television stations from Lee Enterprises for $562.5 million (S)

headline: Mozambique Confronts Huge Flood Losses but Sees Ray of Hope
abstract: Flood waters are slowly receding nearly two months after torrential rains ravaged Mozambique; United Nations and Mozambique report nation must raise about $427 million for reconstruction, which is only just beginning; put death toll at 700; UN aid official Mark Malloch Brown comments (M)

headline: Aetna's New Chief Wants To Be Consumer-Friendly
abstract: Aetna Inc chief executive William H Donaldson is driving hard to transform nation's biggest health insurer into warm, consumer-friendly company that makes more profits and fewer enemies; in his first 60 days as chief executive, he has sidestepped fights with belligerent trial lawyers, embarked on what he calls first steps toward healing strained relations with doctors, and hired executive search firm to find leader for Aetna's health care business; Donaldson is under pressure from disaffected shareholders who played role in ousting his predecessor, Richard A Huber; Donaldson says Aetna is talking with 30 business partners in 17 countries about selling some foreign units; says these assets could sell for $500 million to $1.5 billion; chart (M)

headline: Some A.I.G. Shareholders to Press for More Independent Board
abstract: Several shareholder proposals will challenge dominance of Maurice R Greenberg, chief executive, when American International Group holds its annual meeting on May 17; challenges are not expected to prevail, because of company's profitability, but experts in corporate governance say shareholder demands that AIG create more independent board underscore gap between AIG's management structure and prevailing practices at most American corporations; Greenberg has been allowed to designate his son, Evan, as his successor, even though family does not control company; American International's 18-member board has only 6 truly independent directors; remainder are AIG executives or consultants; in contrast, more than 90 percent of American corporations have boards with majority of independent directors; photo; graph (M)

headline: To Aid Trade Bill, Democrat Creates Plan for Rights Panel
abstract: With supporters of a China trade bill scrambling for every vote, a Michigan Democrat in the House is planning to introduce legislation this week that he predicts will rescue the Clinton administration's top remaining foreign policy goal from potential defeat.     The legislator, Sander M. Levin, said today that he is putting the final touches on a proposal to establish a commission with powers to review human rights, labor policies and development of the rule of law in China. After weeks of test-marketing in Congress, Mr. Levin said his proposal for parallel legislation to the trade bill could recruit enough fence-sitting Democrats to tip the balance in favor of the administration.

headline: In India, the Wheels of Justice Hardly Move
abstract: Cases move at glacial pace in India's overburdened courts, where criminal defendants who cannot afford bail often serve maximum sentences before cases come to trial and civil suits are often delayed for decade or more; scene in Moradabad, where courtrooms are spare and shabby and lawyers work out of open stalls, described; map; photos (M)

headline: New Privacy Law Forcing Changes to Children´s Sites
abstract: April 18, 2000

headline: McCain, in Vietnam, Finds the Past Isn't Really Past
abstract: Sen John McCain visits building in Hanoi, Vietnam, where he spent five years as prisoner of war, including two years in solitary confinement; McCain, long a proponent of better relations with Vietnam, betrays feelings still raw, 25 years later, at how captors treated his fellow servicemen; McCain meets with senior Vietnamese officials to discuss expanded trade and other matters; war is shadow that lurks behind every meeting (M)

headline: Profits Posted By Wal-Mart Beat Forecasts
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores Inc says its fiscal first-quarter profit rose 19 percent and that earnings this quarter will be near highest Wall Street forecasts; net income in quarter ended April 30 rose to $1.33 billion from profit from operations of $1.11 billion a year earlier; sales rose 24 percent, to $43 billion; sales at US stores open at least a year rose 9.1 percent (S)

headline: Famine in North Korea Creates Steady Human Flow Into China
abstract: Estimated 100,000 to 200,000 North Koreans are living illegally in China as result of their government's failure to solve its longstanding food crisis; many fear arrest and deportation to a North Korean jail; say the food aid arriving in North Korea from abroad is being sold on black market at prices that are beyond their reach; aid workers say government seems to have given up on providing food for the whole country and is forcing remote regions to fend for themselves; up to two million people have died from food shortages over last five years; deaths rates are dropping, but that is largely because of Western food aid and because North Koreans have developed survival strategies to blunt what United Nations experts have called 'slow-motion famine'; photo; map (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gold for August delivery rises 3.2 percent to $284.20 per ounce; graph of commodities prices (S)

headline: Loews Cineplex plans interactive displays of commercial video clips in theater lobbies.
abstract: THE next time you step inside the Megacinema Plethoraplex, or whatever your local movie palace is called, you will most likely notice the myriad ways that Hollywood embraces Madison Avenue.    There will probably be advertising on the popcorn bags, on the racks of postcards near the ticket counter, on the signs festooning the lobby and on the slides appearing on screen before the show. There will also probably be some commercials that run before the film starts, not to mention trailers, which are of course ads for other movies. And during the film, you may glimpse products whose makers paid to place them there.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    ITALY: ATTEMPT TO FORM CABINET -- President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi asked Treasury Minister Giuliano Amato to try to form a government, following the resignation of Prime Minister Massimo D'Alema. Mr. Amato, left, a socialist who was briefly prime minister in 1992, said he would present a cabinet soon after Easter. Parliament, where the center-left has a thin majority, will then hold a vote of confidence. The center-right opposition, emboldened by its success in regional elections, wants to block Mr. Amato and force early elections.   Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

headline: Shopping for Harry Potter
abstract: To the Editor:     As the proprietor of a small clicks-and-mortar independent bookstore, Just Books in Greenwich, Conn., I have a Luddite solution to Michelle Slatalla's urgent quest for her daughter, Ella, to be the first one on her block to acquire Harry Potter No. 4 (''Waiting for Harry Potter in Long Lines on the Net,'' Online Shopper, April 27).

headline: Fundamentals To the Rescue?
abstract: Comment on view that Nasdaq selloff merely reflects return to fundamental assessments of company prospects; graph (S)

headline: Pondering The Impact Of a Breakup; Some Say It May Be Too Late To Dismantle Microsoft
abstract: Reaction among rival software developers, mainly small and midsized companies, is muted to Justice Department's bid to break up Microsoft Corp; some say plan is too backward looking, aimed at personal computer software industry Internet is already passing by; they and others predict Microsoft, even split in two, will remain dominant; photos (M)

headline: Suit Against Anonymous Pest Revives Online Speech Law
abstract: April 21, 2000

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of advertising account changes (S)

headline: State Dept. Faults U.S. Aid For War Refugees as Inept
abstract: Internal State Department report, written by top aide to Sec of State Madeleine K Albright, concludes that although Clinton administration has made 'humanitarian intervention' centerpiece of its foreign policy, it has done poor job of delivering emergency aid to people who need it; finds officials responsible for easing human suffering in foreign crises have little influence over high-level decision-making, and in some cases are deliberately shut out; findings discussed (M)

headline: Aetna's Operating Profit Rose 16% in First Quarter
abstract: Aetna, nation's largest health insurance company, says its first-quarter operating profit rose 16 percent; operating earnings were $184 million, compared with $158.5 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 39 percent, to $7.89 billion from $5.69 billion (M)

headline: Gas Prices Under Scrutiny
abstract: US Energy Sec Bill Richardson says Midwest gasoline prices are still too high and that Clinton administration is working to alleviate refinery problems and investigating oil companies for 'potential price fixing' (S)

headline: For Zidane, Dash of Joy in His Genius
abstract: AMSTERDAM—  Back in Marseille, his face still eyes the Mediterranean from a mural painting big enough for a Gadhafi or a Brezhnev. Kids come with marker pens and scribble their name on his shoulders, and locals tell, weirdly, of just-married couples posing for photos in their wedding outfits, seemingly blessed by Zizou's forever-true gaze.

headline: Project Virtual Funk: The Digitizing of James Brown
abstract: Digital Domain computer wizards are working to develop computer-generated animated version of soul singer James Brown, circa 1963, for Experience Music Project, interactive popular-music museum set to open in Seattle; museum, which is being filled with exhibitions and artifacts that tell story of rock 'n' roll, was founded by Paul G Allen and his sister, Jody Allen Patton; photos (M)

headline: A Would-Be Bidder Says BMW Provided Rover Finance Data
abstract: Phoenix Consortium, British group that seeks to buy Rover Cars from BMW AG, says BMW has provided it for first time with Rover's financial accounts; Abbey National PLC denies it finances Phoenix bid (M)

headline: Hospital Company Agrees to Pay $745 Million in U.S. Fraud Case
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, nation's largest health care company, agrees in principle to pay $745 million in civil penalties to settle part of broad government inquiry into whether it cheated federal health programs; this is largest health care fraud settlement ever obtained by Justice Dept; it will not end sprawling investigations into Columbia/HCA; criminal and other civil investigations into company's business practices remain unresolved; settlement addresses civil allegations that company fraudulently increased patient billings to government from its hospitals; allegations that remain unsettled involve whether Columbia hospitals fraudulently overstated their expenses to increase reimbursement from Medicare and other federal health programs and engaged in illegal financial relationships with doctors; deal already reached puts immense pressure on both Columbia and government to resolve entire case before end of year (M)

headline: Nasdaq Jumps 5.34%, Its 7th-Best Percentage Gain Ever
abstract: Nasdaq composite index surges 181.59 points, or 5.34 percent, to 3,582.50; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is up 28.21 points, or 1.99 percent, to 1,448.81, while Dow Jones industrial average climbs 129.87 points, or 1.23 percent, to 10,652.20; graph; chart (M)

headline: SCOTTISH BANK EARNINGS RISE
abstract: An Edinburgh-based bank Royal Bank of Scotland Group P.L.C., which recently won a bidding war for National Westminster Bank P.L.C., said profit rose 33 percent in the first half of the year as a result of Britain's growing economy. The bank said its net income rose to $:444 million, or $693 million, in the first half of the year from $:333 million a year earlier.   Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

headline: Inflation's Toll on Inflated Markets
abstract: MORE than $2 trillion in investor wealth got vaporized last week. It was the worst week in Nasdaq history, and one of the worst in Wall Street's.    While the stock market's ascent into the stratosphere in recent months had been breathtaking, the speed with which this fortune vanished was nothing short of stupefying. After the government's announcement on Friday that the Consumer Price Index for March showed broad and troubling increases, stocks across the board collapsed. The Dow lost 5.66 percent, while the Nasdaq plummeted 9.67 percent.

headline: People
abstract: Gretchen G Teichgraeber is named president and chief executive at Scientific American Inc, succeeding Joachim P Rosler, who resigned; Jack Rotherham, vice president and associate publisher at Rolling Stone magazine, is promoted to publisher, succeeding Terry Hummel, who resigned; Suzanne Grimes, publisher at Women's Sports & Fitness magazine, is named publisher at sibling, Allure, succeeding Erica Bartman, who is leaving; Steven Harrison is named publisher at Auto World Weekly magazine that is being introduced June 15; Rebecca Darwin is named president at VIG Network; Barbara Deering is named president at Primedia Enterprises; Abby Auerbach is named to new post of senior vice president at Television Bureau of Advertising, effective June 5; Jonathan Asher, managing partner at Coleman Group, is named president, succeeding Owen W Coleman, who remains chairman and chief executive; Stephen L Brooks is named to vacant posts of executive vice president and chief operating officer at Grafica Inc; Janet Galchus is named director for Siboney/Interactivo (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Government Reports Decline in Import Prices
abstract: Labor Department reports prices businesses pay for imported goods, excluding petroleum, fell in May for the first time in almost year, suggesting that inexpensive imports are helping to keep inflation contained; says index of imported prices for goods outside petroleum area declined 0.2 percent last month after rising 0.1 percent in April; says prices of imports, including oil, rose 0.6 percent in May after falling 1.5 percent in April; department also reports number of workers filing for state unemployment benefits rose 20,000 last week, to 309,000, highest level in five months (M)

headline: Microsoft Unexpectedly Files Another Brief
abstract: Microsoft files unexpected brief with Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson that quotes from Justice Department's own 1995 argument against breaking up company in earlier antitrust case against Microsoft; also repeats its own earlier legal arguments (M)

headline: Online Bid Soars to $135,805, Provenance Not Guaranteed
abstract: Online bidders push price for 1952 painting believed to be by late Richard Diebenkorn to record $135,805 on eBay, despite questions about provenance; six-figure sale represents not only one of highest prices paid on line for art, but is regarded as powerful testimony to ability of Internet to ignite sales frezny, even for expensive items that may or may not be what people think they are; buyer identified as Rob Keereweer of Netherlands; photo (M)

headline: PERKINELMER BUYING NEN LIFE SCIENCES FOR $400 MILLION
abstract: PerkinElmer Inc acquires Nen Life Sciences from investment group led by Genstar Capital LLC for $400 million in cash (S)

headline: NO LAYOFFS, G.M. PROMISES DAEWOO
abstract: General Motors Corp chairman Jack Smith, vowing there will be no layoffs at Daewoo Motor Co, tries to win support for its bid to acquire ailing South Korean automaker; rival bidder Ford Motor has made similar promises (S)

headline: Patent Claims Pop Up All Over the Internet
Oh, the Psyches and Personalities He Has Seen
abstract: Profile of Caliper Management founder Herbert M Greenberg, 70, who has been blind since age of 10; Princeton, NJ, company has grown into $14 million business in human resources consulting; Greenberg comments; photo (M)

headline: Japan's Leading Wireless Company May Seek Foothold in Britain
abstract: Japan's leading wireless communications company, NTT DoCoMo Inc, hints that it might soon establish presence in Great Britain as part of its frenetic international expansion maneuvers (M)

headline: French Can Pursue Polish Phone Company
abstract: France Telecom and Polish partner, Kulczyk Holding, get exclusive rights to negotiate purchase of 35 percent stake in former Polish phone monopoly, Telekomunikacja Polska, for some $4 billion and right to lift stake to 51 percent by 2001; photo (M)

headline: Testing Pizzas' Pizazz As Maker Hits Market
abstract: California Pizza Kitchens has won a following in 21 states for its designer pizza pies, made of paper-thin crusts with unusual toppings; chain was founded in 1985 by attorneys Larry S Flax and Richard L Rosenfeld; it pursued slow growth plan, opening 23 restaurants in first seven years, but Pepsico bought controlling stake in 1992, and chain opened 60 restaurants in next five years; Pepsico sold out in 1997, and company closed 16 of the 60 new restaurants and resumed more conservative growth plan; it now has 100 restaurants, 74 of them company-owned; it has upgraded food quality and maintained high service standards (M)

headline: AETHER SYSTEMS BUYS IFX, A FINANCIAL DATA COMPANY
abstract: Aether Systems Inc acquires IFX Group, Europe's number 1 provider of mobile financial data, for $85 million in cash; Aether says IFX will become part of planned venture with Reuters Group to provide data services for mobile phone users in Europe; venture, introduced in February, will be called Sila Communications; Aether will own 60 percent (S)

headline: IRELAND UNFREEZES WIRELESS LICENSE
abstract: Ireland's Supreme Court overturns ruling that prevented Irish-American mobile phone company, Meteor Mobile Communications, from using license originally granted almost two years ago, after competitor, Orange Communications, challegned selection process as biased (S)

headline: Figuring Out Whether E-Mammon Can Fit in the Temple
abstract: Ari L Goldman article on efforts by growing number of religious groups with Web sites to incorporate e-commerce into their primary missions and make it consistent with their message; notes some are cautiously experimenting with sales of religious books and gifts; photos (M)

headline: Judge Suggests U.S. Remedy For Microsoft Is Inadequate
abstract: Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson raises serious questions about Justice Department's bid to break Microsoft into 2 parts, seeming to suggest plan does not go far enough; lauds brief from group of computer industry executives suggesting breaking company into three parts; asks government to quickly revise antitrust remedy proposal; rejects Microsoft's bid for months of added hearings, surprising and upsetting company; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: THE AMERICAS    CANADA: PRIVATE FILES DELETED  The government has moved to dismantle a huge computer database that could generate detailed files on 34 million Canadians, alive and dead. In face of protests, the Human Resources Ministry sent tax computer files back to the Canada Customs and Revenue Agency, and government workers deleted a program that connected databases. A Human Resources Ministry spokesman said no backups existed of the files, which included health, tax, travel, employment and welfare records.   James Brooke (NYT)

headline: DANISH COMPANY TO BUY BELTONE, MAKER OF HEARING AIDS
abstract: GN Store Nord will acquire Beltone Electronics Corp, American maker of hearing aids, for $392.5 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: A Tower of Babel for East Timorese as They Seek a Language
abstract: Newly independent East Timor, which endured 400 years of Portuguese rule and 24 years of Indonesian occupation, struggles with highly emotional issue of choosing national language; about 60 percent of population speaks local Tetun and as many as 90 percent of those under 35 speak Indonesian, as do 40 percent of those over 35; only 10 percent speaks Portuguese; announcement by government leaders that Portuguese will be official language has spurred heated debate since move would make linguistic outsiders of great majority of East Timorese, pushing them to sidelines of nation al reconstruction; those most affected would be young with education and skills,who are most vital to building nation; photo (M)

headline: A Bill to Halt Insurer Tax Flight to Bermuda
abstract: Legislation to prevent property and casualty insurance companies from avoiding corporate income taxes by moving their corporate headquarters to Bermuda is introduced by three members of House Ways and Means Committee; Reprs Nancy L Johnson, Richard E Neal and Robert T Matsui sponsor bill (S)

headline: Stock Rally Continues
abstract: Bolstered by strong corporate profit reports, investors flooded back into United States stocks for the second consecutive day. The Nasdaq composite index rose 254.41 points, or 7.2 percent, to 3,793.57, the index's second-biggest gain ever. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 184.91 points, to 10,767.42  Business Day, Page C1.

headline: AOL Launches Multimedia Content
abstract: AOL Launches Multimedia Content

headline: CABLETRON TO SELL DIGITAL UNIT TO GORES TECHNOLOGY
abstract: Cabletron Systems Inc agrees to sell Digital Network Products Group, business it acquired in 1998 from Digital Equipment Corp, to Gores Technology Group; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: BIDDING FOR DAEWOO
abstract: DaimlerChrysler announces $428 million deal to buy 10 percent of Daewoo Motor's domestic competitor, Hyundai Motor, and they submit joint bid for Daewoo; General Motors and Fiat announce they also will join forces (S)

headline: American Tissue Purchase
abstract: American Tissue Inc announces acquisition of paper maker CST/Star Inc (S)

headline: One Aspect Of Messages On the Internet To Be Delayed
abstract: Instant-messaging, popular Internet service that lets users send messages that quickly pop up on recipient's screen, remains mired in technical and political snags; competitors are increasingly hostile to standards proposed by dominant player, America Online, to let users of competing services send messages to each other; charge AOL stalls on interoperability (M)

headline: SONY PLANS BROADBAND SERVICE
abstract: Sony Corp announces plans to begin offering corporate clients broadband Internet access over wireless telecommunications system in Japan this summer; for basic rate of $654 (US) a month, Sony's clients will be able to send and receive data using broadband telecommunications networks operating at rate of 1.5 megabits a second (S)

headline: Nasdaq Turns Lower Again, But Blue Chips Edge Ahead
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 66.11, to 10,687.95; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 1.1, to 1,470.54; Nasdaq composite index declines 53.65, to 3,797.41; graph on Dow Jones average; list of some stocks with biggest percentage gains and losses (M)

headline: Changing Girls´ Attitudes About Computers
abstract: April 12, 2000

headline: Dueling With Dollars (Or Francs, at the Least)
abstract: France's two battling billionaires are at it again. Like boys boasting the better stamp collection, Bernard Arnault, the  chairman of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, and his archrival, Francois Pinault, who owns the Au Printemps department stores, have a history of wanting what the other covets. Last year, Mr. Pinault won their fight for control of Gucci.  Also last year, when Mr. Pinault plunked down $1 billion for Christie's, Mr. Arnault bought the smaller, but still fine auction house Phillips.

headline: Former Chief of GE Capital Is Hired as Conseco's Rescuer
abstract: Gary C Wendt, former chief of GE Capital Services, is named as chairman and chief executive of Conseco Inc, beleaguered insurance and financial services company; appointment is hailed by Wall Street analysts; appointment comes two months after Stephen C Hilbert, who founded Conseco 21 years ago, resigned as chairman and chief executive, along with Rollin M Dick, who quit as company's longtime chief financial officer; Wendt succeeds David W Harkins, company director who served as acting chairman and chief executive after departure of Hilbert (M)

headline: Midway Games Plunges on Earnings Warning
abstract: April 8, 2000

headline: A 'Silent' Generation Speaks Up, and Not So Softly
abstract: George Olsen, letter, responds to Fred Brock's May 7 article on 'silent' generation, those Americans, now in the mid-50's to early 70's, who are too young to have fought in World War II but too old to be considered baby boomers; drawing (M)

headline: U.S. Pursuit of Microsoft: Rare Synergy With Company's Rivals
abstract: William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, has no doubts about who is responsible for his company's antitrust woes. During a news conference last Wednesday, hours after a federal judge ordered that Microsoft be split in two, Mr. Gates spoke pointedly of the ''competitors that have been behind this lawsuit.''    What part did Microsoft's rivals play? The competitors, to be sure, played a crucial role throughout the investigation, litigation and sanctions phase of the suit by the Justice Department and 19 states. It was, in fact, a 222-page white paper written in the summer of 1996 by lawyers for Netscape Communications, Microsoft's main rival in the market for Internet browsing software, that caught the attention of Joel I. Klein, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, and prompted him to order an investigation.

headline: Merrill Lynch And HSBC Set To Offer Global Online Service
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co is teaming with HSBC Holdings to offer online banking and investment services throughout Europe and Asia; Merrill will spend up to $500 million over five years on its half of venture that Merrill's chairman David H Komansky describes as first international combination of electronic banking and investment services; HSBC will own other half of venture; Komansky and HSBC chairman Sir John Bond say link is not prelude to further ties between two companies or full-blown merger, but arrangement does not preclude either company from trying to buy the other; photo (M)

headline: MANAGEMENT: Return of the Native Executive; Many Repatriations Fail, at Huge Cost to Companies
abstract: Thousands of executives every year arrive home from foreign postings and bolt to greener pastures, often at cost to their employers of $1 million or more that was invested in training and overseas expenses; Dr J Stewart Black, managing director of Center for Global Assignments, consulting firm that works with executives going and coming from abroad, says two-thirds of returning executives and their family members that he interviewed described repatriation as more wrenching experience than overseas postings themselves; says twenty-five percent of returning managers leave company within a year, double proportion of departures by those who never go abroad; adds returned managers who leave typically go to competition; Paul Kocourek, senior partner at Booz, Allen & Hamilton who has logged three overseas assignments in 30 years, suggests maintaining network and mentor back at headquarters; Sylvia Dickinson, founder of Dickinson Consulting, firm that counsels outbound and returning executives and their families, comments; some executives comment on problems of re-entry; charts; photos (M)

headline: Senator Frees Up Funds for U.N. Forces in Kosovo
abstract: Sen Judd Gregg, New Hampshire Republican, releases his hold on $40 million in State Dept funds appropriated for United Nations peacekeeping mission in Kosovo (S)

headline: Price Data From May Fuels Rise In Treasuries
abstract: Bond prices rise sharply after government report on consumer prices for May shows no acceleration in inflation; 30-year bond gains 17/32, to 104 26/32, to yield 5.91 percent, down from 5.94 percent; chart; graph (M)

headline: REUTERS AGREES TO ACQUIRE YANKEE GROUP FROM PRIMARK
abstract: Reuters Group PLC acquires Yankee Group Research Inc from Primark Corp for $72.5 million in cash (S)

headline: POTLATCH TO LAY OFF 260 AND TAKE $16 MILLION CHARGE
abstract: Potlatch Corp, maker of lumber and tissue paper, says it will lay off 260 employees, or about 3.7 percent of its work force; will take second-quarter charge of $16 million to cover costs of job cuts (S)

headline: Brazil Encounters Resistance to Privatization of Bank
abstract: Brazilian Government, which over last six years has successfully privatized number of state-owned sectors, is facing unexpectedly tough domestic resistance to sale of Banco do Estado de Sao Paulo (Banespa), one of biggest state assets; Sao Paulo court, with two months remaining until scheduled auction of Banespa, has barred potential buyers from looking at financial records in Banespa's data room, based on lawsuit from unionized bank employees; hundreds of financial analysts representing potential buyers are waiting to review data; opponents of bank's privatization outline their position (M)

headline: The Web's User Profile Undergoes a Broad Transformation
abstract: Web is now becoming thriving marketplace for wide range of people, not just younger, white, heterosexual males; growing number of sites serving minority communities noted; photos (M)

headline: With Relations Warming, Albright Presses China on Taiwan
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright meets Prime Min Zhu Rongji and Pres Jiang Zemin in Beijing, and officials declare new era of improved relations between US and China, which has been bitter at US for more than a year over the NATO bombing of Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, Serbia; Albright urges Chinese leaders to resume talks with Taiwan, but they deflect suggestion; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Commerce Secretary Postpones China Trip
abstract: United States Commerce Secretary William M Daley postpones trip to China this weekend, apparently unable to round up enough members of Congress willing to accompany him on politically sensitive visit; trip is meant to sway members of House of Representatives who remain undecided about granting Beijing permanent normal trade relations, move that would pave way for China's entry into World Trade Orgn (M)

headline: Britain Charges Dutch Truck Driver in Migrants' Deaths
abstract: Perry Wacker, Dutch driver of a truck that became the sealed tomb of 58 illegal Chinese immigrants packed into its airtight container, is charged with manslaughter in Britain, as well as with trying to bring victims into the country and with facilitating the entry of the two survivors; none of victims have been identified, and Tan Wah-piow, London-based lawyer, calls on authorities to grant amnesty to any of victims relatives who may be in Britain illegally so that they can come forward and claim their dead; photo (M)

headline: An informal survey finds don't ask, don't tell is still observed on Madison Avenue.
abstract: Advertising remains a field where homosexual executives remain quiet about their sexual orientation; Jack Sansolo, the first major executive of mainstream agency to publicly discuss his homosexuality, comments on why others have not followed lead after more than decade (M)

headline: FRANCE MOBILE-PHONE PERMITS
abstract: Franc to charge total of $19 billion for four new mobile phone licenses and invites companies to bid; France's three existing cellular companies, France Telecom, Cegetel's SFR unit and Bouygues Telecom, have said they will participate (S)

headline: Sporting a Wall St. Hangover, Asian Markets Fall Sharply
abstract: Selloff that engulfed Wall Street last week spreads through Asia, devastating stock markets and erasing investor wealth in some of most severe declines since global crash of 1987; mood is less grim this time because much of Asia is climbing out of recession that hammered share prices a couple of yeas ago; few people expect current market turbulence to snuff out economic recovery; photo (M)

headline: Business Travel; It's becoming easier, and more common, to combine corporate and family trips.
abstract: Growing number of companies are designing some business trips to build morale by incorporating family or household members; trend is especially evident in popular tourist cities like New York, Las Vegas and Orlando, Fla (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Senate Kills Plan for Panel To Review Cuban Embargo
abstract: Senate, in 59-41 vote, defeats effort to create special commission to study effectiveness of American economic embargo against Cuba; Democrats and Republicans criticize measure was ill-timed, ill-advised and backhanded attempt to change Cuba policy; it would have created commission on which Republicans, who support embargo, would have been outnumbered by Democrats, who want to end it; some senators comment (M)

headline: 60% OF AIR INDIA TO BE SOLD
abstract: Indian cabinet committee decides to privatize money-losing Air India by selling 60 percent stake to strategic partners, private investors and employees; will let foreign airline hold up to 26 percent stake (S)

headline: Bush Opposes G.O.P. Bill On Kosovo
abstract: Gov George W Bush says bill backed by Senate Republicans to set deadline for withdrawing American ground troops from Kosovo would tie his hands if he became president; Sens Trent Lott and John W Warner say they will push ahead with bill, which would cut off funds for troops by July 2001; Republicans seek graceful way out of showdown; Defense Sec William S Cohen says bill would send dangerous signal (M)

headline: The Latest Internet Millionaire Wears a Crown
abstract: Britain's Queen Elizabeth II emerges as one of her nation's newest Internet millionaires when Internet company she backed, Getmapping.com, goes public; her $160,000, 1.5 percent stake in company soared almost tenfold in paper value to beyond $1.56 million, just shy of 1 million pounds, when company began trading on Alternative Investment Market with initial offer price of $3.20 a share, closing around $3.60; Getmapping.com plans to produce first full aerial map of Elizabeth II's realm; company has been given permission to dedicate to her replicas of Domesday Book, ordered by William the Conquerer around 1086 as survey of English lands; Getmapping.com spokeswoman says Queen's stake had been worth $1.39 million at offer price, and had closed at 12.5 percent premium; company says it has so far mapped 85 percent of Britain and plans to make profit by selling aerial maps to real estate companies and local government offices; photo (M)

headline: Ruling Party Picks No. 2 Official To Take Over as Japan Premier
abstract: Japan's governing party nominates its secretary general, Yoshiro Mori, to replace Prime Min Keizo Obuchi, who is in coma following stroke; photos of Mori and acting Prime Min Mikio Aoki; party acts hours after cabinet resigns to ease transition; Mori and new cabinet will be sworn in by Emperor Akihito; new elections are expected soon, probably before Japan hosts economic summit meeting in Okinawa in July; government manages extraordinary transition after keeping news of Obuchi's illness from nation for 22 hours; mechanics of succession and choice of Mori in backroom consultations leads to public complaints that system is both antiquated and relatively undemocratic; Mori, 62, is lifelong party operative whose rose through ranks; burly, raspy-voiced politician is not known for personal popularity or campaigning skills; Aoki had tearfully announced government's dissolution, citing doctors' advice about Obuchi's condition (M)

headline: Swings in Markets Push Some Margin Buyers Out on a Limb
abstract: Volatile swings in stock markets has served as unwelcome reminder of perils of buying stocks on margin, particularly when brokerage firms tell investors to come up with additional cash; many in market point to rise in such borrowing and worry that Americans have gone to troubling lengths to reap bigger and bigger rewards in bull market that seems to have infinite number of legs; New York Stock Exchange says margin debt reached record $265 billion in February, from about $152 billion at end of 1998; margin debt now accounts for more than 1.5 percent of NYSE's total market value, also a record; trader Aaron Talsky, who was forced to sell some of his stock this week to meet margin requirements, comments; photo (M)

headline: Suspected Drug Trafficker Seized in Shootout in Mexico
abstract: A major drug trafficker who officials said oversaw daily smuggling operations for the Tijuana drug cartel has been arrested and charged with racketeering and murder, Mexican authorities said today.    The trafficker, Ismael Higuera Guerrero, was seized on Wednesday in what American officials called a major victory in the fight against drugs. He was captured after traffickers and soldiers exchanged gunfire and the soldiers lobbed tear gas grenades into a Pacific coast mansion at Ensenada, 60 miles south of Tijuana, the authorities said.

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Senate Panel Weighs Computer Exports

headline: CREDIT LYONNAIS FACES PENALTY
abstract: Japan's Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission says Credit Lyonnaise violated Japanese securities law and should be disciplined; says reports to customers were falsified by Tokyo securities arm of Credit Lyonnaise and customers solicited 'with the promise of special profits' (S)

headline: Dell Founder Sold 500,000 Shares in April
abstract: Dell Computer Corp chairman and founder Michael Dell sold 500,000 Dell shares in Apr, raising $27.3 million; typically sells about 8 million shares per quarter (S)2

headline: SUNTERRA, STRUGGLING FOR SURVIVAL, TO DISMISS 930
abstract: Sunterra Corp, owner of time-share vacation resorts, will dismiss about 930 workers at company headquarters in Orlando and might not be able to continue operations; Sunterra stops sales at many resorts (S)

headline: BRAZIL'S PRODUCTION INCREASES
abstract: Brazil's industrial output rises 3.3 percent in April, compared with last year, ninth consecutive month of growth; output of consumer and nondurable goods fell by 7 percent in April, compared with year ago (S)

headline: Laptop Innovations
abstract: Letter by Frederick Willman responds to Peter H Lewis's May 25 article on new laptop computers; says he does not share article's enthusiams for new keypad, noting it lacks lacks built-in incline feature

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS : Even at Funerals, No Escaping Road Rage
abstract: A funeral procession sometimes cannot drive peaceably through city streets without facing the sort of rudeness and rage that have poisoned parts of urban America.

headline: Israeli Official May Face Sex Assault Charges
abstract: Israeli police recommend that Transportation Min Yitzhak Mordechai be prosecuted on three counts of sexual assault, dealing humiliating blow to former general who ran for prime minister last year as first Sephardic candidate in country's history; Mordechai had stepped down temporarily when police launched their probe; he says he is innocent, but that he will resign from cabinet if charges are filed against him; 23-year-old woman who worked as his subordinate brought charge; when investigation became public, police received many other similar allegations from women who worked for him during his army career and subsequently his political life; photo (M)

headline: Fast Action Sought By Microsoft Judge To Find a Remedy
abstract: Judge in Microsoft antitrust case, Thomas Penfield Jackson, sets 'fast track' schedule intended to conclude proceedings and impose remedy by end of May; looming deadline apparently dissuades state attorneys general from asking judge to break up company; Judge Jackson might recommend that Microsoft's appeal be filed directly to Supreme Court once proceedings in his court are over; Microsoft would almost certainly oppose that because in previous rulings some judges on appeals court have agreed with some of Microsoft's positions (M)

headline: Coca-Cola Reaches a Settlement With Some Workers in Bias Suit
abstract: Coca-Cola Co announces tentative settlement with several black employees who sued company 14 months ago, contending that they were denied promotions, raises and other opportunities because of race; settlement, whose details are not disclosed, is intended to cover not just plaintiffs but 2,000 black employees who worked at company over last decade; plaintiffs had sought payments as well as policy changes at company and wanted those extended to all black empoloyees; within minutes of settlement, lawyers representing four other black employees file new lawsuit against company in Georgia state court, asking $1.5 billion in damages; second lawsuit accuses Coke management of such things as intentional emotional hardship, racial harassment and discrimination; Coke executive calls new lawsuit 'act of blatant and disruptive legal maneuvering by other lawyers' (M)

headline: U.S. and 17 States Want Microsoft Broken Into 2 Competing Companies
abstract: U.S. and 17 States Want Microsoft Broken Into 2 Competing Companies

headline: WIRELESS INTERNET PAYMENTS
abstract: Irish software companies Trintech Group PLC and Baltimore Technologies PLC form partnership to establish secure financial transactions in wireless Internet systems; companies are considered leaders in creating systems that assure confidentiality of data transmitted electronically (S)

headline: Brazil Bans Gun Sales After Public Outcry Over Crime Wave
abstract: Brazilian government, faced with growing public alarm over wave of crime, decrees immediate ban today on sale of firearms; move comes as part of broader $1.7 billion national security plan intended to reduce urban violence and reform police during next three years; security package announced by Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso discussed; photo (M)

headline: With WPP Deal Broken, Big French Ad Company May Acquire Y.& R.
abstract: French advertising company Publicis SA reportedly is close to deal to acquire Young & Rubicam in wake of breakdown of merger talks between Y&R and WPP Group PLC (M)

headline: Robert M. Fomon, 75, Is Dead; Ex-Chairman at E. F. Hutton
abstract: Robert M Foman, who ran E F Hutton & Co during its heyday and through the scandal that led to its takeover, dies at age 75; photo (M)

headline: Israeli Armorer in a Global Arena; Aircraft Maker Runs Afoul of U.S. With China Radar Contract
abstract: Israel Aircraft Industries is encountering US opposition to sale of Phalcon early-warning radar system that will be used on Chinese planes; Pres Clinton reiterates concern that China could use radar system against American forces in Taiwan; House Appropriations Committee this week called on Israel to terminate deal, with many members pledging to cut Israel's aid if it does not; dispute to foreign policy analysts is illustration of how Israeli-American strategic ties are still often frayed by miscommunication and mistrust on both sides--as well as by rare but deep divergences in each country's conception of its national interest; China contract has opened first significant rift between Clinton administration and government of Prime Miun Ehud Barak; Israel Aircraft Industries' president Moshe Keret says conflict is also potential business catastrophe, one that he thinks directly threatens his company's prospects for survival in increasingly competitive and consolidated arms industry; company is centerpiece of domestic arms and aeronautics industry that Israel considers key to its defense; graph; chart; photos (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; NO OPPOSITION TO BANK MERGER
abstract: Mexican antitrust regulators say they will not oppose merger between Mexican branch of Spanish bank Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria and Mexico's second-largest bank, Grupo Financiero Bancomer; Frederal Competition Commission says if merger goes through, it will require that Spanish bank sell its stake in Profuturo GNP, pension fund in Mexico (S)

headline: Rebel Group in Sierra Leone Frees 18 U.N. Peacekeepers
abstract: 18 UN peacekeepers among more than 500 held hostage by rebel forces in Sierra Leone since beginning of May are released; heavy fighting reported between pro-government forces in Masiaka, 35 miles east of capital of Freetown (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROME, TOVIE (TUVIA)
abstract: ROME-Tovie (Tuvia). Husband and sweetheart of Ellen Greenblatt Rome, dear brother of Reva Hollander, much beloved stepfather of Batya Cohen. Physicist, mathemetician, teacher, Zionist, friend, raconteur, fighter for truth, mensch. Funeral services today, 9:30AM, Hebrew Institute of Riverdale, 3700 Henry Hudson Parkway, Bronx, New York.    ROME-Dr. Tuvia. Physicist, teacher, true friend, leader. Association of Orthodox Jewish Scientists, ATTICS, C.A.M.E.R.A. May Ellen be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerursalem.

headline: Appeals Court Plans Fast-Paced Schedule for Review of the Microsoft Case
abstract: US Appeals Court for District of Columbia Circuit steps forcefully into Microsoft Corp antitrust case, dismissing government argument that it lacks jurisdiction and setting fast-paced schedule for reviewing Microsoft's request that judges block lower-court order restricting its conduct; Microsoft applauds decision (M)

headline: Finding Gold in Scientific Pay Dirt
