abstract: Celera Genomics Group, which mapped human genome in speed that doubters had said was impossible, must once again defy skeptics who say it will not be able to make money by selling information about the genome; experts say knowing human genetic code will be immensely important for creating drugs and tests for diseases; but even Celera officials acknowledge that genome is not that useful on its own; Celera founder-president J Craig Venter says it is starting point for what we want to develop as a business; genomics companies are using different methods to build businesses out of genome; Incyte Genomics Inc sells access to database about genes to drug companies; Millennium Pharmaceuticals is using genomics to understand disease processes to develop drugs; Human Genome Sciences is developing drugs and selling its information; photo of Celera founder J Craig Venter (M)

headline: 105,000 Genes Identified in Public Data
abstract: DoubleTwist Inc says it has identified as many as 105,000 human genes by performing first comprehensive computer analysis of publicly available data from Human Genome Project; by relying on public data, DoubleTwist, which will sell subscriptions to its database, appears to have made end run around competitors, including Celera Genomics and Incyte Pharmaceuticals, which have spent heavily to do their own sequencing in effort to sell gene data to drug companies; Celera, Incyte and other competitors attempt to minimize DoubleTwist's announcement; Celera president J Craig Venter, Incyte chief executive Roy A Whitfield, and DoubleTwist director Nick Tsinoremas and president John Couch comment; photo (M)

headline: Economic Scene; The trade deficit may seem harmless, but it could be what trips up growth.
abstract: Jeff Mardick (Economic Scene) column examines burgeoning US trade deficit, which has been growing faster than economy in recent years; says it poses threat to future economic growth, because of corresponding rise in foreign debt faster than rise in income; attributes complacency regarding deficit to misleading half-truths that deficits reflect nation's economic strengths and record low savings rate; chart (M)

headline: Nasdaq Index Tumbles Again, Hurt by Microsoft Results
abstract: Nasdaq composite index declines 161.40 points, to close at 3,482.48; Dow Jones industrial average closes at 10,906.10, up 62.05 points; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closes at 1,429.86, down 4.68 points; graph; charts; photo (M)

headline: They'd Like to Buy, if They Can Learn to Turn the Thing On
abstract: John A Cutter article holds elderly see e-commerce as both enticing and daunting; more and more older people are becoming computer savvy, representing relatively untapped market for online merchants; photos (M)

headline: Vatican Issues Text of Third Secret of Fatima
abstract: Vatican, seeking to end mystery surrounding so-called third secret of Fatima, releases photocopy of handwritten manuscript with commentary explaining how it concluded that prophecy contined in it referred to 1981 assassination attempt against Pope John Paul II; says photocopy is full text of document written in 1944 by Carmelite nun Sister Lucia, who is 93 years old and is only surviving witness to apparitions on Fatima believers say began on May 13,1917 that included Virgin Mary, three children and bishop dressed in white, who was killed by soldiers (M)

headline: Amgen Wins Initial Battle In Legal War Over Patent
abstract: Amgen Inc wins early round in lawsuit in which it is trying to protect its leading drug, Epogen, from competition; Federal District Judge William G Young, in pretrial hearing, rules that Transkaryotic Therapies and Aventis have infringed on one Amgen patent covering anemia drug used for patients undergoing kidney dialysis or chemotherapy for cancer (M)

headline: Auto Sales Keep to Torrid Pace Even as Loan Costs Rise
abstract: Big domestic and foreign automakers announce that sales in April exceeded even last year's brisk pace even as loan costs rose; General Motors Corp reports 2.2 percent gain overall as 7.1 percent rise in sales of sport vehicles, pickup trucks and vans more than offset 2.5 percent decline in car sales; Ford Motor Co reports 15.4 percent increase in car sales, while sales of light trucks rose 9.9 percent; DaimlerChrysler's sales rose 5.3 percent, led by sport utilities, pickup trucks and Mercedes cars; Asian companies thrived last month, with Honda's sales rising 14.7 percent from year ago; Toyota's sales, up 15.7 percent; Nissan's, up 31.8 percent and Mitsubishi's, up 55.2 percent; BMW posts 12.1 percent increase, while Volkswagen reports gain of 19.3 percent; photo (M)

headline: HYUNDAI OFFERS SHARES TO CREDITORS
abstract: South Korea's largest construction company, Hyundai Engineering and Construction, is expected to give its creditor banks shares worth 340 billion won ($299.1 million) that it holds in other units of the Hyundai Group; shares will be given to creditor banks as collateral in exchange for short-term financing (S)

headline: LAW FIRM MERGER TALKS
abstract: Freshfields, Britain's fourth-largest law firm, is in negotiations to merge with Bruckhaus Westrick Heller Loeber, law firm in Germany (S)

headline: U.N. Says Sierra Leone Rebels Now Hold 92 Peacekeepers
abstract: Number of United Nations peacekeepers held hostage by rebels in Sierra Leone rises to at least 92; an ominously tense calm follows four days of intensifying clashes between peacekeepers and fighters from insurgent Revolutionary United Front; additional United Nations troops are reported at risk; UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan meets with African leaders to decide what action to take next; photo of UN patrol in Freetown (M)

headline: A Recipe Bank That Chefs Can Customize
abstract: J D Biersdorfer reviews Sierra Home recipe software The Best of Mastercook; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A Correction: Petsmart.com  A front-page article on Sunday about the increasing prices at many Web retailers misstated the status of Petsmart.com. The company is in business and has not been sold. In fact, it is preparing for its initial public offering of stock.    Europe's Antitrust Chief May Block WorldCom Deal  The top antitrust officer of the European Commission, Mario Monti, said he would advise the commission to block WorldCom from buying Sprint unless the companies significantly altered the terms of the deal before the commission's July 12 deadline.    In another telecommunications development, Qwest Communications International's $57 billion takeover of U S West received final federal regulatory approval. [Page C2.]

headline: HYUNDAI PROFIT RISES
abstract: South Korea's Hyundai Motor Co says first-quarter pretax profit totaled 16 billion won ($14.4 million); revenue was up 71 percent, to 4.28 trillion won ($3.86 billion), from year earlier; results are best quarterly profit ever for company (S)

headline: Government Faces Tough Choice on Privacy Regulation
DDB Worldwide takes on the daunting task of changing consumers' ideas about J. C. Penney.
abstract: DDB Worldwide is named advertising agency for J C Penney, taking on daunting task of changing consumers' ideas about retailer; billings estimated at $100 million to $200 million; account was handled by Temerlin McClain (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Inventors dream of a world in which no pair of socks is ever mismatched again.
abstract: Patent database shows inventors continue to tinker with sock and to devise sock accessories; patents for athletic socks and support socks are so numerous that many are barely distinguishable from one another; act of donning socks and challenge of keeping pairs of socks together in laundry also seem to captivate footwear inventors (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: YELLOW CORP., Overland Park, Kan., the largest trucker in the United States, said it would buy back as much as $25 million in common stock, or 6.7 percent of its shares outstanding, after the stock reached a 52-week low.

headline: Intel to Phase Out Processor Serial Numbers Attacked by Privacy Advocates
abstract: Intel to Phase Out Processor Serial Numbers Attacked by Privacy Advocates

headline: Chicago Agencies Win Addy Awards
abstract: Leo Burnett Co, Chicago, and Young & Rubicam, Chicago win top honors in the 32d annual American Advertising Awards competition sponsored by the American Advertising Federation, Washington; Wieden & Kennedy, Portland, Ore, and two units of Omnicom Group also win Addys (Advertising column) (S).

headline: I.M.F. RAISES KOREAN FORECAST
abstract: International Monetary Fund raises South Korea's growth estimate to 8 percent to 8.5 percent for 2000, up from 7 percent it predicted two months ago (S)

headline: BARNES GROUP BUYS CURTIS INDUSTRIES FOR $62 MILLION
abstract: Barnes Group Inc acquires Curtis Industries for $62.1 million (S)

headline: A College Leads the Way in Requiring Online Applications
abstract: West Virginia Wesleyan College is thought to be first college to require students to fill out and send in their application forms online; until now, most colleges have shunned such requirement because they do not want to exclude students who do not have easy access to Internet (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: MIDDLE EAST    ISRAEL: CABINET MINISTER CHARGED -- Transport Minister Yitzhak Mordechai, a prime ministerial candidate in the 1999 election, will be prosecuted on three criminal counts of sexual assault and harassment, the attorney general's office announced. A highly decorated former army officer and defense minister, Mr. Mordechai has said he will resign, waive his parliamentary immunity and contest the charges in court.    William A. Orme Jr. (NYT)

headline: An executive bound for McCann-Erickson/A&L suddenly lands instead at TBWA/Chiat/Day.
abstract: Gary Topolewski, who agreed two weeks ago to leave FCB Worldwide for McCann-Erickson/A&L in San Francisco, unexpectedly announces he will instead join Playa del Rey, Calif, office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, where he will be executive creative director; Topolewski was supposed to start at McCann-Erickson on April 17 (M)

headline: The Shelves or the Web?
abstract: Marsha J Shapiro letter notes sharp competition on line in sale of old books (S)

headline: First-Quarter Profits Increase At Bristol-Myers and Schering
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb and Schering-Plough report higher first-quarter profits; Bristol-Myers Squibb's net income rose 15 percent, to $1.22 billion, compared with $1.07 billion in quarter a year earlier; sales rose 8 percent, to $5.26 billion from $4.85 billion; Schering-Plough's net income rose 17 percent, to $628 million, compared with $539 million a year ago; sales rose 10 percent, to $2.41 billion from $2.19 billion (M)

headline: Governments Learn How to Censor the Internet, Report Says
Bad Behavior Can Be Perfectly Ethical
abstract: Jeffrey L Seglin column The Right Thing discusses what is ethical behavior and what is not (S)

headline: Going Into the Web to Get Out of the Woods
abstract: Internet sites for orienteering, sport of navigation with map and compass, described (M)

headline: More Planning Needed for School Technology
Serving Self While Serving Others
abstract: J T Houk defends his National Hertitage Foundation, one of nation's largest charities, in face of challenges from rival 'donor advised' funds; people who entrust money to foundation set up individual accounts that mimic foundations at fraction of cost; they become eligible for immediate tax deductions for gifts and are encouraged to use money in accounts to pay salaries and expenses for themselves and families; rivals want Congress to outlaw use of such accounts to siphon money to donors and their families; Clinton administration would restrict gifts these funds can make to charities registered with IRS; photo (M)

headline: TELEFONICA TO BUY INTERNET CONCERN
abstract: Telefonica of Spain to buy Bertelsmann's Internet network operator, Mediaways, for $1.6 billion in stock (S)

headline: Shorter Presidential Term Gains in France
abstract: Proposal to cut president's term of office to five years from seven is gaining support from political leaders on both right and left in France; proposal has become hot issue with introduction by ex-Pres Valery Giscard d'Estaing of bill calling for shorter term; Pres Jacques Chirac has opposed change in past, but may shift stance because shorter term would make his age less of issue in re-election bid (M)

headline: ORDER FOR NEW AIRBUS JET
abstract: Airbus Industrie will announce that Emirates Airlines intends to order giant jet, known as A3XX, if it decides to build model to compete with Boeing's 747; Airbus will not make decision on whether to build aircraft, which would seat up to 600 people, until later this year (S)

headline: As Web Expands, Search Engines Puff to Keep Up
abstract: George Cybenko and Brian E Brewington, two Dartmouth College computer researchers, measure how quickly the World Wide Web is expanding and estimate that a search engine now needs a communications pipeline capable of carrying 50 million bits of data a second in order to keep reasonably current (M)

headline: Gates Keeps Washington Dates; Scheduled Sessions Rarely Touch on Microsoft Troubles
abstract: Microsoft Corp founder Bill Gates meets with lawmakers in Washington, DC, where he expresses confidence his company will overturn Federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's stinging ruling that Microsoft violated antitrust laws; Gates sits next to Pres Clinton, whose administration has taken him to court, at White House conference on new economy; Gates sticks to Clinton's agenda--how to spread technology to the poor--and avoids any mention of court case; Jackson orders fast-track remedy in case; state and federal govenments must submit their remedy proposal to judge no later than April 28, and Microsoft is to offer its reply on May 10; hearing would begin on May 24; Justice Department officials say they have not made up their minds what remedies to recommend; chart; photos (M)

headline: Patience Doesn't Pay For Social Security
abstract: Lee J Seidler letter responds to May 28 Economic View column; points out flaw in analysis that concluded that Social Security recipients may be wise to wait until age 70 before taking retirement benefits (M)

headline: Cliff Freeman's campaign for Church's uses the working class and humor to sell chicken.
abstract: Cliff Freeman & Partners develops television advertising campaign for Church's Fried Chicken that comically depicts gritty dinner hour of working-class families, with sarcastic twist (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Japan's Public: Skeptical and Blase
abstract: Japanese public barely shrugs in reaction to dramatic news of Prime Min Keizo Obuchi's stroke and coma, and their elected representatives' initial lies about his condition; outrage in press about deliberate obfuscation and backroom decisions about succession is not shared by Japanese interviewed on street; some are clearly pleased that stability and process are being protected, while others say they are accustomed to such matters being hidden (M)

headline: Gateway Investment
abstract: Rent-Way says it will receive investment of $7 million from Gateway as part of exclusive rental supply agreement; Rent-Way will offer Internet-equipped Gateway computers for weekly rental of about $20 in its 1,100 stores under three-year agreement (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of picture captions with Apr 30 article on improved financial outlook of utility industry after deregulation

headline: Judge Says Online Critic Has No Right to Hide
abstract: June 9, 2000

headline: Not Every Investment Is a Vote of Confidence
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column notes shares of MicroStrategy Inc rose 41 percent on news that it would get financing from an outside investor, but fell 20 percent after Promethean Asset Management invested $125 million convertible preferred stock that will give it 4 percent stake in company; notes preferred investors' interests are counter to those of common stockholders; preferred investors may be content with dividends if stock is rising, but can convert at will, diluting other shareholders' stakes, if stock falls to trigger level; some companies report significant short selling of their stock after such deals; graph (M)

headline: U.N. War Crimes Prosecutor Declines to Investigate NATO
abstract: Carla del Ponte, UN's chief war crimes prosecutor, says there is no basis for formal investigation into whether NATO committed war crimes during bombing of Yugoslavia in 1999 (S)

headline: A Rejection By Oxford Raises Cry Of Elitism
abstract: LONDON—  Laura Spence is by all accounts an exceptional, straight-A student with a promising academic future, and until a week ago no one had heard of the 18-year-old state-school student from Whitley Bay near Newcastle.

headline: DANONE BUYS NAYA
abstract: Groupe Danone, leading seller of bottled water, buys assets of bankrupt Naya Inc (S)

headline: MAXIM PHARMACEUTICALS AGREES TO ACQUIRE CYTOVIA
abstract: Maxim Pharmaceuticals Inc says it has agreed to acquire privately held Cytovia Inc for $73.1 million in stock (S)

headline: Higher Voltage for High-Tech Cars
abstract: Auto makers and suppliers are working to develop more powerful electrical systems to meet demands of power-hungry new features; 42-volt systems are expected as soon as 2004; will supply 8 kilowatts or more, compared with current maximum of 3; change will require re-engineering of many components; drawing (M)

headline: A Site Offers to Send E-Mail With Complaints or Praise
abstract: Wiley Brooks develops Web site TellThemNow.com. that makes it easier for people to send electronic complaints or compliments to corporate leaders, politicians, journalists and celebrities; at heart of service is directory of about 600,000 e-mail addresses (S)

headline: Modified Foods Put Companies In a Quandary
abstract: Nation's biggest food companies face marketing quandry in debate over genetically altered crops, which environmentalists say are potentially dangerous, but which Food and Drug Administration deems entirely safe; though nearly all publicly support biotechnology, growing number are quietly limiting its use in response to public concern; still many say biotechnology crops are so pervasive that it would be prohibitively expensive, and in some cases nearly impossible, to eliminate them entirely; photos (M)

headline: Support for the Psion
abstract: Richard Zakin letter on Psion 7 computer (S)

headline: E.P.A. Says It Pressed 3M for Action on Scotchgard Chemical
abstract: Environmental Protection Agency says it pressed Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing to come up with solution after company's own tests had shown that perfluorooctanyl, chemical used in Scotchguard and array of household products, could pose risk to human health and environment; EPA account differs from that of 3M, which has said that it voluntarily decided to stop making chemical by end of the year becasue tests showed that chemical compounds failed to decompose in the environment; officials at 3M say they have no evidence that chemicals pose long-term threat to human health (M)

headline: In Kurdish Turkey, Problems of Peace
abstract: Turkish army has won its war against Kurdish rebels, and Turkey must now decide what to do with 95,000 village guards who will soon be demobilized and find themselves without jobs or prospects; village guard system was conceived more than decade ago as Kurdish rebellion was intensifying; many of its members rendered invaluable service because they know Kurdish region better than soldiers do; fear now is that if salary is cut off to guards, some may grab their weapons and take to the hills; photo (M)

headline: Christian Democrats Are 'Back in Business,' She Says : Kohl Party Chooses Merkel
abstract: FRANKFURT—  Eager to break with five months of scandal, Germany's Christian Democrats on Monday overwhelmingly elected Angela Merkel as their first woman leader after she delivered a combative speech proclaiming that the party was "back in business."

headline: A forecaster revises his ad-spending predictions upward -- again -- for this year and next.
abstract: Robert J Coen, senior vice president and forecasting diretor at Universal McCann, raises his estimates for ad-spending; predicts spending in 2000 in US will total record $235.6 billion, up 9.4 percent from revised figure of $215.3 billion spent in 1999; national ad spending is expected to rise 11.1 percent, to $141.9 billion, compared with Coen's estimate in December of 9.1 percent, to $139.2 billion; Coen predicts ad spending will reach $251 billion in 2001, increase of 6.5 percent from his adjusted forecast for 2000; Coen's predictions for worldwide spending noted (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Some Enticed by Dot-Coms Now Have Second Thoughts
abstract: Recent tumble in technology stocks makes some employees in thick of dot-com whirlwhind look warily over their shoulders, as stocks of many new-economy companies plummet; people question whether they made mistake by giving up security of big salary for stock options that are not worth much anymore; in much-heralded exodus from old-line companies to dot-com startups in recent years, while some voyagers have found great wealth, others are finding that promised land does not offer the riches or satisfaction they had expected; examples cited (M)

headline: Article 2000060892818339685 -- No Title
abstract: UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT

headline: BEASLEY BROADCAST TO BUY STATIONS FOR $138 MILLION
abstract: Beasley Broadcast Group, owner of radio stations, to pay Centennial Broadcasting LLC about $138 million for three Las Vegas radio stations and three New Orleans stations; under terms of deal, Centennial's president and chief executive, will become Beasley's vice chairman and co-chief operating officer (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: ALTAVISTA CO., London, named Pierre Paperon, formerly a managing director at AltaVista France, to the post of president for Europe.     BEAR STEARNS COS., New York, named Ilan Kaufthal a senior managing director and vice chairman for investment banking. He had been a vice chairman at the investment banking unit of Schroders P.L.C.

headline: Uncovered Short Sales Post Rise of 1.8% on Big Board
abstract: New York Stock Exchange reports rise of 1.8 percent in open short positions during most recent monthly period (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  COTTIN, JACK
abstract: COTTIN-Jack. On April 11, in his 80th year. Husband of Lillian. Brother-in-law of Evelyn Witkin, uncle of Carol and Joseph, Sharon and Andrew, and great uncle of Brian and Sean, Emily and Anna. Dearly loved and deeply mourned.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    SLOVAKIA: EX-PREMIER QUIZZED  Using explosives, a po- lice squad forced its way into a house and detained former Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar. He was taken to Bratislava and, though eventually released, was questioned about unauthorized bonuses given to members of his government, which was defeated in 1998. Mr. Meciar, left, who evaded many attempts to subpoena him, was also questioned in the abduction in 1995 of the son of former President Michal Kovac.   Ladka Bauerova (NYT)

headline: G.E. AND CISCO FORM JOINT INTERNET VENTURE
abstract: General Electric Co and Cisco Systems announce they will form joint venture, called GE Cisco Industrial Networks, to help manufacturers use Internet technology to ease communications between their factories and thier offices; GE says it expects venture to realize $100 million in sales in three to five years (S)

headline: Grace & Rothschild To Shut Its Doors
abstract: Grace & Rothschild advertising agency is closing after loss of largest account; remaining accounts and 11 employees, as well as Diane Rothschild, president, are being absorbed by Della Femina/Jeary, which is being renamed Della Femina Rothschild Jeary & Partners; chairman Roy Grace is not joining firm (M)

headline: KOREAN JOBLESS RATE DROPS
abstract: South Korea's unemployment rate posted its biggest decline in six months in March; seasonally adjusted rate fell to 4.1 percent, from 4.4 percent in February (S)

headline: DOUBTS ON BAAN FINANCING
abstract: The shares of the unprofitable Dutch software maker Baan N.V. fell on concern that the company may not get 150 million euros ($135 million) in equity financing promised by the investment bank Bear Stearns & Company. Under the weight of seven straight quarterly losses, Baan agreed in March to sell shares to Bear Stearns over 18 months. But the company may have fallen below the unspecified minimum market price in the agreement.

headline: EDISON INTERNATIONAL SEEKS HIGHER BID FOR TWO PLANTS
abstract: Edison International seeks higher bids for its stakes in two power plants in the Southwest, after having agreed to sell them to Pinnacle West Capital Corp for $550 million; agreement allows Edison to pursue other offers (S)

headline: Robot Takes Some Danger Out of Firefighting
abstract: J C Bamford Excavators offers tractor retrofitted with water cannons, cameras and remote-controlled attachments for use in firefighting situations too dangerous for humans; photo (M)

headline: Quarterly Sales and Profit Rise Sharply at Motorola
abstract: Motorola Inc says revenue rose sharply in first quarter, to $8.8 billion, up about 20 percent from $7.3 billion in year-earlier quarter; profit more than doubled, to $449 million, compared with $184 million a year ago (M)

headline: Chinese Monetary Official Dies In Fall From 7th-Story Window
abstract: Li Fuxiang, China's top foreign-exchange regulator, dies in fall from seventh-floor hospital window in Beijing; death seen possible suicide, prompted by failing health or by corruption probe of predecessor (S)

headline: British Plans to Leave Sierra Leone Prompt Worry
abstract: Plans by Britain to withdraw peacekeping troops from Sierra Leone prompts concern among UN officials and international humanitarian organizations, as well as diplomats in region; misgivings are echoed on streets of capital of Freetown, whose residents say they want troops to stay; photo (M)

headline: Europe Refuses to Drop Ban on Hormone-Fed U.S. Beef
abstract: European Union decides to extend its ban on beef produced with growth hormones, rejecting demands by US and World Trade Organization to drop prohibition; decision reignites ideologically chared battle between American cattle ranchers, most of whom use hormones to accelerate beef production, and European consumers, who generally distrust food additives; nearly three years ago, World Trade Organization ruled European prohibition was illegal because it was not based on scientific evidence that hormones endanger human health (M)

headline: Switch to 2000 Complete, Agency Closes
abstract: Compressed Data: Switch to 2000 Complete, Agency Closes

headline: European Cities Of Two Minds On One Bourse
abstract: Pioneering merger of London and Frankfurt stock exchanges is running into heavy resistance in both cities; German regulators and state-owned banks fear Frankfurt will lose control over market for small growth companies, which has been huge success in last three years; British officials fear Frankfurt will take all good business and that London traders will be left with little except costs of switching over to Frankfurt's system for electronic trading; some British executives also complain that merger has been engineered by big American investment banks that want lower trading costs even if London is diminished as financial center; photo (M)

headline: That Online Religion With Shopping, Too
abstract: Internet is having effect on how people practice their faith; Barna Research Group study estimates 25 percent of Americans online use Internet for 'religious purposes' each month, mainly to communicate with others via e-mail or chat rooms about religious 'ideas, beliefs or experiences'; religious Web sites range from modest church and synagogue home pages to ambitious, venture-capital-backed religious portals, which hope to attract people from across spiritual spectrum; photos (M)

headline: Israel Honors Mothers of Lebanon Withdrawal
abstract: Israel honors the four women--once called traitors--who started movement to bring Israeli troops home from southern Lebanon; photo (M)

headline: Bankrolling Colombia's War on Drugs: House and Senate Will Now Reconcile Bills
abstract: Senate approves $$1.3 billion in aid to help Colombian government battle narcotics traffickers and their rebel allies; bill must now be reconciled with a more generous version approved by House in March; Gen Rosso Jose Serrano, national police chief, whose anti-narcotics leadership has won praise from American lawmakers, welcomes aid but says US could contribute more to his efforts by reducing its demand for drugs (M)

headline: Spain Asks Dutch to Reduce Stake in KPN
abstract: As talks between Telefonica of Spain and Royal KPN of the Netherlands on a possible merger continued, the Spanish government called today for the Dutch government to reduce its stake in Royal KPN.    Both companies are former state-owned phone monopolies. While shares in both are now traded publicly, the Spanish and Dutch governments still control major stakes.

headline: Cruise in the Caribbean? How About a Week in Lunar Orbit?
abstract: Surprising number of scientists, architects and entrepreneurs are developing concepts and designs for accommodating tourists in space; several companies and groups are preparing for day when rockets to transport people safely and cheaply to lower earth orbit and beyond become available; drawing (M)

headline: GREAT PLAINS SOFTWARE TO BUY SOLOMON SOFTWARE
abstract: Great Plains Software Inc agrees to buy Solomon Software for about $142.3 million in stock and cash (S)

headline: Business; In Praise of the Freedom to Take Chances
abstract: Interview with Stanford University prof Jeffrey Pfeffer, co-author with Robert I Sutton of book The Knowing-Doing Gap, describes how Internet companies in particular can avoid 'knowing-doing gap' and learn to put their best ideas into practice; photo (M)

headline: Group Seeks To Counteract Drugmakers
abstract: Politically potent coalition of 69 health plans, several large employers, unions and consumer advocates called Rx Health Value is beginning broad campaign to slow surge in spending on prescription drugs; they hope to counter drugmakers' huge marketing and advertising campaigns directed at doctors and consumers; group plans to tell doctors and consumers about independent studies showing which drugs, old and new, are most effective, and will seek to increase influence of consumers in Washington; pharmaceutical companies spent $13.9 billion to market drugs in 1999, including pitches to doctors and advertising aimed at consumers; figure is 50 percent more than they spent in 1996, before regulators opened way to torrent of advertising directed at consumers; researchers at Brandeis University say in study sponsored by Rx Value Health that prescription drug costs of insured individuals rose 29 percent annually between 1996 and 1999; graph; chart (M)

headline: DOLLAR FINANCIAL AGREES TO BUY DIRECT GENERAL
abstract: Dollar Financial Group Inc acquires Direct General Corp for about $120 million in cash and assumed debt (S)

headline: British Airways in Corporate Travel Venture
abstract: British Airways and online business-travel service GetThere.com plan to create customized Web sites to provide corporate travel agency services for small and midsize businesses in Britain and Europe; sites will let users book air, car and hotel reservations with same management and reporting tools that large corporations use; companies will be able to book flights on other airlines, but British Airways will be default choice (M)

headline: Gillette Earnings Drop as Retailers Cut Orders
abstract: Gillette Co says first-quarter earnings fell 4.1 percent, less than expected; company earned $258 million, compared with $269 million in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 5.5 percent, to $2.05 billion (M)

headline: Adding Fonts to Increase A Computer's Repertory
abstract: Q. How do I install new fonts on my computer?    A. Adding type fonts to a PC or Macintosh can be very simple, depending on the type of font you want to load. Two common font formats are TrueType and Adobe's Type 1 Font, and you should know which kind of font you are installing. You can usually find that information  when you purchase and download the font from the Web or in the documentation from the vendor who sent your fonts on a CD or floppy disk.

headline: Traveling On the Wings Of the Dollar
abstract: Surge of dollar in past year, rising to highest levels in more than decade against national currencies linked to euro, is enticing American travelers, many reveling not only in their increased income but also in incredible buying power abroad; European Travel Commission expects 12 million Americans to visit Europe in 2000, 3.5 percent increase from 1999 and seventh consecutive annual increase; photos; graph; charts (M)

headline: Appearing Soon at a Store Near You: An A.T.M. for the Ears
abstract: Three technology companies, Digital On-Demand, Liquid Audio and Musicmaker.com are designing and deploying music kiosks in stores across country that allow consumers to make compilations of their favorite songs on CD; kiosks use off-the-shelf technology and employ touch screen selection menus; once consumer selects songs, digital music files are recorded onto blank CD; discs cost about $6 to $20 depending on number of songs; photos of touch screen menu; chart om components of kiosk (M)

headline: DuPont Executive Ends Brief Tenure
abstract: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said on Tuesday that Kurt Landgraf, chairman and chief executive of its pharmaceutical unit for four months, had resigned after failing to find a major alliance to expand the business.    Mr. Landgraf, 53, was executive vice president and chief operating officer of DuPont, the world's largest chemical company, until he was tapped to run the Dupont Pharmaceuticals Company in January. The unit's president, Nicholas Teti, 47, was named its chief executive. He will retain the title of president.

headline: Online Seller of Abstract Work Adds a Money-Back Guarantee
abstract: Kenneth A Walton, who put painting up for auction on eBay Internet site for 25 cents and ended up making $135,805 deal, admits he concocted part of story he used to describe work and is willing to let buyer, Rob Keereweer, out of deal if work is not by Richard Diebenkorn; speculation that work might be by Diebenkorn sparked bidding frenzy, even though description did not name painter; Walton is currently listing four other paintings on eBay (M)

headline: ONEIDA TO BUY DELCO INTERNATIONAL, A TABLEWARE MAKER
abstract: Oneida Ltd agrees to buy tableware maker Delco International Inc for $76 million; also agrees to buy Sakura Inc and Viners of Sheffield Ltd (S)

headline: S3 SHIFTS ITS FOCUS TO HAND-HELD INTERNET APPLIANCES
abstract: S3 Inc says it is shifting its focus from making chips to making hand-held Internet appliances; agrees to sell its majority stake in its graphic chip joint venture to Taiwanese chip maker VIA Technologies Inc, the other partner in venture, for $323 million in cash and stock; S3 will keep minority stake in venture (S)

headline: Net Registration Bill Could Trigger Exodus From French Web Sites
abstract: French Bill Has Web Ramifications

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Advanced Micro Earnings Sharply Exceed Forecasts  Driven by strong sales of its Athlon microprocessors, Advanced Micro Devices posted first-quarter earnings that were nearly double Wall Street's recently revised estimates.    Advanced Micro reported earnings of $189.3 million, or $1.15 a share, sharply exceeding Wall Street expectations of 58 cents a share. Before Advanced Micro reported the results, its shares closed at $68, down 31.25 cents. In after-hours trading, they surged as high as $76. Analysts said the results could help stabilize the Nasdaq and technology stocks in general, especially if other companies meet or exceed estimates. [Page C2.]

headline: Maybe They Should Just Send In a Camera Crew
abstract: Article on various ways workers are trying to make their commute to and from work more interesting, while others are finding more exotic ways of commuting, including using in-line skates; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Files Its Final Arguments Against Breakup
abstract: Microsoft Files Its Final Arguments Against Breakup

headline: Microsoft Tries Another Court: Public Opinion
abstract: Microsoft is mobilizing a pervasive lobbying and public relations campaign in an effort to temper the impact of a potentially devastating federal court ruling and generate positive public and political opinion.    The company is spending millions of dollars to retain former lawmakers and top political figures, fill the coffers of both major political parties and mold public opinion in its favor through sympathetic research organizations and ostensibly independent trade associations.

headline: PrivateSector; Online, and on a Wanted Poster
abstract: Comment on decision by David Kim Stanley, founder of Pixelon.com, to turn himself in to Virginia authorities; Stanley pleaded guilty to 55 counts of fraud in 1989, but has since failed to live up to agreement to repay investors $1.25 million (S)

headline: The Thoroughly Modern, G.P.S.-Equipped Cow
abstract: The Thoroughly Modern, G.P.S.-Equipped Cow

headline: Euro RSCG Acquires Meridian Consulting
abstract: Euro RSCG Worldwide acquires Meridian Consulting Group; financial terms undisclosed (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Letters to the Editor

headline: Economic Scene; Children smart enough to get into elite schools may not need to bother.
abstract: Prof Alan B Krueger (Economic Scene) column on study Krueger coducted with Stacy Dale of Andrew W Mellon Foundation which showed that students who attend more selective colleges do not land better paying jobs a result; says average 1995 earnings of workers who were college freshmen in 1976 were $22,000 more for those from highly selective schools than those from moderately selective schools; but except for students from low-income families, those accepted at both types of colleges had similar earnings no matter which they attended; graph (M)

headline: Political Site Sparks Dispute Over Campaign Regulations
Year Later, China's New View of U.S. Bombing
abstract: Chinese are channeling anger resulting from NATO bombing of Embassy in Belgrade year ago into strengthening of economy and there is little sentiment for renewed protests; Government, which railed against US, is focused on passage of trade bill by Congress which would give country membership in World Trade Organization; many Chinese regard measure as litmus test of American attitudes (S)

headline: THYSSENKRUPP DISAPPOINTS
abstract: ThyssenKrupp, Germany's largest steel maker, reports first-half earnings that fell short of expectations; net income rose to 171 million euros ($155 million) in six months through March, from 62.2 million euros in period year earlier; pretax profit rose to 367 million euros; photo (S)

headline: Unhappy AOL Campers
abstract: Cheryl Johnson letter on Mar 16 article scores America Online for eliminating feature used by thousands of subscribers to create home pages

headline: Comic Superheros Battle Just to Survive
abstract: New comic book publishers are entering field even as established publishers struggle to raise sales in face of drop in number of retail outlets; superhero genre, while still popularly among mostly middle-class, white men who have grown up reading comic books, does not necessarily appeal to younger, more diverse readers need to spur sales; photos (M)

headline: Watching the Grass Grow
abstract: Jonathan D Reichman letter on May 18 article on robotic lawnmowers

headline: French Officials Warn Further Decline of Euro Could Harm the European Economy
abstract: France's Prime Min Lionel Jospin, Finance Min Laurent Fabius and Bank of France governor Jean-Claude Trichet rally to support sagging euro, warning that further decline could damage economy of 11 nations that share currency and adding that European central bank might increase interest rates to halt slide; decline in euro has fanned inflation by increasing cost of imported goods and raised concerns among many of region's 290 million citizens about their savings (M)

headline: American Histories: Chasing Dreams And Nightmares; AVADO BRANDS INTENDS TO REMAIN PUBLIC COMPANY
abstract: Avado Brands Inc says it will not pursue management-led buyout offer and will continue as public company instead (S)

headline: Montenegro Town Rejects a Split With Belgrade
abstract: Election of pro-Serbian candidate Djuro Cetkovic as mayor of town of Herceg Novi, Montenegro, is blow for Montengrin leader Milo Djukanovic, who strongly opposes Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic and is trying to draw his republic out from under Milosevic's sway; map; photo (M)

headline: Bracing For a Deluge, Getting a Trickle; Reaction Proves Calm To Friday's Big Sell-Off
abstract: Investors react calmly to big stock sell-off on April 14; as investors who fled market stepped up again to buy stocks, weekend's awful warnings fade and Wall Street's naturally bullish bias returns; by day's end, many professionals were saying that last week's plunge might have done some good by ending speculative bubble and clearing way for steady, but slower, advance; old technology stocks seem to be back in fashion; graph; photos (M)

headline: A New Math: Fewer Airlines + Higher Profits = More Competition
abstract: Many airline industry analysts believe that if United Airlines-US Airways merger is approved, other big carriers will follow, leaving three giants airlines in control of most of the market; UAL Corp chief executive James E Goodwin and US Airways chairman Stephen M Wolf have faced hostile Congress at several hearings over UAL's proposed $4.3 billion purchase of US Airways; at issue is whether airline industry, generation after 1978 deregulation law prompted wave of industry consolidation, will best serve consumers if it is allowed to become even more concentrated; United-US Airways deal would create giant carrier that would carry one quarter of nation's air traffic; proposal has set off frenzy of merger talks that many are convinced could reduce country's six largest carriers to three mega-airlines; that prospect alarms consumer advocates and lawmakers who already complain that there is too little competition; chart; photo (M)

headline: Designers Tiptoeing Onto the Internet, Clad Mostly in Accessories
abstract: Designers themselves have been reluctant to plunge into e-commerce, although their apparel is sold on luxury sites; many designers use their sites to promote their lines, but only handful are selling anything directly; Nicole Miller, one of few designers to achieve some success selling direct, comments; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft´s Memorandum in Support of Its Proposed Final Judgment
abstract: Microsoft's Memorandum in Support of Its Proposed Final Judgment

headline: SUNGLASS HUT DOUBLES WATCH BUSINESS WITH ACQUISITION
abstract: Sunglass Hut International Inc acquires Watch World International Inc for $30 million in cash, stock and debt (S)

headline: Death Toll in Congo's 2-Year War Is at Least 1.7 Million, Study Says
abstract: International Rescue Committee, leading relief agency, reports that two years of war have caused deaths of more than 1.7 million people in Congo's eastern provinces, where people who manage to flee fighting often die of hunger and malaria; 200,000 of these deaths are attributed to acts of violence, and rest are attributed to war-related collapse of health services and food supplies; Les Roberts, supervisor of survey, comments on findings; map (M)

headline: On a Not-So-Deserted Isle, Robinson Crusoes Compete for Riches
abstract: KOTA KINABALU, Malaysia—  On a "deserted tropical island" several kilometers off the northern tip of Borneo, a group of Americans equipped with only basic supplies is competing to see who will survive the longest in the island's steamy jungles — and walk off with dollars 1 million in prize money

headline: Sales at Retail Stores Showed a Rise of 4.3% in May
abstract: Goldman Sachs retail composite index shows sales in stores open more than a year rose 4.3 percent in May; sales at some specific retailers noted (M)

headline: Reader's Digest In Drug Venture
abstract: Reader's Digest Association says it is creating venture with Merck-Medco unit of Merck & Co to sell discounted prescription drugs on Internet; financial terms undisclosed; venture, called Yourxplan, will offer members discounts on brand name and generic prescription drugs (S)

headline: Nobel Economists Back China's Joining Global Trade Group
abstract: Thirteen Nobel Prize-winning economists, part of gruop of 149 economists, endorse China's bid to join World Trade Organization; letter released in ceremony with top Clinton administration officials does not take position on Congressional vote to elevate US-China trade ties, because of some economists' qualms about delving into political issue; Robert M Solow, Milton Friedman, Paul Samuelson and Merton Miller are among signers (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOLFF, LEON
abstract: WOLFF - Leon. 4/13/06 - 9/13/74. Dearest Father, forever in my heart. With all my love, your daughter Elain

headline: Asian Values, Trumped By the New Economy
abstract: Economic View column by Tom Redburn comments on widespread enthusiasm in Asian countries for doing business on Web; says mania for dot-com stocks aimed at Asian market is one sign, as is speed with which Asia's leaders are realizing that they cannot flourish in new economy by doing business as usual; notes even in China, where freewheeling Internet threatens monolithic power of Communist Party, government solidly backs building infrastructure of wired economy; chart (M)

headline: AIR CANADA NARROWS LOSS
abstract: Air Canada posted a 16 percent gain in revenue to 1.6 billion Canadian dollars in the first quarter and trimmed its operating loss by two-thirds, to 5 million Canadian dollars. The Montreal-based airline's net loss was 34 million Canadian dollars, or 28 Canadian cents a share, compared with a loss of 6 million Canadian dollars, or 3 cents, a year earlier. The 1999 result includes a one-time gain of 39 million Canadian dollars.   Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

headline: Stocks Register Impressive Gains For Second Consecutive Session
abstract: Nasdaq composite index rises 254.41 points, or 7.2 percent, to 3,793.57, second-biggest gain ever; gain comes on top of 6.6 percent rise on April 17; Dow Jones industrial average gains 184.91 points, or 1.8 percent, to end at 10,767.42, following gain of 2.7 percent; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 40.17 points, or 2.9 percent, to close at 1,441.61; graph; chart; photo (M)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Few Reports of Damage From 'Killer Resume' Virus

headline: CHEMICALS MAKER HIRES J. P. MORGAN TO EXPLORE OPTIONS
abstract: Stock of Sybron Chemicals rises 65 percent after company says it hired investment bank J P Morgan & Co to advise it on strategic options to increase shareholder value; shares close at $18.25, up $7.25 (S)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: NYT Article

headline: Your $40 Pledge, Her $3 Tote Bag Turning A Page On Salaries
abstract: Random House Inc chief Peter Olson raised company's starting salary to $25,000 from $20,000 in 1998 and plans to raise it to $30,000 this month; expresses dismay at low starting salaries in publishing industry; publishers apparently expect entry-level employees to be lured by psychic rewards of glamorous field and believe that many young employees can rely on their parents to subsidize them; photo, graph (M)

headline: Spin Like Dervishes, Then Stop to Think
abstract: Public relations agencies, which enjoy huge boom in business from Internet startup, are beginning to reassess whether boom will last, and what to do if it ends; see signs of slowdown; drawing (M)

headline: The New Israel: Land of Milk and Money
abstract: WITH his collarless black shirt, close-cropped hair and wire-rim glasses, Gil Shwed looks like a 20-something denizen of the local coffeehouse scene. But he says he doesn't get out of the office much, unless he is traveling to one of his other offices -- in California, Singapore, Germany, Japan, France or Australia.     Besides, there is a cappuccino machine just down the hall, next to the treadmills and stair machines that Mr. Shwed provides for his headquarters staff, now almost 300 strong and expanding daily.

headline: CHELLO OFFERING POSTPONED
abstract: United Pan-Europe Communications will postpone initial public offering of its high-speed Internet access arm, Chello Broadband, for second time citing strategic talks that could affect offering's valuation (S)

headline: RED HAT AGREES TO BUY CLOSELY HELD SOFTWARE COMPANY
abstract: Red Hat Inc acquires software maker Bluecurve Inc for about $37.7 million in stock (S)

headline: CANADA MOVES TO RELAX BANKING LAWS
abstract: Canada's Finance Min Paul Martin proposes changes in banking laws that would relax some ownership restrictions and give increased power to consumers (S)

headline: MP3 Row Pumping Traffic to Music Sites
abstract: MP3 Row Pumping Traffic to Music Sites

headline: Likely to Be a Best Seller in China: It's No Mystery
abstract: Booklet by Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin expounding his purported breakthrough in Communist doctrine is selling rapidly in China; breakthrough is subject of classic propaganda drive, pounded home almost daily in laudatory editorials and televised testimonals by provincial and social group leaders; effort seen part of Jiang's drive to retain power after he gives up posts as party general secretary, move expected in 2002, and president, expected in 2003; photo (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUMSKY, HARRY
abstract: SHUMSKY-Harry. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Temple Israel of Great Neck George N. Abrahams, President

headline: CIGNA SELLS PORTION OF ITS REINSURANCE BUSINESS
abstract: Life Reassurance, subsidiary of Swiss Reinsurance Co, buys part of Cigna Corp's reinsurance operations (S)

headline: MARRIOTT TO SELL 14 PROPERTIES TO WOLVERINE
abstract: Marriott International to sell 14 Brighton Gardens assisted-living communities to affiliates of Wolverine Equities Company (S)

headline: Top Iranian Cleric Defends Closing of Reformist Publications
abstract: Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, former president who is still behind-the-scenes power in Iran, defends closing of 16 pro-reform publications and accuses them of trying to undermine country's religious underpinning; televised speech cites secular-religious violence after 1979 Islamic revolution, but steers clear of direct attack on Pres Mohammad Khatami (M)

headline: CENTRICA TO OFFER PHONE SERVICE
abstract: Centrica PLC, main supplier of natural gas in Britain, says it will provide mobile and fixed-line services offering Internet access; Centrica will work with Vodafone AirTouch PLC, Torch Telecom and Cable and Wireless PLC; several British utilities are expanding their businesses into telecommunications; graph (S)

headline: General Motors Says Profit Fell Slightly in First Quarter
abstract: General Motors Corp's earnings from continuing operations edged down 2 percent, to $1.78 billion in first quarter, compared with $1.82 billion in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 10 percent, to $46.9 billion from $42.4 billion (M)

headline: A new campaign capitalizes on some fiendish and funny uses for loose change.
abstract: Coinstar plans humorous advertising drive to exhort consumers to dump accumulated change into company's self-service coin-counting machines (M)

headline: CASIO SEES HIGHER PROFIT
abstract: Casio Computer says pretax profit from operations probably reached 14 billion yen ($128.4 million) in year ended March 31, about 2.3 times amount year before; graph (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Memorials  GLADSTONE, BERNARD
abstract: GLADSTONE-Bernard. Lovingly remembered today and everyday. Ruth

headline: Digital Limits
abstract: Robert J Gilliard letter on May 11 article warns use of virtual orchestra is not likely to be limited to supporting touring groups and small ensembles that cannot afford orchestra

headline: Vodafone to Sell Cegetel Stake To Vivendi, Its French Partner
abstract: Vodafone AirTouch PLC, world's largest wireless telephone operator, to sell its 15 percent stake in French telecommunications operator Cegetel to its French partner, Vivendi; Vodafone's sale of stake, which Vodafone saw as having little strategic value, gives Vivendi majority control of Cegetel, which controls French wireless operator SFR; Jean-Marie Messier, chairman of Vivendi, comments; his photo (M)

headline: California Dreamin'; Harvard Business School Adds Silicon Valley to Its Syllabus
abstract: Harvard Business School has undergone transformation that is worthy of the case studies that are hallmark of its MBA curriculum; school whose general management curriculum was famous for turning out future chief executives has shifted focus to study of entrepreneurial ventures, be they dot-com start-ups or divisions of large companies trying to act like small companies; change in curriculum has led Harvard to launch series of initiatives in Silicon Valley, where Stanford, its most important rival, is pre-eminent; shift is not without risks; current entrepreneurial frenzy may prove fleeting, and large corporations have proven they will continue to dominate economy; photos, graph (L)

headline: DATABANK: May 15-19; How Much Higher Can Interest Rates Go?
abstract: Investors are uncertain whether Federal Reserve will continue its campaign of interest-rate hikes following last week's half-a-percentage point increase, Fed's sixth rate hike since June 1999; Fed has indicated that it still regards inflation as a risk because economy continues to grow steadily (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar falls against the euro as decline in US retail sales calls into question further interest rate increases; in New York, euro settles at 96.07 cents, up from 95.30 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: Taking Palm Notes With a Pad and Ink
abstract: Seiko markets SmartPad for taking notes with Palm Pilot; photo (S)

headline: U.N. Agency Sees AIDS Depleting the African Work Force
abstract: United Nations' International Labor Organization, in its first report on workplace impact of AIDS epidemic, says AIDS will have particularly insidious effect on work force over next two decades, not only reducing its size but causing increase in child laborers, moonlighting parents, job absenteeism and retraining costs; says most of the effect will be felt in sub-Saharan Africa, region most affected by AIDS; says by 2015, population of 29 African countries is expected to reach 698 million, or 61 million fewer than total would have been without spread of AIDS (M)

headline: FISHER SCIENTIFIC IN $840 MILLION DEAL FOR PSS
abstract: Fisher Scientific International, one of largest sellers of laboratory equipment, agrees to buy PSS World Medical for $840 million in stock to expand sales of medical products; will also assume about $260 million in PSS debt (S)

headline: The Return of a Desktop Cult Classic (No, Not the Mac); Long Revered for Its Powerful Graphics and Lean Operating System, the Amiga Is Re-emerging From the Margins
abstract: Bill McEwen, former truck driver who acquired Amiga Inc's assets earlier this month, releases new software kit for programmers writting applications for new version of Amiga operating system; applications will run on new Amiga computer that is expected to be on market by end of the year; like old Amigas, new one promises fast-booting system and good graphics; computer has spent years in limbo, being shunted from one company to another; photo of McEwen; chart profiling company from 1987 to present (L)

headline: PEGASUS IS PAYING $100 MILLION FOR 12 DIRECTV AFFILIATES
abstract: Pegasus Communications, largest reseller of DirecTV satellite television service in rural areas, agrees to buy 12 DirecTV affiliates for $100.6 million in cash and stock; acquisitions let Pegasus expand in Texas, upper Midwest and central Plains (S)

headline: AGL BUYS DOMINION'S VIRGINIA NATURAL GAS UNIT
abstract: AGL Resources acquires Virginia Natural Gas unit of Dominion Resources for more than $500 million in cash (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gasoline jumps after industry report shows unexpected decline in inventories; in New York, unleaded gasoline for July delivery rises 4.12 cents, or 4.2 percent, to $1.0167 a gallon; graph; chart (S)

headline: Translate This
abstract: Bruce Tindall letter on Apr 20 article on computer-aided translation notes examples cited contained serious errors

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  Retail Sales -- May

headline: At Home's Chief Executive Is Chosen to Be Its Chairman
abstract: At Home Corp says chief executive George Bell has succeeded Thomas Jermoluk as chairman; Jermoluk will remain board member; photo (M)

headline: MOTOROLA AND SEGA COLLABORATION
abstract: Motorola Inc and video game maker Sega Enterprises say they will develop mobile phones able to retrieve games from the Internet; two companies will develop software that can transmit images fast enough to let users play video games on their phones; graph on Sega stock performance (S)

headline: Assad Patronage Puts a Small Sect on Top in Syria
abstract: Late Pres Hafez al-Assad packed Syria's officers corps, intelligence services, palace guard and ruling Baath Party command with thousand of his fellow Alawites, members of minority religious sect who owe their fortunes and influence to Assad family; efforts of his son and expected successor, Dr Bashar al-Assad, to trim hierarchy of many of old guard whose willingness to accept continuation of Assad dynasty was in question may have actually increased number of Alewites in positions of power; Alewite dominance is never openly discussed in Syria; map; photo (M)

headline: I.B.M. to Hire 1,000 for Database Unit
abstract: IBM says it will hire more than 1,000 people this year and next to develop and sell database software, as company tries to grab sales from Oracle Corp (S)

headline: Advertising Council Chooses Officers
abstract: Advertising Council of New York names John H Costello chairman, succeeding James G Oates; Costello has been vice chairman of council since 1997; Andrea Alstrup will serve as vice chairwoman (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Kohl Remains Defiant in Testimony to Parliament Inquiry
abstract: Former German Chancellor Helmut Kohl appears before parliamentary committee investigating financial misdeeds under his rule, saying he is victim of slander; stance is consistent with defiance Kohl, who was chancellor from 1982 to 19988, has shown since he admitted in December that he had taken about $1 million in undeclared and illicit payments from donors and used it to boster his Christian Democratic Party in formerly Communist eastern Germany; photo (M)

headline: Hostile Bid for Dexter Is Cut, to First Offer
abstract: International Specialty Products Inc lowers its hostile bid for Dexter Corp to original offer of $45 a share, or about $933 million, accusing Dexter of 'delaying tactics' and citing recent fluctuations in financial markets (S)

headline: Rich Nations Issue Blacklist Of Tax Havens
abstract: 29-member Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development issues list of 35 mostly exotic island getaways described as tax havens for companies and people who wish to evade actual tax payments or potential tax liabilities in home countries; identifies 47 other places that have potentially harmful tax laws; gives 35 havens year to overhaul laws or face sanctions (S)

headline: New York Life Sued Over Fees on Its Pensions
abstract: Top executives of the New York Life Insurance Co, including George J Trapp, executive vice president, are accused in racketeering lawsuit of enriching themselves by charging tens of millions of dollars in excess fees to the retirement plans that the insurer maintains for its workers and agents; suit was filed on behalf of retirement plans and James Mehling, former president of NY Life investment unit, Monitor Capital Advisors, who says he was fired in 1999 after uncovering scheme described in the suit; suit contends that pension and early retirement funds maintained for NY Life employees would have had hundreds of millions of dollars more in them if not for excessive fees; action is latest in growing number of suits brought by Eli Gottesdiener of law firm of Sprenger & Lang (M)

headline: DUTCH HOTEL COMPANY GETS OFFER
abstract: NH Hoteles SA, Spain, agrees to buy Dutch rival, Grand Hotel Krasnapolsky NV, for about 525 million euros in stock; NH will aslso assume debt of about 300 million euros (S)

headline: Army Rule Has Ivory Coast on Hands and Knees
abstract: Army remains in firm control in Ivory Coast since staging coup in December 1999 with no indication of when it may relinquish power; uncertainty stems from junta leader Gen Robert Guei, who is behaving more like presidential candidate despite earlier statements disclaiming any interest in power; country was for decades one of few African nations not to have experienced military rule and is still richest in French-speaking West Africa; map; photos (M)

headline: The Six-Year Curse Threatens, but This Time Mexico Is Bullish
abstract: Mexico has history of economic upheaval every six years, at end of every recent presdidential term; economists say that for once economy is strong enough to keep any disturbance caused by handover of power from becoming disaster; they credit Pres Ernesto Zedillo, himself an economist, who has spent last three years reshaping economy and building armor around country's finances to shield them from meltdown (M)

headline: Omnicom takes another seemingly fearless step to expand its interactive empire.
abstract: Omnicom Group, in another step to expand already extensive interactive empire, is investing in Eisnor Interactive, innovative agency that specializes in creating offline campaigns for online marketers; financial terms undisclosed (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Unemployment Rate Rose To 4.1 Percent Last Month  In the strongest signal yet that the booming economy is finally slowing, the Labor Department reported that the nation's private sector employers shed 116,000 jobs in May. It was the largest drop in more than eight years and the first decline since the economy began to soar in the mid-1990's.

headline: Group Says For-Profit Political Site Is Breaking the Law
abstract: April 20, 2000

headline: WORK PLACE MATERNITY RIGHTS PACT
abstract: International Labor Organization adopts pact that strengthens rights of women workers; accord extends maternity leaves from 12 to 14 weeks, guarantees women right to same jobs after their leaves, bars pregnancy tests for job applicants and strengthens breast feeding provisions (S)

headline: Taking His Jet and Going Home
abstract: Warren A. Stephens, chairman of the company whose holdings include the Stephens Inc. brokerage firm, has this message for the University of Arkansas: Move any football games back from Little Rock, my hometown, to Fayetteville, your more remote hometown, and I won't let you play with my jets any more.    For decades, the Razorbacks have divided their games between Little Rock and Fayetteville. The costs of renovating the Fayetteville stadium prompted the school to move about a game a year back from Little Rock to Fayetteville, effective this fall.

headline: RAMBUS SHARES UP 47% ON LICENSING AGREEMENT
abstract: Rambus Inc shares jump 47 percent after Toshiba Corp agrees to pay Rambus royalties for broader range of computer-memory designs (S)

headline: VIACOM PLANS TO REPURCHASE UP TO $1 BILLION OF STOCK
abstract: Viacom Inc says it will buy back up to $1 billion in its stock (S)

headline: Who wants to parody 'Millionaire'? There is no final answer.
abstract: Article on how media are capitalizing on popularity of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire, ABC game show that has been topping Nielsen ratings week after week with Regis Philbin as host; says campaigns for marketers as disparate as exercise clubs, discount retailers and banks have played off 'Millionaire' theme, complete with make-believe lifelines and variations on Philbin catch phrase, 'Is that your final answer?' photo (M)

headline: Foes in Congo Appeal For U.N. Peacekeepers
abstract: All sides in war in Congo appeal for United Nations to deploy peacekeepers swiftly following signing of latest cease-fire in 18-month-old conflict; factions for and against Pres Laurent Kabila appear militarily weary and financially pressed (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Fraying the Trade Ties; Politics in Taiwan Are Straining Business Links With China
abstract: Chinese government has put out word that Taiwan businessmen with ties to Taiwan's new Pres Chen Shui-bian or who favor independence for Taiwan are putting their China operations at risk; statement is widely interpreted as warning to computer maker Acer, regarded as unofficial spokesman for corporate Taiwan, and Acer founder Stan Shih; Stan Shih is one of several captains of industry in Taiwan who has been caught in treacherous political waters between Taiwan and China; for first time, China is scrutinizing political beliefs of Taiwan's business leaders and warning those who stray from official line that there is only one China; political analysts say crackdown could undermine historic role of commerce as bridge between Taiwan and China, binding countries closer even when they diverge politically; trade has been remarkably resistant to politics since China opened its doors to Taiwan two decades ago; in first quarter of 2000, while China was threatening military action if Taiwan elected Chen, Taiwan exported $6.2 billion of goods to China, 16 percent increase over 1999; it imported $1.3 billion, a 33 percent increase; Taiwan's investment in China is showing signs of weakness; graph; chart; photos (M)

headline: I.M.F. Is Expected to Ease Demands on Debtor Nations
abstract: International Monetary Fund managing director Horst Kohler says fund, which has ordered developing nations to enact wrenching reforms as price for emergency aid in recent years, is likely to curtail demands it makes of clients who borrow money in future; streamlining conditions IMF imposes on borrowers is one of changes Kohler is weighing as panel he commissioned to study role of the agency completes draft report; Clinton administration says it backs overhaul of process; photo (M)

headline: CHECKFREE IN DEAL FOR BANK OF AMERICA ONLINE ASSETS
abstract: CheckFree Holdings says it will buy Bank of America's online bill payment service; in exchange, Bank of America will receive 16 percent stake in CheckFree; stake, valued at $325 million, would make bank CheckFree's largest shareholder (S)

headline: The Case Against Retail Stocks
abstract: George Strachan, Goldman Sachs vice president, explains why his team of analysts have grown cautious about retailing stocks, even as Americans are shopping and buying at unprecedented rate; photo (M)

headline: Finding Out How Much Free Shipping Is Worth
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column reports on using site called freeshipping.com, which has search engine that points shoppers toward million products that site's 125 retail partners are willing to sell without charging shipping and handling fees; drawing (M)

headline: Regarding Sexism On the Job: Plus Ca Change...
abstract: Suddenly, the engineering workshops at Snecma S.A., the engine maker based in Paris, seem as pristine as a chapel. The nude photographs and girlie calendars that used to be plastered on some of the walls have disappeared into desk drawers or been tossed into the trash bin.    For that, the men in the department mostly have one of their few female colleagues to thank. Fabienne Lecore, an aerodynamics engineer, said she started arguing against the cheesecake from the moment she joined the company 13 years ago.

headline: Cisco and SBC Expect Alliance
abstract: Cisco Systems is expected to announce that it has entered into multibillion-dollar alliance with SBC Communications; executives at two companies say that SBC will be among largest buyers of Cisco's routers and switches that are used to build Internet's infrastructure; Cisco and SBC will co-market and co-sell their products and services; will also collaborate on joint research and product development (S)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Pentium 4 Chip Said to Run at 1.5 Gigahertz

headline: RISK OF ARMS RACE SEEN IN U.S. DESIGN OF MISSILE DEFENSE
abstract: American intelligence officials reportedly warn that limited national missile defense that Pres Clinton is considering could set off cold-war-style arms race between China, India and Pakistan; American officials say antimissile defense is not aimed at Beijing, but they acknowledge that system being designed could significantly undercut or even neutralize China's small nuclear force, which could lead China to add to its nuclear arsenal; say this could prompt China's regional rival, India, to do same, as could India's rival, Pakistan; Pres Clinton has said he plans to decide later this year whether to proceed with missile defense system based on four criteria: missile threat, technological viability of program, effect on arms control and cost; response of China and Russia is important factor in his decision; photo (M)

headline: Serb Opposition Leaders Going to Moscow to Ask Putin's Help
abstract: Serb opposition leaders emerge from private meetings and tell rally of fewer than 5,000 people that they will fly to Moscow to ask Russian help in moderating policies of Pres Slobodan Milosevic; gesture comes three days after government seizes Studio B television station and silences independent broadcasting, including radio B2-92; Milosevic's wife's party prepares anti-terrorism law that is expected to be used against opposition (M)

headline: French Couples Take Plunge That Falls Short of Marriage
abstract: Civil solidarity pact, new form of legal partnership originally intended for gay couples, is proving wildly popular in France; gives couples some, but not all, of benefits and responsibilities of marriage; gays are celebrating pact like marriage, while heterosexuals tend to treat it as trial run for marriage, and often do not even tell parents; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Invests in Digital Video Developer
abstract: Microsoft Corp will invest about $18 million in SeaChange International Inc in return for stake of less than 2 percente; companies will jointly develop technology to let video and audio be programmed once to run on both televisions and personal computers (S)

headline: GERMAN UTILITY MERGERS STYMIED
abstract: Antitrust regulators in Germany and Belgium block two big mergers in German power industry on grounds they stifle competition; RWE AG sought to purchase VEW AG for $4 billion, and Veba AG sought $14 billion merger with Viag AG (S)

headline: Of Forty-Niners, Oilmen And the Dot-Com Boom
abstract: Essay by Patricia Nelson Limerick on parallels and distinctions between mining or panning for gold in 1850's, digging for oil in early 1900's, and founding modern technology company now; drawing (M)

headline: TALKS ON ROVER RESCUE
abstract: Consortium seeking to acquire Britain's money-losing Rover Cars opens talks in London with BMW, Rover's owner, which has said it will close automaker if it cannot find a buyer this month; newest talks are with Phoenix Consortium, led by former Rover chief executive John Towers; photo (S)

headline: Everywhere but the Dinner Table
abstract: Recent speech at New York InfoTech Forum by Research In Motion Ltd chmn James Balsillie, creator of BlackBerry hand-held, wireless Internet device, prompts confessions from users who have become obsessively dependent on BlackBerry; Balsillie doubts device causes obsessive behavior, but concedes 'it definitely gives obsessive people an outlet' (M)

headline: TWO KOREAS AGREE TO FIRST MEETING OF THEIR LEADERS
abstract: South Korea and North Korea agree to June summit meeting between two countries; says Pres Kim Dae Jung will hold his first meeting with North Korea's reclusive leader, Kim Jong Il, in Pyongyang, North Korean capital, to talk about economic cooperation, reunification of separated families and political reconciliation; plans for 1994 summit meeting were scrapped on death of North Korean leader, Kim Il Sung, that year; North Korea recently established diplomatic relations with Italy and resumed talks with Japan for first time in years; summit meeting is announced simultaneously in South Korean and North Korean news media, in example of extraordinary degree of coordination between two countries whose armies still face off across 38th parallel; photo (M)

headline: PUTIN SUGGESTING ALTERNATIVE PLAN ON MISSILE DEFENSE
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin hints that Russia and US could collaborate on new ways to shoot down enemy missiles soon after they are launched, rather than in space, as proposed by US; idea seems to resemble plan known in US as 'boost phase defense,' which has been proposed by a number of arms control advocates, who say it would provide US, Europe and Russia with the protection that Clinton administration insists it needs from so-called rogue states; such a system would be little use against Russian nuclear force, making it far more acceptable to Russian military; administration officials react cautiously to suggestion (M)

headline: Justice Dept. Asks Appeals Judges to Let Supreme Court Act First in Microsoft Case
abstract: Justice Department files a brief with United States Court of Appeals aimed at persuading judges not to begin work on Microsoft Corp case until Supreme Court decides whether to take it; Microsoft wants appeal first heard by lower court, United States Circuit Court of Appeals for District of Columbia (M)

headline: MEDALLION FINANCIAL TO PURCHASE AMERITRANS CAPITAL
abstract: Medallion Financial Corp, which specializes in making taxicab-related loans, agrees to buy Ameritrans Capital Corp for about $16.9 million to create largest US taxi-medallion lender (S)

headline: From the Trade Debate: Democracy and Economics, Idealism and Politics
abstract: Excepts from remarks by Reps Richard Gephardt, J Dennis Hastert, David Bonior, Charlie Norwood and Thomas M Davis at House debate on bill to grant China permanent normal trading relations (M)

headline: A Sound Sleep and a Good Return
abstract: Some people who suffered through the Great Depression are disinclined to take investment risks, often to the dismay of their more market-savvy children; these people are ultraconservative investors who accept a low rate of return in exchange for guaranteed principle and a good night's sleep; drawing (M)

headline: Fallon Is Honored For Commercials
abstract: Minneapolis and New York offices of Fallon Worldwide win most honors in the agency category at ninth annual show sponsored by Association of Indepoendent Commercial Producers, NY, honoring work on television commercials (Advertising column) (S)

headline: SETBACK FOR MONSANTO SOYBEANS
abstract: Brazil's federal district court votes to uphold cautionary ban on sale of Monsanto Co's genetically modified soybeans until environmental impact study can be completed (S)

headline: The new business-to-business marketplaces are turning to the old hands for help in selling industrial goods.
abstract: Young business-to-business entrepreneurs are scouring industrial companies for sales force that can convince target customers to switch to Internet commerce; seek veterans in field who understand customers' discomfort; drawing (M)

headline: Uganda Cult's Mystique Finally Turned Deadly
abstract: Ugandan authorities say death toll has risen to at least 924 people among members of Movement for Restoration of Ten Commandments of God, making it highest death toll of any cult in modern history; police now speculate that some cult members rebelled and asked for their money and belongings back when world did not end on Jan 1, as cult leaders had prophesized; photos; map (M)

headline: MARKS & SPENCER CUTS PAYOUT
abstract: British retailer Marks & Spencer, for first time in its 106-year history, cuts its dividend, as part of struggle to revive profit and fight competition; reduces dividend from 14.4 pence, to 9 pence; cut triggers jump of 40 pence in its stock, to 260.75 pence; photo of chairman Luc Vandevelde (S)

headline: A Screenful of Windows
abstract: Letter by Michael Meisels responds to May 25 Q&&A column; says Windows operating system has a built-in shortcut to close a window and all its parent windows

headline: Uranium Enrichment Plant In Ohio Chosen for Closing
abstract: United States Enrichment Corp, private company that runs nation's only two uranium enrichment plants, says it will close one of them in a year, in Portsmouth, Ohio, because of high costs and depressed market for reactor fuel; other plant, which is in Paducah, Ky, will remain open; decision to close Ohio plant, which would eliminate about 1,000 jobs, draws criticism from Congress; Energy Department, which sold plants two years ago, has asked questions recently about whether shutdown is advisable; under privatization law, plants were supposed to remain open until 2004 (M)

headline: Unisys Evaluating Possible Conflict
abstract: Unisys Corp is evaluating its relationship with Bozell Group after eight years; billings estimated at $20 million; reason is decision by Unisys competitor Compaq Computer Corp to hire FCB Worldwide as its agency; FCB and Bozell are both owned by True North Communications (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Economic Scene; Forecasting an election; at Iowa you can even bet on it.
abstract: Hal R Varian (Economic Scene) column on how Iowa Electronic Markets at Tippie College of Business at University of Iowa is forecasting Presidential election; says Iowa Electronic Markets involves real money, although maximum opening balance for trading account is limited to $500; says Commodity Futures Trading Commission has ruled that as long as IEM conforms to certain guidelines, commission will not intervene; Yale University macroeconometrician Ray Fair's system for predicting outcome of race noted; graph (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: Networking in Southern California; 'Anti-Silicon Valley' Broadcom Chief Rules in the Wired World
abstract: Interview with Henry T Nicholas 3d, co-founder and chief executive of Broadcom Corp, who likes to think of his company, based in Irvine, Calif, as the antithesis of a Silicon Valley company and himself as the antithesis of the new age, new economy Zen master; he directs, and subordinates follow, right down to the dress code; table of biographical data; photos (M)

headline: 'Millionaire' Makes Sortie Into 'E.R.' Zone
