abstract: ABC quietly lets celebrity edition of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire run eight minutes long, just enough to blunt start of NBC's strongest series, ER; move lets ABC show beat ER in its first half-hour; photo (M)

headline: 360networks in Expansion
abstract: 360networks Inc agrees to acquire one million square feet of space to house computer networking equipment in Los Angeles, Atlanta and Dallas from Telecom Real Estate Services for $144 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: At Extra-Special Time, Jubilation in Jammed Rome
abstract: Despite shiny veneer of modern comfort and efficiency, Holy Year 2000 Jubilee in Vatican during Holy Week is laced with same kind of humble piety and awe that drew Jubilee pilgrims to Rome in 1300; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TESORO PETROLEUM INC., San Antonio, an oil refiner and fuel seller, agreed to buy eight gasoline stations in the western United States from closely held Gary-Williams Retail Co. for an undisclosed price.    ROHM & HAAS CO., Philadelphia, the largest United States specialty-chemical maker, agreed to buy a unit of Mitsubishi Chemical Corp. that makes chemicals used in the production of semiconductors. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. and 17 States Propose Dividing Microsoft in Two  The Justice Department and 17 states asked a federal judge to split Microsoft into two companies, one that would make computer operating systems and the other including applications software, like the word processor Word and the spreadsheet program Excel, and Microsoft's Internet properties.

headline: Net Journalism Tries to Regroup After Layoffs And Setbacks
abstract: Web journalism is usually cast as savior or savage. For some people, online journalism is a path to interactive enlightenment and economic liberty. But to the puritans of the old media world, Web journalists are apostates who have confused liberty with license and whose delusional disregard for profit can end only in self-immolation.    It was hard for the puritans not to act smug last week.

headline: Private Sector; To Academia, and the Spotlight
abstract: Joseph E Stiglitz, who resigned as chief economist of World Bank in January after clashes with officials of International Monetary Fund and Treasury Sec Lawrence H Summers over how to best support developing economies, sums up his experience by saying, 'Government believes in negotiated truth' (S)

headline: Joining Sri Lanka's Sword: Might of Censor's Pen
abstract: Sri Lanka's chief censor, Ariya Rubasinghe, is purging criticism of government's faltering war on separatist rebels from newspapers, radio and television; government imposed what journalists there say is harshest censorship of press ever; it also banned public rallies and trade union strikes that are deemed contrary to national security; previous governments in Sri Lanka have also clamped down during country's 17-year war with Liberation Tigers, but new regulations are more far-reaching and include harsh new penalties; photo (M)

headline: McKesson HBOC to Form Online Division
Religious Party Pledges to Quit The Coalition Cabinet in Israel
abstract: Shas Party, in new show of brinkmanship, says its ministers will quit Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak's governing coalition at next cabinet meeting on order from its rabbis; Barak delays cabinet meeting to let talks continue (M)

headline: He Didn't Say It. He Knew It All Along.
abstract: Robert J Shiller, Yale economics professor and author of Irrational Exuberance, discusses his view that Wall Street investors are driven by not by rational analysis but by impulse, herd behavior, dinner party chatter, intuition, media hype and fear of being left out; argues that stock market indexes are almost always too high or too low, that they are now reaching their highest peak ever and that if history is a guide, the stock market is due for a decline that might last for years; drawings; photos; graphs (L)

headline: Singapore Telecom Renews Expansion Efforts
abstract: Singapore Telecommunications, one month after losing bid to buy Cable and Wireless HKT to Pacific Century CyberWorks, renews effort to become first pan-Asian telecommunications company, this time by turning its attention to Malaysia; Singapore Telecom is in talks to buy 14.5 percent stake in Time Engineering, unit of Renong of Malaysia, for 649 million ringgit, or $171 million; Singapore Telecom is considering buying 40 percent of Time dotCom, spinoff of Time Engineering; photo (M)

headline: Maytag to Lay Off 120
abstract: Maytag Corp to lay off 120 workers in its laundry appliances division, 4.8 percent of workers at plant, because of slower washer sales (S)2

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Big 3 Warn Dealers About Net Brokers

headline: Economic Scene; Work visas are allowing Washington to sidestep immigration reform.
abstract: Alan B Krueger (Economic Scene) column on how work visas under temporary visa program, H-1B, are allowing US lawmakers to sidestep immigration reform; says number of skilled temporary foreign workers who enter US each year under H-1B visa program is growing compared with annual influx of permanent legal immigrant workers; holds if immigration reform is off the table, it makes economic sense to increase number of skilled immigrants by issuing visas; adds economic principles also suggest that playing field between H-1B workers and rest of work force should be leveled; says foreign workers under program are not protected from exploitation on the job; graph (M)

headline: What Goes Around . . .
abstract: Edmund and Kathleen Bennett, founders of Bennett Funding Group, accuse Richard Breeden, group's court-appointed trustee, of manipulating its books in plot to force it into insolvency; prosecutors say collapsed company bilked 12,000 investors out of $700 million in huge Ponzi scheme; Bennetts' son, Patrick R, has been convicted on 49 charges and his brother, Michael, has pleaded guilty to conspiracy and other charges in connection with case (M)

headline: In Public Relations, 25% Admit Lying
abstract: PR Week survey of public relations executives about ethics in their industry finds 25 percent admitted lying on job, 39 percent said they exaggerated and 44 percent felt uncertain of ethics of assigned task; photo (M)

headline: AIRLINES IN A PUSH FOR SHORTER LINES
abstract: Airlines are spending tens of millions of dollars on new technology in hopes of whisking passengers through terminals more quickly, redefining what executives glumly call 'the airport experience'; automated systems being installed by Continental, Delta, Northwest and Alaska Airlines will allow passengers to print own boarding passes and allow direct wireless communications with reservations desks; business travelers are currently main beneficiaries of improvements, but much of new technology will eventually available to all passengers; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Assad's Son Gets Syrian Party's Blessing
abstract: Syria's Baath Party, support beneath 30-year rule of Hafez al-Assad, gathers to pledge allegiance to his son, Bashar, and to vest him formally with political authority he has quietly exercised in past two years of his father's illness; party delegates indicate their readiness to install younger Assad, an ophthalmologist by training, as member of their national governing board and to endorse him for job of president; Bashar Assad has expressed interest in bringing Syria into modern information age; he may be limited in his ability to impose modernization on hidebound one-party system that has run nation's economy and social life for its own benefit; photo (M)

headline: CADBURY SEEKS KRAFT CANDY UNIT
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes is in talks to acquire French candy and chewing gum business of Kraft; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Seoul Leader Lands in North for Meeting
abstract: South Korean Pres Kim Dae Jung, arrives in North Korean capital of Pyongyang for first-ever series of talks between leaders of both countries almost exactly 50 years since start of Korean War; receives warm welcome from Pres Kim Jong Il and throng of thousands on arrival; South Koreans harbor sense of hope about visit, but also deep uncertainties about dealing with North, one of world most secretive and unpredictable nations; efforts at rapprochement between both nations over past two years described; map; photos (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of advertising account changes (S)

headline: LANDRY'S SEAFOOD ENDS PLAN TO BUY RAINFOREST CAFE
abstract: Landry's Seafood Restaurants ends plans to buy Rainforest Cafe after Rainforest shareholders reject sale (S)

headline: PrivateSector; The Other Dell's Silicon Venture
abstract: Interview with Adam Dell, venture capitalist who specializes in fledgling Internet companies; he is brother of Michael Dell, founder and chief executive of Dell Computer; photo (M)

headline: DOMINION RESOURCES SELLS BRITISH POWER UNIT STAKE
abstract: Dominion Resources agrees to sell its 80 percent stake in British unit Corby Power Ltd to PowerGen PLC for about $80 million (S)

headline: New U.S. Farm Subsidy Plan Is Contrary to European Position
abstract: Clinton administration introduces sweeping new proposal at World Trade Organization to change way governments subsidize farmers, challenging European Union's extensive agricultural subsidies; American plan would simplify financial support to farmers and reduce or end disparities in tariffs to increase market openings for agricultural goods from other countries (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; AZTECA IN PACT WITH NBC
abstract: Mexico's second-largest broadcaster, TV Azteca, and the NBC unit of the General Electric Company have dropped three-year-old suits charging breach of contract. TV Azteca agreed to pay NBC $46.2 million, while NBC will buy a 1 percent stake in TV Azteca, worth $26.2 million. NBC also agreed to invest in the Internet company Todito.com, which is 50 percent owned by TV Azteca. TV Azteca had accused NBC of failing to provide programming and management assistance agreed to in a three-year contract signed in 1994, while NBC said that TV Azteca never paid for programming it did receive.   Dan Fineren (NYT)

headline: After Bad Year, Xerox Ousts Top Executive
abstract: Xerox Corp, besieged by competition and battered stock price, ousts its chief executive G Richard Thoman; Anne M Mulcahy, head of company's general markets organization, is named president and chief operating officer; because those were titles Thoman held before being named chief executive, Mulcahy's promotion seems to elevate her to heir apparent; chairman Paul A Allaire and Thoman comment; photo (M)

headline: Heinz Profit Climbs 9.8% In 4th Quarter
abstract: H J Heinz Co says fiscal fourth-quarter profit rose 9.8 percent on lower manufacturing costs and increased sales; profit in quarter ended May 3 rose to $226.4 million from $206.1 million; sales rose 4.9 percent, to $2.59 billion (M)

headline: House Backs Bill To Ban Net Fees
abstract: US House unanimously endorses bill that would prohibit federal fees on Internet access (S)

headline: Kmart Puts Account Up for Review
abstract: Kmart Corp unexpectedly places its advertising account in review after more than five years at Campbell Mithun; billings estimated at $100 million (Advertising column) (S)

headline: A Tangled Web
abstract: Letter by Rica Mendes-Barry reponds to April 13 article on Priceline grocery service policies; comments on Priceline's system of catching people who make illegal product substitutions

headline: NO MORE LUNCH AT SEOUL EXCHANGE
abstract: Korea Stock Exchange to abolish its lunch-hour break, move delayed because of protests from unionized workers (S)

headline: DIGITAL INSIGHT, FINANCIAL SERVICES COMPANY, EXPANDS
abstract: Digital Insight Corp says it is entering online lending market by acquiring privately held AnyTime Access in $140 million stock deal (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: A Mass of Nuclear Friction; Tension and Mistrust at New High for British Complex
abstract: British Nuclear Fuels, government-owned company that operates Sellafield nuclear power complex in England's northwestern coast, is under pressure to abandon its disputed fuel reprocessing business and focus its attention on disposing of waste and cleaning up nuclear sites; workers at plant were found to have falsified documents involving fuel rods that were in transit to Japan; it was first shipment of such fuel rods to Japan, crucial customer of company; discovery coincided with efforts by company to secure government approval of plutonium processing at complex designed to turn out 'mixed oxide' fuel--blend of uranium and plutonium; John Storer, engineer at plant, says timing was disaster; things turned out far worse than Storer imagined, causing equivalent of commercial meltdown at complex, which has been cauldron of environmental, commercial and social tension ever since opening of first unit; graph; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LASER VISION CENTERS INC., St. Louis, which provides lasers used in vision-correction surgery, said it bought the closely held Southeast Medical Inc., Mandeville, La., which provides mobile cataract services, to expand its cataract-surgery business to 34 states.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar gains on expectations Federal Reserve will continue to raise interest rates, increasing returns on dollar deposits; in New York, the euro settles at 89.50 cents, down from 90.13 cents; graph (S)

headline: FIGHTING RESUMES NEAR THE CAPITAL OF SIERRA LEONE
abstract: Sierra Leone edged back toward war today as government and rebel forces fought each other in a town not too far from the capital here, and the United Nations force that is supposed to keep a peace between them sank deeper into disarray.    Panic spread through Freetown early today after the United Nations force mistakenly announced that rebels of the Revolutionary United Front were advancing on the capital by using human shields and stood less than 15 miles from this seaside capital. Even after the United Nations retracted its announcement in the predawn hours, the streets of Freetown remained tense through the day.

headline: Buying Used Books Online
abstract: Cheryl C Cigan letter on May 4 article notes most sellers of used books allow returns

headline: Swiss Vote for Closer Links to Their Neighbors
abstract: Swiss voters break with isolationist tradition and approve by two-thirds majority set of agreements with European Union that will link nation more closely with neighbors; government hopes accords are first step toward joining 15-country union; agreement bolsters Swiss economy through trade and commerce without binding it any closer politically, for now, to rest of Europe (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: House Approves Measure To Repeal Inheritance Tax  The House voted to repeal the federal inheritance tax, drawing a veto threat from President Clinton even as Democrats joined Republicans in recognizing the issue's political potency. The vote was 279-136, with 65 Democrats voting in favor.    Republican leaders, who have made repeal of what they call the ''death tax'' one of their main priorities, said they were driven in part by a desire to help owners of small businesses and family farms, who have long complained that the estate tax made it costly if not impossible to pass their holdings along to another generation. But Republicans also said they viewed the tax as inherently unfair and even immoral, no matter who pays it. [Page A1.]

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DANA CORP.,  Toledo, Ohio, the largest maker of light-truck axles in the world, said it planned to sell its Chelsea Power Take-Off unit, a maker of auxiliary power equipment for trucks.    MASTEC INC.,  Miami, which helps companies build and maintain communications networks, received a five-year contract worth at least $100 million to help build a fiber optic network for the Comcast Corp., Philadelphia, a cable television company.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: At Cisco, Options Machine Churns Unfettered
abstract: Cisco Systems, one of three most valuable companies in world, is heavy user of stock options for its executives and other employees; its chief executive, John T Chambers, was granted options valued at $44 million in 1999, and now worth $159 million; some institutional investors and management experts worry about long-term cost of giving employees large, discounted stakes in their companies; photo; graph (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE; EASTERN EUROPE OIL MERGER
abstract: Hungarian oil and gas company MOL announces it will buy 36.2 percent stake in its Slovak counterpart Slovnaft for $262 million (S)

headline: VIBRANT CANADIAN GROWTH
abstract: Canada's gross domestic product grew at annual rate of 4.9 percent in first quarter, down from 5.1 percent in fourth quarter of 1999; exports grew 3.3 percent and outlays for plants and equipment were up 2.7 percent (S)

headline: Vaduz Journal; The Prince and His Black Sheep: This Is No Liechtenstein Fairy Tale
abstract: German magazine Der Spiegel in Nov 1999 published what it said were details of German intelligence report accusing Liechtenstein banks of being tied to Sicilian Mafia, Latin American drug lords and Russian gangs; Prince Hans Adam II, whose ancestors bought country in 1699 from Austrian crown, accuses Germany of seeking to ruin Leichtenstein as tax haven; map; photos (M)

headline: Teletubbies Switch Fast-Food Alliance
abstract: Itsy Bitsy Entertainment Co, part of Handleman Co, has decided that Teletubbies fast-food promotion for 2000 will be in partnership with McDonald's Corp; previous promotion came last year with Burger King unit of Diageo PLC (S)

headline: New-Media Threat From the 1930's
abstract: David Nasaw's new biography of William Randolph Hearst holds he complained in 1930 that newspaper executives were responding too slowly to competitive threat from radio; photo (S)

headline: AN OLIVETTI MOVE ON BOND INTEREST
abstract: Olivetti, in move to control future borrowing costs, will link interest on $17 billion of existing debt to credit ratings, paying more if ratings fall and less if they recover (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Japan's Nikkei Index Posts A Decrease of 3.7 Percent  Japanese stocks fell as sweeping changes in the makeup of the benchmark Nikkei index on Monday forced investors who track it to raise money to buy the new components. The Nikkei index of 225 issues declined 706.64 points, or 3.7 percent, to 18,252.68. For the week, the Nikkei fell 11 percent, its biggest one-week loss since 1990.

headline: Conde Nast, the League of Women Voters and Oldsmobile join forces to urge women to vote.
abstract: Conde Nast, League of Women Voters and Oldsmobile are joining forces to urge women to vote in Presidential election; photo (Advertising column) (M)

headline: HITACHI FINANCIAL MERGER
abstract: Hitachi Credit Corp and Hitachi Leasing Ltd will merge in effort to become leading provider of leasing services and consumer loan products (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: ERNST & YOUNG, New York, named Beth A. Brooke, national director for tax consulting services, to the new post of vice chairwoman for strategy and corporate development for North America.    INVESTORFORCE.COM,Wayne, Pa., which offers online content, research and analysis tools for asset management, named Robert Hull chief financial officer and chief operating officer.

headline: Movies Fit for Television
abstract: Stanley Rose reply to A M Sullivan's Mar 30 letter holds DVD format shows films on television screen exactly as originally filmed and shown in movie theater

headline: Stocks Continue Sharp Sell-Off In World Markets
abstract: April 14 rout on Wall Street reverberates across Asia, with so-called old economy stocks sliding together with technology issues as investors worry about fallout from declining stocks on United States economy and nation's demand for Asian exports; photo (M)

headline: Dam in Turkey May Soon Flood A '2nd Pompeii'
abstract: Article on frantic efforts by archaeologists in Turkey to excavate ruins and bring out beautiful Roman mosaics before site is submerged by water that is rising inexorably behind new dam; photos; map; Mehmet Onal says there are hundreds more villas and priceless artifacts under earth, but provincial governor says he is powerless to stop inundation of 'second Pompeii'; items removed range from five-foot-high bronze statue of Mars to 65,000 ceramic impressions and seals, and mosaics depicting scenes of Greek mythology; ancient city of Zeugma had 70,000 residents and was base for Roman legion at edge of Roman Empire; dam half mile from site is part of multibillion-dollar Southeast Anatolian Project, centerpiece of Turkey's development plans (M)

headline: LOSS FOR TOKYO PHONE COMPANY
abstract: Tokyo-based cellular phone company Hikari Tsushin Inc reports operating loss of 12.9 billion yen ($123.6 million) in six months ended Feb 29; graph (S)

headline: New Stock Offerings That Are Planned During the Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Activeworlds.com Inc., Newburyport, Mass., 1.2 million units, each consists of one share and one Series B warrant. H. D. Brous & Co.

headline: Israel Abruptly Halts Reprisals on Lebanon
abstract: Israeli government halts its reprisal bombings in Lebanon even after another cross-border guerrilla offensive; Israel will need international backing in its coming troop withdrawal from southern Lebanon; American government urges Israel and Hezbollah to restrain themselves and expresses disapproval of both sides' attacks on civilians and civilian targets; Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak and his government faces pressure from right-wing opposition to bomb again and more intensely, but opposition is not strong; map (M)

headline: Nortel-Hewlett Venture
abstract: Nortel Networks Corp and Hewlett-Packard Co agree to create devices and services jointly for wireless-Internet access; Nortel says it will add 2,000 high-technology jobs in Europe as it builds new wireless centers in Spain and Germany and Internet laboratories in Norway and Sweden (S)

headline: Putin to Visit North Korea; U.S. ABM Plan May Be Target
abstract: Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin plans to visit North Korea next month, move that underscores his active foreign policy and seems calculated to counter Clinton administration's plan for a national missile defense; announcement comes on heels of Putin's meeting with Pres Clinton in Moscow, in which the two leaders found themselves at odds over administration's plan for a limited antimissile system; Korea visit is expected to provide Putin with opportunity to make case that diplomacy, not missile defense, is the way to cope with emerging missile threat from North Korea and to challenge idea that North Korea is a 'rogue state,' description that US has used to justify its antimissile plans (M)

headline: Shut Out No More: Damaged Funds Reopen
abstract: Comment on losses suffered by mutual fund portfolios during recent Nasdaq market selloff (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Percent           Yesterday   Day Ago   Year Ago       Prime rate   9.00   9.00   7.75        Discount rate   5.50   5.50   4.50        Federal funds   5.31   6.18   4.49        3-month T-bills   5.63   5.64   4.26        6-month T-bills   5.74   5.76   4.36        10-yr. T-infl.   3.97   3.98   3.90        10-yr. T-note   6.05   6.04   5.13        30-yr. T-bond   5.91   5.93   5.50        Telephone bd.   8.05   8.12   7.27        Municipal bds.   5.96   5.92   5.23          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Should Microsoft's Fate Be in Private Hands?
abstract: Economist Robert E Hall suggests that Justice Department, having won antitrust ruling against Microsoft Corp, should leave remedies to be determined by private suits against company; says consumers may have been overcharged over $7 billion in recent years because of company's anticompetitive behavior; Robert Litan (Bookings Institution) rejects proposal (M)

headline: Two Steps Forward, Two Steps Back
abstract: Stocks pulled in different directions last week, rising on news that retail sales fell, indicating Federal Reserve's interest-rate hikes have succeeded in slowing the economy, and falling on fears that economic slowdown will hurt corporate profits (M)

headline: Motorola and Flextronics Sign Production Deal
abstract: June 1, 2000

headline: For the South, a TV Stunner; in the North, Fanfare Is Lacking
abstract: Deluge of remarkable scenes from South Korean Pres Kim Dae Jung's visit to Pyongyang for summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Il keeps South Koreans locked to their television sets all day long and far into night; but people in North see only sparse and carefully edited coverage of historic event that includes no quotes from visiting head of state; photo of South Korea's first lady Lee Hee Ho, embracing her former teacher Kim Ji Han in their first encounter in more than 60 years (M)

headline: New-Home Sales Hit 5-Month Low in April
abstract: Commerce Department reports new-home sales declined 5.8 percent in April, to annual rate of 909,000 units; sales rose 5.8 percent in March; median price of new home fell 2.2 percent, to $161,400 in April--lowest since it was $160,000 in October--from $165,000 a month earlier; manufacturing index of National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago fell to 53.9 in May--lowest since September--from 56.5 in April; Conference Board's leading indicators index dropped 0.1 percent in April after rising 0.1 percent in March and falling 0.3 percent in February; graphs (M)

headline: CELOTEX SELLS GYPSUM WALLBOARD AND CEILING TILE UNITS
abstract: Celotex Corp sells its gypsum wallboard and ceiling tile businesses to British firm BPB PLC for $345 million (S)

headline: Rounding Up a Pair of Mules
abstract: Letter by Angela Belt praises June 1 article on buying shoes on Internet

headline: Gephardt Says China Trade Bill Will Erode U.S. Influence
abstract: Rep Richard A Gephardt, House Democratic leader, says he would oppose permanent normal trade relations with China to maintain American leverage over Beijing's behavior on human rights and religious liberties; says America cannot trust Chinese government to make progress on its own, and should not surrender its ability to influence Chinese policy through trade; Gephardt's position is at odds with virtually every senior Democrat in his party, from Pres Clinton and Vice Pres Al Gore to Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle; Gephardt's position comes as no surprise, given his strong ties to organized labor, which opposes measure (M)

headline: World Bank Cites Itself in Study of Africa's Bleak Performance
abstract: World Bank study finds people in sub-Saharan Africa, region devastated by war, corruption and disease, live less well now than in 1960's; study, prepared jointly with United Nations and African development institutions, holds aid donors, including bank, share in blame, with heavy flow of aid doing little to ignite sustained economic growth; notes bank has reinvented how it manages aid (M)

headline: ADC IN $200 MILLION DEAL FOR CENTIGRAM
abstract: ADC Telecommunications Inc agrees to pay $200 million in stock and cash to acquire Centigram Communications Corp (S)

headline: Clinton Issues Order to Ease Availability of AIDS Drugs in Africa
abstract: Pres Clinton issues executive order making AIDS drugs available far more cheaply throughout sub-Saharan Africa, against wishes of United States pharmaceutical industry; executive order declares that United States government will not seek to interfere with countries in that region that violate American patent law in order to provide AIDS drugs at lower prices; order extends to most of Africa special arrangement provided last year to South Africa; it allows African countries to either license local comapnies to produce generic versions or import drugs from third countries where they are available at lower cost (M)

headline: Chirac Seeks Shorter Term For President
abstract: French Pres Jacques Chirac proposes that presidential term be shortened from seven years to five, move that could profoundly change nature of French politics and help him in next elections; long opponent of change, he now now believes cutting term is necessary to modernize country's democracy; opinion polls indicate 75 percent of French population favors change; shorter term has been proposed by presidential candidates in last three decades, but their enthusiasm waned once they assumed office (M)

headline: Microsoft Wins Year's Reprieve From Penalties
abstract: Federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, trial judge in Microsoft antitrust case, unexpectedly delays sweeping restrictions on company's business practices until higher court affirms them; restrictions, ranging from features of its software to relations with customers and rivals, were to take effect in 11 weeks; were part of his order that also called for breakup of company; stay is issued as case is sent to Supreme Court for direct review; Microsoft lauds decision; had argued for weeks that conduct restrictions would cause grievous harm to company and its customers; Justice Department also praises move; says it is of particular importance to national interest (M)

headline: Prudential Ponders Stake in Japanese Insurer
abstract: Prudential Insurance Co of America tentatively agrees to take 20 percent stake in Kyoei Life Insurance Co, one of Japan's many faltering life insurers; Japanese insurer will receive cash infusion of up to 30 billion yen, or about $277 million (M)

headline: Photo Bought on the Web May Show Emily Dickinson
abstract: Prof Philip Gura has found photograph that may show 19th century poet Emily Dickinson at age 25 or 30 and is displaying it on Internet; will compare photo with her only known photo, which shows her at 17; photo (S))

headline: Buying Used Books Online
abstract: Forrest Proper letter lauds May 4 article on shopping for used books on line

headline: 11 G.I.'s Hurt As Serbs Protest An Arms Arrest
abstract: Eleven American soldiers are injured in southern Kosovo by angry crowd of Serbian villagers protesting Serb's arrest for illegal weapons possession; Polish peacekeeper and interpreter are also hurt after violence erupts in routine patrol procedure in Sevce (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: ASIA    INDONESIA: ACEH ACCORD -- Indonesia and pro-independence rebels in Aceh province said they would sign a three-month cease-fire, raising hopes of an end to a decades-long conflict that has killed thousands of civilians. But the Free Aceh Movement said the deal to be signed by mid-month did not mean they were giving up their struggle to end Jakarta's rule over the province. The government and the rebels are scheduled to sign a memorandum of understanding in Geneva on May 12.    (Reuters)

headline: MetLife Issues Nearly 500 Million Shares to Policyholders
abstract: Metropolitan Life Insurance Co issues nearly 500 million shares to more than nine million policyholders, instantly making company's shares the most widely held in America; sells additional 202 million shares to investors at initial price of $14.25; shares finish day up nearly 8 percent, at $15.375; photos (M)

headline: Indonesian Ferry With 500 Aboard Vanishes Without Trace
abstract: Overloaded Indonesian ferry appears to have sunk in heavy seas, and officials say they fear loss of nearly 500 people, many of whom were fleeing religion-based killings in remote Maluku islands; rescuers say they have found no trace of ferry or any survivors, nearly 24 hours after receiving last distress message; ferry was on rute from Halmahera Island, where as many as 200 Christian villagers were killed week earlier in continuing fighting between Christians and Muslims; map (M)

headline: Turkish Region Recalls Massacre of Armenians
abstract: Few resident of Elazig, once center of Armenian life in what is now eastern Turkey, share doubts of others in Turkey that 1915 slaughter of Armenians occurred; cite accounts told by grandparents; most people in rest of Turkey know little about killings, with Turkish textbooks stressing only that Armenian militants were rebelling against crumbling Ottoman Empire and ignoring or discounting killings of hundreds of thousands of civilians after abortive revolt; conflicts over how to deal with episode have spurred worldwide propaganda war between Armenia and Turkey; map; photo (M)

headline: PMC-SIERRA BUYS THE REST OF MALLEABLE FOR $229 MILLION
abstract: PMC-Sierra Inc, designer of computer chips for communications and networking equipment, to buy remainder of Malleable Technologies, chip maker, for $229.3 million in stock; PMC-Sierra will pay 1.25 million shares for the 85 percent of Malleable it does not already own (S)

headline: Amtran Orders Jets From Boeing
abstract: Amtran Inc., parent of the discount carrier American Trans Air Inc., has ordered 47 jetliners from the Boeing Company valued at $2.9 billion to replace aging aircraft and expand its fleet.    The order includes 37 of Boeing's 737-800 jetliners and 10 of the 757-300's, partly financed by Boeing's capital arm and two leasing companies. Amtran, which flies under the name ATA to 27 United States cities from hubs in Chicago and Indianapolis, will lease 17 of the 737-800's from aircraft lessors and purchase the other 30 planes from Boeing.

headline: UKRAINE CONSENTS TO SHUT CHERNOBYL BEFORE YEAR'S END
abstract: Pres Clinton leaves Russia for Ukraine on last leg of final European trip as President; addressed Russian Parliament before departure, urging legislators not to reject Washington's proposal for limited national missile defense and to make changes necessary for full participation in global trade; is welcomed in Kiev by Ukraine Pres Leonid Kuchma, who uses occasion to announce planned closing on December 15 of Chernobyl nuclear power station, site of worst radiation accident in history; says Clinton has pledged to solicit Group of Seven industrialized nations and Russia for help in shouldering costs of shutdown; Clinton pledges additional $78 million in new American aid; addessses thousands gathered in St Michael's Square; photo (M)

headline: U.S. and 28 States Plan Attack Against Promissory-Note Fraud
abstract: Federal and state authorities say they will join forces in fighting fixed-rate investment frauds that bilk thousands of American investors, particularly older people, out of hundreds of millions of dollars a year; cases involve promissory notes--investments that typically involve loan to a company in exchange for fixed rate of return; officials estimate that more than 3,000 Americans were victims of promissory-note fraud last year; Securities and Exchange Commission and 28 attorneys general say they plan to dedicate more resources to investigation and prosecution of these cases; regulators in Michigan brought charges earlier this year against IRM Corp, accusing it of bilking 2,435 people out of more than $82 million through fraudulent promissory-note investments; in New York, prosecutors working for Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, file civil suit against two insurance agents in Kingston, NY, Frank Fucilo and Tiber Tomshaw; James McNerlin of Kingston explains how he lost $103,000 investing with Fucilo; photo (M)

headline: A Miffed Moscow Means Headaches for Ikea
abstract: Ikea opens its first Russian store in Khimki; customers throng store, backing up traffic for three miles; completion of overpass that would ease flow of traffic is blocked by Moscow city government; Moscow roadblock is reminder of worst aspects of doing business in Russia, where laws and bureaucrats can be arbitrary, rules can change quickly, and corruption is always a problem; city's refusal to relent is a negative signal for other foreign investors; photos (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: UNIVERSAL DISPLAY, Ewing, N.J., a developer of flat-panel displays, was named the prime contractor of a $1 million contract from the Department of Defense to make flexible, lightweight display materials.

headline: When Referring to Wireless in Europe, Use the Future Tense
abstract: Investors given free Internet-equipped Ericsson cellular phones at technology conference, Barcelona, Spain, quickly discover that wireless application technology is still far from ready to attract mass market; experience dampens somewhat hype at conference about wireless application protocol; drawing (M)

headline: Philippine Conglomerates to Create Joint Internet Purchasing Site
abstract: Philippine Conglomerates to Create Joint Internet Purchasing Site

headline: Quality Time (and Diapers) at 10 Downing
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair, nudged in public by his wife Cherie to take some of paternity leave his government has just authorized for British parents, cancels public appearances for week to spend time with her and new son Leo; photo (S)

headline: Homework Help From an Expert
abstract: B J Pinchbeck, 13, comments on the Web site for homework help that he and his father built when he was 9; photo (S)

headline: Estee Lauder Buys Stake in Hair Salon
abstract: Estee Lauder Companies purchases majority stake in Bumble & Bumble LLC hair salon and cosmetics manufacturing business for undisclosed price (S)

headline: Knight Errant Or Erring? Sotheby's Tale
abstract: Profile of A Alfred Taubman, who resigned in February as chairman of Sotheby's and is now stepping down as director of art auction house; focuses on Taubman's alleged involvement in what Goverment prosecutors say was scheme between Sotheby's and its chief rival, Christie's, to split business and fix commissions; Christie's has as much as acknowledged antitrust violations by entering government program that promises leniency to first conspirator in antitrust trust cases to confess; no one has been charged, and much about investigation remains murky; Taubman's business career, which began in 1950, detailed; chronology; photos (M)

headline: Norwegian Diplomat Killed
abstract: A gunfight between Yemeni police officers and four kidnappers on Saturday left a Norwegian diplomat dead, just hours after he and his son were taken hostage, Norway's Foreign Ministry said today.   Gudbrand Stuve, 44, who was kidnapped while touring the region with his family, was shot after the police stopped his captors at a checkpoint outside Yemen's capital, Sana, the ministry said. Mr. Stuve's 9-year-old son was not injured.

headline: International Paper Offers $6.2 Billion for Champion
abstract: International Paper Co offers to buy Champion International Corp for cash and stock worth $6.2 billion, or $64 a share, two months after Champion agreed to be acquired by Finnish paper giant UPM-Kymmene Corp (M)

headline: Life in South Hard for North Koreans
abstract: South Korean government officials say 900 North Koreans who defected to South Korea over past 20 years have failed to adapt to life in free world, despite generous financial aid, job training and other assistance; their difficulties illustrate deep disparities between two Koreas since they went to war 50 years ago, and demonstrate how difficult it would be to reunite Korean peninsula; most North Korean defectors never reach South Korea; they live under conditions in China almost equally as harsh as those they fled, with little or no hope of reaching South Korea; photo; map (M)

headline: QANTAS CONSIDERS SUPERJUMBO JET
abstract: Australia's largest airline, Qantas Airways, is 'looking very seriously' at Airbus Industrie's planned superjumbo jet, giving European plane maker another possible customer as May 26 decision on whether to sell 550-seat plane approaches; photo (S)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Web Business Based on Old West

headline: Keeping World Safe for Comfy Underwear
abstract: Scholastic Inc issues over six million copies of books in Dav Pilkey's series of epic novels for children featuring Captain Underpants; fourth volume is already No. 2 on children's best-seller list, and fifth book is on way; photo (M)

headline: THE BOSS; The Nicest Man on Wall St.
abstract: The Boss column profiles John H Slade, honorary chairman of executive committee at Bear, Stearns & Co; photo (M)

headline: MORE INTEREST IN HYDER
abstract: Western Power Distribution, joint venture of PPL Corp and Southern Co, is considering bid for Hyder PLC; Hyder agreed in April to be bought by Nomura Securities Co for 2.3 billion pounds ($3.6 billion), but if Western Power decides to make bid, it could derail that deal (S)

headline: Trichet in Credit Lyonnais Inquiry : French Bank Probe Reaches Governor
abstract: PARIS—  The governor of the Bank of France, Jean-Claude Trichet, said Friday he was facing investigation in the scandal surrounding the collapse of the bank Credit Lyonnais SA.

headline: Unilever Chief Presses Bestfoods on Takeover Offer
abstract: Unilever co-chairman Antony Burgmans, stepping up pressure on reluctant takeover target Bestfoods, says he believes $66-a-share offer made earlier this month for Bestfoods is 'serious money' and that company wants management of Bestfoods to meet with Unilever to discuss it (M)

headline: CARDINAL HEALTH TO PURCHASE MEDICAL SUPPLY UNIT
abstract: Allegiance Corp unit of Cardinal Health agrees to acquire Bergen Brunswig Medical Corp, medical-supply distribution unit of Bergen Brunswig Corp, for about $181 million (S)

headline: Neither Notebook Nor Palm
abstract: Joe Hutsko (State of the Art) column notes that as manufacturers of some palm-size organizers prepare to withdraw their bigger handheld entries from market, Psion PLC, Britain, has introduced its new Series 7 model, most powerful yet; in reviewing Series 7, Hutsko notes that it looks like notebook computer, but does not have such things as hard drive or ability to run same programs you use on desktop; says, instead, Series 7 runs scaled-down applications; notes new Psion model is size of large paperback and weighs just over 2.5 pounds; says if he did not already own Hewlet-Packard Jornada 820, Psion Series 7 would be his first choice as companion to his desktop computer (M)

headline: FORD SAID TO LEAD IN DAEWOO BID
abstract: South Korean news reports say Ford Motor has won exclusive negotiating rights to buy heavily indebted Daewoo Motor from committee of creditors, beating out rival bids from alliance between DaimlerChrysler and Hyundai Motor and alliance between General Motors and Fiat (S)

headline: MTV Networks Unit Selects Modernista
abstract: MTV: Music Television in New York, part of the MTV Networks unit of Viacom Inc., said yesterday that it had named Modernista in Boston to handle a new brand-image campaign that will run both on and off MTV. Billings have not been determined.    Christina Norman, senior vice president for marketing and on-air promotions at MTV, said the decision came after a three-month review that had been narrowed to Modernista and two other agencies: DiNoto/Lee in New York and Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami. MTV's in-house advertising department also pitched ideas that would be developed into campaigns, she said, adding that ''the in-house process is and always has been ongoing.''

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Portals Struggle to Convert Browsers to Shoppers

headline: At Midcareer, Unlikely Segues Into Dot-Commerce
abstract: Not all dot-com entreprenuers are 20-something nerds in sneakers and pizza-stained shirts; Sergio Mazza, Mary Furlong and James Harrington, all past 40 and well-established on traditional career paths, have each launched Internet ventures at midcareer; each started a Web-based business that extends and amplifies their earlier careers; each has knack for synthesis and an open mind about packaging their expertise and experience in new ways, characteristics that may be more important for success in new economy and technical wizardry; photos (M)

headline: After Weeks Without Leader, ABC Network Gets President
abstract: Walt Disney Co names Robert F Callahan, president of its radio and television stations division, president of newly named ABC Broadcast Group; he will retain his position as executive in charge of Disney's radio and television stations; ABC Television Network has been without direct leader for weeks even as it has stood at number 1 in ratings; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Percent           Yesterday   Day Ago   Year Ago       Prime rate   9.50   9.50   7.75        Discount rate   6.00   6.00   4.50        Federal funds   6.44   6.51   4.69        3-month T-bills   5.62   5.69   4.59        6-month T-bills   5.91   5.92   4.83        10-yr. T-infl.   4.06   4.06   4.00        10-yr. T-note   6.01   5.99   5.92        30-yr. T-bond   5.89   5.89   6.06        Telephone bd.   8.24   8.24   7.83        Municipal bds.   5.89   5.92   5.48          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Gervase Cowell, 73, Manager of a Soviet Turncoat Spy, Dies
abstract: Gervase Cowell, British secret agent, dies at age 73 (S)

headline: S1 CORPORATION SHARES RISE ON INVESTMENT REPORTS
abstract: Shares of S1 Corp, whose technology enables financial companies to do business on Internet, jump after group of financial institutions agree to invest $244 million in company (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Payback for those who sold the bull market short: missing out on high-technology's rapid descent.
abstract: Market Place column on short-sellers of technology stocks; says meteoric rise of technology stocks over last few years forced many short-sellers to abandon positions, shut their operations or liquidate their portfolios and go into cash; says when technology sector and market over all finally had bracing retreat in April, some of investment funds that have specialized in selling stock short, or betting that stock prices will drop, were not positioned to profit (M)

headline: Nortel Makes Inroads in Building Wireless World in Latin America
abstract: Nortel Networks of Canada seeks to capitalize on competition sweeping Latin America's telecommunications markets; has built fixed-wireless phone service in Mexico for Axtel that uses radio waves like cellular phone, but for use only in fixed site; is building fixed wireless system in Mexico City for Axtel's main competitor, Unefon, and is busy installing advanced communications systems throughout hemisphere; is also expanding in Asia and Europe; graph; map; photos (M)

headline: Murdoch Contracts Prostate Cancer
abstract: Rupert Murdoch, News Corp chairman, has prostate cancer and will have radiation therapy (S)

headline: Unlikely Alliance Is Formed To Pass Bill on China Trade
abstract: Pres Clinton enlists aid of unlikely ally Republican Repr Tom DeLay--majority whip, fierce anti-Communist and perhaps his most venomous critic on Capitol Hill--in campaign to win passage of decisive bill granting China membership in World Trade Organization; DeLay, who led charge to impeach Clinton, finds himself im improbable role as president's chief water-carrier in all-out battle on administration's top foreign policy goal; insists his personal distate for Clinton is not clouding professional task to round up necessary votes on crucial issue; odd alignment is one of many spawned by bill, opposed by labor unions and conservative religious groups but supported by farmers and some high-tech executives; support for measure grows with endorsements by Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, and former Presidents Carter, Ford and Bush; photo (M)

headline: OBITUARY : Antoine Geoffroy-Dechaume, 94, Pioneering Harpsichordist
abstract: PARIS—  The French harpsichordist, musicologist and composer Antoine Geoffroy-Dechaume, 94, died April 15. He played a pioneering role in the renewal of early music (16th to 18th centuries) by publishing findings culled from school manuals of the period and by teaching the conventions governing the way music was written and performed in those days.

headline: China's No. 1 Oil Company Goes Public With Whimper
abstract: China's flagship oil company, PetroChina Ltd, plods through its first day of trading in Asia, closing 5 percent below its offering price on day when Hong Kong market rises; company's shares fall on New York Stock Exchange after closing unchanged in their first trading session; PetroChina's American depository shares close at $15.1875, down $1.25; PetroChina has been singed by political firestorm surrounding its initial public offering in US; AFL-CIO led patchwork alliance of labor unions, Republican lawmakers and Tibetan monks who accused company of human-rights abuses and planning sweeping layoffs at PetroChina's parent, China National Petroleum; photo (M)

headline: McCaw Steers 2 Satellite Companies Toward Merger
abstract: Craig O McCaw, cellular telephone pioneer, announces completion of his investment group's $1.2 billion rescue of ICO Global Communications, which went bankrupt last summer; says he will merge company, renamed New Ico, with Teledesic LLC, satellite network partnershiphe founded with William H Gates, Microsoft Corp chairman, into venture called ICO-Teledesic Global Limited, which will be run temporarily by Russell Daggatt, chief executive of Teledesic; McCaw will control 54 percent of New ICO (M)

headline: Greenspan Treads Softly After Market's Gyrations
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan offers soothing words to investors, saying as explicitly as he ever has that central bank's interest rate increases are not intended to drive down stock prices, address at White House conference on technology and economy; identifies wealth being generated by rising stock prices as primary cause of imbalances in economy that could potentially lead to inflation; Greenspan seems intent on drawing distinction between raising or lowering interest rates based movements in stock market and acknowledging that Wall Street's effects on rest of economy are so powerful that they have to be taken into account in monetary policy (M)

headline: Young & Rubicam To Invest in Naviant
abstract: Young & Rubicam Inc says it will make cash investment of up to $20 million in Naviant Inc, agency that offers interactive marketing services; Young & Rubicam is taking about 5 percent stake in Naviant (S)

headline: FORMER REDSKINS OWNER BUYS FLORIDA KEYS NEWSPAPERS
abstract: Thomson Corp sells its Florida Keys newspapers to John Kent Cooke, former co-owner of Washington Redskins; price undisclosed; Cooke Communications LLC was formed to make purchase (S)

headline: Blair Meets With Ford Chief to Discuss a Factory's Fate
abstract: Britain's Prime Min Tony Blair and other government officials have held talks with Ford Motor Co as it contemplates closing plant in Dagenham, Eng; Britain's troubled auto industry is facing severe cutbacks and job losses; Blair has met with Ford chief executive Jacques A Nasser and he and other officials were talking with Ford about internal review of its European operations expected to be concluded in mid-May; labor unions have threatened to strike other Ford plants in Britain if Dagenham factory is closed; map (M)

headline: SYKES SELLS EMPLOYEE BENEFITS UNIT IN RESTRUCTURING
abstract: Sykes Enterprises, which runs customer-support centers for Microsoft and other companies, is selling its employee-benefits unit for $165.5 million in cash to Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe as part of reorganization that will include some office closings and firing of unspecified number of workers (S)

headline: Teachers Try to Keep Up With E-Mail From Parents
abstract: June 7, 2000

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil climbs on concern that gasoline might be in short supply during summer driving season; in New York, crude oil for June delivery rises $1.01, or 3.4 percent, to $30.33 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: The Shelves or the Web?
abstract: Matt Hillletter on selling books to other individuals on line (S)

headline: MILD CANADIAN INFLATION
abstract: Canada's inflation rate rose in May to 2.4 percent annual rate, up from 2.1 percent in Apr; gain is less than expected (S)

headline: Cuban Door Will Reopen. Just Don't Ask When.
abstract: Joseph Kahn Economic View column sees momentum building toward repeal of 38-year-old embargo on trade with Cuba, though big breakthrough remains unlikely as long as Fidel Castro is still alive; meanwhile, even the most modest relaxation to permit sales of food and medicine to Cuba faces uncertain prospects in Republican-controlled House; Cuban-American lobby is pushing to limit sales to cash-on-delivery basis only, a restriction under which trade rarely flourishes; graph (M)

headline: CHAIRMAN FOR WORLD ONLINE
abstract: World Online International names successor to chairwoman Nina Brinks, who resigned after accusations that she misled investors about sale of her own stock before company went public; new chairman will be James Kinsella, who is chief executive of MSNBC.com; photo (S)

headline: In New Forum for Domain Name Disputes, Trademark Holders Dominate
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Diageo Said to Be in Talks For All or Part of Bestfoods  Diageo, which owns Pillsbury bakery goods and Haagen-Daz ice cream, is negotiating to buy all or part of Bestfoods, the maker of Skippy peanut butter and Hellmann's mayonnaise, executives close to the talks said.    Diageo is holding trans-Atlantic negotiations with Bestfoods in hopes of combining Bestfoods' bakery business with its own bakery business and possibly spinning off the newly combined unit into a company that might be controlled by Bestfoods' management, the executives said. [Page C2.]

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Total Sys Svcs Inc    TUESDAY  Chesapeake Corp  First Comwlth Finl Corp Pa  Fleetwood Enterprises Inc

headline: After Visit, Congressman Wouldn't Halt Iraq Sanctions
abstract: Repr Tony P Hall, first American member of Congress to visit Iraq to assess impact of economic sanctions, says while some of suffering he saw is 'heartbreaking' he does not support lifting of embargo, imposed following invasion of Kuwait in 1990; releases report calling for greater US attention to problems of country's population; says Iraq still poses military threat and that until government of Pres Saddam Hussein cooperates in eliminating weapons of mass destruction as required by UN, lifting of sanctions would be irresponsible (S)

headline: Asleep at the Books: A Fraud That Went On and On and On
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on biggest accounting fraud ever at CUC International, one that cost investors $19 billion and involved more than $500 million in phony profits over three years, questions how fraud managed to go on since early 1980's; Securities and Exchange Commission contends fraud was easy to pull off because CUC officials knew which subsidiaries would be audited, and therefore hid most obvious frauds in subsidiaries that they knew auditors would not look at; graph (M)

headline: Security Stocks Rise on Virus Worries
abstract: Security Stocks Rise on Virus Worries

headline: WILINK.COM TO ADD KNUTSFORD GROUP OF BRITAIN
abstract: Knutsford Group PLC to acquire WILink.com, financial information services company, for stock, cash and notes in deal worth $83.3 million; combined company will be renamed WILink.com PLC and offer online investment services to individual investors (S)

headline: WILLIAMS WILL PAY $150 MILLION FOR NATURAL GAS PLANT
abstract: The Williams Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to pay Columbia Energy Group $150 million for its Cove Point liquefied natural gas plant in Lusby, Md. In the transaction, Williams will receive the largest liquefied natural gas import site in the United States, as well as 87 miles of pipeline that the company intends to connect to its Transco pipeline system. Williams, based in Tulsa, Okla., owns and operates a natural gas pipeline system and a fiber optic communications business that uses the pipeline system's rights of way. It had revenue of $8.59 billion in 1999.

headline: STOCK MARKET IN STEEP DROP AS WORRIED INVESTORS FLEE; NASDAQ HAS ITS WORST WEEK
abstract: Stock market suffers steep drop as investors turn away from equities in sharp waves of selling; beleaguered Nasdaq index plunges 355.49 points or nearly 10 percent to 3,321.29, finishing worst week in its history with 25.3 percent loss; Dow Jones industrial average falls 617.78 points or 5.66 percent to end week down 7.3 percent in worst performance since 1989; technology stocks lead plunge; all 30 stocks in Dow fell, while all but 16 stocks in Standard & Poor's 500 index dropped; only 5 of 100 biggest companies on Nasdaq posted gains; sell-off prompted by Labor Dept report that core consumer prices rose 0.4 percent in March, or more than economists predicted; graphs (M)

headline: Radio Stations Sold
abstract: Clear Channel Communications acquires 29 radio stations from Roberts Radio for about $65.9 million (S)

headline: Shoe Designer Is Charged With Fraud
abstract: Steven Madden, designer who is chairman and chief executive of popular women's shoe company, Steve Madden Ltd, is arrested on charges of securities fraud, including accusations involving initial public offering of his own company; in separate indictments, federal prosecutors in Brooklyn and Manhattan charge Madden with securities fraud, conspiracy and money laundering saying he participated in more than 20 fraudulent initial offerings of stock dating back to 1993, when his company went public; in related civil lawsuit, Securities and Exchange Commission says that stock frauds generated about $7 million in profits for Madden and others; commission is seeking to bar Madden from serving as officer or director of any publicly traded copmany; Madden's arrest casts cloud over his fast-growing company; photo (M)

headline: Ex-Microsoft Employee Publicizes a Potential Security Flaw
Important Dates in Microsoft´s History
abstract: Important Dates in Microsoft's History

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro rises one percent, to 94.21 cents; chart (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Richard Pinder was named to the new position of regional director for the Greater China and Southeast Asia operations of Leo Burnett Worldwide, Hong Kong, part of the B Com3  Group. He had been managing director at the London office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group.  * John Cooper was named to the vacant post of president at the Toronto office of Rapp Collins Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group. He had been vice president for marketing, customer service, e-commerce and corporate communications at Federal Express Canada, Toronto, part of FedEx Corp.

headline: PROFIT JUMPS AT FRENCH BANK
abstract: France's Societe Generale SA says first-quarter profit rose 53 percent; net income rose to 883 million euros ($790 million) from 576 million euros a year earlier (S)

headline: Ford to Close British Plant, Laying Off 1,900 Workers
abstract: Ford Motor Co will close auto assembly plant in Dagenham, Eng, by 2002 and lay off 1,900 workers; cites its 'unacceptable' financial performance in Europe, holding it earned only $28 million there on sales of $30 billion in 1999; workers and unions score plan; Ford also says it will close Belarus plant; photo (M)

headline: HSBC Will Acquire French Bank for $10.6 Billion
abstract: HSBC Holdings to acquire Credit Commercial de France in deal worth $10.6 billion; ING, rival bidder, concedes defeat (M)

headline: A Promising Farm Tool, for Some
abstract: American Farm Bureau Federation sees agricultural business poised for transformation through computers; so far, farmers are using Internet mainly to shop for best deals on machinery and supplies; some are exploring Internet to find best prices for crops; some Web sites let them sell crops directly to consumers; photo (M)

headline: Chinese Express Joy and Relief at Passage of Trade Bill
abstract: Chinese greet House vote to grant China permanent normal trade status with joy, tempered with worries about wrenching economic changes expected as China opens its markets to outsiders; government expresses concern about conditions House attached to bill (M)

headline: Serb Opposition Leader Is Shot in Montenegro
abstract: Well-known Serbian opposition leader Vuk Draskovic is shot and wounded by gunmen in Montenegro, where he fled last month from Serbia and sought protection from Pres Milo Djukanovic; Draskovic is leading campaign for early elections to remove Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic from power (M)

headline: Reporters and Editors Defend A.P. Story on Korea Massacre
abstract: Associated Press reporters and editors defend Pulitzer Prize-winning account of alleged massacre of South Korean civilians by US troops in 1950, in face of attacks on credibility of witnesses; US News & World Report and Stripes.com are citing documents undermining credibility of three of dozen soldiers cited by AP (M)

headline: Appearing Soon at a Store Near You: An A.T.M. for the Ears
abstract: Appearing Soon at a Store Near You: An A.T.M. for the Ears

headline: Charity Web Domain Hijacked
abstract: Charity Web Domain Hijacked

headline: Companies See Barriers to Cooperating on Cybersecurity
Anonymous Shopping At Stores on the Web
abstract: Ecount announces PrivateBuy service, which allows for online shopping without fear of credit card or identity theft (S)

headline: Elsie Widdowson, 93, a Pioneer in Nutrition
abstract: Elsie Widdowson, nutritionist, dies at age 93; photo (M)

headline: CANADA TO SELL OIL COMPANY
abstract: Canada will sell its remaining 18 percent stake in Petro-Canada, country's second-largest integrated oil company and eliminate 25 percent limit on foreign investment in company (S)

headline: Business Travel; The hotel industry is increasingly paying attention to the number of women on the road.
abstract: With women making up 40 to 45 percent of overall business-travel market, the hotel industry is paying increasing attention to women, looking more closely at such things as responsive service and more pleasant, home-like rooms; marketing program developed by Wyndham Hotels and Resorts to increase its share of female business travel market discussed (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Australians' Self-View :Ambiguous
abstract: SYDNEY—  Living Up to Expectations

headline: National Pride Over a Virus In Philippines
abstract: Editorial in local newspaper The Manila Standard captures sense of national pride in Philippines as computer student Onel de Guzman all but admits creating destructive program that crippled e-mail systems around the world; fellow students swell with pride at drab little AMA Computer College where de Guzman had outlined something close to rogue program in thesis proposal; de Guzman, after several days of hiding, appears at news conference, seeming overwhelmed by extent of destruction, and admits that 'it is possible' that he had unleashed program that caused tens of millions of dollars of damage in more than 20 countries; de Guzman says he had been fooling around with fellow students in informal club called GrammerSoft and had only wanted to create 'a gimmick'--term used among young people in Philippines for event that is exciting and fun (M)

headline: Accusations That Moscow Spies on Party Gain Weight
abstract: Yabloko, Russia's leading pro-democracy political party, posts on its Web site charge that federal intelligence agents spy on party, charge echoed in scathing letter to security service from party leader, Grigory Yavlinsky; charge gained weight when two young party members claimed federal agents engineered their ejection from university when they refused to spy on party; students were reinstated after their complaints became public (M)
